PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
PETITION.PARA: Motion (by Senator Carrick)-by leave-agreed to:
That so much of sessional orders be suspended as would prevent petitions lodged with the Clerk being presented this day.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Tasmanian Wilderness Areas
To the honourable the President and Members of the Senate, in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at proposed future hydro-electric developments in South West Tasmania. As this area is on the Register of the National Estate it is therefore of national concern and your petitioners humbly call upon the Senate to conduct a Senate Inquiry into South West Tasmania. A Federal Inquiry has been recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly call upon the Federal Parliament not to allocate funds or allow funds to be raised for development of roads or dams in the South West of Tasmania but rather to provide such funds as would enable the preservation of this area. This is a national issue and therefore Tasmanians should not be made to bear any financial burden resulting from its preservation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Childs (from 51 citizens), Mulvihill (from 95 citizens), Scott (from 50 citizens) and Sibraa (from 51 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised-that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer, profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing. Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
(1) All pensions and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the National Average Male Earnings seasonally adjusted
(2) Removal of the means/income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973.
Reintroduction of Medibank; in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

(3) To alleviate Australia's shortage in housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government immediately inject $200 million into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 68 citizens) and Ryan (from 45 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Institute of Early Childhood Development
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate.

The humble petition of citizens in Victoria showeth that at a general meeting concern was expressed as to the necessity to retain the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous institution.
Your petitioners therefore pray that you would make note of the following resolution passed at a public meeting held in Melbourne on 12th August, 1981:

''We request that the Federal Government continue funding the Institute of Early Childhood Development as an autonomous specialist institution recognizing that it is unique in its capacity to serve the needs of the early childhood field in Victoria and throughout Australia.''
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle (from 5 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Gambling Casino: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra would debase the National Capital and increase crime in Canberra.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should seek to preserve the dignity of the National Capital by disallowing any ordinance to authorise the establishment of a gambling casino in Canberra.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Department of Social Security
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the shortage of staff members in the Department of Social Security has resulted in poor service to clients and delays in payment of benefits.
That the recent standdowns of staff of the Department of Social Security have exacerbated the above situation and caused undue hardship to pensioners and beneficiaries.
Therefore, your petitioners urge that:
(1) Staffing levels in the Department be increased to a level acceptable to staff members.
(2) The Government demonstrate its concern for clients by rescinding the standdowns and allowing staff back to work with no loss of salary.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: La Boite Theatre, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

1. The decision by the Australia Council to discontinue the General Grant of $20,000 (which is in the nature of recurrent funding) to La Boite Theatre, Brisbane, will jeopardise the continued viability of the theatre, and in particular, the Main House Theatre; Adult Theatre Workshops; Youth Theatre activities and the existence of the professional core of the theatre.
2. The decision has been taken without sufficient consultation and without giving sufficient notice to La Boite Administration.
3. The absence of Federal Government funding will mean the loss to Brisbane of genuine community-oriented and community-based projects and of the regular presentation of Australian plays.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will request the Government to cause the Theatre Board's General Grant of $20,000 to La Boite Theatre to be reinstated without delay.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

(1) That the Minatome uranium deposit at Ben Lomond, near Charters Towers, exists within hydrologically unstable ground in a region of intense seasonal rainfall and is generally regarded as uneconomical and unsafe.
(2) That safeguards taken against the uncontrolled dispersal into the environment of toxic elements and radioactive material have already been proven to be totally inadequate.

(3) That the continued development of the Minatome uranium leases poses an unacceptable risk to the future health of residents living in the vicinity of Ben Lomond and communities and pastures along adjacent waterways, to residents of Charters Towers and, potentially, to residents of Townsville, only 50 km to the east.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate carefully weigh the limited economic benefit to a 100 per cent French-owned company against the health of a large number of Australian citizens and a significant section of our grazing industry and refuse to allow the granting of export licences for any uranium products from the Ben Lomond mine.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Hospital Fees: Greenslopes, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

1. That the decision by the Federal Government to introduce fees at the Repatriation General Hospital, Greenslopes, was made without prior consultation with medical staff at the hospital and implemented at short notice.
2. That fee introduction will place the hospital in the untenable position of having to compete with the State's free hospital system.

3. That this competition will result in a substantial loss of specialist medical personnel and community non-entitled patients, both of whom are complementary and vital to maintaining the standards of excellence that this hospital has achieved.
4. That the consequence of such losses will be a deterioration in health care standards to veterans in Queensland.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled call upon the Government through the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to declare a moratorium on the introduction of fees at the Repatriation General Hospital, Greenslopes, until the full ramifications of this decision are studied more closely and the patients and staff are allowed adequate time to prepare for any financial changes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Western Australia respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade Postal and Mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by-
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the Postal and Mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Postal Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the State of Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the plan by the Australian Postal Commission to downgrade Postal and Mail services throughout Australia, will place in jeopardy the existing services and the security of the mails by-
downgrading a large number of official post offices;
reducing the number of post offices open for business during the lunch period;
reducing the number of street posting boxes;
delaying telegrams by reducing the number of delivery offices;
downgrading post office services by employing untrained and unqualified staff; and
using private contractors for mail cartage.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Australian Government will take immediate action to prevent the Australian Postal Commission implementing any plan which will downgrade the Postal and Mail services of the citizens of Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sinai Peacekeeping Force
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. Bipartisan concern exists in the Australian community over involvement of Australian military forces in the Middle East where those forces are not under United Nations auspices;
2. Concern is also evident about Australia's military capacity to provide those forces without weakening Australia's defence;
3. Sinai is not an area within Australia's sphere of influence; and
4. Australian agricultural export markets may be adversely affected by Australian military participation in Sinai.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament does not ratify Australian military participation in the proposed Sinai peacekeeping force, unless that force is fully controlled by the United Nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That many thousands of women and children in the Australian community who use the services of Womens Refuges, Womens Health Centres and Womens Rape Crisis Centres:

(1) Express their concern at the decision of the Federal Government to pass to the States the responsibility of funding those essential services because of the poor record already demonstrated by some States;
(2) Call on the Federal Government to reverse that decision;
(3) Request that the Government ensure one Department to administer all funds for the above under the heading of Womens Services;
(4) Propose that future funding be on a guaranteed triennial basis taking into account inflation and indexation increases; and
(5) Ask for a positive policy commitment for a substantial injection of funds to consolidate existing services and to develop new initiatives for women and children in the Australian community.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the proposed imposition of Sales Tax on items concerned with home building and contents-clothing, books, magazines and newspapers.

Your petitioners therefore call upon the Federal Parliament not to implement such legislation as will permit these increases in costs to become a further burden on home builders, families and children, or inhibit the purchase of news and or information.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unsolicited Mail
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That the misuse of private mailboxes as a repository for unsolicited newspapers and advertising material constitutes a hindrance to the delivery of legitimate mail.
(2) That as a result of this misuse, legitimate mail is often lost.
(3) That private mailboxes should be regarded with the same sacrosanctity that public mailboxes are.
(4) That private mailboxes are the final link in the chain of mail movement and, therefore, should be afforded the same Commonwealth legal protection as every other stage of mail handling already is.
(5) That certain charitable and other responsible public interest organisations have a legitimate claim to limited use of mailboxes, subject to a form of licensing.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Parliament legislate to protect the free movement of mail in Australia right up to the point of delivery and that local authorities be subsidised to enable them to license charitable and certain other public interest organisations for limited mailbox deliveries and to police such by-laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as ''Australian Soldier'' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewomen of 1939-45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation Zone Allowances
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. We are totally dissatisfied with the proposal to relegate the City of Mt Isa from Zone A to Zone B in the taxation scheme of Zone Allowances.

2. This dissatisfaction arises from proposed discrimination by the Treasurer against a group of citizens who have provided, are providing and will continue to provide a massive contribution to our nation's wealth.

3. The proposal will mean but little to the total concept of federal finances, but removal or reduction of allowances will mean much to the budgets of the ordinary people of this city and to the turnover of our traders.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Treasurer take immediate steps to act on our behalf and ensure that:
1. The recommendation of the Cox Report of the Zone Allowance Inquiry which recommended that the City of Mt Isa be placed within Zone B in assessing Zone Allowances be disregarded by his government.
2. That due consideration be given to all submissions from this region which clearly demonstrate the need for the continuation of zone allowances at a level far greater than now operating.
3. That this new increased level take into account the measure of inflation since 1958 and set the annual figure for Zone A at $48.00.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Speed Limit Outside Schools
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

There is need for a speed limit of 25 kilometres per hour adjacent to schools, one hour before school starts and one hour after it ends; a speed limit should be implemented for kindergartens and playgrounds during daylight hours.
That Parliament put these views to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety with the idea of making the speed limit in these areas unified throughout Australia.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament should take urgent action on this matter so as to save the lives of many children.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to alter the restrictions on the broadcasting and televising of election matter in an election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That-
(1) The Senate notes that the warning given by Senator McLaren in Notice of Motion No. 20 on 25 March 1981 has now become a stark reality.

(a) The warning being that if the Liberal Premier of South Australia Mr Tonkin transferred moneys from the State's loan account to compensate for the shortfall in the revenue account this would have a serious effect on State housing and transport needs.
(b) That the total amount of transfer funds from the loan account now stands at $81m.

(2) The Senate congratulates the Leader Opposition in the South Australian Legislative Council Mr Chris Sumner, M.L.C. for carrying out the close check on recent State Budgets which now reveals that the 1981 Tonkin Budget is the most disastrous in modern South Australian history.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement relating to the notice of intention to withdraw the Money Lenders (Amendment) Ordinance given yesterday by the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, Senator Austin Lewis.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The effect of this Ordinance is to exempt building and credit societies from provisions of the Money Lenders Ordinance governing contracts for loans at an interest rate above 12 per cent per annum, with retrospective application to 1 December 1980. The explanatory statement attached to the Ordinance indicated that its purpose was to remove the duplication of the regulation of building and credit societies in the Australian Capital Territory, which are regulated by the Co-operative Societies Ordinance 1939.

SPEECH.PARA: The Attorney-General (Senator Durack) advised the Committee that, while certain provisions of the Money Lenders Ordinance remained legally applicable to the societies, until December 1980 the provisions had no practical application to them. He explained to the Committee that, with the sudden increase in the general level of interest rates at the end of last year, the societies were found to be in technical breach of the applicable provisions and could have been placed in a difficult financial position if the situation had not been remedied by the Ordinance. The Committee had entertained some misgivings concerning the retrospective operation of the Ordinance, the adequacy of the explanatory statement initially provided with the Ordinance, and the administrative delays which occurred in remedying the situation. The Committee was also concerned, under its principle (B), that the legal rights of borrowers from building and credit societies were being diminished, while the rights of borrowers from other lending institutions were not similarly affected. Following detailed explanations from the Attorney-General and, in particular, in view of the consequences that could arise for building and credit societies if the Ordinance were now to be disallowed, the Committee decided not to proceed with the notice of disallowance given by the Chairman on 10 November 1981.

On behalf of Senator Lewis, and in accordance with notice of intention given yesterday, I now withdraw business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1, standing in his name and relating to the disallowance of the Money Lenders (Amendment) Ordinance 1981. Notwithstanding the decision to withdraw the Ordinance, the Committee reports that it was not completely satisfied with the reasons given for the delay in making the Ordinance, and with the adequacy of the explanatory statement provided with the Ordinance.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Did the Commonwealth last year finance the production of a promotional film on Project Australia to be shown to prospective licensees and sponsors? Did the film claim that there was a 58 per cent unprompted awareness level amongst the public three months after the launch of the Project Australia campaign? How was this figure justified given that many businesses have accepted it as accurate? Is it not a fact that a recent study has shown that after nearly two years of the Advance Australia campaign its awareness level is 8 per cent? How much public money has been spent directly on the Project Australia and Advance Australia campaigns?
—I will seek a response to those questions from the Minister for Industry and Commerce.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. In view of the food shortages prevailing in Poland and the Australian Government's decision to provide monetary assistance, will the Government further consider providing assistance in the form of beef shipments that will not only alleviate the food difficulties of Poland but also provide jobs for abattoir workers and steady the alarming falling saleyard stock prices around Australia?

—Recent statements by the Prime Minister and by the Minister for Foreign Affairs made plain Australia's concern about the situation in Poland and our desire to be of assistance to that country. I suspect that that view would be shared in most corners of this Parliament. The Prime Minister announced some contribution to relief assistance. I think individual members of this Parliament also have received requests for assistance from organisations which are concerned with providing medical assistance to Poland. The matter is very much on the agenda at the moment. It has been the main practice, I understand, for Australia to provide aid in an untied form. This is unusual in most countries. Our aid has tended to be provided in terms of money which has been available for use as the recipient country thinks fit. However, there is, of course, plenty of precedent around the world for food aid to be provided. I will refer Senator Watson's suggestion to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Minister for Primary Industry for consideration.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. His office was notified that I intended to ask a question on this matter. Did the Minister receive a copy of a letter dealing with the alleged gassing to death of prisoners by Australian soldiers in South Australia in 1940-41 using lewisite gas? This letter was sent to the office of the Minister for Defence on 24 November. Does the Minister agree that this letter, although unsigned, contained such extraordinary allegations that it requires investigation? What steps has the Ministe taken to check the allegations made in that letter? What has been the result of his investigations?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Defence. I do not have any information relating to it.
—I raise a point of order, Mr President. May we have the Attorney's answer again? We did not hear one word of it here.
—I call again the Attorney-General.

—It is rather a strange procedure to have to repeat an answer. I simply said that I did not have any information in relation to the matter. I will have to refer the question to the Minister for Defence.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and is similar to the question I asked yesterday. I refer to Australia's conditional decision to participate in the Sinai peace monitoring force. Australian participation is conditional upon there being a significant European involvement in Sinai such as is proposed on the part of the United Kingdom, France, the Netherlands and Italy. I wish to ask about the additional Australian condition that there be a significant prospect of Israel and the Palestinians progressing with autonomy talks. Is this Australian condition not tantamount to the European view expressed in the European Economic Community's Venice declaration which calls for Palestinian participation in the peace process? In those circumstances, is it not true that if Israel does not accept the European countries' participation along with their Venice declaration then Israel at the same time would not be accepting Australia's participation along with our Palestinian condition? Finally, when does the Australian Government expect the Israeli response to be concluded in respect of European and Australian involvement in the Sinai force?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague's question raises several important issues. As the Prime Minister made clear in his Press statement on 24 November, the most important condition on which Australia's participation in the Sinai peacekeeping force depended has now been met; that is, the announcement to participate by Britain, France, Italy and the Netherlands meets the Government's requirement for a balanced multinational force and makes it possible for Australia also to participate. I table the Prime Minister's Press statement for the convenience of honourable senators. I should point out that the Prime Minister's statement to the Parliament on 22 October did not set progress with the autonomy talks as a condition of Australian participation. Rather, the Prime Minister noted that a solution to the Palestinian issue was clearly central to the future stability and peace of the Middle East and he looked to further progress on this matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Australian and European policies on this matter are not identical. Notwithstanding the European Community's support for Palestinian self-determination and recognition of the importance of the Palestinian Liberation Organisation's being involved in negotiations, the four European participants have not made these factors conditions for their participation. Australia's policy on the Middle East dispute is based on Security Council Resolution 242 which recognises the right of all states in the region, including Israel, to live in peace within secure and recognised boundaries and calls on Israel to withdraw from territories occupied in 1967, and on the legitimate rights of the Palestinians including their right to a homeland alongside Israel. Australia does not, and will not, recognise the Palestine Liberation Organisation until it recognises Israel's right to exist. While the Government has no firm indication of the timing of Israel's response to the offer to participate by the four European countries we understand that the Israeli Cabinet will consider the matter on Sunday next, 29 November.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Despite all that is now known of the adverse effects of smoking on health, especially on the developing foetus, can the Minister comment on what appears to be a common advertising practice by cigarette manufactures-conducting so-called 'games' in shopping centres allowing the distribution of prizes to all who participate? There is no prize for guessing what the prizes are. I witnessed one such game last week in which nearly all the participants were young women, some of whom were pregnant and almost all of whom were accompanied by small children. Is there any action available to either Federal or State governments which would have the effect of making cigarette manufacturers face up to their moral obligations in regard to these highly vulnerable groups of Australians and potential Australians?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to say that there is no health issue in Australia which is so clear cut as the association between cigarette smoking and health. Senator Giles has raised a matter which is probably the best proven association known today. It is said that smoking is the single greatest preventable health hazard facing Australians. This Government, in responding to a Senate standing committee report, has actually made a commitment as a matter of government policy to seek a reduction in tobacco consumption in Australia. That is a firm Government commitment which obviously is directly contrary to the interests of the cigarette industry.

ANSWER.PARA: I must acknowledge that this is an area of unresolved tension. The Government has taken some actions which include the encouragement of debate to bring out the information to which Senator Giles has referred; it has assisted with the dissemination of accurate information and it has utilised the excise as a tool to control the consumption of tobacco. I am not certain that one can take administrative action to force anyone to address moral issues. But to the extent that the Government does take action, for example to insist on the labelling of packets with warnings and information on tar and nicotine contents, that is further action to try to ensure that we have an informed community which is in possession of the facts regarding cigarette smoking. In the end the resolution of this problem will rest with people. It involves action by the whole community, not just governments. However, I must add that it is distressing if promotional activities by anyone are directed at people who are not yet old enough to make mature judgments. Since cigarette smoking is an addictive and harmful practice, any such promotional action directed at those not yet able to make mature decisions is to be deplored.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Finance noted the headline in today's Australian Financial Review entitled 'A State of insolvency-How Wran has squeezed New South Wales dry'? It was stated in the article that New South Wales has a massive and growing borrowing program, both from the Commonwealth and the private sector and that at the end of June 1981 the State owed the Federal Government $4,885m with an annual interest bill of $438m. Can the Minister confirm the above allegations and inform the Senate what steps the Commonwealth will take to secure the loan and interest due to it in view of the disastrous financial situation of the New South Wales Labor Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the article but I did hear a radio comment about the same subject. As I understand what was said, it pointed to the fact that a lot of the reserves of New South Wales have been used instead of raising charges to increase revenue in that State. I am not able to confirm the figures that were given by Senator Lajovic, nor am I able to make any comment on them. I will seek some information from the Treasurer regarding the matter and see that the Senate is advised.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I have had complaints from pensioners who have not been able to obtain medicines formerly on the Commonwealth free list. I cite one case of a pensioner, Mr George Woods of Mile End, South Australia, who has an invalid wife and five children. Mr Woods had a colostomy operation five years ago and needs suppositories to give him comfort. He has been informed recently that these are no longer on the free list and that he must pay for any he needs. Is this kind of saving by the Department of Social Security justified? Is this what Mr Fraser meant when he said that the Government was concerned with the health of people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to know which preparations are being talked about before I can give a comprehensive answer but I can advise Senator Elstob that the Minister has to receive a recommendation from an expert committee that medications be placed on the benefits list. That committee is called the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. In the absence of a recommendation from that Committee, the Minister has no power to include any item on the pharmaceutical benefits list. The obvious reason for this is that it is a matter which requires some expert input. The Minister has a fairly broad based committee which gives him advice. He then has the option of either accepting or rejecting that advice. But he cannot include items which have not been recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee. That Committee also has a capacity to vary its recommendations from time to time. It is therefore possible that particular items may be taken off the list if the Advisory Committee so recommends or if it removes its endorsement of a medication remaining on the list.

ANSWER.PARA: Those drugs which cost less than the patient contribution automatically come off the list. It could be that as a result of movement in the patient contribution, certain drugs are no longer on the list of pharmaceutical benefits. It sometimes follows that it is different for those holding pensioner cards. There is a separate list for pensioners; it is slightly more extensive but, again, the Minister can act only on the recommendations he receives. It might be helpful if Senator Elstob could make known the medications which are in dispute and about which he is concerned. I can then make specific inquiries in relation to his patient and those medications.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and relates to the industrial dispute presently taking place at the Sydney Haymarket telex exchange. In view of the inconvenience to telex customers caused by the dispute, I ask: How many days has the dispute been going on? What is the Government's attitude to the dispute? What action will be taken by the Government in an effort to achieve a satisfactory and early resolution of the dispute?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that Australian Telecommunications Employees Association technical officers have been taking industrial action at the Haymarket telex exchange and that bans have been applied against the remedying of any faults in equipment. I understand the basis of the dispute is that the union is seeking to have the exchange staffed 24 hours a day whereas at present it is staffed for two shifts-16 hours a day-and has been unstaffed between 11 p.m. and 7 a.m. The union has claimed that there is a need for an additional 25 staff. Telecom has replied that it can see no justification for that extra number, particularly in comparision with other capital city telex exchanges. I understand that Telecom Australia has been negotiating over this issue and that it has offered to undertake a staff review. I am also aware that Telecom has already advised the union that payroll deduction facilities have been withdrawn and that Telecom will not negotiate further on the substantive issue until all bans have been lifted and all industrial action has ceased.

ANSWER.PARA: Telecom advises that it is examining other responses which can be used if the present industrial action continues. My briefing information does not give the date of commencement of the dispute, and that was one of the parts of the question. I can obtain that information for Senator Missen. I am advised, however, that already 380 telex customers in Sydney are without service. So the dispute is starting to affect the service available in Sydney, and it is therefore of some significance. I am further advised, too, that so far 26 employees are on 'no work as directed, no pay' in accordance with the procedures laid down in appropriate legislation. I will try to obtain the other information that Senator Missen was seeking and make it available to him.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Is it a fact that the Western Australian Government and the Ashton joint venturers have agreed to that Government's establishing a tax regime for diamond mining which allows for a royalty of 22.5 per cent of profits beyond a trigger level of about $20m a year? Does this seriously undermine the Commonwealth's claim that a resources tax on profits derived from our natural resources would frustrate or impede the development of projects based on our great endowments of minerals and energy? Has the Minister noted yesterday's plea by the bipartisan Senate Standing Committee on National Resources that fresh consideration be given to the imposition of such a tax? Finally, will this national Government again look at the possibility of levying such a tax to raise revenue for the Australian people as a whole or will it continue to abdicate its national role in favour of alliances between governments and developers in resource-rich regions of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the diamond mining resource in Western Australia is of enormous interest to all Australians. It is important that its development, although primarily a State matter, should be such that in its final result it gives the maximum benefit to all Australians. This is the first major discovery of diamonds in Australia and the development of this new deposit could place us in the forefront of the industry. Much of what has been written or said recently on the Argyle project has tended to be inaccurate or speculative, with allegations that the project being developed by the Ashton joint venture will be dominated by overseas interests.
—None of this has got anything to do with the question.

—Mr President, may I interpose by simply saying, in answer to that, that yesterday Senator Tate indicated that he was seeking information on this matter, and I am proposing to give him the information he sought. I hope the Opposition will not attempt to frustrate its own honourable senators.
—Why don't you give him the information he asked for?

—In due course, when the chatterboxes cease, I propose to do so. The joint venture is still in the process of examining a number of options, including consideration of all the possibilities, and the application of foreign investment guidelines will ensure equity in this regard. The companies concerned are fully aware of the Government's objectives that arrangements entered into for resource development should be in the interests of Australia as well as in the interests of the companies concerned and their shareholders.

ANSWER.PARA: The references that have been made publicly to particular royalty rates and the details of the arrangements agreed between the Western Australian Government and the companies involved are, as I understand it, still before the Western Australian Parliament for ratification. The development of the Argyle diamond deposit will be carried out under the laws of the Government of Western Australia. That Government recently concluded an agreement with the joint venture partners which embraces such matters as mining titles, the mining program, royalties, production arrangements and the further processing of that production. The agreement requires ratification by the Western Australian Parliament, following which it can be expected that the companies involved will make decisions about the development of the project.

As to the final part of Senator Tate's question, I have not yet had an opportunity to read the report. I will read it with considerable interest. I have read that the report suggests that one alternative method of equity, but not necessarily the only one, within the industry would be some form of resource rent tax. Since I have not read the report and since I do not know the nuances behind that, I am not able to comment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is not clear to me from the answer given by the Minister whether, in saying that he will give some consideration to the Senate Committee's report, he is agreeing with the actual example I gave, that is, that here we have a great resource development project going ahead despite the imposition of a resource rent tax by the Western Australian Government. In other words, does this not undermine the Minister's constant claim that the imposition of such a tax would impede or frustrate the development of our great projects based on our national resources and energy?

—Since at this moment there is no clarity at all on what will be the royalties or taxation measures of the Argyle venture, and as the matter has to be ratified by the Western Australian Parliament, it is impossible to comment on some hypothetical question related to it. I repeat: When I have the information on both of these matters I will be able to comment.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy, leads on from the last question asked. I refer him to the misguided report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources headed 'The Development of the Bauxite, Alumina and Aluminium Industries'. I ask: Will the Minister give an unqualified guarantee that the Federal Government will not impose a resource rental tax? Does he consider that power charging prices for natural resource projects are exclusively a State matter? Are mineral royalties also exclusively a State matter when the projects are within State boundaries?

—Mr President, I take a point of order. I restrained myself when Senator Tate asked his question, but I feel that I must respond on this occasion. The report does not recommend the establishment of a resource rental tax.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I had previously given that indication in response to Senator Tate. I had drawn attention to the fact that the report had not done that; it had simply indicated one of an alternative set of circumstances. Because I understood that and because I have not read the report fully, I have said that I cannot comment. As to Senator Crichton-Browne's final question, the payment of royalties within State boundaries is a State matter. Unless those royalties are derived from an off-shore area, when they are shared, they remain a State matter, and so do the various imposts. The Government's policy as it stands at this moment is not to impose a resource rental tax. That is its policy.

—Mr President, I take a further point of order. It is usual in this place when reports are tabled to wait for at least six months for some reaction from the Government as to what attitude it takes to that report. The ink is not dry on this report and we have the Leader of the Government giving the Government's reaction.
—Order! Your point of order is not upheld. I ask honourable senators, when making points of order, to be pretty sure about the matters they are raising and not to take advantage of situations.

—I repeat what I said because Senator McLaren has not understood it. Twice I have said-let me say it for a third time for the honourable senator from Murray Bridge-that I have not read the report and therefore I cannot respond to it. This is the third time I have said that today. Let us hope that it has now struck home.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. It is supplementary inasmuch as I could not hear the precise answer because of the interjections. Did I hear the Minister say that there will not be a resource rental tax?
—I said that the existing policy of the Government is not to impose a resource rental tax.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, refers to the statement by the Minister for Health that the Government will crack down on people who take out hospital only health cover and use hospital outpatient services for medical treatment because this practice threatens the success of the Government's new health care scheme. Can the Minister tell us how the Government will crack down on these people who are using an option in the new health scheme? How does this statement line up with the repeated statements by the Minister for Health that hardly anyone has taken out hospital only insurance and that it has been causing no problem at all in the running of the present health scheme?

—With the best will in the world, I must say that I have not seen the statement to which the honourable senator refers. I will have to refer the matter to the Minister for Health. Since the question involves things which he said, it is only to him that we can go to get an answer to the honourable senator's question.

—Has the Minister for National Development and Energy seen recent reports from Colchester in the United Kingdom that over two years the local authority has taken steps to reduce its fuel costs by converting its fleet of vehicles to run on methane gas produced from the treatment of raw sewage at one of its own plants? Will the Minister advise whether research into this form of energy use is being undertaken in this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —A great deal of research has been done here and elsewhere in the world into the use of methane for a variety of purposes. For example, we hope to tap methane from coal mines for use in addition to the ordinary gas supplied as town gas. The various uses of methane from sewage are of particular interest throughout the world. To take one significant example, in China at this moment something like 90 million people derive the energy needs of their villages and towns from the use of methane made from sewage. So it does have a wide use. If we in Australia were to use methane produced from sewage it would not be able to compete as an automotive fuel with either petrol or liquefied petroleum gas because the modifications required for methane use are similar to those for LPG use. For instance, methanol is not compatible with plastic and to use it we would have to make all sorts of alterations to motor car design.

ANSWER.PARA: A more logical use for methane derived from sewage is as a source of power, particularly for the treatment plants themselves. That is taking place already in Australia-in Adelaide, at Carrum near Melbourne, and at Bondi. After meeting the plants' own power requirements there is limited surplus gas, if any, for other uses. Apart from sewage, the utilisation of methane from the treatment of industrial and agricultural wastes as a fuel supplement for industry could result in useful energy and cost savings. The National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council is currently considering proposals in this area. I will look to see whether there are any more technical details regarding automotive use. It is fair to say that one of the more significant uses of methane gas would be in any crisis to turn it into methanol to run automotive vehicles. We could do that by a fairly simple technical process.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister for National Development and Energy. I ask him to believe me, as he has not read the report, that the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, in referring to the aluminium industry, states on page 23 of its report:

QUESTION.PARA: The Department of National Development and Energy has no greater knowledge of electricity contracts in the various States than is available to the general public.

With the knowledge that the general public knows very little about this issue because of the secrecy of relevant authorities, including State governments, is the Minister concerned by this situation? I ask the Minister about that part of the report which questions the need and the desirability for special incentives from governments in order to attract more of the aluminium industry to Australia. Given this information, is the Minister concerned that at this very moment the Federal Government may be considering granting additional loan funds to the State Electricity Commission of Victoria to cover any shortfall should Alcoa of Australia Ltd insist on a lower electricity tariff for its smelter at Portland in Victoria? Does the Minister agree in the light of these facts that the Government would need overwhelming reasons for making a decision to force Australian and Victorian taxpayers to subsidise further this impoverished multinational corporation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the overall establishment of electric power and power stations in Australia is one that directly concerns my Department and me as a Minister. It is fundamental to whether Australia is to have sufficient electric power to be able to expand its industries for the indefinite future, whatever they may be. To that extent I have said, and I repeat, that I believe the major problem for Australian resource development for the future will not be getting an energy balance in petroleum or hydrocarbons but maintaining sufficient electric power to expand. I say that as a rider. I add that water for the development of electricity is an element of primary importance.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I say that my Department has been keenly interested in the general question of the financing of electric power stations, for the very good reason that the tariffs charged go towards the repayment of the capital commitments and therefore, depending on the rate of repayment, can facilitate or restrict the forward development of power stations. To that extent my Department has collected of its own accord and by seeking a considerable amount of information-whether it could have more knowledge than the general public is a matter for dispute--

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate committee did not think so.

—I know that. The Department has not portrayed itself as having any expert knowledge. It has said, as I would say, that the States have kept tariff charges close to their chests, and that, as they regard commerical and industrial tariffs as being confidential as between the client and the generating authority, they do not release that information. But it is fair to say that we have a keen interest in this matter because, when it comes to Loan Council matters and infrastructure borrowing, of course the Commonwealth has a very real interest indeed. Although I have not read the report I am very conscious of what my Department would have told the Committee. It is true that my Department would be keenly interested to have the maximum amount of expert knowledge on this matter and it has been in continuous discussion with the States on the matter. So that is the basis of the first half of the question.

ANSWER.PARA: I am not aware of any proposition at this moment that Victoria is seeking additional infrastructure borrowing funds as an offset to the problem with Alcoa. That may be one of its suggested approaches for the future, but I am not aware of it at the moment. It therefore follows that I cannot respond to a hypothetical question in that regard. The problem with the generation of electricity in the past has been a fundamental one in that the various State authorities have sought to keep the lowest possible tariffs and to have only a minimum excess of their generating capacity so that they can cope with financing. When it comes to a period in which there is a need to expand, the calculation of my Department is that--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. I think it is about time you reminded the Senate and in particular the Minister of Standing Order 100, that in answering a question he shall not debate the subject matter. What has been happening over the last few weeks is that Senator Carrick has been having a lengthy debate on questions without applying himself to specifically answering them and giving nothing more.

—I have on other occasions in this chamber asked that honourable senators try to keep their questions as short as possible because long questions do require, on many occasions, long answers. I would also ask Ministers to keep their answers as short as possible. If we have short questions and short answers more honourable senators will have a chance to participate in Question Time. I again call the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick.

—Mr President, this question is an involved one with a number of parts. I am endeavouring to give a serious answer. If I gave a simplistic answer it could be wrongly interpreted. I simply end by saying that the keeping of the tariff situation and the financing situation of power stations at the level which has been attractive to the general public in the past has meant that there is now in Australia a difficulty of forward capitalisation. That is the one that is facing Victoria. It is the one that is facing many Australian States. I will look at the report of the Senate Standing Committee, especially at page 23. If there is anything further to add I will give it to Senator Chipp.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to the current dispute with the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. Is that dispute interfering with the payment of pensions and benefits in New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —To date there has been no interference with the payment of pensions in New South Wales or indeed in any other State. There has been some delay in the payment of some benefits, the unemployment and sickness benefits, because of the need for the payment of those to be activated on a fortnightly basis by the beneficiaries. However, the most recent position is that with respect to the cheque run which is almost completed, about 250,000 pension cheques which were due to be printed over recent days have not been printed. They have not been printed and they are not being printed today in Sydney because the officers from the computer centre who are responsible for the work have not reported for duty this morning. Apparently that is at the direction of the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association. It is a very significant fact because, of course, the public statements of the ACOA have been that it is seeking to maintain the payments of pensions and benefits. It is very interesting to look at what was said jointly last week by Barry Cotter, the New South Wales branch secretary, and David Bunn, the Victorian branch secretary. In a Press release last week they stated:

ANSWER.PARA: ACOA has tried throughout this dispute to minimise hardship to clients. This is in stark contrast to the behaviour of the Department which has carried on its confrontationist policy and stood down substantial numbers of staff.
As to difficulties with respect to pensions, which in fact were non-existent at that time, they further stated:
These difficulties have been caused by the standing down of staff who administer pension payments and answer pension enquiries on pension payday.

That is in stark contrast to the situation where officers who have not been stood down have, at the request or direction of ACOA, not fronted to do the computer run which will produce that quarter of a million cheques. It is a further indication of the total lack of consistency between the statements of the ACOA and the actions of the ACOA. The tactics which are being adopted to disrupt the operations of the Department are disgraceful and are an abrogation of their duties as public servants. In the latest bulletin I have seen, which is dated 23 November, under the heading 'Management rattled as ACOA members stand firm' one finds the marvellous sentence:
The unpredictable and imaginative nature of the action is keeping Management on the run and minimising stand downs.

The fact of the matter is that at the moment there is a delay with respect to that run. Of course, consistent with the view I have always expressed that the Government will do everything possible to ensure that payments are maintained to pensioners and beneficiaries, alternative plans are under way which will ensure that pensioners will receive their payments with the minimum possible disruption. These may well become ongoing arrangements as there is no evidence to suggest that the ACOA will cease using pensioners as the innocent pawns for industrial blackmail.

I remind the Senate, in the context of this latest ACOA action, that it was Mr Cotter who said last June: 'Do we have to starve pensioners to get wage justice?' It appears to me that the position of the ACOA is now exposed. I challenge it to declare its position on the delay of pension cheques by the holding up of computer runs. I think it is disgraceful behaviour. It will not succeed. I believe that it should be condemned by every member of this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Social Security been advised of the fact that the Kings Cross Refuge is in severe financial difficulties and is facing imminent closure of its operations unless the assurance can be given that the next six months' funding will be made available early in January? Will the Minister agree to see representatives of the refuge urgently to discuss the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received reports via my Department in the terms which were raised by the honourable senator in his question. The matter has been the subject of consideration by the State Department in New South Wales, which is involved with us in the program under which this refuge and others are funded. At present I have a recommendation from the State Minister not to meet the request of the organisation. I am considering the recommendation of the State Minister, Mr Stewart. If I can get to speak with Mr Stewart today I propose to discuss that matter with him.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, the position is that the shelter has very substantially increased its outgoings by very substantially raising the salaries of the people who are employed in the shelter. I will not attempt to reproduce the rises from memory, but I can tell the Senate that they are very substantial rises which in no sense relate to the level of funding which was agreed for the balance of this financial year. The shelter has put itself in a situation where it cannot meet or it has not got the funds to meet the increased salaries it has agreed to pay. I have little doubt that the State Department and the State Minister have given the matter careful consideration, as have the officers of my own Department who have forwarded a recommendation to me which I have yet to consider. The matter involves two governments. I hope the fact that they are of different political colours illustrates that it is not a partisan matter. There is a problem. We have had problems aired in this chamber recently of organisations which receive funding at a set level and then proceed to spend at a level which is greatly in excess of that funding. At this stage I can say to the Senate only that I have not made a decision on the request that has been made but I am considering the view that has been put to me. I had a request some time ago to visit the refuge concerned. I find it physically impossible in this portfolio to see all those who request to see me. In this case I suggested that the people concerned should see officers of my Department and I believe contact has been made between the officers and the organisation. I think I am in possession of all of the basic facts and I will be examining them over the next few days. I will also examine the request made by the honourable senator. I understand that the refuge wants an answer by 27 November and I will certainly endeavour to give it consideration within the time requested.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Can the Minister inform the Senate why a decision was made by Telecom Australia that if people do not want the international subscriber dialling system connected to their telephones, they have to pay Telecom for the non-use of it? Does the Minister agree that it should be a case of the user pays whereby those people who want the facility of ISD should pay for the cost of it and those people who do not want it-such as the owners of a supermarket in Ferny Grove, Brisbane where the public use the phone as a convenience-should not have to pay for not wanting an ISD connection?
—I have been asked a question in similiar terms to this one previously in the Senate. I responded on that occasion at some length.
—I asked a question about this.

—Senator MacGibbon indicates that he asked a question previously. I responded at some length to indicate the policy which Telecom applies of imposing a fee for those people who wish to have their phones barred from the ISD service or, for that matter, from the subscriber trunk dialling service. I will try to obtain a copy of that detailed answer and make it available to Senator Bjelke-Petersen.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF BUSINESS AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS: RESIGNATION OF PERMANENT HEAD

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Did the Permanent Head of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Besley, announce his resignation on 27 October? Had he packed his bags and cleaned out his office by 5 p.m. on that day? Was his appointment as Managing Director of Monier Ltd announced the following day? Is Mr Besley currently on leave from the Public Service and still receiving his salary? Can the Minister say what the circumstances were of Mr Besley's hasty departure? In particular, has the Public Service Board approved of his new position?

—I can say emphatically that the Public Service Board has agreed that, Mr Besley having expressed a desire to leave and take a particular appointment outside the Public Service, the procedures that are being followed are within the guidelines of the Public Service.
—That was a remarkably quick decision-he resigns one day and it is approved by the Public Service Board the next.

—If the chatterboxes will decline from interjecting I will say that, as to specific details, I do not know the dates concerned but I am aware that the Public Service Board has taken a thorough interest in this matter and has satisfied itself that the procedures are well within the normal behaviour and guidelines for a public servant.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I was provoked by a question asked yesterday by Senator Archer in which he indicated that dangers were involved in running, or jogging as he called it. Does the Minister agree that there are many more dangers to one's health from lack of activity? Has the Minister seen an article in the New Scientist in October this year in which it is shown that Great Britian lags behind the United States of America by an appreciable amount in the prevention of heart disease and that with more education many thousands of lives would be saved in that country? Will the Minister ascertain whether enough education is taking place in Australia about matters contributing to heart troubles? Does he agree that high blood pressure, too much cholesterol in the blood, cigarettes, obesity and lack of physical activity, combined with stress- which some of us are under at times in this place-make one more likely to develop heart disease and that education about these matters should be carried out continuously in this country?

—I must confess that although I am not a regular reader of New Scientist I have in the last 10 minutes been made aware of an article in a copy of New Scientist dated 22 October 1981. I can confirm to Senator Townley that that article does in fact set out many of the matters which he has raised in his question. I am aware that in this country there has been a quite dramatic downturn in the number of deaths from heart disease over the last five or 10 years. That mirrors a similar downturn in the United States of America. I must say as one who was previously fulminating against high cost technology such as that being used in cardiac units that I have had to revise my views because we are at a loss to know exactly why that improved outcome has been occurring in Australia or anywhere else. It is, however, true to say that the factors mentioned by Senator Townley-increased blood pressure, high cholesterol, obesity, cigarette smoking and lack of exercise-are correlated with more heart disease and with worse outcomes. I understand that choosing the wrong parents is also not a very good thing.
—It is the main reason.

—Senator Walters says it is the main reason. Senator Walters did not choose the wrong parents, not in a parliamentary sense, anyhow. In this country there is a very active program of research into the matters raised by Senator Townley. I can confirm for him that regular exercise is one of the things which are thought now to be contributing to the improved outcomes which have been noted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Attorney-General. Is he aware that Dr Struan Sutherland, of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories, Australia's best known and one of the world's leading anti-venom researchers and the man responsible, among other things, for the recent breakthrough in the cure for funnelweb spider bites, is now up for nearly $12,000 in personal legal costs as a result of an incident in June this year when he tipped a bowl of paper clips and pins over the head of his immediate superior? Is the Attorney-General further aware that the incident followed, and was a response to, what clearly appears to have been a long campaign of harassment and attrition against Dr Sutherland by the CSL in the course of which the staff working for him has been reduced from 12, including five professional biochemists, in January 1980 to just one junior technician and a half-share of a washing-up lady in July 1981?

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Attorney further aware that following the paper clips incident Dr Sutherland was suspended from duty and charged with the disciplinary offence of disgraceful and/or improper conduct, for which the penalties included dismissal and that, extraordinary as it sounds, the CSL briefed Queen's Counsel for five days to conduct the case against Dr Sutherland and that as a result he was obliged to incur these costs of the magnitude that I have mentioned because he was in fact fighting for his professional life? Finally, since Dr Sutherland was in the event found guilty only of improper, and not disgraceful, conduct, and that he was only reprimanded, the lightest penalty that could be handed out, does the Attorney agree that in all the circumstances it is manifestly unfair for Dr Sutherland to have to pay the cost burden involved? Will the Attorney fully review the case with a view to an ex gratia payment being made to Dr Sutherland by the Commonwealth?

TALK.START.PARA: —I call the Attorney-General. I suggest that the length of his answer does not have to be in proportion to the length of the question.

—My attention has been drawn to this matter by none other than Senator Evans himself. I am grateful to him for the further information that he has now provided, even though the Senate may have found it rather lengthy in content. However, I can assure the Senate that the material that has been submitted to me in relation to this matter far exceeds anything that Senator Evans has already said about it. To deal with this matter will involve reading a good deal of transcript and also no doubt making some inquiries from my colleague who is responsible for the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. I will undertake to do so, but I cannot give any further assurances at this stage.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry a question. He will be aware of the concern of Australian fishermen about the high level of fish imports from New Zealand. He will also recall the Press statement by the Minister for Primary Industry of 27 August in which he stated that he was arranging for an industry mission to New Zealand to discuss the matter with New Zealand industry and fishing representatives. Can the Minister inform the Senate as to what action has been taken in this matter? When is the report of the mission to New Zealand to be made available?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the concern of Australian fishermen about the high level of fish imports from New Zealand. I have some advice from the Minister for Primary Industry on the matter which was raised by the honourable senator. It is no doubt of great interest to the Senate to know that imports of fish from New Zealand have increased by more than 70 per cent since 1978-79. That, of course, explains the concern of Australian fishermen referred to by Senator Archer in his question.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the complaints received by Mr Nixon over some months he requested the Department to examine the situation in relation to fish imports and report to him. The report stated that increased imports from New Zealand were a major factor affecting the market for reef fish, gemfish and trawl species generally. A high proportion of this increase is from joint ventures involving Russian and other foreign vessels, mainly catching a species of fish called orange roughy or sea perch. The Minister issued a Press release outlining these findings on 27 August. That is the Press release referred to by Senator Archer in his question. The Minister indicated in that Press release that industry representatives and a senior official from the Department would visit New Zealand to discuss the matter with industry and fisheries representatives. The mission visited New Zealand betwen 21 and 26 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —How about giving an answer without notice?

—The Minister understands that New Zealand exporters have agreed to stop sending whole or headed orange roughies-a very good description for Senator Georges-to Australia as they compete directly with the whole fish sold by many Australian fishermen. The mission is presently finalising its report and recommendations to the Commonwealth and State governments. I am glad that I had that information from the Department of Primary Industry. It is the last day of sitting and I know that honourable senators like to get that sort of information before we rise.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware that the Royal Hobart Hospital has just announced that its domiciliary nursing service, covering most of Hobart, is to be severely restricted and that it is not to receive referrals of any new patients? Will the Minister acknowledge that this is a direct result of a cutback in Federal funds and that it is highly short-sighted on the part of the Federal Government not to provide sufficient funds for community health services, especially as the more such services are used the less pressure there is on the more costly hospital system? Will the Federal Government take steps to ensure that more funds are available not just to Tasmania but to all States for community health services so that the home nursing care, to which people are entitled, can be made available?

—If what Senator Coates said about the service provided by the Royal Hobart Hospital is correct, I have no doubt that the decision was made by the Labor Government of Tasmania, for which it alone is responsible. It is entirely within the province of a State Government to order its own priorities. In determining funding for this year and when the new health arrangements were made, account was taken of the needs for community health services. Arrangements were made for the amounts which were attributed to community health services to be increased by 10 per cent when the formula was drawn up for the amounts which should be received by the States. Adequate money has been provided for the continuation of community health services. It is entirely a matter for the government of a particular State to determine how it will order its priorities. If the Government of Tasmania has determined that it will set aside a domiciliary nursing service to the detriment of the people of Tasmania that is something for which the Government of Mr Holgate will have to answer; it is not something which is properly referrable to this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—I seek leave to make a statement on that subject.
—Order! Senator Mulvihill, do you wish to raise a point of order or make a statement?
—Mr President, I take this opportunity to warn the Minister, who is the trigger man who cuts off Question Time, that--
—Order!
—I will be speaking on the adjournment and keeping him here for another 20 minutes.
—Order! Senator Mulvihill, I ask you to be seated when I rise to my feet and to show respect for the Chair, no matter what subject you wish to discuss.
—I was provoked by Senator Carrick.
—Please respect the Chair, even if you think you were provoked.
—Mr President, by leave, I want to remind the Senate and indeed Senator Mulvihill that the action of--
—Who says you got leave?
—I seek leave, Mr President.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, because Senator Mulvihill has said what he has said, I want to say that precisely what happened today is what was confirmed by the Standing Orders Committee, which is a bilateral committee of this Parliament, and that is that at the end of one hour the Leader of the Government in the Senate shall do what I did. There was no discourtesy to Senator Mulvihill or anybody else. During Question Time for the whole of this session it has been my habit to make sure that the Opposition gets more questions than the Government. That in fact happened. So there has been no discourtesy. I acted strictly within the Standing Orders. I rose after one hour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr President, I seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I think there is a motto 'Who dares, wins'. I do not want to be provocative. I simply say that, whatever the Standing Orders Committee does, the system is not good enough when honourable senators cannot ask a question at least on alternative days. That is what I want to be strived for. I am not issuing an ultimatum, but I assure Senator Carrick and the Senate that when I do speak tonight or early in the morning it will not be for the duration that one of the non-socialist senators spoke early this morning.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 November, Senator Sibraa asked me a question about the form of advice received from the Zambian authorities in relation to the death of the Australian Broadcasting Commission journalist Tony Joyce in Zambia. Senator Button asked me a related question. Senator Sibraa reminded me of these questions yesterday when he asked a supplementary question. I can confirm what I said in reply to Senator Sibraa yesterday. The advice received from the Zambian authorities is in fact the letter received by the Prime Minister from President Kaunda. There is no separate report.

ANSWER.PARA: The letter cannot be tabled in the Senate for the reasons I have already explained. But it is clear from what the Prime Minister said in the Parliament on 17 September that there are different versions of the facts in relation to the shooting. I confirm to Senator Button that one of the accounts the Government has received is that Tony Joyce was shot while sitting in the back of a Zambian police car. Communications from Australian Foreign Affairs officers overseas are confidential, but in any case in this instance no Australian Foreign Affairs officer was present at the time of the shooting or indeed in Zambia at the time. Therefore, the Prime Minister has commented that it is unlikely that the issue will be fully resolved. Regrettably, that is so. I share that view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today in Question Time I promised to try to get for Senator Missen the date on which certain industrial action in relation to telex services began. I am able to inform Senator Missen and the Senate that the action to which he referred in his question commenced on 9 November this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation arising out of Question Time.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
