TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time, Senator Thomas, in an extraordinary intervention, stated that he had restrained himself while I was asking a question and that he wanted to make it clear that the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources had not recommended the imposition of a national resources tax. As there is a clear implication that I had misled the Senate and suggested that the Committee had so recommended, I wish to make two comments. Firstly, my question asked whether the Minister had noted the plea of the Committee that fresh consideration be given to the imposition of such a tax on behalf of all Australians. Secondly, I quote the one and only paragraph in the report dealing with a national resources tax:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee believes that any review of the current taxation applying to resources based industries should include consideration of the use of resource rent tax or other variable tax on profit. Where an industry's profitabality provides a return on its investment significantly greater than that necessary to call forth the investment in the first place then there are valid reasons for considering a higher rate of tax on that 'excess' return on investment. This is particularly the case where, in the provision of services such as electricity to industry, there is some justification for believing that the full value of the resources used to provide that service are not being recovered from the purchaser. In evidence to the Committee the Secretary of the Treasury acknowledged, in an appropriately qualified answer, that in the circumstances outlined above, a resource rent tax would be a suitable mechanism for 'picking up' any excess profit resulting from under pricing of resources and services supplied to industry.
Mr President, I thank the Senate for allowing me to make it clear that I, in asking my question, really merely repeated the terms of that paragraph within the Senate Committee report.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1981, Senator Robertson asked me a question concerning funds for the Department of the Parliamentary Library and recommendations of the management review of the departments of the Parliamentary Library, Parliamentary Reporting Staff and Joint House. Funds for the Parliamentary Library and any matters relating to its funds come under the jurisdiction and control of Mr Speaker and me and the Parliamentary Librarian. The Joint House Department has no authority over or responsibility for internal matters of the Parliamentary Library or any other parliamentary department. Consistent with this, the cuts which were made by the Department of Finance in bids for the Parliamentary Library for the current financial year are presently the subject of discussion and negotiation between Mr Speaker and me and the Leaders of both Houses.

INTERJECT.PARA: With respect to the recommendations contained in the reports of the management consultants on the three service departments, these are currently under discussion with the permanent heads. Certain recommendations relating to the individual functional operations of the three departments have been implemented. These were, in fact, implemented prior to my becoming President. No recommendations in connection with amalgamation of functions of the departments have been effected, and, in fact, since my becoming President, certain positions which were proposed to be implemented have not been proceeded with. I can assure honourable senators that Mr Speaker and I will certainly make no decisions for change without a thorough assessment of the recommendations and careful consideration.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981, Senator Colston asked me whether the 1982 diaries supplied to honourable senators were printed in Hong Kong. I am informed that the 1982 Senate diary is a standard item-Model 72PA-supplied by an Australian company based in Sydney. The diaries for 1981 and 1982 were manufactured in Hong Kong to that company's specifications. Since 1978, the Department of the Senate has purchased desk diaries from a Canberra firm, which selects an Australian company to supply the diaries on the basis of the lowest available price. The Canberra firm arranges with a local manufacturer for the hot foil stamping of the Australian crest and the word Senate on the front cover of the diary.

INTERJECT.PARA: It is understood that the recommended retail price, which includes sales tax of 17 1/2 per cent, is $6.80 and that the recommended retail price of a similar diary made in Australia is approximately $15.00. The cost of each 1982 Senate diary is $5.85. Inquiries will continue to be made of other Australian companies to ascertain whether a similar diary made in Australia can be purchased at a price comparable with that of the present Senate diary.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —During the hearings of Estimates Committee A, I undertook, in reply to questions from Senator Evans, to consider making a statement to the Senate on the present situation of the staffing of the Department of the Senate and the implementation of the management consultancy review conducted by P.A. Consulting Services Pty Ltd. I now table that statement and, with the concurrence of the Senate, incorporate it in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: The document read as follows-

The consultant's report was given to my predecessor, Sir Condor Laucke, in July 1980. In accordance with one of the recommendations of the report, he established an implementation committee, consisting of senior officers of the Department of the Senate, which has considered the report and made recommendations, some of which I am in the process of considering.

A number of the recommendations have already been implemented with success. For example, a procedure section has been established under the control of a principal parliamentary officer (procedure) who also advises non-government Senators on procedural matters. I believe that this arrangement is working most satisfactorily. The previous records and table offices have been amalgamated and restructured as a single unit. It is now a central and more convenient point of contact for the provision of many of the services available for senators and their staff. The amalgamation has also permitted the introduction of improved administrative and staffing practices, with consequent advantages to the Department.

In accordance with the report of the consultant, there has been some re-arrangement of the responsibilities of certain senior officers. Also, the number of attendant positions has been reduced and the functioning of the attendant staff is being kept under constant review. In addition, many of the minor administrative changes recommended by the consultant have been implemented. I might add that, after the new arrangements have been operating for twelve months, a further review is to be carried out to evaluate their success.

In the committee secretariat it has not been found possible to implement the recommendations of the consultant. In accordance with the review, the implementation committee held discussions, first with the committee chairmen and, at a later stage, with committee chairmen and Opposition representatives from the committees. It was the unanimous view of these meetings that the consultant's recommendations for the committee secretariat be rejected.

The consultant did remark, in relation to the Department as a whole, that the existing grades in the Department make career path planning, with desirable interchange and rostering, more difficult and stated that there was a need to devise a means to enable the classifications of the positions in active use to be varied from time to time to meet work and staffing requirements. The consultant also stated that there was a particular need to increase flexibility within the committee secretariat to cope with the inevitable loss of staff, and within the Department as a whole to permit better use of resources.

The implementation committee has had discussions with the committee chairmen and Opposition representatives on this matter and discussions are to be held with officers of the Public Service Board to try to resolve the difficulties inherent in the inflexible staff structure currently existing in the Department.

Discussions with officers of the Public Service Board will also cover two other areas within the departmental structure which either the implementation committee considers that the consultant's review has not adequately covered or to which, because of changing circumstances, it cannot agree. These areas are-relief staff, and the secretarial services available to senators and to the Department, including increased and new uses of word processors. It is anticipated that these problems will be overcome satisfactorily in due course.

Staffing problems associated with the establishment by the Senate of three select committees have been resolved. A number of temporary positions have been created to staff these committees and a temporary increase in the Senate staff ceiling has been approved for the duration of the inquiries.

Since the consultant presented the report in 1980, demands on the Senate staff have altered and, in certain areas, have increased. This has been caused by a number of factors, not the least of which, has been the change in composition of the Senate since July 1981. I have instructed my officers to keep Senate staffing under a constant review and to advise me immediately any problems arise. In this way I hope to ensure that all the services currently provided to the Senate and to senators are not only maintained at their present level but, if possible, are improved. To this end, to my knowledge and observation, all Senate staff are co-operating to the full extent in instituting and developing the changed staffing and functional arrangements.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Button proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The consistent incompetence and impropriety of the Fraser Government.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The topic of this matter of public importance has just been read to the Senate. I must say right at the outset that in the terminology used-'the consistent incompetence and impropriety of the Fraser Government'-there is perhaps a slight error. This matter of public importance was drafted in the early hours of the morning in circumstances which might be described as less than favourable for the most lucid expression of what one intended to say. I think I should have said 'the inconsistent incompetence and inconsistent impropriety of the Fraser Government' rather than using the word 'consistent'. When one moves about this country talking to people in the electorate, one learns that one of the great concerns which they have, whether they be in business or employees of business, or whatever walk of life they come from, is a growing concern about the inconsistencies in the Government's policies. They are asking: 'Where is it all going? What on earth is going to happen next under this Government?'

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, in a sense, if I may borrow an expression from Sir Charles Court, it would be almost a state of excitement were it not so tragic in terms of what this Government's policies are doing to the economy, to business confidence, to the social fabric of Australian society and to the poorer sections of the Australian community by massive transfers of wealth in one form or another from the poorer to the wealthier sections of society. The notion of incompetence and impropriety is, in a sense, not entirely mine. I think the point I wish to make on that issue is very well illustrated by a statement released last week not by some radical fringe group in Australian society but by the Confederation of Australian Industry. It expressed concern that its commitments were in jeopardy because of changes of policy by the Fraser Government. In that statement the Confederation of Australian Industry said:

What is even more disturbing is that these about-face decisions are usually preceded not by an announcement by the responsible Minister but by what is now a recognisable pattern of rumours and leaks which in turn mostly end up being correct.

Of course, that statement contains every element of an allegation of inconsistency and change in the Government's policy. This tragic level of performance by what even the least charitable of us would describe as a once great party is sad. It is sad that we have to raise these issues on the last sitting day of the Senate before Christmas. We would have liked to send honourable senators opposite away with a cheery message, but I am afraid that course is not open to us.

I see that Senator Carrick has been drawn to the barricades yet again to defend this shonky and incompetent Government, to answer the allegations which we will make about these issues and which I will be making in the course of my remarks. I know what the defence will be, because Senator Carrick has only one defence. He reaches in his grab bag of supportive allegations and he goes back to the period of the Labor Government. He says: 'But look, people were saying these things about the last Labor Government from 1972 to 1975. What is wrong with us? We have an alibi'. He will say: 'A Labor Government was like this too'. Organisations like the Confederation of Australian Industry were saying these things about--

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be happy to disappoint you.

—Senator Carrick will not have anything to say if he does not talk about this. He never has in the whole history of his career as Leader of the Government in the Senate. Senator Carrick will talk about these things. Before he does I want to remind him that this Government came to power in 1975, in all that bastardry that went on in 1975-the constitutional turmoil that was created by this Government$ by Malcolm Fraser and his acolytes in 1975-and justified all that at the time in the assumption that a Fraser Government would do better.
—But we have.

—Senator Martyr says: 'We have'. Let us have a look at that in terms of, firstly, recent promises and performances. We do not want to rummage-to use Senator Carrick's phrase-in the dust bins of history of four or five years ago. We do not need to.
—I bet you don't.
—We would be quite happy to if Senator Thomas wants us to but we do not need to because we have limited time and last year's record will suffice. Last year, seeking re-election, Mr Fraser said:

SPEECH.PARA: The central objective of the Government's policy is to reduce inflation.

This year's Fraser Budget predicts that inflation will rise to 10 3/4 per cent-a modest prediction in the likely circumstances. Last year before the election Mr Fraser promised increasing employment and reduced unemployment. On page 55 of the Budget statements for 1981-82-the Government's Budget-a slackening of employment growth and little change in unemployment are predicted. In fact, unemployment is increasing. Last year Mr Fraser promised to keep taxes at the lowest possible level. This year's Budget increases sales tax by 40 per cent and pay-as-you-earn tax by over 20 per cent. This year's Budget belies the promises made last year before the election. No wonder Mr Hugh Morgan, the Chairman of the Australian Mining Industry Council, commenting on the Budget, said that this Government does not understand what it is doing. Last year Mr Fraser promised to:
Distribute the tax burden as far as possible, with particular concern for low income families.

In fact, Budget tax increases have been assiduously directed towards the less wealthy section of the Australian community. Taxes have hit low income families with one and two children more than anyone else, not to mention the absence of housing policies of this Government and not to mention the failure to honour promises about family allowances. Not to mention any of those things, taxation policies alone have hit families most and low income families most of all. These are some of the broad indicators of the rhetoric and performance of this Government over the last 12 months.

Let us look at some of the aspects of the Government's administration of its own departments. The Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, for example, was abandoned and the committee members were left to hang out to dry because this Government wanted to look after some friends. Sir Peter Abeles was probably the first businessman to walk into a Liberal Party meeting and address it about his interests. That was why the Holcroft Inquiry was abandoned. We can look at Australia Post, an area of government responsibility. For the first time in the history of that organisation it made a loss last year and, at the same time, this Government hived off its most profitable activity, the Australia Post Courier Service-again at the instigation of a company, Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd of whom, I think, Sir Peter Abeles, coincidentally, happens to be managing director. That is what happened to Australia Post this year.

Telecom Australia has had severe interest rate impositions placed on it this year by this Government. The McKinsey report on Telecom, which this Government has ignored, recommends additional capital for Telecom. This was a Government commissioned report which the Government would not release. I released it in the Senate. This year in relation to Telecom we have seen such incidents as the giving of viewdata, which was to be operated by Telecom in conjunction with a wide range of private enterprise companies, to private monopolies run by Packer and Myer. In today's paper we see that Australian Consolidated Press Ltd, as represented by Mr Packer, now wants to retreat from that position and get on Telecom's back again in the running of viewdata. That decision about viewdata which goes to the heart of dissemination of information in a free society and to the heart of profitability for an organisation such as Telecom, was made against the advice of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, against the advice of the Department of Communications, and against the advice of the Department of the Treasury. It was made by Cabinet against all that advice, and it was made in particular by the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair).

The people of Australia are beginning to ask why? The answer is that that question would not be asked by the people of Australia if this Government faced up to such issues as the freedom of information legislation which it has virtually abandoned despite its electoral promises, if it would face up, as other democracies such as the United States have done, to the issue of the disclosure of funds made available to political parties. That is why people are very suspicious about decisions made by the Minister for Communications. That is an issue which this Government has to face up to. Where is the money coming from?

Another example of the Government's incompetence relates to the broadcasting and television legislation which was introduced into this Parliament last week. This is the second set of broadcasting and television Bills to be introduced. The first Bill having been abandoned, the legislation was amended as a result of pressure from a particular media proprietor. That legislation goes to the integrity of the Government's Budget because it reduces the Government's revenue at the instigation of one media proprietor. The Government is immovable on the question of sales tax on such things as books, children's shoes and clothing, all issues which are relevant to the mass of the Australian people and their standard of living. It is not immovable when it comes to pressure from a very powerful and wealthy vested interest in this country.

The report of another government instrumentality, Qantas Airways Ltd, was tabled in the Senate last week. The financial directive to Qantas by the Australian Government, which is crucial to its operations, has been under discussion for five years and has not yet been made public. That is very relevant to questions relating to Qantas's accounting and financial performance, a performance which is bad. Another semi-government instrumentality, Trans-Australia Airlines, is now reducing services to the outback of Queensland. Questions are suddenly being asked in this place about TAA's services, and properly so. Senator Bjelke-Petersen is acknowledging that I acknowledge her questions on this point. Those services are being reduced as a result of Government policies in relation to Trans-Australia Airlines. It is something about which we warned this chamber six or nine months ago, but the Government was not then prepared to take the warning. It has now happened. In the last year we have seen the farce of the so-called razor gang, which was a public relations gimmick. This Government is devoted to public relations gimmicks as distinct from real policies. It was an amateurishly compiled exercise abolishing 40 committees, three-quarters of which were created by Liberal governments, and half of which were created by the Fraser Government. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, in answer to that allegation, said that a government is entitled to change its mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —To see the error of our ways.

—That is right, to see the error of its ways. But that is precisely what business and industry are complaining about. Quite recently Sir Roderick Carnegie said words to the effect that this Government continually changes the ground rules. As Mr Max Burr, the Liberal Federal member for Wilmot in Tasmania has put it, the Government on many issues is firing from the hip with ad hoc policy decisions that do not seem to correspond perhaps with other policy decisions that have been made in the past. Nobody knows where the Government is going because it has no sense of direction itself. It keeps changing its minds on these important issues. Another example is the continued loss to revenue arising from tax avoidance. Last year the Government saved $1.5m because of its staff ceilings policy in the Taxation Office. At the same time millions of dollars-an estimated $46.5m for last year-are lost through tax avoidance schemes which cannot be followed up because of inadequate staff ceilings.

SPEECH.PARA: Another area of Government policy which is very important to consider is that of industrial relations because it illustrates the Fraser Government style. The Government talks up and beats up issues but it has no policies on and no creative imagination about the issues that ought to be involved. Let us look at the 35-hour working week issue which was debated in the Senate earlier this year. Senator Carrick talked his head off about how the Government would make a stand on this issue. I refer honourable senators to what Alcoa said to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission a fortnight ago. A newspaper article which dealt with the hearing before the Arbitration Commission stated:
The Federal Government failed to honour its promise of support to Alcoa earlier this year when the company sought assistance in resisting the shorter hours campaign . . .
The article continued:
Mr Ian Douglas QC detailed a series of futile negotiations between the company and the Federal Government in April and May on the question of support in countering the hours campaign.

The article went on at great length and pointed out that this Government talked big about that issue but when the crunch came it went to water and left those companies out on a limb. That is not an industrial relations policy. That is consistent with the rhetoric and empty headedness of this Government and nothing else. This Government has built up in industrial relations the greatest armoury of weapons for use in industrial disputes that any government has ever had but the record of disputes remains the same. Nothing has happened on this issue except a lot of noisy wind from Government spokesmen.

During this year we saw the Prime Minister, the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) and the Treasurer (Mr Howard) boasting of cheating the Premiers out of $70m. We have seen scandal after scandal revealed from National Country Party Ministers in the administration of their portfolios. Ministers have received the benefit of low interest housing loans on which they pay virtually no repayments at all. We have seen decisions relating to Telecom dictated not by advice but by venality on behalf of particular Ministers. We have seen a decision in relation to telecommunications on Lord Howe Island-one suspects, overriding Telecom-made by the Minister for Communications for some motive which has not been publicly revealed but which is not consistent with orderly policy making. We have seen the Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd situation. He has moved from funeral parlours to dairies. The Minister for Communications follows his mafioso career. One way or another--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I take objection under Standing Orders to the suggestion that the Minister for Communications is following his mafioso career. I ask that it be withdrawn without qualification.
—I withdraw. The word mafioso refers to Mafia philosophy which is--
—I ask that there be an unqualified withdrawal.

—I withdraw. This issue of the National Country Party and the Liberal Party is of crucial importance to this Government because the Prime Minister has standards about the Country Party which are different from the standards which he himself has laid down and has applied to people such as Senator Withers, who sits in this place. That is a very important consideration in government policy making. This year we also had the Peacock resignation. That is another issue which paralyses the decision-making of this Government. The Industries Assistance Commission report on the car industry has not been responded to by the Government because the Prime Minister does not know where the Peacock voters will go in the Liberal Party caucus. That is what is paralysing the Government in its decision-making on this issue, as it is on industrial relations issues. So, we have great conflicts within the Government: An abandonment of standards of principle previously prescribed by the Prime Minister to help his friends and an abandonment of standards of government to protect the Prime Minister from revolt within his own ranks. This Government has ignored the interests of the Australian people. It looks after its great and powerful friends by operating a system of patronage. It indulges in costly overseas stunts to conceal those issues and projects a phony nationalism as a gigantic fraud on the Australian people.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the past six years the people of Australia, through the ballot box by an overwhelming majority, have put into office and re-elected the Fraser Liberal-National Country Party Government. Let the test be this: The judgment was made by the 7 million or 8 million people of Australia at the ballot box and not by the fruity melodrama of Senator Button. That judgment was made in favour of the competence and integrity and the imaginative policies of the existing Government. I will deal step by step with the matters raised by Senator Button. I would not want to disappoint Senator Button who, of course, always asks me to go back to the past. So I will go back to 1979. On 18 July 1979, the Leader of the Federal Opposition, Mr Hayden, said of the Whitlam Labor Government:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as a Government we disappointed and disillusioned many Australians by some of our actions, our individual excesses in the period 1973 to 1975.

I stress the words 'we disappointed and dis- illusioned many Australians by our actions, our individual excesses . . .'. That was a statement to the Australian Labor National Conference on 18 July 1979, a mea culpa from the heart of the Labor leader.

Senator Button now raises this matter of public importance. Let me state the positive aspects concerning this Government. This Government has had re-endorsement at the ballot box on three occasions; two of them by extraordinary majorities. The Budget which has just been brought down has been commended by virtually every prominent and authoritative economist and financial writer in Australia as being a Budget that was correct for the circumstances and in the interests of the people of Australia. Our economy has been commended in reports of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development and by nations abroad as one of the best run economies in the free world, an economy which some six years ago had been placed by the Whitlam Government in the top bracket of inflation. Mr Hawke referred to inflation running at 16 per cent or 17 per cent at the time. I suppose the Opposition would accept those figures as being correct. It has now been reduced to 9 per cent or 10 per cent. I repeat that our economy has been commended. Our Budget aims to do two things. It aims to take Australia out of the top bracket of inflation, where it was put by the Whitlam Labor Government, and to put it in the lower quarter of the scale of OECD countries. That is what we are doing.

We have witnessed some extraordinary situations. There has been talk of some inconsistencies of the Government. It has been said that manufacturers have had some problems with this Government. Let me give honourable senators some information on this matter. Mr Willis, a spokesman for the Australian Labor Party, was reported in the Sydney Morning Herald on 18 July 1979 as saying:
We just can't keep on supporting small manufacturing industries all the time with protection.

We now know that that is the Labor Party's policy, and the Leader of the Opposition stated that. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Lionel Bowen, in a speech to the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union, stated:
We must accept that in the future a more efficient manufacturing industry may involve fewer workers.

I think some mention was made that this Government was not reducing tax enough. It is worthwhile remembering these things. In the Australian Financial Review of 29 June 1972, Mr Hayden, the now Leader of the Labor Party, stated:
As a purely personal statement, I'm a high tax man.
Addressing the Labor Economists Conference, Brisbane in June 1978, Mr Willis said:

If Labor does not gain office next election then by 1983, when we could next hope to gain office, we would face a mammoth task in rebuilding the public sector-and maybe an equally mammoth task in convincing the electorate that it should pay a higher level of tax to enable us to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —How long ago were these quotes? When was that said?

—That was said by Mr Willis when he addressed the Labor Economists Conference, Brisbane in June 1978. I think there was some suggestion that indirect taxation increases are wrong. Mr Hurford, in the Age of 29 June 1977, is quoted as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: When it comes to further revenue we will seek to find it, in progressive ways, from indirect taxes.

We have a situation in which a government which failed and which by its leader's statement indulged in all sorts of excesses and failures is now saying in Opposition: 'Look here you fellows, you are doing these things the wrong way'. I pointed out earlier that we have been commended overseas for what has happened. What has happened in Australia since the Labor Party went out of office in 1975 is that whereas in 1974-75 there was a massive shedding of employees from manufacturing industry-120,000 to 150,000 people in the space of 12 months or less by vicious across the board 25 per cent tariff cuts, against protection-the party responsible, the Labor Party, is now saying: 'You have not got your manufacturing policies in tight order'. We had a situation in which a government was thrown out of office. Senator Button referred to scandals. Why was it thrown out? It was thrown out because of the massive culmination of disaster after disaster. Ministers were thrown out and turned over by Mr Whitlam, and resigned. Finally there was the Khemlani loan affair which is recognised by every right-thinking person as a massive breach of principle, a scandal perhaps of a magnitude greater than anything we have had in Australia. This is the party which on what may be the last day of this session is trying to gain some capital.

Senator Button said: 'You do not have an industrial relations policy'. In 1974-75 the Labor Party had a troika in industrial relations. It was in government and had the industrial relations portfolio. It had an Australian Council of Trade Unions President named Mr Hawke. It had as Federal President of the ALP the same Mr Hawke. It had the capacity within the unions, within the Government and within the Labor Party, with absolutely no restriction at all, to resolve industrial relations at every point in Australia. Six million working days were lost then, the record for all time. We reduced it to one million.

The Labor Party has had the sheer gall to come here and talk about industrial relations despite the fact that when the Labor Party was in government and had, I repeat, an industrial relations Minister and as Federal President of the Labor Party a person who was the ACTU President it had, with the combination of all powers in its hands, the record industrial strife and turmoil of all time. Now members of the Labor Party come to us and say that these things are wrong. Now they try to drum up talk of scandal. It is important to remember that it is all innuendo. There is nothing that they can tangibly raise except repetition. The situation now is quite different from the Khemlani situation. The absolute tragedy of that time is now documented. I think the word 'shonky' was used to describe the dealings. Was there ever such a shonky dealing as the behind the scenes dealing giving unduly high commission, mortgaging Australia for the indefinite future, running an Executive Council illegally, and refusing to tell the Governor-General of the day what was being done? This is the party that has the gall on the last day of sitting to talk of scandal.

What has it raised? Telecom Australia has said, and it is quite clear, that the policies it makes as to the direction of its telephone public works are its policies and not those of the Minister as such. The Opposition talks about Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd but it can produce nothing on this matter. One after another Opposition senators talk innuendo. Stripped down, what have we? We have a situation in which six years ago they were flung out of office and twice since then that decision has been reconfirmed in a very substantial way. They have condemned themselves by their own statements on every one of these policies that they have raised today. Against that we have a government which took the highest inflation that Australia was facing in that period and virtually halved it. It is bearing down on inflation. Of course it will cut expenditure in doing so. If it is to stop the proliferation of public works borrowings and if it is to take the heat out of public loan raising, the first thing it has to do is to reduce its own deficit so that it does not have to go into the market and borrow in public loans, pushing up interest rates. It can leave the public loan borrowing market to those of the private sector to borrow for the creation of more jobs and more industry. That has been eminently successful.

This Government is the government that over the decades created the highest home ownership of any country in the world. It did so by enabling the ordinary families of Australia to amass their little capital, which was sneered at by the Dedmans of this world who did not want little capitalists as such. We have always put the thrust in that way. Now, by the empty rhetoric, come these phrases: 'But we do not care about the little people. We do not care about the poor. We care only about big business'. Let me say without any qualification that the overwhelming bulk of the great social welfare legislation and innovations in Australia has been brought about by governments of Liberal faith. Governments of Liberal faith brought in age pensions, widows' pensions, child endowment, pharmaceutical benefits, medical and health benefits and so on. It was this Fraser Government that brought in the family allowance scheme and this Fraser Government which, in this Budget, extended the scheme. If we look, one by one, at the types of legislation that have been brought down in Australia, the picture emerges. Labor talked and talked land rights for Aborigines but which State governments and which Commonwealth government introduced land rights for Aborigines? The South Australian Liberal Government did so. Where does the Wran Labor Government stand on this issue? It is dragging its heels in this situation. The Fraser Liberal Government is showing world leadership on a massive scale on this issue in the Northern Territory. So we have talk on the one part and action on the other.

If people are looking for a government which has looked and acted with true concern, they must look to the Fraser Government. It is easy and cheap to talk. The Labor Party, over all its history, has put over a massive confidence trick. It has talked about how it is the friend of the workers but it destroyed living standards in 1973, 1974 and 1975. If people want to look at some real legislation which has been put in place and if they want to look at the way in which industrial trade unionism as distinct from political trade unionism has been strengthened, they must look to governments of Liberal faith.

Let us look at what the Leader of the Opposition has said. First of all, he talked about there being a lack of confidence in the community. I can only say that time and time again over the past year, in conferences at Cabinet level with business leaders in this country, business leaders have said without qualification, even up to and including the last few days: 'Your Budget was absolutely right. Your Budget with its emphasis on bearing down on inflation and interest rates was absolutely right'. Commerce and industry in Australia know that the policies which we have put in place are the best policies for Australia. The people of Australia know that the way in which to help them, the way in which to ensure that their living standards continue to rise and the way in which to ensure that they can buy homes and acquire more property is to have lower inflation and an abatement of interest rates.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are both going up.

—It is by those means that we can achieve these things; not by the lifting of strident voices, not by all this talk which produces nothing, not by all this arguing all the time by Opposition members, not by that kind of conflict which is inherent in the Labor Party, not by these kinds of confessions, these mea culpas of the Labor Party which I have read out. By positive action, this Government moves on and on with policies which will benefit the Australian people. It is not for nothing that the countries of the Western world are looking to Australia today as a major hope in terms of resource development to create for them the opportunities for the safeguarding of their own living standards.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have seen is Senator Button getting up day by day in this chamber exploiting this so-called urgency motion technique, using the rhetoric of melodrama and the abandonment of fact. He supports a leader who says that he is a high tax man. He supports a spokesman who says that small business must go. 'We can't', says Mr Willis, 'keep on supporting small manufacturing industries all the time with protection'. If Senator Button wants to have the kinds of scandals of the past, of course, his blueprint is there. He can back the kinds of industrial relations policies that were the most disastrous in history because the most over promoted individual figure in Australian political and public life, the man who was the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Federal President of the Australian Labor Party, and who is now a front bench Opposition member in the other place, failed completely when he had the opportunity to do something about the situation. When the Labor Party had the opportunities it failed completely. Now all it has to put forward is the rhetoric of melodramatic nonsense. The fact is that the very health of the economy, the very resilience of business, commerce and industry in this country and the very attraction to this country of foreign investment support the fact that our policies are right and that Labor's policies remain condemned. I move:
That the business of the day be called on.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The first meeting of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills was held on 25 November 1981. I was appointed Chairman, Senator Michael Tate, Deputy-Chairman and Miss Anne Lynch, a Senate officer, Secretary of the Committee. The Committee has put in train enquiries for the purpose of appointing legal counsel to the Committee and will proceed to examine Bills which, in either House of the Parliament, are held over for debate in 1982. The Committee will determine guidelines, procedures and reporting methods so that it can effectively report on Bills during the trial period of operation up to 30 June 1982. Any suggestions from members of the public coming within the terms of reference of this Committee should be addressed to the Secretary, Parliament House, Canberra, and will be considered by the Committee. The terms of reference of the Committee are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: That a Standing Committee of the Senate, to be known as the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, be appointed to report, in respect of the clauses of Bills introduced into the Senate, and in respect of Acts of the Parliament, whether such Bills or Acts, by express words or otherwise-
(a) trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties;
(b) make rights, liberties and obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers or non-reviewable administrative decisions; or
(c) inappropriately delegate legislative power or insufficiently subject its exercise to parliamentary scrutiny.

That the Committee, for the purpose of reporting upon the clauses of a Bill when the Bill has been introduced into the Senate, may consider any proposed law or other document or information available to it, notwithstanding that such proposed law, document or information has not been presented to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations I present a report on the Committee's references on certain annual reports.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

The annual reports which are contained in the document tabled deal with the Australian National Gallery, the Australian Wheat Board, various trust funds of the Australian military forces and the Nominal Defendant, the Nominal Defendant being an officer of the Australian Capital Territory. The only substantial outstanding matters in all of these reports are those concerning the Australian Wheat Board. This has been an ongoing problem and one on which numerous reports have been delivered in the Senate on behalf of the Committee by Senator Rae.

Although clearly there has been negligent administration within the Wheat Board in previous years, and I suppose in the Department of Primary Industry, to which it is responsible, the Wheat Board has a continuing problem in accurately determining the stocks which it holds and therefore in presenting accurate financial statements. The problem is that the Board has no effective control over its licensed receivers. The licensed receiver is usually a State-wide grain handling authority although in some cases it is not. Some of the State-wide grain handling authorities are co-operative companies. Some are statutory bodies appointed by State governments.

In the past some of these licensed receivers, regrettably, seem to have been more concerned with asserting their perceived territorial rights than with efficient administration. It is to be hoped that in the future commonsense will prevail in negotiations between the Wheat Board and its State licensed receivers and that mutually acceptable means will be devised by which the Board can accurately determine its stocks and therefore accurately report its financial position.
