DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment: Government Response

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment report on Australian Marine Science. The statement has been distributed to honourable senators. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
AUSTRALIAN MARINE SCIENCE
REPORT FROM THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT
Statement by Senator the Hon. Peter Durack, Q.C., Minister Representing the Minister for Science and Technology

The Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment tabled its report concerning Australian Marine Science on 11 June 1981. The Government has considered the Report and noted carefully its recommendations. I am pleased now to present the Government's response to the report. I seek leave to table a document which presents the Government's response to each recommendation and to incorporate it in Hansard.

The Government views the report as a substantial and valuable contribution to the development of policies for marine science in Australia. Its 45 recommendations present a detailed plan for the co-ordination and future development of Australian Marine Science. The Government is pleased to note that many elements of the report's recommendations are already the subject of government initiatives or are matters presently under consideration by the Government and its advisory bodies.

The Government fully supports what it believes to be the Committee's broad objective which underlies its detailed recommendations, namely, the continued development of a viable, effective and productive Australian marine science program. The Government does not, however, at this time accept some of the specific solutions proposed by the Senate Committee, particularly as these relate to the establishment of a statutory Marine Science Council and its subsidiary bodies. These elaborate arrangements are considered not to be warranted by the present and near-future scale of Australia's marine science, and their establishment would be contrary to the Government's policy of financial restraint and its concern to reduce the number of statutory bodies.

The Government recognises that Australia's marine science effort should be concentrated on matters of high national priority to produce results of direct benefit to Australia. To achieve this the Government will ensure that all available resources are used in the most effective way. To gain maximum benefit we must also ensure that the results of this concerted effort are not only readily available to those who can make use of them, but are also in a form which meets their needs.

The Government's commitment to meeting these objectives is amply demonstrated by the actions it has taken in recent years. Many of these are described in the document I have tabled. It is both significant and gratifying that these initiatives are generally in accord with the Committee's recommendations for the future development of Australian marine science.
I would like now to draw attention to some of the more important aspects of the Government response to the Senate Committee's report.

Perhaps the most wide-ranging recommendations in the report concern the establishment of a Marine Science Council having a combined advisory, policy-development, financing and co-ordinating role. As I have stated, the Government fully recognises the need for a comprehensive marine science policy and agrees with the Committee that this should be based on the best available advice. This requires the co-ordination of up-to-date information from all sectors of the community concerned with marine science. However, the Government does not believe that, at this time, a Marine Science Council provides the most appropriate way to carry out these functions.

The mechanisms established by the Government to develop advice on which to base marine science policies and to implement such policies are in many instances relatively recent and are of a scale commensurate with our current marine science effort. Moreover, these mechanisms are such as to lend themselves to further development as the overall marine science effort evolves. The Government proposes that the Committee's Report serve as a useful paradigm, in some instances, perhaps even a blueprint to guide this development.

Some changes have already taken place aimed at improving the effectiveness and flexibility of policy and funding advisory bodies. The Australian Marine Sciences and Technologies Advisory Committee which was established as a standing committee of ASTEC now reports directly to the Minister for Science and Technology, while special funding for marine science and technology projects have been co-ordinated by amalgamating the Funding Advisory Panel of AMSTAC with the Queen's Fellowship in Marine Science Committee.

The Government believes that AMSTAC has functioned to good effect. AMSTAC's terms of reference provide a broad charter for it to draw information from any source it judges appropriate when developing its advice to Government. In doing this AMSTAC has used a range of mechanisms including workshops, the establishment of specialised working groups, consultation with experts and the wide circulation of discussion papers.

The Senate Committee's report rightly puts great emphasis on the need to co-ordinate advice from the regions and from individual marine science disciplines. We appreciate this need, but believe that the committee structure recommended in the report, while being more elaborate and potentially more costly than present arrangements provides no guarantee of being more effective by gaining access to a wider source of information, of providing a sounder source of advice or of meeting needs more efficiently than is presently achieved by AMSTAC. Indeed, the increased formality of the proposed mechanism might well inhibit the collection of frank and timely advice. In taking note of the Committee's recommendations, however, the Government will consider whether the resources currently available to AMSTAC are adequate. The Government would not wish to inhibit AMSTAC from taking further initiatives in liaison, consultation and co-ordination to ensure that its advice comprehends views from all relevant sources. AMSTAC is giving increased attention to canvassing the views of the users of marine science data and information, as well as research workers and administrators in various regions and disciplines.

We have given particular attention to the Committee's recommendations concerning the establishment of a Ship Operations Unit. Research vessels are costly to acquire and operate. They should be utilised as fully as possible, subject, of course, to the necessary considerations of scientific and cost effectiveness. Since the proposed CSIRO oceanographic vessel alone has been designated as a national facility up to the present and we do not, therefore, consider it necessary to establish a Ship Operations Unit. In reaching this decision we have noted that overseas experience indicates that research vessels are best managed by their respective major user. However, the Government supports the view that user committees be established by organisations managing a research vessel designated as a national facility.

The Senate Committee has recommended that a centralised Information Services Unit be established. We fully support the view that a marine science program can be effective only to the extent that the data and information it produces are made available to those who need them. However the Government does not believe that centralisation at this time provides the most effective solution. As a first step towards improving the management of marine science information the Department of Science and technology is compiling an inventory of marine science data banks and a directory of current marine research projects. Working Groups of AMSTAC are also examining aspects of this general problem in greater detail.

One very important aspect of marine science information services identified by the Senate Committee relates to the need for basic oceanographic data on tides, currents, wave climates surges, etc. Such data are required by all agencies involved in the use and management of the sea and its resources. The general lack of such data is a matter of considerable concern which the Minister for Science and Technology has under detailed consideration at the present time.

I would like also to mention those recommendations which advocate that certain fields of research should receive increased priority and funding in the context of a national marine science program. Some of these fields concern research directed towards solving practical problems, such as marine pollution. Others highlight the need to develop a more profound understanding of fundamental marine processes and to collect routine oceanographic data to support activities such as the management of marine resources, design of coastal engineering works and the conservation of the marine environment. These recommendations are welcomed and are consistent with the Government's views. Indeed, the allocation of marine sciences and techologies grants for 1981-82 is evidence of that consistency. But I would emphasise that priority areas will also be strengthened by the other Government actions I have mentioned earlier and by those initiatives detailed in the document I have tabled.
In summary, the Government welcomes the Senate Committee's report as a most useful contribution to the continuing development of policies for marine science.

The Report will remain a useful reference document, of value not only to the Government but also the the marine science community. The Government will continue to take into account the Report's recommendations and to assess their appliability to meeting the emerging needs of Australian marine science as it continues to develop and new actions and initiatives by the Government are seen to be required.
Government Response to Recommendations

Recommendation 1-An Australian Marine Science Council be established. This Council would: operate as the national adviser on marine science matters, especially in the areas of policy development; co-ordinate marine science research efforts; liaise with similar bodies overseas; and finance marine science research projects.
Response-The Government considers that a Marine Science Council as proposed by the Senate Committee is not appropriate at this time.

Recent initiatives of the Government have demonstrated its strong commitment to develop a worthwhile, effective and cohesive marine science program. Support has been given to the relocation of the headquarters of CSIRO's marine research facilities in new laboratories in Hobart and to the acquisition by CSIRO of a specialised oceanographic research ship to be operated as a national facility. The Antarctic Division of the Department of Science and Technology has been transferred to new facilities in Kingston, Tasmania, and is being developed as a centre of excellence in Southern Ocean marine biology. The Australian Maritime College in Launceston was established by Commonwealth legislation in 1978 to provide for maritime and maritime related education and training for the shipping, fishing and allied industries. Substantial new resources have been directed to increasing our knowledge of the Australian Fishing Zone and a large part of this assistance is being channelled through CSIRO's Division of Fisheries Research. The Australian Institute of Marine Science has had its staffing levels increased and is endeavouring to establish for itself a major scientific reputation as a centre of tropical marine research. The new structure of the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics will include a Division of Marine Geosciences and Petroleum Geology; funds have been allocated for the Bureau to undertake a major geophysical survey of Bass Basin. Additional resources have been provided for the work of the Navy Hydrographer and the Division of National Mapping to accelerate the charting of Australia's marine areas. These operational developments have been supported by the development of policy advisory mechanisms. Special funding has been provided for marine science and technology projects for allocation on the advice of the Funding Advisory Panel of the Australian Marine Sciences and Technologies Advisory Committee. For greater flexibility this panel has now been amalgamated with the Queens's Fellowships in Marine Science Committee. As a result of the recent Review of Commonwealth Functions AMSTAC now reports to the Minister for Science and Technology. This has served to consolidate marine sciences and technologies advisory and funding functions within a single Ministry that has also an operational role.

These arrangements are the result of recent initiatives designed to cope with the present and near-future level of marine science activity. The considerable cost and disruption that would be involved in setting up a Marine Science Council are not justified at the present stage of development of Australian marine science. Acceptance of these recommendations would also be contrary to the Government's policy of financial restraint and its concern to reduce the number of statutory bodies. Existing institutional arrangements, including AMSTAC exercising a co-ordinating role and providing advice on marine sciences programs and priorities, are considered adequate for meeting present needs. The Government believes that AMSTAC already has functioned to good effect and with continuing support will become even more effective. The organisational model and concept proposed in this and related recommendations, though inappropriate at present, may have a place at some future time as Australia's marine science effort evolves.

Recommendation 2-The Australian Marine Science Council co-ordinates research efforts through Regional and Marine Sciences Committees and an Advisory Committee. The Council, through its Executive and Secretariat, would be responsible for operating an Information Services Unit and a Ship Operations Unit. The Council would also manage the two proposed Research Institutes, presently operating as the Australian Institute of Marine Science and the CSIRO Divisions of Fisheries Research and Oceanography.
Response-See Response to Recommendations 1 and 15.

Recommendation 3-The Australian Institute of Marine Science Act 1972 be repealed and replaced with an Australian Marine Science Act. This Act would contain such provisions as are necessary to enable the Australian Marine Science Council to fulfil its proposed functions.
Response-See comment on Recommendation 1. The Government does not consider these legislative changes are necessary.

Recommendation 4-A Marine Science Research Endowment Bill be enacted to establish a Marine Science Research and Development Fund. The Australian Marine Science Council would be responsible for advising the Minister for Science and Technology on the administration of the Fund.

Response-Not accepted. The Government does not believe that the establishment of a Marine Science Research and Development Fund would offer any advantage over existing funding mechanisms. Such a Fund would account for only part of the Commonwealth's total expenditure on marine science research. It could not comprehend Tertiary Education Commission and Australian Research Grants Committee funding of marine science for example, and would have no effect on State or private sector funding activities. The Government considers that a plurality of funding mechanisms helps to maintain a proper balance of funding availability between research, development and routine monitoring. In certain circumstances amalgamation of funding sources may be desirable to increase the flexibility of funding. For this reason AMSTAC-FAP and Queen's Fellowships in marine science have already been amalgamated. Co-ordination between Commonwealth funding agencies already occurs, and ensures that proposals are transferred to the most appropriate agency.
Recommendation 5-A small Secretariat be made available by the Department of Science and Technology to provide administrative support for the Council.
Response-See comment on Recommendation 1. The Department of Science and Technology provides secretariat support for AMSTAC.
Recommendation 6-Four marine science regions be identified. These regions would be based on northern, eastern, southern and western waters.
Response-See response to Recommendation 8.
Recommendation 7-Four Regional Committees be established, comprising representatives for all major marine science agencies in each region.

The Committee recognises that two streams of committees will be necessary: one stream to co-ordinate and advise on a regional basis; and the other stream to deal with special disciplines in marine science. Recommendations 8-12 refer to these committees.
Response-See response to Recommendation 8.

Recommendation 8-The role of the Regional Committees be: to co-ordinate research activities within the region, to the extent of advising the Council of any overlap; to provide a means of encouraging co-operation and liaison between researchers and agencies in that region; to ensure that individuals or organisations seeking finance for marine science have access to the financing process; to advise the Council of areas of research, or research projects, which they consider are worthy of support, and to generally represent the region's interest.

Response-The Government recognises the need for the co-ordination of regional advice but believes that the Committee's proposed regions are not an adequate reflection of the scale, complexity and natural regionalisation of Australia's continental margin, of the very different priorities attached to the scientific study of particular regions (such as the Barrier Reef, Bass Strait and the North-West Shelf) or of the location of existing and proposed facilities around the Australian coast. The proposed Committee structure would be unduly cumbersome and expensive. AMSTAC's terms of reference provide a sufficiently broad charter for it to obtain necessary information from regional, sectoral and disciplinary sources when developing its advice to Government. AMSTAC is expected to give increasing consideration to specific regional research needs and priorities. Already AMSTAC is moving to cultivate closer links with regional organisations such as the Antarctic Research Policy Advisory Committee, the various committees concerned with the Great Barrier Reef, regional committees of the Australian Fisheries Council, the Victorian Institute of Marine Sciences and other state-oriented marine science agencies.

Recommendation 9-Appropriate Marine Sciences Committees be established. These Committees would include the interests of the following areas: marine biology; fisheries research and technology; marine geosciences; oceanography; marine taxonomy; coastal and ocean engineering; and marine environmental studies.
Response-See comment on Recommendation 10.

Recommendation 10-The role of the Marine Sciences Committees be: to co-ordinate research activities undertaken in their field and to reduce unnecessary duplication of research; to operate as an information source to researchers by providing resumes of current research being undertaken in the field; to encourage joint research projects across agencies and regions; to ensure that individuals or organisations seeking finance for marine science research have access to the financing process; to advise the Council of areas of research, or research projects, which they consider are worthy of support; and to generally represent the discipline's interests.

Response-See comment on Recommendations 1, 6, 7 and 8. The Government believes that co-ordination of research activities is best achieved by ensuring that operating agencies receive effective support for scientific collaboration and for encouraging and facilitating contacts between working scientists through the promotion of conferences and workshops, and the dissemination of information. Inadequate co-ordination and collaboration arise as often at the interdisciplinary level as within specific disciplines. AMSTAC will continue to establish specific-purpose working parties to undertake major investigations in the course of which advice and information is sought from non-government disciplinary organisations such as the National Committee on Coastal and Ocean Engineering (of the Australian Institution of Engineers), the Australian Marine Sciences Association, and the Consortium for Ocean Geosciences of Australian Universities. AMSTAC is conscious of the need to identify, and to seek information from those organisations which utilise the results of marine science as well as those carrying out research.

Recommendation 11-One broadly based Advisory Committee be established to advise the Council on program planning and evaluation, education and training, and the conferring of fellowships, scholarships and project and program grants.

Response-See comment on Recommendations 1 and 2. Advice on marine sciences and technologies programs is provided to the Minister for Science and Technology by AMSTAC. The amalgamated AMSTAC-FAP and Queen's Fellowships in Marine Science Committee advises the Minister on the conferring of fellowships and on project and program grants in the context of priorities set by the Minister on advice from AMSTAC. Responsibility for advising the Government on the level and pattern of provision of tertiary education lies with the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission.

Recommendation 12-The CSIRO cease to conduct marine science research, and the Divisions of Fisheries Research and Oceanography become a separate Research Institute. This Research Institute, together with the Australian Institute of Marine Science, would become Research Institutes responsible to the Australian Marine Science Council.
Response-See comment on Recommendation 13.

Recommendation 13-Each Institute would have its own Board, to which the Director of the Institute, subject to Council policy, would be responsible for the management and operations of the Institute. The research programs would be approved annually by the Council and would be financed by the Marine Science Research and Development Fund. The Council would direct the Institutes to develop independent programmes to avoid unnecessary duplication.

Response-Not accepted. See response to Recommendation 1. CSIRO has a responsibility to continue to play a major role in Australian marine science in accordance with Science and Industry Research Act 1949 as amended in 1978, following the Government's acceptance of the report of the Independent Committee of Inquiry into CSIRO. The Executive of CSIRO has given marine research a high priority. The Government believes that removing the marine science divisions from CSIRO would, without providing any compensating benefits, break existing links which facilitate interdisciplinary consultations and a multidisciplinary approach especially to problems which bear on both the terrestrial and marine environments. With CSIRO the marine science divisions interact on the widest possible range of skills and resources and utilise the capabilities of various scientific disciplines to meet changing objectives. The Government has previously accepted the recommendations of ASTEC that the future long-term role of AIMS (5 years ahead and more) be determined by the situation at that time, including the reputation and capabilities of AIMS and of other institutions, as they evolve and that for the foreseeable future AIMS should direct its research towards programs associated with the tropical waters of Australia, particularly, the Great Barrier Reef Region, and chiefly in appropriate marine biological/ecological fields.
Recommendation 14-In view of the importance of the dissemination of information the Australian Marine Science Council becomes a user of the CSIRONET computing service.
Response-CSIRONET is a commercially available computing service and its facilities are available to whoever needs them. Several marine science data banks are already stored on CSIRONET.
Recommendation 15-The Council establish an Information Services Unit to service the information needs of the organisation and researchers and agencies concerned with marine science.

Response-The Government recognises that the effective management of information is a key element in a national marine science program and believes that it is of prime importance that the transfer of information and data are readily available to those who have a need for them. However, it believes that a strongly centralised information services unit is not practicable. Data and information are best managed by those with prime responsibility for collection and with the necessary expertise to analyse them. A basic need in information management is to have a readily available central registry of what data and information are available and where they can be obtained. To this end the Department of Science and Technology is currently compiling an inventory of marine science data banks and a directory of current research projects. In addition, a research officer is being funded through the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account to investigate the fishing industry's need for scientific information and how to develop better mechanisms for distributing this information.
Recommendation 16-The Council establish a Ship Operations Unit to co-ordinate the operational management of marine science research vessels.
Response-See comment on Recommendation 18.

Recommendation 17-The Ship Operations Unit be responsible for co-ordinating information concerning available ship time on Australian and overseas vessels in Australian waters. The Unit would administer a fund to enable scientists to take up ship time opportunities at very short notice.
Response-See comment on Recommendation 18.

Recommendation 18-The Ship Operations Unit establish a Users Committee, comprising representatives of the various disciplines which require access to research vessels. The Users Committee would be an integral part of the Ship Operations Unit.

Response-The Government accepts that research vessels need to be utilised to their maximum extent possible subject to necessary considerations of scientific and cost effectiveness and that a mechanism is needed to co-ordinate the use of available ship time. However, it does not consider that a centralised system of control is required at this time and believes that research vessels, including those acquired as national facilities, should be managed by major operational agencies. The Government has already accepted ASTEC advice that organisations managing a research vessel designated as a national facility should appoint a committee, comprising representatives of major users of the vessel, to provide advice on the allocation of vessel time.

Recommendation 19-Marine science research vessels purchased, or chartered, as national facilities be managed for the most part by experienced marine contractors and that these contractors form part of the Ship Operations Unit. Such contractors would liaise closely with the Users Committee to ensure compatibility in decision making.

Response-In response to the report of the Review of Commonwealth Government Functions, the Government has decided that there should be further contracting of its services to the private sector where practicable. In this regard the need is recognised for maximum scientific and cost effectiveness in the use of research vessels. Accordingly the Government will consider in particular cases whether the best results would be achieved through management by marine contractors or through Government operation. In all cases close liaison between operators and users is essential.
Recommendation 20-Wherever possible all marine science research vessels be chartered, and experienced marine contractors consulted in identifying research vessels suitable for charter or purchase.

Response-The practice of chartering research vessels is well established in Australia. If a vessel is required for a definite and short-term project, chartering may provide the necessary flexibility if a suitable vessel exists, is available, and can be used to full capacity during the charter period. However the Government believes that, where there is a continuing need, or where a long-term project is envisaged, purchase may be cheaper than chartering. All relevant sources of advice are used in identifying vessels suitable for charter or purchase.
Recommendation 21-Encouragement be given to developing modular research vessels.

Response-Most research vessels constructed recently have some provision for interchanging laboratories but overseas' experience has shown that fully modular research vessels have not proved generally effective. It is the view of the Government that users should be uninhibited in selection of vessels designed to meet particular needs.
Recommendation 22-The Ship Operations Unit fully consider the acquisition of small research vessels for use by bodies such as universities, colleges and museums.
Response-The acquisition of small research vessels is a matter for the individual institutions concerned.

Recommendation 23-AMSTAC and ASTEC oversee the establishment of the Australian Marine Science Council. Thereafter, AMSTAC and its Funding Advisory Panel would no longer exist, as the Advisory Committee would assume the responsibilities of AMSTAC.
Response-See comment on Recommendation 1.

Recommendation 24-A marine science policy be developed incorporating such aspects as: the types of research to be financed; and mechanisms for the selection, financing and effectiveness of research as well as the exploitation of research results.
Response-See comment on Recommendation 1.

Recommendation 25-All possible avenues be explored to acquire a complete bathymetric and hydrographic survey of the Australian coast as rapidly as possible. These measures could include financial assistance to the Royal Australian Navy Hydrographer, The Australian Survey Office, the Division of National Mapping and private contractors.

Response-The Government accepts the importance of having a complete bathymetric and hydrographic survey of the Australian coast. It has recently committed the ''Cape Pillar'' for additional bathymetric work, at least until the end of 1982. The Division of National Mapping of the Department of National Development and Energy has been allocated additional funds of $1.5 million in 1981-82 for that purpose.

Recommendation 26-Funding of physical and chemical oceanography be increased, particularly in determining an understanding of the tides, waves and circulation patterns of the continental shelf. Priority should be given to processing this information such that it can be widely made known to other marine scientists.

Response-Accepted. The Government decided in 1980 to establish CSIRO Marine Science Laboratories at Hobart to be supported by an oceanographic research vessel. The Government notes that CSIRO attaches high priority and commitment to marine sciences and especially oceanography, and inter alia is reallocating staff and resources to this end. The need for routine collection and distribution of oceanographic data is being considered and proposals aimed at meeting this need are being developed.
Recommendation 27-The Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 be amended so as to reduce the period for the release of information from five years to twelve months.

Response-Not accepted. The Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 was extensively amended in 1980 following consultation with all State Governments. Amendment of the relevant provision (Section 118) was considered at that time, but it was decided that no changes would be made to this provision.

Recommendation 28-Priorities for coastal and ocean engineering in the protection of our foreshores and the development of our mineral resources be better recognised. Emphasis should be given to the provision of tanks and basins for the simulation of wave, current and wind impact on structures and the sediment bed.
Response-This recommendation is in accord with advice received from ASTEC/AMSTAC and is being considered in detail by a working group of AMSTAC.

Recommendation 29-The adoption of a national code to provide a development-free zone of approximately 1 km from the shoreline for those areas of the Australian coast which have not yet been developed and where there is any risk of shoreline erosion or instability.

Response-Although the Commonwealth has constitutional power with respect to maritime areas beyond low water mark adjacent to the States, under the offshore constitutional settlement each State is to have the same power with respect to the adjacent territorial sea (including the sea bed) as it would have if the waters were within the limit of the State. The establishment of such a zone would, therefore, be mainly a matter for the States, subject to any Commonwealth legislation. The matter will be taken up with them in accordance with the Commonwealth Government's decisions on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment and Conservation Report on Management of the Coastal Zone which is being considered by the State Governments.

Recommendation 30-A blue-water research vessel be acquired, or a modular laboratory be developed for, the marine geosciences, and that Australia seriously consider participating in the forthcoming Ocean Margins Drilling Programme. Priority should be given to upgrading the services provided by the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics.

Response-The matters raised in this recommendation have also been foreshadowed as important issues for future action by AMSTAC in its report ''Towards a Marine Sciences and Technologies Program for the 1980's''. Participation in the Ocean Margins Drilling Program is not considered warranted. However the Government is expecting to receive shortly a proposal from Australian marine geoscientists concerning participation by Australia in the second phase of the International Program of Ocean Drilling. In the reorganisation of the Bureau of Mineral Resources, Geology and Geophysics, the Public Service Board has agreed to the formation of a Division of Marine Geosciences and Petroleum Geology. This Division will undertake regional offshore geological and geophysical investigations and analyse and integrate offshore petroleum exploration data.
Recommendation 31-Priority be given to studying the biology of marine micro-organisms, plankton and the fish resources of the 200 n.m. zone.
Response-Accepted. The Government has already significantly strengthened CSIRO's capacity to undertake research related to the resources of the Australian Fishing Zone.
Recommendation 32-Increased finance be provided for marine taxonomy and for the upgrading of museum facilities.
Response-The Government accepts the importance of marine taxonomy to Australian marine science and notes that AMSTAC-FAP has supported projects in this field.

Recommendation 33-Priority be given to research into the distribution, allowable yields and management of current and potential fisheries. To foster such research, greater liaison between government and industry should be developed.

Response-Accepted. The Department of Primary Industry has established a comprehensive system for collecting catch and effort data from foreign vessels operating in Australian waters as a basis for research and the development and management of the Australian Fishing Zone. An extensive feasibility fishing program has been carried out by means of foreign and Australian commercial partnerships. The results of both these programs are available to industry. The Australian Fishing Council has established the Australian Fishing Zone Committee, a government/industry committee which reports to it annually on the interrelations of foreign and Australian fishing in the AFZ. The reports of the Committee are published. Additionally, there is extensive consultation with industry when foreign operations are approved and during the development of fishery management and development regimes. Industry is represented on the Fishing Industry Research Committee which advises the Minister for Primary Industry on expenditure of funds from the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account.
Recommendation 34-The possible over-exploitation of the North West Shelf by foreign fishing ventures be immediately examined, and if necessary, rectified.

Response-See comment on Recommendation 33. There are serious deficiencies in the knowledge and understanding of the functioning and appropriate management of tropical, multi-species, trawl fisheries. Examination of the basis of this recommendation must await further development of our understanding. The CSIRO Division of Fisheries Research is examining a proposal for research of this type. In the meantime, however, the exploitation of the North West Shelf is being managed on a very conservative basis.

Recommendation 35-Priority be given to researching the effects of oil spills, waste disposal and effluent on the marine environment, especially on coral reefs. This research should include the development of a marine pollution monitoring system.
Response-Accepted. The Government notes that a number of research programs are underway which are relevant to this recommendation.

Recommendation 36-Attention be paid to the impact of tourism on the Great Barrier Reef. The possibility of developing an extensive underwater viewing gallery should be explored as a means of reducing this impact whilst at the same time promoting tourist interest.

Response-Accepted. The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority has this matter under investigation. The development of proposed tourist facilities on the Great Barrier Reef and adjacent coast is being considered so as to increase opportunities for the public to experience the Reef environment, while at the same time minimising human impact on it.

Recommendation 37-The declaration of the 200 n.m. Australian Fishing Zone should be accompanied by research into the fauna of this zone, especially mammals, and how they can be adequately protected from the over-exploitation of their foodstocks.

Response-See comment on Recommendation 31. The Fisheries Act obliges the Minister for Primary Industry to take account of the effects of fishing on cetaceans. Recent government actions on whaling have demonstrated the Government's commitment to conservation of marine mammals.
Recommendation 38-The development of appropriate technology for the marine sciences be encouraged, especially in relation to remote sensing and fisheries technology.

Response-Accepted. This recommendation is consistent with the Government's policy of a balanced development of Australian marine science. Development and utilisation of advanced technology already is part of marine science activities. For example, the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account has funded a CSIRO/West Australian Institute of Technology study on the applications of remote sensing to fisheries. The Australian Maritime College is also involved in developing appropriate technology. The College's School of Fisheries provides training in the application of modern fishing techniques. There is an ongoing defence program of design studies for industrial production of the Laser Airborne Depth Sounder which can greatly increase the rate of collection of data from coastal waters shallower than 50 metres. Both CSIRO and AIMS regularly use remote sensing techniques in their research.

Recommendation 39-The Australian Marine Science Council provide finance for the operation of facilities at the island research stations. Programs conducted at these stations would be the responsibility of the Consortium of Island Research Stations.

Response-The Government is aware of the important contribution made by the island research stations to marine research in the Great Barrier Reef and notes that parent institutions of island research stations are eligible to apply for funding support through marine research and development grants.
Recommendation 40-The marine science laboratories at Cronulla be retained as research and training facilities for marine scientists in the Sydney region, especially for university-based scientists.

Response-CSIRO will have no need for a residual presence at Cronulla when the proposed Marine Science Laboratories are constructed in Hobart. The Government has noted this recommendation and will take it into account when consideration is given to the future of the Cronulla facilities.

Recommendation 41-Support be given to increase the number of graduates in the marine sciences whose initial degrees are based on the pure sciences. Emphasis should also be given to the provision of courses in resource management and marine technologies.

Response-The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission is responsible for advising the Government on the level and pattern of provision in tertiary education. The Commission's planning for the 1982-84 Triennium has been based, among other things, on there being no increase in student numbers in universities during that period. This is consistent with the findings of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training. The Government's policy is that, in expensive and highly specialised fields of study, decisions on the number of places to be made available will be influenced primarily by manpower considerations. The Government acknowledges however that an improvement in the quality and comprehensiveness of labour market information is a prerequisite for any significant advances in the use of manpower consideration in educational planning. AMSTAC will review the adequacy of trained manpower in the marine sciences.

With regard to the provision of courses, the Australian Maritime College currently offers a number of relevant undergraduate courses and is planning to introduce post-graduate courses in hydrographic surveying and fisheries technology. The college also provides short, specialist, non-award courses to meet the needs of maritime industries.

The Government has currently under consideration a suggestion that the proposal for a National School of Fisheries be examined further with a view to its development in the 1985-87 Triennium. It is recognised that such a school would complement the role of the Australian Maritime College with regard to fishing and related activities.

Recommendation 42-The number of Queen's Fellowships be increased both to give young Australians an opportunity to continue their research in this country or overseas, and to attract researchers from overseas on a short-term basis.

Response-The recent amalgamation of the Queen's Fellowships in Marine Science committee with the AMSTAC-Funding Advisory Panel enables an appropriate balance between fellowships and project grants to be reached year to year.
Recommendation 43-Post-graduate scholarships be made available in the marine sciences and technologies, to be tenable in Australia and overseas.

Response-The number of new Post-graduate Awards provided by the Commonwealth Government has been increased from 700 in 1980 to 800 in 1981. This increase was in response to the recommendations of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education and Training. It has not been policy under the Post-graduate Award Scheme to allocate Awards to particular areas of study. Traditionally the Awards have been available in open competition on the basis of academic merit to people in all disciplines.

Recommendation 44-The Australian Marine Science Council finance marine science in this country through the mechanism of the Marine Science Research and Development Fund. Research directed towards national priorities would be financed through project and program grants, scholarships and fellowships. This Fund would also finance the Ship Operations Unit, the Information Services Unit and the operations of the Research Institutes and the island research stations. Financial support for research conducted at these, and all other facilities, would be subject to successful application for grants, scholarships and fellowships.
Response-See response to Recommendation 4.

Recommendation 45-Adequate levies be placed on industries exploiting resources in the 200 n.m. zone, especially foreign-owned fishing ventures and oil and gas industries. The revenue derived from these levies should assist in the financing of marine science research, and in the provision of inspectors and scientific observers on foreign fishing vessels.
Response-The hypothecation of general Government revenue derived from fishing and offshore crude oil production to specific Government expenditure is contrary to general Government budgetary policy.

(iii) in such event, the President or the Deputy-President shall lay any such report upon the Table at the next sitting of the Senate.
(2) That the foregoing provisions of this resolution, so far as they are inconsistent with the Standing Orders, shall have effect notwithstanding anything contained in the Standing Orders.

I have moved this motion to enable the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations to submit reports to the President during the period when the Senate is in recess. They will then have the status of being tabled reports.

TALK.START.PARA: — I rise to express my objection to the fact that the motion proposed by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) involves a considerable amount of queue jumping in the area of notices of motion. I have no objection to any of those matters which have already been the subject of a second reading debate in this chamber or which were introduced in this chamber being brought forward. Those matters include all items set out in the motion except Notices of Motion Nos. 70, 66, 58, 67, 62 and 63. My question is: Why does the Government propose to allow these items to jump the queue ahead of other notices of motion which other senators, including me, have placed on the Notice Paper? I was not consulted in any shape or form as to whether I agreed to the jumping-up of those notices of motion over other notices of motion. I say quite frankly that I am not prepared to vote in any shape or form for those notices of motion if there is not prior consultation about their being brought forward. There are other measures by which I can display my displeasure in regard to this matter. I do not care whether the Senate meets tomorrow or next week.
—You're not usually here anyway.

—I am usually here all right. I am here more often than Senator Walsh is. He was caught out last night accusing the Government, the Australian Democrats and me of supporting tax dodgers when all we were doing was supporting what the Australian Labor Party policy spokesman on primary industry had been saying. That shows how much people believe what Senator Walsh says. Getting back to the Bill before the chamber, there are other proposals. It will take the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) a long time to read his statement if he is not granted leave to have it incorporated in Hansard, and other measures can be adopted. I make it perfectly clear that once a notice of motion is placed before the Senate it becomes the business of the Senate. Also, if back door arrangements are made between the Australian Labor Party, the Government and the Democrats, leaving aside the rights of individual senators, so be it, but the Senate cannot expect my support for any of those motions if they come before the Senate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a point in what Senate Harradine has said about these matters, but it is of course inevitable in the operations of the Senate in the last hours of a sitting that arrangements will increasingly be made between the Whips of the major parties. Let me say for my part in relation to the issues to which Senator Harradine has referred, that is, the notices of motion, that I had sought to advise him by letter that those notices of motion were coming on. However, that is not true in respect of the items set out on the last page of the red sheet, the two items from the Australian Democrats relating to a discussion on liquor advertising and a liquor education fund.
—And a Labor Party Bill on sex discrimination. Let's be accurate about what is on the last page of the red sheet.
—I am not criticising; if Senator Mason would not be so touchy--
—I am not touchy. I just want to be accurate.

—I am not criticising the Australian Democrats. If you would let me finish what I was about to say, in relation to those two Bills, for example, like Senator Harradine, I did not know until I saw the red sheet this morning that those two notices of motion were going to be on the Notice Paper today. It is quite likely that Senator Mason did not know that the Sex Discrimination Bill was going to be on the Notice Paper today.
—Perfectly correct.

—What in essence I am trying to say is that we are all in something of a mushroom club in relation to these matters which appear on the third page of the red sheet. Senator Harradine, with respect, is in no different situation from many other senators in relation to those matters. Insofar as the matters which appear on the second last page of the red sheet are concerned, I cannot speak about the matter of closed ciruit monitoring other than to say that it is a matter which has already been discussed in this chamber. As to the matter relating to the establishment of a select committee on the electoral system, this is a matter of which Senator Harradine was advised. I suspect that the matter relating to East Timor is one of which Senator Harradine was not advised. I apologise if I am remiss in any way in relation to that matter. All I am saying is that I think many individual senators are in the situation Senator Harradine is in. We want to deal with these matters during this sitting. I hope that Senator Harradine understands that he is not alone in respect of the issues he has raised.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The major provisions of the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1981, which I will enumerate, are to tighten the confidentiality sections of the principal Act to ensure that information relating to personal activities cannot be released; to allow for the release of information relating to the activities of an organisation where there is good reason to do so; and to increase penalties on officers or past officers of the Australian Bureau of Statistics for unauthorised disclosure of information from $1,000 or 12 months imprisonment to $5,000 or two years imprisonment, or both. The Bill also removes the penalty of imprisonment on persons giving false information to the ABS, which was a matter of some discussion and indeed of some amendment when an earlier Census and Statistics Amendment Bill related to the Australian Bureau of Statistics passed through the Senate in May of this year. I might add that the current penalty imposed on officers of the ABS for disclosing information without authorisation was introduced in May of this year.

SPEECH.PARA: We have two specific amendments in this Bill amending decisions made by the Government only six months ago. This supplements and reinforces the comments made by Senator Button in the matter of public importance and the comments he quoted from Mr Carnegie that one of the great problems of this Government is that it keeps changing the rules. These are relatively unimportant matters, but they are symptomatic of a very serious deficiency of this Government that it cannot seem to make any decision and stick to it, or it makes a bewildering number of changes. For example, in the last 15 months it has, on no less than four occasions, changed the depreciation rates for tax purposes on capital equipment. Senator Martyr said earlier today that the changes the Government makes are in recognition of past errors. The Government has seen the error of its ways. If that was really what was happening, I suppose we should be grateful. I think we are entitled to expect that occasionally the Government might see its errors before it actually enacts them. It might have seen the errors of the assortment of tax rorts that we have seen come straight off the top of the head of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) over the last 18 months. The Government has them under review now. It will almost certainly remove some of them within the next 12 months. Is this Government incapable of recognising error at the time it is commiting error? If other people can recognise its errors, is it so crass that it never can?

I will make some brief general comments about the Australian Bureau of Statistics concerning the imposition of staff ceilings by the Government and the steady erosion of the scope of the Bureau's statistical collection and processing activities. These have very serious long term implications for economic planning not only by the Government, but also by private industry. In determining what is just or equitable policy, the restrictions placed upon the Bureau are equally serious. For example, nobody who is seriously interested in the study of income distribution in determining the effects of particular policy changes on income distribution-on whether changes are progressive or regressive-can do without the Bureau's household expenditure surveys. The last expenditure surveys were taken in 1974-75. I have been informed that it was planned that another survey would be taken in 1983, an interval of almost 10 years. I am now given reason to believe that that may even be cancelled or further deferred. It would be bad enough if the interval between these household surveys was nine or 10 years. If the next survey is to be deferred even longer, it ought to be quite unacceptable. There is a wealth of information in those household expenditure surveys for people who are interested in income distribution and, in particular, for people who are interested in a more progressive income distribution. I know that that excludes probably the majority of the people in the Senate, but the information is now seven years old and inevitably it is becoming obsolete and increasingly unreliable. But the Government, in pursuit of its ideological objectives, without even pausing to consider whether they are rational or not, insists on imposing staff ceilings on the ABS and reducing the scope of its data collection and analysis. In some instances there are crude political reasons for doing so. The Government does not want the public to be informed. Apart from having an ideological objection it has a very pragmatic political objection to the public being accurately informed by the Bureau about matters which are embarrassing to it.

The Opposition is supporting this Bill. Once again it makes a plea to the Government to reconsider its whole attitude towards the Australian Bureau of Statistics and to attempt to restore the organisation at least to the level of efficiency at which it once functioned. The information that the Bureau could provide is really indispensible not only to people who are interested in equity questions but also to the efficient operation of both the private and the public sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to see the provision in the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill amending the Census and Statistics Act so that no longer will Australians who fill in forms incorrectly be liable to six months in gaol. That provision was put into the Act on 13 May, six months ago, when the composition of the Senate was different from what it is now. At that time I moved an amendment, the effect of which would have been to remove that six months gaol term which, to my knowledge, was the first time in Australian peacetime history that a citizen would be liable to be gaoled for the way he or she filled in a form.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party supported that amendment, and to his great credit, so did Senator Michael Townley of the Liberal Party. But six months ago the Government used its numbers in the Senate to defeat the amendment and maintain the penal sanction. There was considerable public reaction over the matter and I undertook that when the Australian Democrats numbers were greater in the Senate I would bring forward a private member's Bill to correct the matter. On 10 June I gave notice of my intention to bring in that Bill which was then prepared and printed. Earlier this session I notified the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) as a courtesy that the following week I would bring that private member's Bill forward and that I believed it had the numbers to pass the Senate. I was then notified that the Government itself had accepted the measure and was incorporating the provision in this legislation now before us which has, of course, since passed through the House of Representatives under the auspices of the Treasurer, Mr Howard.

Once this Bill has passed the Senate it will have removed a dangerous totalitarian-type precedent from the law. Naturally the Australian Democrats indicate their support for it. The Australian Democrats also give the Government the fullest possible credit for its flexibility and wisdom in bringing through this matter, even though originally it was a Democrat initiative. There should be no accusations of backing down or weakness but only of a proper and statesmanlike recognition of what is right and what is wrong. I say that of the Government with all possible sincerity.

This is a bridge that the Government has crossed. It has conceded that in no way does it diminish its prestige or strength by the principle of accepting a Democrat initiative and bringing it into law. That is a very important bridge, and crossing it could have important implications for the future. It exhibits a wiser and much more democratic view of the undertakings of this House and the other place than that expressed in some thoughtless areas of the Government where members cry out for double dissolution elections and political crises whenever the will of the Executive is thwarted in the smallest possible way and threaten, as Senator Carrick said on the media two days ago, to have triggers and section 57 Bills 'as a warning to those who seek to frustrate'. The Australian Democrats perceive themselves as a target for that remark, but the remark is completely unjustified as indeed what has happened with the Census and Statistics Bill indicates.

We do not seek to frustrate. It is a fact that the Government's legislative program has been able to proceed substantially in a normal way during this session of parliament. Its major taxing and Supply Bills have been respected. That has been a matter of deliberate policy on our part. But it does not mean that we should lie down under the bed and never bring forward to this place any measures which might be in the least different from the Government's measures. I believe that the Bill before us now indicates a degree of flexibility in the Government that bids fair for the future. I trust that the Government will bring the enlightened view it has shown about this measure, concerning the gaoling of citizens over census forms, to other matters that have recently engaged the attention of the Senate. The decision to gaol citizens over the census papers was quickly shown as being unpopular in the community and, as a result, the Government has decided to change it. All credit to it, I say again. But I remind the Government that there is another equally unpopular measure which it ought to change in its own interests and in the interests of the community as soon as it can. I commend that action to the Government along exactly the same lines. I refer to the iniquitous and notorious application of sales tax to children's school shoes, clothing, the means of information-books, magazines and newspapers-and the building materials for new houses. Those are the necessities of life.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Mason, I do not think that what you are saying relates to the Bill before the Senate but I admire your political skill.

—Thank you very much, Mr Acting Deputy President. My own feeling is that it is a parallel situation which I am bringing to the attention of the Government but I accept your ruling. Like the decision on the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill, such a decision relating to the sales tax Bills would be perceived as wise, statesmanlike and altogether to the credit of the Government. That is how the decision on the gaol terms and the census forms ought to be perceived. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too admire Senator Mason for his skill in bringing forward his argument about sales tax. I am glad that you were able to lower the boom on him appropriately, Mr Acting Deputy President. It is true that the Government was impressed with the arguments of Senator Mason last May but I think that one or two points need clarification. Firstly, as was argued in the debate last May, the amendment set out in the Bill at that time imposing the penalty of a gaol term on those who provided false information-I hope Senator Mason will acknowledge this- was to apply only in those cases where there was a deliberate intent to provide misleading or false information. I make that clear to all parts of the Senate. It was not an attempt to impose such a draconian penalty on those who might innocently or accidentally provide incorrect information in their census forms.
—I would like to clarify one point. It was a drafting error , was it not?

—As I said, the Government was very impressed with Senator Mason's argument at that time. As Senator Mason said, he gives us credit for having reconsidered the situation. We took his argument into account. Nevertheless, I wanted to make it clear that the penalty applied to deliberate intent to provide false information. That is a significant point when viewing the total argument.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh referred to the household expenditure survey. It is true that the next survey will not be conducted until 1984. It will be recognised that the household expenditure survey presently being utilised for the preparation of the consumer price index series and so on will, by then, be ten years old. However, that is not to say that the Government is ignoring its responsibilities in this regard. As I said, it will be moving to the collection of new information in 1984. I thank honourable senators from all parts of the Senate for their support of the legislation and wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Robertson)-by leave-agreed to:

That consideration of Government Business, Order of the Day No. 2, Defence Acts Amendment Bill 1981, be postponed until after the conclusion of consideration of whatever item of business is before the Senate at 2.15 p.m.

Senator Harradine-Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. One cannot go out of this chamber for the calls of nature without having something slipped into the order of business. Has there been a change in the order of business?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there has been a change in the order of business following the moving of a motion for which leave was sought. The Defence Acts Amendment Bill will now be dealt with after 2.15 p.m.

—by leave-I attempted to discuss this matter with Senator Harradine this morning at the doorway of the chamber. He was not able, because of other matters, to listen to me. This business has been brought on in the normal way.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 November, on motion by Senator Button:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I spoke briefly last night to the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1981 I indicated that the Government, in opposing this measure, was not opposed in total to the concept of union amalgamation-quite the contrary. We believe that it is a very important area of development in industrial relations. Before I address a few remarks to that matter, I will make observations about one or two of the matters raised by Senator Siddons in the chamber last night when he spoke immediately before I spoke. Amongst other things, Senator Siddons said: 'Why are there so few mergers?' That is a reasonable question. Obviously the answer must relate in some measure at least to a lack of enthusiasm amongst trade unionists for that sort of amalgamation.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the honourable senator referred also to the circumstances in the Federal Republic of Germany where, of course, there are only 16 or 18 unions. They are industry-based unions. Of course, it is not easy to compare the circumstances there with the Australian circumstances. Trade unionism in West Germany has grown basically from a nil position after World War II to the position it stands in today. The Germany of Adolf Hitler and the years prior to 1945-46 was a Germany that knew no trade unionism at all. It has had the distinct advantage of developing along lines that are preconceived and planned.

Senator Siddons said further that anything that could be effective in avoiding industrial strife should be sought. Who could disagree with that? Indeed, it would be to everybody's advantage to find a form or measure of amalgamation of trade unions that could aid in avoiding industrial strife. I do not believe that there is a consensus about amalgamations at this stage. I do not believe that there is a circumstance which ensures that industrial strife and action can be avoided by a specific legislative proposal. It has to grow from the basic members of that community which is involved with industrial relations, namely the management and the unionists-the management and the employees.

Senator Siddons mentioned further that unions should decide which unions should amalgamate. That is a pretty reasonable proposition on the surface but, if it were adopted, would it produce an industry-based union? It would not necessarily do so. It may well produce only a great conglomerate of unions without any real relationship, one to the other. One has to ask: Should it be possible for that sort of amalgamation to take place with less than 50 per cent involvement of the unionists concerned? I make a few remarks relevant to this legislation because any legislation that has as its objective the improvement of industrial relations in this country is legislation that needs to be thought about sincerely, clearly and logically. Amalgamation must surely come with a real measure of agreement from the mass of unionists and from the employers. It cannot be successful if it is promoted by only one group.

A solution to the industrial relations problem in Australia is of enourmous importance in a number of fields. It would be directly responsible for Australia's capacity to reach the quite exciting potential that it has for all its citizens, for itself as a nation, and for the contribution it can make as a nation among the nations of the world. Only by a successful and responsible industrial relations situation can that sort of potential be arrived at; only by that sort of relationship can we develop in this country the sort of enthusiasm that our opportunities should be engendering. Productivity and the general affluence of Australian society are directly related to our capacity to solve the problems. Perhaps this legislation seeks to contribute towards a solution. But in the view of the Government, at this stage, it does not give the sort of solution we need, basically because it is still unresearched to some degree and because it is an area that involves an enormous concentration by all parties involved in the negotiations and the deliberations.

The amalgamation of trade unions for its own sake is not necessarily desirable. The situation in which unions become bigger by sheer absorption one or another does not necessarily solve any problems. Indeed, it may create problems. It may well submerge the rights, objectives, aspirations and pride of smaller trade unions, craft unions, which have existed in this country for generations and which are, in a real sense, the direct descendants of craft unions in many other parts of the Western world, certainly of those found in Great Britain, the United States and Canada. If a procedure which made amalgamations easier than they are today were to be implemented, there would be a threat to significant numbers of old, small, efficient and proud unions. I do not believe we can involve ourselves willy-nilly in creating that sort of situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —And submerging their skills too.

—And submerging their skills. There is another fallacy in the assumption that just by increasing the scale or size-the physical dimensions-of a union by incorporating more and more people within a particular umbrella the problems of demarcation disputes will be ruled out. Of course, this is not the evidence of the history of amalgamations of trade unions. That is a suggested plus that may well be little more than a negative. I believe jealousies and competition probably increase with the size of organisations. As I look around massive companies, be they multinational or national, it seems to me that very often the greater they are, the more massive they are, the tougher becomes the competition between them and the more ruthless become their operations.
—You do not believe that bigger is better?

—Not necessarily. Generally speaking, there is no complete certainty that unions, just by growing bigger and bigger, will solve the problems that relate to industrial relations. I do not believe the present requirement for an amalgamation-that 50 per cent of the membership of the unions involved should vote and that at least 50 per cent should favour the amalgamation-is unreasonable. I know that there are objections on the grounds that it is hard to get that many people to vote and that there are certain reasons for that. But if 50 per cent of the people in the unions involved cannot be persuaded to vote to indicate their stance on amalgamation, I assume that they cannot be awfully interested in actually effecting an amalgamation.

SPEECH.PARA: I have touched very briefly on the history and nature of unions in this country. I think this is relevant because the capacity to move towards the ultimate objective of amalgamations, the production of industry-based unions, must be dependent in some measure on the history of the unions we are talking about. In the main the Australian trade union system-and it has been a great organisation-has contributed very significantly to Australian development over the last 50 years to 100 years. Unions in Australia have traditionally been of the craft variety. The industry-based unions have to be considered, certainly with a view to amalgamation. The industry-based unions, from many points of view, seem to have a reasonable and proper objective and may have significant advantages. But in my view-and this is relevant to the Government's attitude-there are not yet sufficiently and clearly defined guidelines in the area of industry-based unions to enable us to move to the development of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. What is an industry?

—We need to examine very closely what we mean by an industry. We have to have an authority recognised by all the people involved in the unions and in the field of management and we have to be sure that these people recognise that authority in the final term as well as the guidelines and the definition of the organism they are attempting to develop. The enterprise-based union is another interesting area involving, in some sense, amalgamation. But the enterprise-based union is found much more in a traditional situation and is found, significantly, in Japan. It may have a contribution to make in the Australian field. It is not an easy union to bring about but it is not something that can be laid aside as unworthy of consideration. The enterprise-based union develops a significant loyalty and pride amongst both the unionists and the management.

SPEECH.PARA: Community of interest is an interesting term too. I find it very hard to identify exactly what is meant by community of interest referable to trade unions. A bricklayer, presumably, would belong to the construction industry, yet he might be using some form of public transport to move to and from his work, be it a train, a bus or whatever. That vehicle would be part of the transport industry. Does he have a community of interest with the transport industry? An enormous number of questions have to be identified and defined before we can move with confidence into the development of amalgamated unions in any or all of these fields.

Amalgamation is an area where intense research is still necessary by a whole range of parties. I believe it is an area in which no real consensus of view has been established to this point. It has to be accepted that industry and enterprise unions would necessitate a very real and difficult restructuring of the union situation in this country and that is something that cannot be taken lightly. An authoritative body would be needed to apply guidelines and to determine the nature and scope of industry unions. I conclude my remarks by saying once again that the Government is certainly concerned that amalgamation, where it is seen to be a proper and fitting solution capable of making a contribution to industrial peace, must be right in our sights. But until we identify totally and absolutely the direction in which it is to take place it is best that this legislation be opposed.
Sitting suspended from 1 to 2.15 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-The Senate is dealing with the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill (No. 2) 1981. In replying to the debate, I will refer to the major points which have been raised and I believe I can do that best by dealing with the issues raised by Senator Chaney. Senator Chaney read a speech which-I do him the kindness of saying that with charity considering the time of year-I believe was prepared by Mr Viner's office. There is no other explanation of the tortuous argument which is advanced other than that it was prepared in Mr Viner's office. I will deal with some of the major issues which are raised in that speech.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Government is saying in response to a private member's Bill which I introduced and which was drafted by the Government, discussed with the National Labour Consultative Council, and promised prior to the last election to be introduced in this session of the Parliament, is that it now has a new view of the whole issue. It says that it is very concerned about industry-based unions. I am not sure whether the Government is concerned about industry-based unions or enterprise-based unions which are what it referred to in a recent statement by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner. But, let us assume that the Government is concerned about industry-based unions. The Liberal-National Country Party record on the question of union amalgamations can, I think, fairly simply and accurately be described in this way: In 1971, there was a large number of union amalgamations under consideration; in 1971, the then Attorney-General, Senator Greenwood, had a very strong belief that somehow governments did better out of small unions which they had divided and conquered-that was the simplistic view of the world which the late Senator Greenwood had-and that big unions would automatically mean conglomerates of power which would be controlled by communists, left-wingers and undesirable figures who would be a thorn in the side of Liberal governments.

Between 1972 and 1975, the Labor Government sought to introduce amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to facilitate amalgamations of trade unions. These amendments were defeated in the Senate by the then Liberal-National Country Party Opposition. In 1975-76, when this Government was returned to office, it again began reconsidering this issue. In 1980, the Government negotiated with its own established body, the National Labour Consultative Council, which is representative of employers and unions, and reached agreement with that body about the contents of the Bill which are the same contents as those in the Bill that I introduced last night. Not only was this Bill the subject of consultation and agreement, but also was it the subject of electoral promises. Now the Government is being confronted with its own promise-breaking and with its own breach of faith with the National Labour Consultative Council. Senator Chaney referred to that body very nicely by saying: 'I take it that this matter will cause some concern to members of the National Labour Consultative Council but they will be informed'. That is very nice of the Government. It does not matter how gentlemanly or how courteous one is about informing people, if one lies to them they will not respect one as a gentleman. They will think that such a person is a phoney gentleman. If honourable senators do not understand that, let me explain. The Government said that it would inform the National Labour Consultative Council of its change of mind. That is very gentlemanly. Before the last election the Government informed and promised the Council that it would adopt this legislation. The Government has broken that promise. All I am saying is that it does not matter how gentlemanly the Government is in dealing with that body in the future, I do not think it will be very grateful on the basis of the Government's being nice to it about informing it. The Government informed the Council, as it informed the people of Australia, before the last election that this legislation would be introduced.

As I have said, the Government has suddenly discovered the virtues of industry-based unions. It is not a new discovery. In 1977 I discussed this matter with the then Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Street. At that time Mr Street said that he was very keen to develop procedures which would facilitate industry-based unions. At that time I said: 'That is a good idea'. Nothing was done about it until 1980 when promises were made by the Government relating to unions amalgamating with a community of interest. The Government, in approaching this issue of industry-based unions, has larded Senator Chaney's speech with quotations which I made in the Senate. I am quoted as saying on 2 June 1981 that the case for industry-based unionism is overwhelming. I am also quoted as saying:
I am not so naive as to say that it would be an easy task to change the basis of Australian trade unionism to industry based unionism in the foreseeable future--

TALK.START.PARA: —What does it say again?
—I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not so naive as to say that it would be an easy task to change the basis of Australian trade unionism to industry based unionism in the foreseeable future--

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you mind if I quote that?

—Not at all; the honourable senator has done so already.
