What I want to know is why has Senator Chaney, in this nitwitted speech which he gave last night-I must say that is the only way of describing it; I am charitable enough to say that they are Mr Viner's words, not his-when confronted with an amalgamation Bill in the Senate in November 1981 suddenly discovered the virtue of my words when the Government totally ignored them in 1980. In 1980, after I had uttered those words, the Government said: 'We are not concerned about Senator Button's views because we will go ahead with this community of interest unionism'. The Government made that promise. It is very kind of the Government to think of me in retrospect, but a lot of water has flowed under the bridge since then. The Government ignored those words in 1980 and 1981. I think it is unreasonable that it should take them into account now.

SPEECH.PARA: In the course of Senator Chaney's remarks yesterday-quite apart from the emergence of this new-found view of the Government about these issues; it was a new-found view after six years of Fraser Government and 10 years of Liberal government since the issue was first discussed in this Parliament-he dealt with a number of other more minor issues which are raised by the Bill. The fundamental issues which are raised by the Bill are that the Government made promises; it recognised that this form of legislation was desirable; it recognised an agreement with the trade unions and the employers; it made promises on the basis of that agreement; and proceeded to prepare a Bill. One thing that is important in industrial relations is expressed in the words used by the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Fraser, in 1975. He said that the most important ingredient in good industrial relations was an attitude of mutual trust and respect. Neither the trade union movement nor employers in this country can have any feeling of mutual trust and respect with a government which behaves in the way in which this Government has behaved in relation to this legislation.

I turn now to some of the details of what Senator Chaney said. He referred to the difficulties which organisations allegedly have under the present legislation. There is no doubt about that. The Australian Textile Workers Union, the Clothing and Allied Trades Union of Australia and, more latterly, the Australian Boot Trade Employees Federation, have been seeking to amalgamate for nearly 10 years. Those three unions instructed me as late as today that they have already spent $14,000 on this issue trying to arrange an appropriate amalgamation ballot. They say that because of the high turnover in each of those unions the 50 per cent threshold required by the current legislation in terms of voter participation is impossible to attain, and that the 25 per cent threshold which is suggested by this legislation of mine would be difficult to attain.

TALK.START.PARA: —What percentage of union members would actually have to say that they wanted amalgamation-12 1/2 per cent?

—That is right, but we are working in a situation where, if we take some of the unions concerned, they have a 50 per cent turnover of membership each year. So they do not have the same members from one year to another. First of all, under the proposals in this Bill, they have to obtain the consent of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, which would say whether or not the amalgamation proposed was in the public interest. That is a very important consideration. No doubt that is why the Government put it in its Bill. Secondly, we have to get--
—The point I was making was that I am concerned about the democratic rights of those union members.

—I understand that; so am I. We are not against democratic rights for trade union members. If the Government had the same approach to the shareholders of major companies in insistence on democratic rights--
—I do not think 12 1/2 per cent would be acceptable.

—Come on! The honourable senator should have a look at the Companies Act. I am saying that it is almost impossible to get 50 per cent of members to vote in most union ballots. Under this provision, after they have obtained a 50 per cent vote they then have to get half of those people to approve effectively of the amalgamation. I think the proposal we have made, and which the Government originally made, is suitable and desirable in relation to the question with which the Senate is now concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the question of industry-based unions. What concerns me about this issue is that, in opposing this legislation, the Government is really saying-this is still being said-that what worries it a lot is that some big conglomerates of unions might emerge which would exercise too much power in society. I want to know what is different and unique about Australia which requires us to have 280-odd unions in a country of 14 million people when all the modern democracies of Western Europe get by with less than 20 unions each. What is so unique about Australia that we require that vast proliferation of unions, many of them very small? I think that is the question which Government senators have to address their minds to in approaching their own legislation. However, I do not think that is the issue at all. What is the issue is who controls those unions in terms of the political composition of the union leadership.

This Government always arrives at the extraordinary conclusion that some unions, because of their political leadership, are necessarily in an industrial sense more militant than those unions which have a totally different political complexion or leadership. For example, if it wants to be, the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia which is not said to be a militant union, nonetheless can be a very vociferous and agile union in terms of industrial disputation if issues affecting industrial interests of members are concerned. If honourable senators look at the records of various unions they can draw no conclusions about political complexion of unions dictating the degree of industrial disturbance in which those unions are involved. I say that by way of observation because I am concerned that Senator Walters and others who have an interest in this matter have that particular worry as far as possible alleviated. I do not think we can draw any conclusions, from the ideological composition of union leadership, as to the degree of industrial disputation in which a particular union is likely to be involved.

What I think is a very real danger in a society in which there is rapidly changing technology, is small unions in very key positions, because of high technology. The classic example is those boorish, dreadful people at the New South Wales Caltex oil refinery who stand up New South Wales-stop pulling the levers-because of their very sectional interests which are not in the interests of the trade union movement as a whole in New South Wales. Those people at the Caltex refinery are very few in number but they are a classic example of the sort of power which can be organised in an increasingly technological society by a small, irresponsible group in a key position. Generally speaking, in the context of a larger union-I know this does not apply in the Caltex situation-we will find, just as we do in political parties, that the extremes tend to be absorbed in the overall good of the union in terms of dictating its policy. I think that is a very good thing. If we have a consensus situation in which extremes in small unions are isolated in positions to exercise great power, they are much more likely to exercise it. In my view that is a very positive argument for amalgamations and not an argument which is based on the view which has been traditionally held in Liberal-National Country Party circles that society and the work force never change. Of course, the composition of the work force is changing daily and the sort of task which people are being asked to perform is changing daily almost on the same basis.

In conclusion, I find the Government's arguments in relation to this legislation extraordinary. What we have here is a demonstrated lack of faith by the Fraser Government in employers and the trade union movement about a matter on which there is total agreement. If the Government is a tripod, if I can put it that way, the only argument it has left is that it is protecting some alleged and fictitious public interest in relation to this matter. I do not think that is acting in the public interest. It is a neurotic fear by ill-informed, conservative politicians about the consequences of change of this order. It is a fear which was, of course, overcome for a period when the Government faced an election. If anything frightens conservative politicions more than neurotic fears about the work force, it is fears about an impending election. In that context the Government will say anything, as it did in the run-up to the 1980 election, on this important question of union amalgamations.

The most important thing is that this country makes important breakthroughs in the log-jam which exists in industrial relations in Australia. We must get some creative policy making from the Government, and some forward looking policy making in the area of industrial relations, otherwise we will lapse further and further back, and the Government will have paid agitators such as Andrew Peacock calling on it more and more to have a wages policy and to look at the questions related to collective bargaining in industry. As I said, all these questions will keep cropping up for those opposite from paid agitators such as Mr Peacock. They should not worry about the Laurie Carmichaels and other people out there, they will get them in their own party. They are so resistant on the basis of old mythology to constructive, positive and creative changes in industrial relations that in fact nothing is happening. It is not only newspapers such as the Australian Financial Review that write off this Government's industrial relations policy as a disaster area; it is the view of most informed commentators on industrial relations issues. It is a tragedy that Senator Chaney had to come into the Senate chamber last night and read that ill-informed apologia of that failed Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, in order to try to resist this important and significant Bill which I commend to the support of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I will respect the granting of leave and not launch into a fully-blown speech. As the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) has in fact replied it would be unfair to do so. It may be more advisable to take up with him the individual specific matters on another occasion. I want, in this very short statement, to put to rest once and for all the basis for the derived wisdom as to the importance of amalgamations; that is to say--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a very doubtful point of order just to be of assistance to Senator Harradine. I was just indicating to the Leader of the Opposition that if he wished to seek leave to make a brief statement following Senator Harradine's speech the Government would not deny him leave. I mention that because of Senator Harradine's inhibition. I am sorry to interrupt the debate but I thought I would give an indication.

—It has been indicated to me that on this matter I could speak for the full half hour, but since the Senate has given me leave, and I respect that, I will restrict my remarks to burying once and for all one piece of derived wisdom. It seems to me that everywhere we go people state that amalgamations are necessary to prevent all these demarcation disputes that apply right throughout Australia. We hear how dreadful and intransigent these demarcation disputes are. Senator Button and Senator Siddons referred to this aspect. It is referred to regularly in the Press. Indeed on the last occasion that Senator Chipp, Senator Siddons's leader, spoke about this matter on 3 June 1981 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I ask one of my colleagues in the Labor Party to correct me if I am wrong. I am told that about 20 per cent of all time lost through strikes is caused not by bloody-minded unions or by employer lockouts but simply by demarcation dispute wars between different unions on the same job.

According to the latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, disputes under the heading 'Trade Unionism' amounted to 1.5 per cent of all working days lost-not 20 per cent, not even 15 per cent, not even 10 per cent, not even 5 per cent, but 1.5 per cent. That was the figure for disputes relating to trade unionism. The column lists disputes concerning employment of non-unionists, inter-union and intra-union disputes, sympathy stoppages in support of employees in other industries and recognition of union activities. All of those types of dispute accounted for a mere 1.5 per cent of the total working days lost from all the causes of industrial disputes. I hope that puts to rest once and for all that particular furphy. I hope the Senate will recognise that, on further figures available from the Australian Bureau of Statistics, disputes derived from demarcation issues represent less than half of that 1.5 per cent. We are talking about introducing a Bill allegedly to overcome a massive problem of demarcations which comprise conservatively perhaps 0.8 per cent of working days lost.

Let us get down to facts. Let us examine these proposals and put them under some sort of scrutiny in the future, rather than taking as read what we have been told. Indeed, there is no guarantee whatsoever that amalgamations will solve demarcation disputes. In fact, the largest demarcation dispute in the history of Australia-I am going from memory-was one on the west coast of Tasmania between a fitter member and a boilermaker member of the same union, the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union.

TALK.START.PARA: —What year was that?

—That was just after the Boilermakers and Blacksmiths Society, the Amalgamated Engineering Union and the sheeties amalgamated. So far as Western Australia is concerned; there was a dispute in the Pilbara region between two members of the AMWSU within, I think, only the last year. There is no guarantee whatsoever that amalgamations are going to--
—How does that compare with the record prior to amalgamation?
—That would be an interesting examination. I have not undertaken such a study, but it is the sort of examination which should apply.
—You are using it as an example.

—Yes. I concede that we ought to have a good look at all of the figures and not accept this nonsense which is thrown about, that there are all these demarcation disputes. In fact, some of the worst types of demarcation disputes occur between members of the same union; for example, over the issue of the use of contractors. Honourable senators may remember some of those very difficult oil industry disputes in the last couple of years. Two of the disputes which affected the community most were between contractor members of the Transport Workers Union of Australia and oil company driver members of the Transport Workers Union. The amalgamation of unions will not help the situation. I believe that far more detailed consideration should be given to this matter. It was pointed out that in the Federal Republic of Germany there are only 16 unions. So what? That does not mean that because there are fewer unions there are fewer disputes. As it happens, in Germany there are fewer disputes of a politically oriented nature. That is because the Federal Republic of Germany will not wear political disputes.
—What percentage of disputes do political disputes constitute in Australia?
—The percentage is not great.
—Apart from the Medibank thing, which was a big one, I agree.

—The disputes are not divided in these figures. They are largely in the area of bans, such as bans on ships carrying materials to a port of a country which is not liked by a particular union, bans on uranium and that sort of thing. One can carry the fewer unions and fewer disputes argument too far. Take Japan as an example. Japan has far fewer disputes but it has 73,000 unions. So that is no argument. As to the suggestion that Senator Siddons made last night about wearing the American system, I issue a slight warning about that. America does have craft unions and it also has major amalgamated unions in the vehicle industry, such as the Auto Workers Union. However, there are far longer disputes in the United States where there is collective bargaining. They are massive disputes. I refer to man days lost. I will take this up with Senator Siddons at some other stage and not bore the Senate with it now. The United States figures do not hold up to the Australian figures so far as major industrial stoppages are concerned. It has been said that we ought to pass this Bill so as to arrive ultimately at the situation of having industry unions. As Senator Scott rightly asked, what is an industry union?
—With respect, I never said that.
—I know the honourable senator did not say it. It was suggested by Senator Siddons.
—I laid down about 15 categories.

—The honourable senator suggested the categories used by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. I could take up the time of the Senate for hours by going through all of these categories and asking whether this union or that union would give up its members to an amalgamated union. For example, in the category of transporation would the Waterside Workers Federation give up its members to the Transport Workers Union?
—The question is: Should they be allowed the right to do it if they wish?

—This is the crux of the whole matter. If one is talking about rights, that then leads to another aspect-about which I felt I would not waste the time of the Senate-which concerns the problems contained in the Bill in regard to the electoral base of those eligible to vote, irrespective of the number. I am surprised that Senator Button, with all his fine legal experience in the industrial world, would have been part and parcel of the drafting of this legislation.
—I was not. The Government drafted it, not me.

—That explains it. I should say that I rest my case. Finally, it may be said that the National Labor Consultative Council is in support of this. So far as the employer representatives on the National Labour Consultative Council are concerned, my response to that is: What have they to do with it? So far as the Australian Council of Trade Unions is concerned, its policy is not for amalgamation of unions on an industry basis. Let us not kid ourselves. That is why Senator Button did not make that distinction. He did not say that this was a Bill to establish industry unions. Senator Siddons thinks it is but it is not. That is not what will happen.
—It is going to make it easier for them though.

—No, it is not. For example, in the railways, I do not reckon that you would have an ice cream's chance in hell of getting the AMWSU to give to the Australian Railways Union its members in the railway workshops. Obviously the policy of the ACTU is not to have industry-wide unions. Its rules envisage industrial unions 'by industry or sector'. If the ACTU were to be asked, 'Into what industries ought the unions to be grouped?' the Government and the Parliament would have something to go on. But under the current circumstances the policy is one of 'bigger is best', and in my view bigger is not best. I agree with Senator Scott that some of the craft unions ought to be maintained in their entirety. We should not lay the foundations for tearing down unions, of enabling the larger ones to gobble up the smaller craft unions. All the talk nowadays is not of amalgamations of large and small unions; it is of amalgamations of big unions. If the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) becomes law, 12 1/2 per cent of a smaller craft union could be gobbled up into a larger union.
—Could decide to be gobbled up.

—That is right, senator. That is what I am saying. The 12 1/2 per cent could decide to be gobbled up and that would apply to the whole range of that particular trade. I am not fussed greatly about it but I am throwing it in so that we will not lose our perspective. In those circumstances, with skilled and unskilled people in the same union, there certainly would be problems in union meetings and so on. It could well create bases for intra-union disputation. Australia needs to ensure that there are groups of unions which have specific attitudes, in regard to the skilled trades particularly. It is on the skilled trades that Australia's future physical development will depend. I maintain that what is suggested in this particular Bill will not do industrial relations any good. I am sorry to have sought leave to speak at this stage. I am doubly sorry not to have entered into the debate more fully so that Senator Button and I could have a discussion about it. At this stage I am not convinced that I should vote for the Bill. Let the ACTU come out with what it means by industries and I will have a look at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-It is a matter of deep sorrow to me that I have failed to convince Senator Harradine. But I am persistent in all things and want to try again. First of all, I agree with much of what he said on the subject of demarcation disputes. The figure he chose for demarcation disputes as a percentage of total industrial disputation for this last year is one which is very favourable to his argument; the best ever.
—No, it is the latest. It is on working days.

—Yes. What I am saying is that it is the best figure ever for demarcation disputes. If one looks back a little I think one will find that in a normal average year the rate was running at about 7 per cent-that is to say, considerably higher than the 1.5 per cent that the honourable senator mentioned.
—Not on working days.
—I am talking about the numbers of disputes.
—But working days are the issue. On that basis rarely, if ever, is the rate above 2 per cent.

—It depends on which tool one uses to assist the argument. I am not persuaded that working days are the issue; it is the fact that the percentage for such disputes is significant. But I am not saying in any sense that amalgamation is the final solution to demarcation disputes. I believe it would assist in some ways. But it is not the basis upon which the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill (No. 2) is brought forward.
—The rules of the unions ought to apply.

—The basis upon which this Bill is brought forward is that firstly there can be no confidence about industrial relations or a basis for discussions between unions, employers and government if the Government is not to honour its responsibilities and the promises which it has made in the industrial field. They were made both to the employers and to the employee representatives on the National Labour Consultative Council. They were made to the Australian electorate prior to the last election. The Government has a mandate for my Bill. As I said earlier, I did not draft the Bill; the Government did. I am merely bringing forward its Bill which it promised it would introduce.
—It has probably seen the light of day.

—It is a conversion on the way to Damascus. It has been a very long day for this Government because it considered this issue 10 years ago, it has continued to consider it in a torturous and prolonged way ever since.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the basic reasons why this legislation is proposed is the important question of the use of resources by trade unions and the availability of resources to them. I think the resources would be put to much better use by amalgamated unions. Earlier in this debate I specifically referred to the textile, clothing and footwear unions. As I pointed out, for nearly 10 years they have been trying to amalgamate under the provisions of the present law. This industry has followed a torturous path over the last 10 years with massive disemployment, massive closure of mills and factories and the continuing threat of the Industries Assistance Commission recommendations on the whole question of protection hanging over its head. I think there would be a much better use of union resources if the amalgamation which those three unions desire were to proceed. The unions say that they cannot amalgamate under the present law. Because of the high turnover of members in those unions they just cannot get--

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have to look at the eligibility of the electorate in that situation and not the voting numbers.
—The eligibility of the electorate for what?
—For the purposes of voting for an amalgamation.
—If the honourable senator is saying that one should look at the eligibility clauses of the unions, as I take it he is--

—No, the financial eligibility. The honourable senator is talking about turnover. It is a question of whether or not those persons who are not genuinely in the industry get a vote. If they are not genuinely in the industry they do not get a vote.

—All I am saying is that the problems attendant upon those unions are enormous. The honourable senators solution would in a machinery way artificially delineate membership and would require an enormous number of amendments to the Act.
—You are trying to do it now as part of this.

—Yes, I am. I think that would be extremely difficult. The other reason is that we believe that the amalgamation process in such industries as the car industry, the shipbuilding industry and so on would make for easier lines of communication and negotiation between unions and employers. I understand that the employers believe that too. This Bill, in the context of its now being presented to the Senate, is supported by the Australian Council of Trade Unions for the sorts of reasons which were advanced in the second reading speech. I know, we all know, that vested interests are involved in the trade union movement. It is believed that some interests in certain industries would be better served by bigger unions; others believe that vested interests are best served by smaller unions. But whatever the position of the smaller unions is, the fact that this society has to face up to is that in times of very rapidly changing technology craft union demarcations arrived at in the 1850s are not necessarily appropriate in a contemporary society of the 1980s. That is one of the issues that has to be faced up to in relation to the question of amalgamations. It is very important in terms of developing a more modern trade union movement in Australia. Those are the things which we regard as important. I do not dissent from some of the views which have been put by Senator Harradine. I argue that on balance the solution which we propose is much better than the legislation which presently exists and which is keeping the industrial process in Australia from advancing in a more progressive way.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 October, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The substance of the Defence Acts Amendment Bill 1981 is by and large uncontroversial and, for that reason, the Opposition will not be opposing it at the second reading stage. But there are some matters to which the Opposition has expressed hostility and we will be moving amendments in an endeavour to improve the Bill in those respects. I also understand that an amendment will be moved by the Australian Democrats in the Committee stage which will have the result of the debate taking off in a rather different direction from that which is involved in the rather pedestrian provisions of the Bill as it presently stands. But it is only with the Bill as it stands and with possible improvements to it of the kind that the Opposition will recommend that I will be dealing in the second reading debate.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill deals with four distinct subject areas. In the first place it provides for the payment of additional compensation to members of the reserve and emergency forces who become totally incapacitated through personal injury in the course of their service with the Defence Force. Secondly, it re-enacts and revises provisions relating to co-operative arrangements between the defence forces of Australia and other countries, especially in two areas; first of all, mutual powers of command between such forces and, secondly, in relation to the treatment of those absent without leave in a co-operative arrangement situation. The third major area that is changed by the Bill is the creation of the new rules for public access to declared areas of defence land. The fourth subject matter of the Bill amounts to a series of uncontroversial amendments to the regulation-making powers relating respectively to the forfeiture of salary and allowances in certain cases, the payment of compensation to persons suffering loss or damage in certain cases, the application of Commonwealth, State and Territory taxes to Defence Force canteens and, a little more importantly, the conduct of defence courts and boards of inquiry so far as the compellability of witnesses is concerned and their protection in other proceedings.

I do not need to say anything more about the last of those areas. I do, however, want to make a few remarks about the first three of them and to indicate the scope of the five amendments which the Opposition proposes to move, all of which amendments in fact relate to the single area of co-operative defence arrangements. It is my hope that in dealing with the Bill in this way it will not be necessary for me to speak at any length at all during the Committee stage in relation to the Opposition amendments, but I can now foreshadow the substance of them and the detail necessary for our purposes in this chamber.

Let me begin with a few remarks on the subject of the compensation provisions of this Bill. As was acknowledged by the Opposition spokesman, Mr Scholes, in the House of Representatives when the matter was there debated, these amendments are a significant improvement on the present position and an acknowledgment of the need-an acknowledgment only granted, it must be said, after the matter became somewhat controversial-for equity of treatment as between reservists and regular soldiers. Formerly an incapacitated reservist would receive compensation based on his civilian salary for a period of 26 weeks after which he would then fall to be compensated under the Compensation (Australian Government Employees) Act, the provisions of which are notoriously and disgracefully inadequate. As a result of this measure, the reservist will be entitled to be paid at a rate not less than 7.6 per cent of his civilian salary once the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen) has made the necessary declaration.

We endorse this improvement but, at the same time, we notice and draw attention to serious weaknesses as we see it in the new provisions. That is a situation which might arise where a young reservist who receives an adult military salary, as indeed he should because of the risks he is taking, receives that salary according to rank, but receives a civilian salary by contrast which is age related and is considerably below the adult rate. In those situations if he is injured his long-term compensation will be based on that civilian salary rather than his reservist's rank which might be an adult one and much superior in terms of the salary return. In other words, he will receive only 76.5 per cent of his 17 or 18-year-old civilian salary, as the case may be, for the latter part of the duration of his incapacity. It seems to us that no proper account is taken of his adult needs, or of the fact that he would have graduated to an adult civilian salary in due course. This is not a matter on which we propose to move an amendment in this place any more than we did in the House of Representatives, but we would like a reasoned response from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) to this particular point because it does seem to us to be one of some capacity.

The second major area with which the Bill deals, and the area in respect of which we do have a number of amendments, is the matter of arrangements with the forces of other countries. The Bill inserts new Part IXB in the Defence Act covering the general ground previously contained in Parts III and IV of the Defence (Visiting Forces) Act 1963. The object of the new provisions is to set out the general rules for the kinds of co-operative arrangements with other forces of which Australia has a long history, primarily of course with the forces of the United Kingdom and the United States, in Europe and the Pacific and, in more recent decades, in Korea, Malaysia and Vietnam, and with which again regrettably it appears we may be about to engage in the Sinai.

I said that there were two areas within this large subject area of co-operative arrangements that are dealt with by the Bill. The first of those two areas is the question of the mutual powers of command, and three kinds of situations are envisaged by the Bill. The first is where there is what is described as an attachment between respective forces. Here it is provided that where an individual member of the Australian Defence Force is attached temporarily to another force, or vice versa, in that situation the person so attached becomes subject to the service law, including the disciplinary law, of the force to which he is so attached. The second situation is where the forces are described as serving together. Here the provision is that when the Australian Defence Force or a component of it is serving with others, the respective officers and non-commissioned officers of the forces in question are to be empowered to give orders to their subordinates in the other forces, although it is further provided that breaches of discipline by Australians are to be dealt with by Australian authorities under Australian service law. In a final refinement and description of these co-operative arrangements, it is further provided that in a situation where the Australian defence forces are described as acting in combination with forces of another country, a relationship implying a slightly closer degree of co-operation than is involved in merely 'serving together', there is provision that the commanding officer of the combined forces has the power of both command and discipline in accordance with Australian service law.

These are complicated provisions but, by and large, in substance they are acceptable to the Opposition. We accept their general legitimacy and the general desirability of the different kinds of integrated arrangements which are described in the Bill. We acknowledge the desirability of there being clear ground rules governing the command relationships and the disciplinary relationships in those respective types of situations. However, it is our belief, and this belief is embodied in our amendments, that there ought to be some reciprocity with other countries concerned before we enact legislation of this kind, which has the potential to place Australians in a subservient position. We do not object to the reality or necessity or desirability of, on occasions, Australian servicemen being placed in a subservient position vis-a-vis the superior officers or NCOs in other forces. But we do believe that if that is to happen then it should happen only in a circumstance where, if the boot is on the other foot, there is equally a willingness on the part of the other country concerned to legislate so as to ensure that the same relationship will apply there.

Thus, if I might describe at this stage the substance of our amendments in this respect, I think it will save some discussion of this aspect at the Committee stage. Our first amendment is to provide that attachments, properly so-called, may take place only if the country with which the attachment arrangement is proposed has equivalent legislation making its nationals subject to Australian service law when they happen to be attached to our forces. The second and third of our amendments, which I will be moving formally in the Committee stage, deal not with the attachment situation but with 'serving together' or 'acting in combination'. Here we wish to provide that the declaration of the Governor-General establishing these relationships, or at least establishing the command and discipline implications of these relationships, should be subject to parliamentary approval. In this case we are talking about parliamentary approval by both Houses. I make it clear that amendments Nos 2 and 3 on the sheet which has been circulated are interrelated.

We are not saying by these amendments that Australian forces cannot serve together with, or act in combination with, other forces without parliamentary approval. It is that proposition which is essentially the subject matter of the Australian Democrats' amendment which, as they have foreshadowed in the media, they will move in the Committee stage. We are saying only that the new rules governing who is subordinate to whom and who has command and disciplinary powers over whom should not come into effect unless and until there has been affirmative parliamentary approval. We anticipate, of course, that Parliament would not approve of such a declaration taking effect and these rules relating to command and discipline relationships coming into force if it were not satisfied, again, that reciprocity applied and that the countries with whom the Australian forces were serving accepted themselves some obligations for their own nationals to obey Australian commands where appropriate. That is the substance of the amendment.

I note in relation to the amendment that the Minister for Defence, Mr Killen, expressed some sympathy with the approach adopted by the Opposition and our concern that there should be formal reciprocity of this kind. He indicated in the course of the debate in the other place that he would seriously consider and take on board our proposals and give us an appropriate response when the matter came to be debated in this chamber. I regret to report to the Senate that that consideration does not seem to have moved Mr Killen even to the extent of giving us a reasoned reply. I will read into the record the letter which he sent to the Opposition defence spokesman, Mr Gordon Scholes, on 30 October 1981. It stated:
During the course of the debate in the Committee stages of the Defence Acts Amendment Bill on 23 September, I undertook to examine certain amendments proposed by the Opposition.
I am now in a position to inform you that I examined these amendments but, after consultation with my colleagues, it was decided by the Government that the amendments would not be proceeded with.

Perhaps there is a reasoned justification for the Government's not proceeding with the sympathetic consideration of the amendments proposed by the Opposition. If there is a reasoned basis for it, not just the usual obtuseness of the Minister for Defence and his Department, we would be delighted to hear about it in the Attorney-General's reply in this chamber. If this matter is dealt with in the reply to the second reading debate we can make the Committee stage much less elaborately long-winded than it might otherwise prove to be.

The remaining matter under the general head of co-operative arrangements that is dealt with in the Bill is the treatment of absentees without leave. The Bill makes various provisions with respect to those absent without leave relating to their apprehension, detention and treatment while in custody. Basically, those provisions seem to the Opposition to be quite sensible, satisfactory and unobjectionable but we have two amendments in this area-Nos 4 and 5 on the list which has been circulated. Perhaps it is a convenient time to indicate briefly what they are. Amendment No. 4 relates to proposed new section 116F which provides that if another country with whom Australia has a co-operative defence relationship asks Australia to apprehend deserters or those absent without leave, the authorised officer in Australia may, at his discretion, issue a warrant to apprehend the persons in question. We in the Opposition simply say that this provision is too open-ended and that there should be some appropriate time limit-we have suggested two years but we would be willing to consider a longer period-beyond which the deserter or person absent without leave cannot be arrested and returned under the authority of this kind of provision.

We are not proposing that there be some kind of general amnesty necessarily for people in this situation in the sense that they cannot be apprehended or convicted for any other offence that they may have committed when absent without leave while in Australia as members of a force with which we have a co-operative defence arrangement. There may well be other sanctions which are perfectly appropriate to apply. We are just concerned that years after the event-maybe 20 years or 25 years in some cases-this power will have a potential application. In this respect we do not think that Australia should be committing itself, creating a statutory obligation for itself, to co-operate in rounding-up operations of this kind that some other formerly friendly country with whom we have had a co-operative relationship may be minded to embark upon.

The other remaining amendment, which is No. 5 on the circulated Opposition list, relates to the procedure governing the issuing of warrants for the apprehension of persons arrested without leave. This Opposition amendment provides for a time limit beyond which such a warrant cannot be executed. We suggest 30 days as an appropriate period. Again, this is negotiable. We also seek to provide for an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review on the merits of the circumstances in which a warrant is issued under this legislative authority. That is the approach that the Opposition adopts. It is a slightly more velvet gloved or sympathetic approach to the problem of persons absent without leave than that which is implied in the Government's proposed legislation. We re-emphasise that our major concern, in our view of this legislation, is with the reciprocity requirements that we see as being appropriate and indeed necessary if we are to have these new command rules established and given permanent statutory form. I will be briefer about the remaining matters.

The third large area dealt with by the Bill and the last area about which I want to have a word or two concerns the question of public areas of defence land, of which there is a very large quantity scattered around various parts of Australia. The Bill proposes a new Part IXB for the Defence Act which provides in particular for the declaration by the Minister of certain defence land to be public areas, and the appointment of rangers with a provision that any member of the Australian Federal Police or a Territory police force is to be regarded, ex officio, as a ranger for this purpose. It vests these rangers with a number of powers relating to arrest, search and seizure and also vests in the Minister powers to make by-laws relating to the control and management of these public areas of defence land. Again we have no amendments to these provisions but we feel some aspects deserve brief comment.

First, so far as the powers of rangers are concerned, I simply say that the provisions made for arrest, search and seizure do perhaps justify very close attention in this legislation, as they do in any other. One would have wished that the Senate Standing Committee on Scrutiny of Bills was in existence to give the benefit of an informed report on the implication of these provisions to enable their better consideration, particularly occurring as they do buried away again in a compendious piece of legislation. On the basis of the scrutiny we as an Opposition have been able to give these provisions I think it is fair to say that by and large they seem to conform with the kind of criteria as specified in the Australian Law Reform Commission's 1975 report on criminal investigation governing special situations of this kind, particularly in remote areas.

In principle we do not see any fundamental objections to these provisions and indeed we further note in this respect with some pleasure, if incredulity, that the basic recommendations of the Law Reform Commission in relation to arrest, search and seizure seem to have been picked up in the Criminal Investigation Bill, Part II and Part V respectively which was introduced into this place last week. I say no more about arrest, search and seizure although there are some possible difficulties in the way that these provisions will operate in practice if they are not sensitively applied.

However, there is a little more to be said about the question of environmental standards in defence areas and the mechanisms proposed for the guaranteeing that satisfactory environmental standards are maintained. The Minister is empowered by the Bill to make by-laws covering a number of different areas, in particular those relating to the prohibition of pollution of soil, air or water, the use of fire, the use and parking of motor vehicles and generally the protection and preservation of public areas. It appears that most of the powers that this Bill would build into the Defence Act have been borrowed from the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, but not so as to integrate the arrangements for environmental management of defence land with the arrangements that are involved in the operation of the national parks system. Rather, what this Bill would establish is a separate system of national parks. There is no suggestion that there would be a proper plan of management developed in relation to defence land, as is crucial in the national parks administration. I understand that the Department of Defence never at any stage even consulted the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service on this legislation.

If the Opposition is wrong in that belief or understanding we would be delighted to have the Minister tell us so. There may be some considerations especially relating to national security and so on which are peculiar to defence land and which would require some modification of the basic parks legislation. But the essential objects of that legislation and this, relating to the conservation of this land and access to it by the public, are so similar that it seems absurd that there could not have been a better meshing of both the legislative provisions and the proposed administration of the land in question. This seems to be a case of interdepartmental power politics prevailing at the expense of the national interest. I conclude on the note that we have these reservations, these caveats, these proposed amendments to the Defence Bill. We find the Bill essentially a piecemeal approach to a set of piecemeal problems, but I suppose that is inevitable in a clean-up piece of legislation of this kind. Whatever further objections we have, we will reserve them for the Committee stage. We do not oppose the second reading of the Defence Acts Amendment Bill 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats take a somewhat more fundamental and serious view of the Defence Acts Amendment Bill 1981 than does the Australian Labor Party. This legislation is a sort of catch-all of a large number of bits and pieces in the defence area. This seems to us to be a suitable vehicle to deal with an area which not only is of great concern to the Australian Democrats but also, I suggest, is quite reasonably of concern to hundreds of thousands, if not millions, of people in this country. It concerns the circumstances under which Australians can be sent overseas either to war or as members of some kind of peacekeeping force, such as that proposed for the Sinai. Our law is deficient compared with that of certain other countries, such as Canada, in that such decisions are Executive decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: I take honourable senators back to when Australia found itself in a classic dilemma, one of the greatest dilemmas this country has ever faced. One of the most divisive issues that has ever oppressed our history occurred between 1962 and 1971 when some 50,000 Australian servicemen from all three Services were engaged in the war in Vietnam, the result of which was a communist government for the whole of Vietnam. The hostilities almost certainly resulted also in the later destruction of the free governments in neighbouring Cambodia and Laos and the incorporation of all of what was once French Indo-China into the communist state. During that decade of war 492 members of the Australian forces were killed. Of these deaths, 187 were of young men who had no choice as to this tragic early end to their lives because they were conscripts set to fight in an unwinnable and unjustifiable foreign adventure which, judged on any standard, was a disaster and which, far from deterring the spread of communism in Asia, actually contributed significantly to it and speeded up that process. As well as those deaths many more young Australians were injured, nearly 3,000 of them. Of these more than 1,000 were conscripts.

As if this were not enough, the war has left behind further legacies of horror and suffering for our people. During the war large areas of Vietnam were sprayed with agent orange containing the herbicide 2,4,5-T in its worst and most dangerous form, highly contaminated by large percentages of the poisonous chemical dioxin, which is rightly judged by experts as being possibly the most dangerous substance on the face of the earth and which is responsible for the deformation of children in the womb. The evils of that war were not confined to a single generation of Australians but were passed forward to the next. Even there it might not end. Recessive defects of this type may well show up even in generations not yet born. This is the area of consequence we are talking about as a result of a decision taken to involve Australia in a war without the proper consultation of its people and of its Parliament and without the right, which we are seeking in our proposed amendment, of the Parliament, as the voice of the people, to have some control over the situation.

In view of this, it is worth looking at the origins of the Vietnam war. There are very many differing versions about how Australia got into that tragic and wasteful episode. For many years it was stated officially that we went there to answer a call for help from the Government of South Vietnam, but that is now completely discredited and is known to be not true. Papers released in the United States as a result of the effective freedom of information law there indicate that the United States wanted Australia there with other countries so that the United States would not be seen to be acting alone. That was the motivation; that was why Australia was there. Of course, we were not told at the time or subsequently that that was the reason. In fact it was stated over and over again by the then Government that the reason was that the government of a free country had asked us to help. But that was not true. So again we must look at the motivation of government, its honesty, should it be left alone in such a situation without the control of the Parliament and the debate in the Parliament that would result from our proposed amendment should it become law.

What are the motivations of government, the pressures on it, to conceal and to dissimulate? It is said that a nation which cannot learn from the lessons of history has no future. If history has proved anything, it has certainly proved that. So it is reasonable and rational for us to look at the history of the Vietnam war to see what we can learn from it. Australian involvement in that war before it ended was opposed by millions of Australians, certainly by the majority of Australians. It was passionately and actively opposed by scores of thousands-possibly hundreds of thousands. It became a deeply divisive issue in our community and we still bear the scars of it. It has resulted in a deep scepticism on the part of young people about the validity of our process of government. Many of them are not on the electoral role because they fear future wars in which they might again be sent overseas through no choice of their own to fight, against their own will and against the will of the people.

The Democrats' major interest in this Bill is the foreshadowed amendment which I have circulated and which, if carried, would mean that no such foreign adventure could ever happen again without the consent of both Houses of the Federal Parliament. To the Australian Democrats this is a matter of great concern, a matter on which we have received tremendous representations from the community and a matter which we know, beyond any shadow of doubt, that the Australian community wants. Yet it seems to me quite likely that members of this Parliament whom those people elect to do reasonably what they think is right and proper will ignore this situation. I suggest even at this stage that they will ignore it at their peril. The two Houses of Parliament-I stress the two Houses of Parliament-are responsible to the people of Australia and should reflect their will.

It is a current fact that the House of Representatives alone does not reflect the will of the people. The Government does not have a majority in the Senate. This situation is certain to continue into the indefinite future. Hence it is imperative that the sanction of both Houses and especially that of the Senate be obtained before fighting forces or so-called peacekeeping forces are sent overseas. This will be a resonable role for the Senate in its role as a cautionary House, a House of review. It would not be enough for the House of Representatives alone to do this. The House of Representatives by its nature is virtually a rubber stamp of the Executive and becomes more and more so with every day that passes. It has even been castigated to that effect in recent days by its own Speaker.

How can we in this Senate then suggest that the House of Representatives alone should have any responsibility or any authority over this matter? Yet the Labor Party has foreshadowed an amendment to our amendment to seek to water it down to the extent that only the House of Representatives would have to be consulted in the case of any warlike activities on the part of the country. The Australian Democrats feel that the Labor Party, if it has any sincerity or any basic honesty whatsoever, will support the passage of our proposed amendment through the Senate. If it fails to do so it will be rightly judged by the people of Australia for its perfidy, its weakness and its political cynicism. It would mean that its protests over the Vietnam war over the years can now be seen as quite cynically shed crocodile tears; no more than that.

The same basic comments could apply to the Sinai force. When brought to the test on this matter the Labor Party, in fact, went to water. It does not want to support a situation in which the representatives of the people have control over this matter. What its motivations are for that I cannot even begin to divine. I would be interested to hear, perhaps in the Committee stage, some explanation from the Labor Party on just what it thinks its motivations are. Furthermore, this is one of those important, basic and continuing isues in the community concerning the rights of the people to be consulted through their representatives on whether they go into the most serious, disruptive situation government could ask of them-to go into war. I suggest to the Labor Party that if it fumbles this one it is not something that will be easily or quickly forgotten, nor should it be.

The amendment takes into account the need for government to act quickly in the event of emergency. There is provision for it to act quickly but it must call both Houses of Parliament together within 48 hours to approve that action. This is a similar provision to the one which already applies in Canada where parliament must be called together within ten days. We feel that in a modern world with modern transport there is really nothing to stop parliament being called together more quickly, and I think that would improve that kind of situation. The amendment also exempts from service personnel abroad for the purpose of buying stores or equipment, those abroad on missions involving their own training, or crews of Australian ships and aircraft abroad. If there are any categories which we have overlooked-we have a fairly long list of them-we will not mind further amendments being moved to extend them if that would improve this proposal.

I think one basic point is that in Australia we now have a society that will not accept the idea that it must be told what to do by some higher source of wisdom. The new generation of Australians wants part of the action and it also wants safeguards against precipitate, unsavoury or unexplained executive action, especially in a matter as important as this. It is also a much better informed generation than have been previous generations. The enormous switchover of what were once mainly entertainment media to public information and debate functions indicates that. I think any government which ignores this trend must do so at its peril. If the Labor Party puts itself up seriously as an alternative government it cannot also, I suggest, dither like a rather elderly waitress hesitating over which table to serve first-the principle sitting at one table or expediency sitting at the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to comment very briefly on the remarks of Senator Mason. I do not know whether I should do this now or when the Bill is considered at the Committee stage. Are we all speaking now on the amendments so that we can get rid of the Committee stage fairly quickly?
—Either now or later.

—I feel that the Australian Democrats' proposal, as I understand it, deals with the purposes for which the Government would be sending troops overseas. They would include, firstly, unilateral action taken by Australia in its immediate area-for example, Papua New Guinea and its territories in the South Pacific; secondly, action in conjunction with its allies-for example, the United States or under an international agreement such as the five-power agreement; or, thirdly, action taken under the United Nations or international auspices. Those are the sorts of purposes for which I can envisage the Government deciding to commit forces to serve abroad.

SPEECH.PARA: It is to be noted that the commitment of Australian forces for any of those purposes may be to meet an emergency but it may also be to prevent an emergency from developing. That is the key point-for example, in a case where a friendly government, foreseeing trouble, requests the presence of Australian troops. Of course, that occurred recently when the New Hebrides requested Papua New Guinea to supply troops. The Democrats' amendment seems to me to run into the following difficulties: It assumes that Australian troops would be committed abroad only in an emergency-that is, proposed new section under 50C (3); it allows troops to be despatched immediately but provides that they may not be required to continue to serve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. Would it not be more convenient if Senator Harradine were to leave his detailed remarks on the proposed amendment to the Committee stage? I appreciate that some of us have been endeavouring to foreshadow the Committee stage to speed things up, to the extent that we are getting to the substantive debate about amendments which are not technically before us and which have not been properly introduced. I think that makes it difficult.
—Thank you, Senator Evans. Perhaps that would suit Senator Harradine.
—I agree with that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am somewhat confused by Senator Evans's intervention on Senator Harradine making a speech at the second reading stage in the way in which Senator Evans invited honourable senators to deal with the matter. But we are always fairly confused by Senator Evans's suggestions. I suppose there is nothing new about that. As I understand it, we will not now deal with this matter at the second reading stage but in the Committee stage. There is not much for me to say in summing up this debate because all honourable senators who have spoken support the measure. Therefore it ought to be given a second reading without any further delay.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 4-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 4A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 2, after clause 4, insert the following clause: '4A. Section 50C of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section substituted:
''50C. (1) Members of the Defence Force may be required to serve within the territorial limits of Australia.

(2) Subject to sub-section (3), members of the Defence Force may not be required to serve beyond the territorial limits of Australia except in accordance with a resolution agreed to by each House of the Parliament authorizing the service.

(3) The Governor-General may by proclamation declare that an emergency exists requiring the service beyond the territorial limits of Australia of members of the Defence Force, and such service may be required in accordance with such a proclamation.
(4) If the Parliament is not in session when a proclamation under sub-section (3) is made, it shall be summoned to meet within 2 days after the making of the proclamation.

(5) If the Parliament is in session when a proclamation under sub-section (3) is made, but either House of the Parliament is adjourned for an indefinite period of time or for a period of time which will expire more than 2 days after the making of the proclamation, the Presiding Officer of that House within the meaning of the Parliamentary Presiding Officers Act 1965, or the person who is deemed to be the Presiding Officer of that House for the purpose of that Act, shall summon that House to meet within 2 days after the making of the proclamation, notwithstanding anything contained in the resolution of adjournment of that House.
(6) A proclamation made under sub-section (3) shall cease to have effect on the day next succeeding the day on which the Parliament next meets after the making of the proclamation.
(7) For the purpose of this section, service beyond the territorial limits of Australia does not include service by members of the Defence Force-
(a) pursuant to their temporary attachment as provided by section 116B;
(b) as part of an Australian diplomatic or consular mission;
(c) on an Australian vessel or aircraft not efgaged in hostilities or in operations during which hostilities are likely to occur;
(d) for the purpose of their education or training; or
(e) for purposes related to the procurement of equipment or stores.

This amendment is fairly lengthy. I think honourable senators have had the opportunity of seeing it. I will speak briefly to it although I did mention it in the second reading debate. Basicially, clause 4 requires Australian military forces to serve overseas. It does not contain any provisions limiting the carte-blanche right of the Government to send the troops overseas. That is, of course, the purpose of our amendment. In other countries the provision we propose applies. In Canada, the Governor-in-Council may deploy troops anywhere, any time, subject to Parliament meeting within 10 days to approve action taken. In the Federal Republic of Germany there are limitations. There is constitutional prohibition against German forces participating in a war of aggression. Participation in a collective military action for preservation of peace is permissible only if that force is deployed in a situation which, at that time, represents an illegal attack on the Bundesrepublic. In Japan, the 1947 Constitution of Japan, by article 9, provides:
. . . the Japanese people for ever renounce war as a sovereign right of the nation . . .

The Self-defence Forces are authorised to protect the peace and stability of Japan against direct and indirect aggression. Self-defence Force personnel may not be deployed outside Japan. This has been interpreted by successive governments as precluding participation in United Nations peace keeping and observation teams. In the United Kingdom there are no restrictions on the monarch as commander-in-chief to deploy forces on the advice of his ministers, with a successful noconfidence motion in Parliament and a subsequent election as the ultimate and only sanction. In the United States, the President has independent power to take military action whenever the interests of the United States require it. Congress, however, has power to raise and support armies and to declare war. However, a study prepared in 1951 for the Committee on Foreign Relations cites at least 125 incidents in America's history in which the President has ordered the armed forces to take action or maintain positions abroad without congressional authorisation. So Congress's powers in respect of that right have been eroded.

The Australian Democrats' amendment seeks to place the responsibility for a decision to send Australian troops abroad with the two Houses of Parliament subject to exceptions covering the movement of personnel in the normal course of their activities and the need to take quick action in an emergency. The Government will still be able to act quickly in an emergency declared by proclamation but must obtain parliamentary approval within two days. If Parliament is not in session the provisions require it to be recalled to make this decision. I wish to make the point at this stage, because it has been mentioned by Senator Harradine, that we do not necessarily see this as merely operating in an emergency. It is only the subsequent recall of Parliament which operates in an emergency. In a situation where the Government wished to send a force overseas for any reason whatsoever and where it had the time to do so it would, of course, be able to put it through and justify it before both Houses of Parliament in the normal way.

The provision excludes overseas service by members of the Defence Force pursuant to their temporary attachment, as provided by section 116B, as part of an Australian diplomatic or consular mission on an Australian vessel or aircraft not engaged in hostilities or in operations during which hostilities are likely to occur, for the purpose of their education or training or for purposes related to the procurement of equipment or stores. In those provisions we have tried to provide a situation which is realistic and in which the Government has the utmost freedom of action for the normal and ordinary purposes that its armed forces might be concerned with, short of the two major areas of actual hostilities and use as a fighting force or as a peacekeeping force in some remote country. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the amendment in its present form. We do not believe that decisions to send Australian troops overseas should require-important, crucial and controversial as those decisions often are-the assent of both Houses of Parliament. We do not believe that but we do believe it is appropriate that there should be an opportunity for parliamentary debate before any such momentous step is taken, making due regard for situations of emergency. In order to clearly state our position in that respect we propose to move a further amendment to the Australian Democrats' amendment to delete the references, where appearing, to 'each House of the Parliament' and to substitute the words 'the House of Representatives'. The result of that amendment will be to guarantee that Executive decisions of this kind are brought before the Parliament at the soonest reasonable opportune moment, preferably before the decision is made, except in emergency circumstances. It is not required that the Parliament as a whole convene and certainly it is not required that this chamber, with all its idiosyncratic performances over the years, have a veto power over the Government's decision.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a long way and a short way of debating this whole subject matter. The long way is to tackle it in the way in which the Australian Democrats have endeavoured to do, primarily in the speech at the second reading stage by Senator Mason and in a shorter fashion in his contribution to the Committee stage; that is, to review all the kinds of circumstances and cases which have arisen in the past, from the Boer War to the Sinai, or which might arise in the future, to talk about the pros and cons of excursions overseas and raise the spectre-indeed it is often a spectre-of very unfortunate decisions which have often been made in the past, and to suggest on the basis of that that we need some more checks and balances in the future to ensure that they do not happen again. To approach the argument in that way inevitably is to get drawn into a very long argument. It is not an argument which we are anxious to join.

Our attitudes to the pros and cons of military adventures in the past are perfectly well known. Our attitudes against the proposed current adventure to the Sinai are equally well known. We do not find it necessary to apologise in any way for the kind of tirade that has been directed against us today by Senator Mason. That is one of the reasons I feel a trifle churlish at the moment in responding to his contribution. Our attitude to such military adventures as Vietnam was known and perfectly apparent to the Australian people before the Australian Democrats ever existed on this planet, while indeed their leader was actively participating in the implementation of those heinous decision and while this collection in the chamber were barely out of their political nappies. Indeed, there is plenty of evidence on the basis of today's contributions and others this session that they are still in their political nappies. We do not need any moralising or any hypocritical, sanctimonious grandstanding from Senator Mason or anyone else on the subject of our attitudes, our beliefs and our convictions about the morality or immorality of particular excursions by Australian troops overseas. We simply do not regard those issues as being helpful. We do not regard all the argument, all the controversy and all the emotion that have been generated by those issues as being relevant or helpful to the consideration of the matter that is being brought forward. So, the short way in which I propose to deal with this matter is as follows: While it is desirable that the Parliament debates this matter of the proposed sending of foreign troops overseas, while it is not good enough for Malcolm Fraser, the Prime Minister-I am sorry, Mr Chairman; I have to give him his due title-to make the kind of statement he made yesterday while a chamber of this Parliament is still sitting, without any attempt to have that statement put down and to be made the subject of discussion in this Parliament, and while it is appropriate that the Parliament has the opportunity to debate these matters and for fierce critical opposition to be expressed to them, we do not believe, when all is said and done, that foreign policy issues and decisions of this kind, war and peace decisions as they are in extreme situations, are matters which are other than pre-eminently matters in our system of government for the executive government of the day. These are the kinds of decisions which governments are elected to carry out. These are the kinds of decisions for which governments must retain the ultimate responsibility. These are the kinds of decisions-

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliament should have no say in sending troops overseas?

—Parliament certainly should have a say. Parliament should certainly be consulted, and the opportunity should arise for debate. But these are quintessentially executive decisions. The Opposition does not, as much as Senator Chipp and his party seem to have overlooked the fact-
—What sort of humbug is that, that the Parliament has a say? You know it is a rubber stamp.

—It is a question not whether Parliament should have a say but whether the Senate and the ratbags who inhabit it from time to time are to have a veto power over the decisions of the government of the day. It is a question of the kind of decision for which a government will properly win plaudits if it is right or for which a government will properly win condemnation if it gets it wrong as this Government has so often got it wrong in the past. I simply do not think and the Opposition simply does not think that it is appropriate to vest this kind of veto power in a chamber which so often has a non-government majority. To do so is to give succour, to give nourishment to all the accumulated nonsense that so often in the past has been talked about the role of this chamber in our system. This chamber has a role of review. It has a perfectly proper role and it has a major contribution to make. I understand that that is a position which has been accepted by the Democrats. You have contributed actively to making this place an effective house of review. But you do not believe any more than we believe that this chamber should exercise a power of life or death over the government of the day, over its capacity to survive. You do not believe any more than we believe-in fact you have taken an even stronger point about it-that this chamber should have the capacity to interfere in fundamental Budget decisions of this Government. You have made that perfectly clear and you have said it publicly over and over again. You do not believe any more than we do--
—Order! The honourable senator will address his remarks to the Chair.

—Mr Chairman, the Australian Democrats do not believe any more than we do that this Senate should have the power to second-guess the Government when it has a clear mandate for the course on which it has chosen to embark. We simply take the view that there are a series of such limitations which it is perfectly proper to impose upon the Senate in our parliamentary constitutional system. Whatever may be the delusions of grandeur of some honourable senators in this chamber, we are not a United States-style congressional chamber. We are not a legislative body which has the powers, or should have the powers, of the United States Senate. We are not a body which is engaged in a legislative capacity in a kind of tug-of-war, a veto power, a counter-balanced relationship, with the Executive Government in the way that is indispensibly necessarily the case in a United States-style presidential system. Of course it is appropriate that the United States Senate should exercise a veto power over war and peace decisions, about the dispatch of troops and all the other things where presidential power was so outrageously gained and added to in the 1960s and 1970s. That is not appropriate here.
—Assume the Government brought in a Bill for conscription. Don't you believe this chamber should have a power of veto?

—That is not the question that is in issue. We are not talking about policy matters which may or may not have the endorsement of the electorate in this situation. We are talking about fast moving executive responses to international war and peace, military situations. They are quintessentially government decisions for which the government of this day must bear the responsibility. They are not the kinds of decisions for which this chamber should have the capacity to exercise a veto power. I do not want to be any ruder than I have been about the Democrats in this debate but with the track record of that Party in this place, we could have a situation that while we are waiting for the Democrats to make up their minds as to what their attitude should be towards some important matter of war and peace, or the dispatch of troops overseas, the war in question could well be over on the basis of the experience we have had over the last few months. It is just not appropriate in matters of this kind. I can only repeat, quintessentially executive and Government matters-for the Democrats, or anyone else who exercise a balance of power when they do not constitute the majority parties, to act in this way. It is a fundamental point about the relationship of these chambers to each other and about the relationship of the legislative arm to the Executive arm in our parliamentary system of government.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the basis on which the Opposition expresses its view on this matter. We do not want to get into the pros and cons of particular adventures or to be accused in any sanctimonious fashion about retreating from our obligations to express condemnation about so many of these adventures which manifestly deserve that condemnation. We simply make it clear that we tread the high constitutional ground in expressing our opposition to the Democrats amendment in its present form and we hope that on mature reflection the Democrats and certainly the rest of the chamber will follow us in that direction. I move:
Proposed new clause 4A, proposed new section 50C, sub-section (2), leave out 'each House of the Parliament', insert 'the House of Representatives'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Should the defence of Australia be at the mercy and risk of the dithering of the Australian Democrats in this chamber? That is the question in this amendment. It is not a question of some high parliamentary sovereignty. It has always been the case in Australia that the Executive Government responsibly reviews defence situations. It makes decisions in the best interests of this country and brings those decisions to the Parliament for debate. In the amendment before us the Australian Democrats have brought forward an irresponsible veto power over the Executive Government, whether it is a Liberal or Labor government. I believe it is totally opposed to the tradition of executive responsibility in matters of defence for this amendment to be moved by the Democrats. I oppose it utterly. I agree with the great part of Senator Evans's speech and I only urge that he take the implications of his reasoning, that is to reject the amendment that the Opposition has put forward.
—We are sure we are right now that you and Evans agree.

—That may be so. It is a very rare situation when Senator Evans and I agree. But I ask that the Opposition take the full thrust of its argument and oppose its own amendment. For the same reason as it is inappropriate for the Democrats to have a veto, I believe it is inappropriate to have the dithering and delay of having to recall the House of Representatives to debate this question. The Opposition ought to reconsider its amendment and withdraw it. In effect, these two amendments delay the passage of this Bill. I do not believe there is any hope whatsoever of an amendment in either form being favourably considered by the House of Representatives. Then it becomes a matter of continual tossing of the Bill between the two Houses.
