I reject, as I said, putting the defence of Australia at the risk of the dithering Democrats of the Senate, and I oppose both amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is indeed a pity that Senator Teague came down from the high constitutional plane that Senator Evans was wont to try to tread. Unfortunately, Senator Evans only managed to get there once or twice. The interesting point we had from both speakers is that in no circumstances must we have any restraint about going to war; we must have no shortfall; we must have no debate; we must have no discussion at any time. Let us get this matter moving. Let us rush into war without a thought! Let us not have a parliamentary debate on the matter! The point the Australian Democrats have been making is that it is now time to reform this country, not to stand on the conservatism of Senator Evans and Senator Teague, which says that it is sufficient for a few people to make an announcement in Parliament-let us be very clear about this-that commits this country in its most serious form and in a most serious way. Of any action this Parliament may take, of any vote this Parliament may have, the vote about whether we should again enter a war must surely be the most serious.
—We are saying that it should be the House of Representatives.

—I am saying that it should not simply be the House of Representatives. I am talking about the Parliament, which at this time happens to constitute two Houses. I believe this Parliament ought to have a say in that most serious of decisions. Surely if we are to engage in a developing democracy we will take more and more away from the Executive, which up to the present has been merely a reflection of the old necessity to lean upon kings, emperors and dictators, and put it in the hands of the representatives of the people. That in Australia constitutes two Houses. I certainly believe that we could give two days to making a decision that is not merely about whether we are to pass another Customs amendment Bill or increase the amount of levy on an apple, or whatever else we want to do in this country. We spend two or four or six days on those matters. But no, when it comes to war we must not do that. We must not take even two days to commit this country to a course which possibly could lead not only to the death of some of our soldiers but also to the total destruction of this country. That is what we are talking about in modern warfare. I believe that in modern warfare at some stage or another it is necessary to bring to this Parliament-to both Houses-a decision about whether we are to commit this country on that line.
—Do you want one man to choose?

—It seems to me a pity that it is not possible for people here to think beyond the present numbers in this place. Senator Thomas referred to one person making the decision. He would allow one person in the form of the Prime Minister to make it but will not have the representatives of the people make it. If any government that has a majority in the House of Representatives is to commit our troops, surely it is possible for it to argue to this chamber, even if it does not have a majority, that that is a course upon which we must embark. Surely the Government is not trying to tell me that if the course of action is one which can be argued for in the community, is not one which divides us down the middle, as did the Vietnam war, but is one which has the support of the community, it would not have the support of this House? The type of proposition that is being put is that if the Government has the majority in the lower House, even if it does not have the majority in this House, by all means let it take this country into that type of war even though it will divide the country yet again. That is no problem at all; but we must spend time upon time on other inconsequential motions!

SPEECH.PARA: That is the type of proposition that is being placed before this Parliament, that in the future this chamber must be excluded from one of the most vital and most important decisions that any country could make. That is what the proposition is of those who are opposed to this motion. That is what is being proposed to this Committee. That is why we have moved this motion and that is why we will continue to press in the electorate our belief that that type of decision should no longer be a decision of an Executive, but of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not as yet spoken on behalf of the Government, so I should formally do so, although I think the Government's view on this subject is very well known. The position is that the Government opposes the amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats, and I will deal with it in a minute. The Government also is opposed to the amendment that has been moved to that amendment by the Opposition. The Government is opposed to the necessity for a parliamentary resolution, whether it be by both Houses or by the House of Representatives only, to a question of the kind that is raised in this amendment. The debate, and in particular Senator Macklin's contribution to it, would seem to indicate that the issue on which Parliament is to be consulted is simply an issue of whether Australia would send troops overseas in a war. In other words, as I understand Senator Macklin's argument, he was saying that Parliament ought to be consulted about whether Australia goes to war.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the amendment proposed by the Democrats goes very much further than that. It provides that members of the Defence Force may not be required to serve beyond the territorial limits of Australia except in accordance with parliamentary resolution. Australian members of the Defence Force may be required to serve beyond the territorial limits of Australia in a host of different situations. The Democrats' amendment contains some exceptions to that rule, but the exceptions, of course, are by no means exhaustive of the various situations which may arise not just to a defence unit or a force but to a member of the Defence Force. It is not an issue at all of whether Australia is to go to war or to give an expeditionary force or something in the old traditional sense. It is an extremely wide proposition and one which would be quite unworkable in ordinary situations that crop up. Even if some attempt is made to exclude those situations, there are bound to be others cropping up which will not be excluded and Parliament will have to deal with them. I make the point that that is not by any means the ground on which the Government is opposing the amendment. Let me hasten to say that.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better have a better ground than that or I would even support it.

—I am just saying that this is the nature of the amendment that has been proposed. It is an extraordinarily unworkable sort of amendment and one which might be expected from Senator Mason, who obviously has had very little experience in these matters.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, the Government is also just as much opposed to the proposition put forward by Senator Evans that decisions of these kinds should require the support of the House of Representatives. If there were a case for Parliament to approve decisions of this kind by the Executive I think the proper course would be to do it by an Act of Parliament or by the whole Parliament, not just by one section of the Parliament. But I adopt-the Government basically adopts-the arguments that Senator Evans put forward, arguments which I think completely negative the amendment he has moved. The Government rests its case, as Senator Evans put it, on the high ground of constitutional tradition, propriety, legality and, if I may say so, sound government. This is essentially an Executive decision.

Of course the Parliament does have a major role to play in these matters. The Executive cannot raise forces or money to sustain forces without the Parliament. Parliament can express its views in relation to the decisions made on these matters. Government and the Executive take great pains to try to ascertain public opinion on these sorts of decisions. But essentially these decisions have to be made by governments, and they have to take the responsibility for them. Governments stand or fall by the propriety of their decisions. The Government would be deeply opposed to and concerned about any derogation of that very important principle of the responsibility of governments under our constitutional system.

All sorts of arguments and detail can be advanced. Senator Harradine commenced to advance an argument during the second reading stages of the legislation. I am pleased he has returned to the chamber and I hope he will have an opportunity to expand further that argument. In the world in which we live a whole variety of situations face governments. There may be a variety of immediate emergencies; there may be a need to send troops overseas to prevent emergencies occurring; or there may be different levels of an infinite variety of hostilities. These situations can be properly dealt with only by the Executive. They are not appropriate for decisions of the Parliament. As I have said, the Parliament, representing the people, has always had in these situations ample opportunity to express views about these decisions. In the end, Parliament has enormous control because of its power over the purse and its power of raising defence forces. Amendments to legislation may well be required and large volumes of legislation are always required, as we saw in the national security regulations during the war years. There is ample opportunity for parliamentary consideration and parliamentary control in the making of decisions of these kinds, but the actual decisions themselves are essentially Executive decisions under our constitutional system.

I am delighted that Senator Evans has supported that very basic constitutional principle. I am delighted further that he has not been seduced by arguments that the United States has these sorts of provisions, because unfortunately he is sometimes seduced by those comparisons. Comparisons with the United States are quite inappropriate in this case. The United States Senate has to ratify treaties and all the vast range of appointments to government. There is just no comparison between the United States constitutional system, and certainly the position of its Senate under the United States Constitution, and our situation. I also place on record the Government's opposition to this amendment, on the high constitutional principles which, as I have already said, have been well enunciated by Senator Evans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleague Senator Mason and the amendment proposed by the Australian Democrats which provides that, before Australian troops are committed overseas, such a decision by the Executive would need the support and vote of the majority of both Houses of Parliament. Senator Evans, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, moved an amendment that such approval need be by only one House of Parliament, namely, the House of Representatives. I hope I do not embarrass Senator Evans by calling him a close personal friend of mine for whom I have an unbounded admiration and affection. Quite often we exchange pleasantries here and, while the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) was speaking, Senator Evans accused me of being embarrassed about Vietnam stating that that was why I was taking such a strong stance on this question. I readily concede that I, Don Chipp, am embarrassed about Vietnam. I am embarrassed; my conscience is troubled about the years in which I opposed the Jim Cairnses, the Labor politicans of this world who wisely opposed our involvement in Vietnam. I wonder what sort of a result we would have if we had a secret ballot of members of all political parties in both chambers on the question: 'Do you approve in retrospect, with the wisdom of hindsight, Australia's involvement in Vietnam?'. How many would vote that we did the right thing?
—Of course they would.
—People like Senator Chipp.

—It is predictable that Senator Watson and Senator Walters would vote for it but I am talking about the thinking members of this Parliament, the people who do learn some of the lessons of history. An overwhelming number of the members of this Parliament would admit that the decision was wrong. If someone wants to make political capital about my situation at that time he is entitled to do so. But at least I hope to be forgiven in some part by having the grace to admit that I was wrong in supporting the decision; indeed, at the time I was Minister for the Navy. I do not resile from the accusation of my friend Senator Evans. Perhaps it is because of Vietnam that I am so sensitive.

SPEECH.PARA: I will tell the Senate a story that is not new. It has been told several times; I told it in a book which I wrote a few years ago. I had been in the Parliament only a couple of years when one evening a very close friend of mine, the Honourable Senator Shane Paltridge, a close confidante of Sir Robert Menzies, said: 'Chipp, for some extraordinary reason the old man has an affection for you. He is deeply upset. Will you go in and see him?'. Being a humble back bencher, terrified, as all of us were, of Menzies, I hesitated to go in without an appointment but Paltridge, wonderful man that he was, said: 'Look, go in. He needs a friend'. I went in and, to my surprise, Sir Robert Menzies welcomed me. He sat there for a while and then said: 'I want to tell you something. I have a problem. This afternoon Cabinet agreed to send troops to Vietnam. We do not yet have a request from the Vietnamese Government to send troops. We do not have a request from the Americans and some bastard in Cabinet has leaked it to the Press'.

TALK.START.PARA: —'I want you to tell me what to do'.

—Go for a jog around the lake, Senator Walters. It would improve a lot of things. The incident happened in mid-afternoon. During the dinner hour a telex or some form of telegram came from Saigon resembling a formal request by the then Vietnamese Government that Australia send troops to fight in a war. If the oddity that the Australian Government had already decided to send troops before it had been asked to do so does not impact itself upon Senator Walters, I should not be surprised. But that was the fact of the matter. In the event, on that day Sir Robert Menzies, the Prime Minister, was saved by the dinner gong because the Press and the Opposition had the story and were about to embarrass the Government over the issue but the dinner hour intervened and at 8 o'clock he was able to come out and announce the participation of Australian troops in Vietnam. Of course, he then received the unanimous support of all members of the Liberal Party and the Country Party, including me. The outraged cries at that time of the Labor Party, which I repeat was subsequently proven to be right, did not mean a damn thing.
—Is it true that the actual telegram came from Armidale?

—I love the frivolous and mischievous interjections of my friend Senator Button. Normally I enjoy them. But, if he will forgive me, I can do without them this time because we happen to be talking about the very serious matter of the commitment of Australian soldiers to a bloody, fighting war overseas. I just wonder whether Senator Teague, for whom I have regard, would believe that that is the proper way in which to commit young Australians to fighting and dying overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: What are the Democrats saying? We are saying that in a situation like that it should be the Parliament of this country that makes that decision. What Senator Evans and Senator Teague are basically saying is that it is outrageous that we should entrust to the democratically elected representatives of the people the task of making this decision. What a dreadful proposition the Democrats are putting up! To coin the phrase used by Senator Evans when he was describing some of his own colleagues, why entrust some ratbags elected to this place to make such a fundamental decision? All wisdom is focused in the magical group of people who comprise the Cabinet. I have a list of the present Cabinet, which is made up of 14 people-13 males and one female. To my knowledge only one of those people has been engaged in overseas service. That is no reflection on them; I merely state it for the record. What makes that list of 14 people so magical that they can commit Australia to a fighting, bloody war overseas? What is wrong with a proposition that enables democratically elected representatives to have a say in this matter?

What are we talking about? As Senator Macklin says, this is not an amendment to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. We are not debating a banking Bill. This is about the ultimate obscenity-war. If there is any question about which the elected representatives of the people should have a say on whether to commit their young men and women it is war. I hope that nobody in this chamber is stupid enough to believe that the next war will be like a Vietnam war. I hope nobody here is idiotic enough to believe that those kinds of hostilities will be played by the so-called gentlemanly rules of Vietnam, where the worst thing that happened was the use of friendly napalm. The next war will be something almost indescribable in terms of my personal comprehension.

I now turn to Senator Evans's points. I must say that I cannot understand the basis of his logic. He talked about high constitutional principles or whatever. But he says that the Executive should have the say about sending troops overseas to fight and die.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the House to which it is responsible.

—And the House to which it is responsible. But he says that it is not the other House, that the House under no circumstances must be consulted. By very definition of what Senator Evans has just said the Executive on that day-the day the troops are being committed-would have the majority in the lower House and, judging by the performance of the lower House over the years, would have a rubber stamp on any action it took. What a farce, what a humbug it is for Senator Evans to say: 'Let one House of Parliament make this decision'. What he means is: 'Let the Executive make the decision unencumbered and unhindered'. Stripped to its naked terms, that is exactly what the Labor Party wants. If he were to tell me that the lower House is more democratically elected than the Senate that would be a queer argument for a Labor politician to put. Under the present system, at any one time a candidate needs 51.5 per cent of the popular vote even to look at gaining office in the lower House, whereas at least in this chamber where we have a system of proportional representation, if a political party gets X per cent of the vote it gets X per cent of the seats. I have just about had the ridiculous argument that this House is not democratically elected. I would have thought that this chamber is one of the most democratically elected Houses in the Western world, as is the Tasmanian legislature.
—When your vote as a Victorian is worth one-tenth a Tasmanian's or one-quarter of a Queenslander's?

—I remind Senator Evans of something that I did not think he would need to be reminded of. Five Australian Democrats and one Independent, Senator Harradine, can do absolutely nothing in this chamber unless at any one time we have the support of 28 other senators in the chamber. He knows that there has to be a majority. What rubbish his argument is. I come to this point: If Senator Evans is saying that only one House should make the decision, approve the decision or ratify the decision as to whether to send Australian troops overseas, how can he adopt a stance that a Bill, say, to amend the national service Act must go to two Houses?
—We are very happy to get rid of the Senate's vote in relation to that, too. I have made that clear.

—I acknowledge Senator Evans's interjection. Let it be recorded in Hansard that the Labor Party-this comes from the shadow Attorney-General-now says: 'If Mr Fraser wants to introduce conscription or an amendment to the Act he can do it unilaterally. That is okay with the Labor Party; it need not come to this Senate'. I find that to be a quite remarkable revelation from the Labor Party. I would have thought that the commitment of troops to Vietnam in the early 1960s was inevitably followed by conscripts. I repeat what I said during the election campaign: Mr Fraser can commit troops to the Sinai because he has Executive power but if that becomes a Vietnam-type situation with an escalation in the conflict, if he then finds that the regular army cannot achieve what it is supposed to achieve and if at that stage he needs conscripts which he would get if a shooting war broke out in that part of the world, there is no way in which-I hope while the Democrats and the Labor Party are here-Mr Fraser could have passed a Bill which sought to re-introduce conscription for overseas service. In view of Senator Evans's recent interjection I would be delighted if he were to say in this place-I think he owes it to this Parliament-that in that hypothetical situation the Democrats at least would have the support of the Australian Labor Party in vetoing a Bill to conscript people to the Sinai.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no wish to prolong this debate but I cannot allow misrepresentation of the kind that has just been uttered by Senator Chipp to pass without remark and uncorrected. The position is that the Australian Labor Party's attitude with respect to the powers of this Senate has been placed on record in our platform as our long term perspective. It is perfectly clear that we do not think the Senate ought to have any powers at all in respect of any class of legislation and that ultimately a constitutional amendment-it is hoped it can be achieved by way of consensus, by agreement-can be reached whereby the powers of this place are simply reduced to those of delay and whereby this place can assume its proper role as applying the spotlight of scrutiny on legislation rather than having power of life or death over it. We disagree about the long term role of this place. That disagreement is perfectly clear.

SPEECH.PARA: Until that millennium comes about, our present position in respect of the powers of this place are equally clear. They have been articulated by numerous senators on this side of the chamber on numerous occasions particularly over the last six months. We will not vote against any Government Bill which is crucial to the Government's survival in office, and in particular the Supply and Appropriation Bills come into that description, nor will we vote against any Government Bill, whatever its character and however obnoxious we find it to be, if the Government has a clear-cut electoral mandate for the Bill. That is the position which we have adopted. That is the position which I believe has been understood by the Australian Democrats before today. I find it inconceivable that this Government could ever-certainly it could not at the moment-claim an electoral mandate for a conscription Bill of the kind that Senator Chipp hypothetically advanced and without such a mandate of course we would regard it as obnoxious and of course we would vote against it. But we would be placed in a very difficult position if the Government did go to the next poll and state its willingness, its desire, its intention to put a conscription Bill to the people. If we fought against that, as undoubtedly we would if that were a part of the Government's program, and if the Government was then elected on that program, consistent with the principles we have enunciated in this place today we would find it very difficult to oppose such a Bill because we are--

TALK.START.PARA: —We would have no difficulty.

—The Democrats have no difficulty whatsoever in changing their minds, as they change their socks, as the wind changes. They have a fantastic degree of flexibility when it comes to grandstanding upon whatever grandstand happens to be erected and available for them to prance upon at any given time.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to prolong this already overprolonged consideration. The issues and principles which we are considering are perfectly clear. I could say many more things about this legislation but I think it is time that we all exercised a bit of self-restraint and got on with the business of this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason, when he speaks, may be able to clarify a couple of points I am concerned about in respect of the Australian Democrats' proposed new clause 4A, which provides that the Governor-General may declare that an emergency exists and that emergency ceases to exist the day after either House of Parliament fails to vote positively authorising service in territories beyond Australia. That is the position as I see it. There are exemptions in proposed new section 50C (7). But as I was going to say in the second reading debate, I envisage that any government of this Commonwealth of whatever political character may wish to commit forces to serve abroad in, say, the following three categories of service: First, unilaterial action by Australia in its immediate area, for example, Papua New Guinea and its territories in the South Pacific; secondly, action in conjunction with its allies, for example, the United States, or under an international agreement such as the five-power agreement; and thirdly, action under United Nations or international auspices.

SPEECH.PARA: One problem that I have with the amendment is that it assumes that forces would be committed for any of those purposes to meet an emergency situation. But it may also be to prevent an emergency from developing. For example, a friendly government which forsees trouble may request the Commonwealth for the presence of Australian troops. I have already given the example of Papua New Guinea, not Australia, sending troops to the New Hebrides. It was not an emergency; it was a request for troops and that request was met by Papua New Guinea. The Australian Democrats' amendment seems to run into certain difficulties. It assumes that Australian troops would only be committed abroad in an emergency apart, of course, from those exceptions in proposed new sub-section (7) which do not meet my point. It allows troops to be despatched immediately, but provides that they may not be required to continue to serve except in accordance with a motion agreed to by both Houses of Parliament within two days. Let us suppose that there is a real emergency, that troops have been flown, say, to a neighbouring country, and that Parliament, when it meets two days later, fails to approve the despatch of troops.

TALK.START.PARA: —They come back.

—Yes, they come back, but their immediate withdrawal might have disastrous consequences not only in the theatre itself but also to civilians in the theatre. On the other hand, let us suppose there is no emergency but merely the prospect of a future emergency which, it is believed, might be averted by the presence of Australian troops. Under the Australian Democrats' amendment, troops could only be despatched if the Governor-General proclaimed that an emergency existed requiring members of the Defence Force to serve abroad. In the circumstances envisaged in that situation, I suggest that such a proclamation may not be warranted and, indeed, may not be acceptable to the power that is seeking the support of the Australian troops and seeking our presence. It might also not be acceptable to an ally with whom Australia proposes to take some joint action. Some of the countries that I envisage may be involved in this would certainly be embarrassed if Australia declared that there was an emergency situation in that particular country when, in fact, the request had been made on the basis of simply preventing the emergence of an emergency.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the comments made by Senator Mason in respect of similar provisions in other countries: I think he mentioned West Germany, Japan and the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Canada.

—And Canada. I am sorry. I do not think the precedents cited by Senator Mason carry much weight in the case of Australia. Let us take as examples the German and Japanese cases. They are exceptional cases in that they derive from the defeat of both of those countries in World War II. That is clear to everyone. Much was made by Senator Mason of the Japanese self-defence forces, but he must remember that the constitutional provisions surrounding the establishment of those forces were made as a result of the defeat of Japan in World War II. Canada's geographical position and its responsibilities in its own area-which is, of course, also the area of the United States-are very different from those of Australia. I think Senator Evans adverted to the United States of America. Of course, it is governed by the Constitution, but that has given rise to great difficulties. A compromise arrangement has arisen out of the Vietnam war, but those of us who have been to the United States and have discussed this matter with key people, both in the administration and outside, know that there is an uneasy situation in that country about the present arrangement. The most important point that should be recognised is that Congressional authorisation has not really worked.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I should like to deal with the aspect of both Houses of Parliament and then the amendment put forward by Senator Evans. Certainly the latter is more acceptable than the former. As has been said, it is impossible, surely, to provide to this chamber the power of determinant in respect of this most important and, as Senator Chipp said, I think, horrendous-or some such word-matter, the possibility of war. Surely that is an area for the elected government including all the back up that is required in consideration whether to commit troops in a situation of modern warfare. That might seem to be leading me towards the acceptance of what Senator Evans said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, no.

—Oh, no! But the problem there, as I saw it, in the example that has been given by Senator Chipp, was that Parliament was meeting on that particular day and the matter was the subject of scrutiny by Parliament. But it made no difference.
—Think of what would have happened if the Democrats had been there.

—Yes, I hate to think of that. The point that I want to make is that the decision is the responsibility of the elected government. If the Prime Minister makes the decision so that the Governor-General gives the authorisation to commit forces overseas, surely that is a major decision. If the representatives of the people object to that decision, that Prime Minister deserves the censure of the Parliament, deserves the censure of the House. The opportunity to move a censure motion against the Prime Minister is available to the House at any time.
—That is if it has the numbers.
—Oh, no. The honourable senator is saying if it has the numbers. Under his proposition, if it had the numbers it would go through anyhow.
—But not if it came to this House.

—That is where our paths divide. We are not in the position, surely-no one in his or her right mind would suggest that the Democrats and Brian Harradine ought to be in a position-to determine the issue whether troops are committed overseas. As the Leader of the Australian Democrats says, it is a matter of a most grave situation. If the elected representatives of the people object to such a decision, they have the right, through the forms of either House of Parliament, to censure the government and, in the case of the House of Representatives, it has the power to censure the Prime Minister. If the censure motion is carried, as it could well be if it were so contentious, with some of the Government members supporting the censure, it would be on the Prime Minister's head to resign and for the government to resign at that stage. What is more likely to happen is that beforehand the party members of the political party in power would force the resignation of the Prime Minister and a new Prime Minister would take his place. All that could happen without affecting the integrity of our armed forces.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view, that is a most important consideration and that is why I propose not to support, particularly, the amendment moved by Senator Mason and I regret that I am not able to support the amendment moved by Senator Evans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take the points made by Senator Harradine one by one in the order in which he made them.
—Is that necessary?

—I will deal with them briefly. I think I am the best judge when I rise to speak of what it is necessary to say, not Senator Evans, with respect. He speaks for long enough in this place, as is well known. I mentioned earlier that proposed new sub-section (7) could be extended. Senator Harradine referred to the existence of an emergency. I take his point. The amendment would be improved by saying 'an emergency or other situation'. That probably covers the point that he made. This could easily be put in an amendment if it were to go that far. He said that another power might be offended or have difficulty because our Parliament had to approve of our forces going to war. I suggest that our law should hardly be bent to suit other people to that extent. This does not cause any difficulty. People who want to have any sort of relationship with Canada know perfectly well the provisions in that country's law. Nobody thinks anything of that. They have to be abided by.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine referred to the availability of a censure motion. I would think it most unlikely, where the Executive has firm control of the House of Representatives, which is, of course, the case, that a censure motion could be moved. It would be very unlikely to have any possibility of being carried. I find generally the Labor-Liberal correspondence on this matter quite disquieting, although, for the sake of formality, the Australian Democrats will oppose Senator Evans's amendment. We believe it is axiomatic that the House of Representatives is a rubber stamp of the Executive. That is precisely what it is. I reiterate that even its own Speaker has said so publicly in recent days. In that case there is very little doubt about it. It is a completely hollow mockery to suggest that any virtue whatsoever could be achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Parliamentary debate. The spotlight of scrutiny.

—What value is that? He knows as well as I do-Senator Tate made this point-that plenty of other forms of the House would be available to initiate debate on such a matter such as the raising of a matter of public inportance. In other words, what Senator Evans is offering is hollow, as he knows.
—Parliament may not be sitting and this will force it to come back. That is why it is important. Acknowledge that.

—I acknowledge that one small point. If the 48-hour clause were allowed at least Parliament could be recalled. But I still suggest to Senator Evans that that is not enough. That is our view. We oppose Senator Evan's amendment. We are deeply disquieted that the Labor Party should take the view that it does. There are questions of political principle which cannot rationally be applied to the real world. That is what Senator Evans is doing in this case. He is taking a view that he has of this place and the other place and he is looking at the real world, I suggest, through a completely distorted set of spectacles as a result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to reply to two matters which Senator Chipp brought up in his very fiery and rhetorical way which, I think, completely misrepresented the position of the Australian Labor Party. At one stage he accused the Labor Party of saying : 'Perhaps it is all right that Mr Fraser can do what he likes, for example send troops to Sinai, by sheer Executive power'. The Labor Party is saying by its amendment that even a future Labor government should be stripped of an unfettered power to commit Australian troops to serve abroad. We say that a government should not pretend to be exercising some royal prerogative to wage war, unfettered by the opinion of the elected representatives of the people. We say that Mr Fraser, or Mr Hayden after 1983, should be able as the Prime Minister, the leader of the government, to commit Australian troops to serve abroad only if he retains the confidence of the House of Representatives. That is a much larger and more democratic advance than the proposition which Senator Chipp tried to put as the position of the Labor Party when he said that we were in agreement with the Prime Minister of the day exercising unfettered Executive power to commit Australian troops abroad.

SPEECH.PARA: We say that no government, no Prime Minister, no Cabinet, no party room majority can decide that. It has to be decided by positive resolution of the House of Representatives. The Labor Party will continue to maintain that that intense link which should exist between the House of Representatives and the Government, so that only the House of Representatives can create or bring down a government, should have its effect in this very important area, this matter of vital national concern, the sending of Australian troops abroad. The failure to pass such a motion would, in our view, be the equivalent of a censure motion such as Senator Harradine says may be a substitute. We prefer to see the House of Representatives members themselves in that forum confronted with a decision, debating it on the record and resolving one way or another the question of sending Australian troops to serve beyond our territorial limits. Secondly, in a sloppy use of language Senator Chipp asked: 'What is wrong with the proposition that the Senate should have a say in this?' We say that, in our bicameral system, there is nothing wrong with members of this chamber having a say, debating the matter at length, being part of the deliberative process of the Australian people, fulfilling their role as elected representatives, albeit elected in a different manner to that of the House of Representatives, but not in a manner which entitles them to hold a threat of veto over the House of Representatives and its resolution. This is the point. Senator Chipp and the Australian Democrats want to go beyond the deliberative function, the review function, the scrutiny function, the full debate within this chamber. They want it to have a power of veto over the Executive which retains the confidence of the House of Representatives in the committing of troops beyond the territorial limits of Australia.

Senator Chipp, in agreement with Senator Macklin, said: 'Don't think for one moment that the next war will be like the one fought in Vietnam'. He evoked visions of a final holocaust. I say that it is most likely that Australian troops will be involved in another commitment to our north. Let us for a moment imagine that once again, Indonesia is engaged in confrontation with Malaysia and that the government of that friendly Commonwealth country calls on the Australian Government to provide troops in order to withstand some invasion by Indonesia. Let us say that the Labor government agrees that that ought to be the case. But let us say that a conservative coalition of senators, in a temporary majority in the Senate, thinks that, rather than confronting Indonesian troops in Malaysia, perhaps Indonesia ought to be pacified in some way and those troops not be committed. That is a more likely scenario than anything conjured up by Senator Chipp. Some people would want to substitute Papua New Guinea for Malaysia, but I think that Papua New Guinea has different ties on our hearts, right across the broad spectrum of Australian politics. So I have used the example of Malaysia and confrontation. I say that no Australian government which retains the confidence of the House of Representatives should be put in a position where it is vetoed by a Senate of a different political complexion in a matter such as that.

I entered the Parliament because I changed my view about Australian politics in the course of the Vietnam war. I certainly take umbrage at Senator Chipp's implying that many of us in the Senate are not concerned about the commitment of Australian troops abroad. We on this side are extremely conscious of the enormity of what one is doing in asking a fellow Australian to serve overseas, beyond our territorial limits. We are also conscious of the proper constitutional arrangements, which should serve this country not only in questions of war and peace but also throughout the whole of our political and national arrangements. We say that the intense relationship forged between the House of Representatives and the Executive ought to be the criterion which governs our arrangements in this case.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out of Senator Mason's amendment (Senator Evans's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be inserted (Senator Mason's amendment) be inserted.
Question resolved in the negative.
Proposed new clause negatived.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, clause 8, proposed new section 116A, sub-section (2), line 19, at end of sub-section, add ''being a country which has before the making of such declaration enacted legislative provisions having equivalent effect to the provisions of this Part in respect of members of the Defence Force''.
(2) Page 5, clause 8, proposed new section 116C, sub-section (5), line 18, after ''section'', insert ''and subject to sub-section (5A)''.
(3) Page 5, clause 8, proposed new section 116C, after sub-section (5), insert the following sub-section:

''(5A) (a) Where the Governor-General or an authorized person makes an order under sub-section (5), the order shall be laid before each House of the Parliament within 5 sitting days of that House after the making of the order.
(b) Any order which is not laid before each House of the Parliament in accordance with paragraph (a) shall be void and of no effect.

(c) An order laid before each House of the Parliament in accordance with paragraph (a) shall be deemed to have been revoked at the expiration of 10 days after the order has been laid before both Houses of the Parliament unless each House of the Parliament has by resolution declared that the order is approved.''.
(4) Page 6, clause 8, proposed new section 116F, add the following sub-section:

''(2) An authorized officer shall not issue a warrant under sub-section (1) unless he is satisfied on reasonable grounds that the person who is the subject of the warrant became an absentee without leave within the period of 2 years preceding the request referred to in that sub-section.''.
(5) Page 7, clause 8, proposed new section 116H, after sub-section (3) insert the following sub-section:
''(3A) (a) A warrant issued under sub-section (3) shall not be executed within 30 days after the warrant is issued.

(b) Within 30 days after a warrant is issued under sub-section (3), an application may be made to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal for a review of the decision by the Minister to issue the warrant, and a warrant which is the subject of such an application shall not be executed until the application has been determined.''.

The amendments are to proposed new sections 116A, 116C, 116F and 116H. I remind the Senate that I do not propose to explain or recount the arguments for these amendments again, except to say that amendments (1), (2) and (3) are about the reciprocity arrangements that we have proposed. We request a reasoned reply from the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on this matter since we did not get one in Mr Killen's letter which I quoted during the second reading debate. Amendments (4) and (5) contain our suggestions on the absence without leave provisions. Again we would appreciate a reasoned reply there. We request the Attorney-General to reply to another matter I raised in the second reading debate-the compensation provisions of the Bill and the crticisms made that they are insufficient in their application to young reservists who may be critically injured. With that I hope it will be unnecessary for me to rise further on these matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support all the Labor amendments except No. (4) which was moved in substantially the same form as it was moved in the House of Representatives. This is the amendment that seeks to introduce a limitation period of two years after which Australia would not apprehend absentees without leave from the forces of other countries who had requested assistance. This amendment seems unnecessary in view of proposed new section 168H which in effect gives the responsible Minister full discretion over what happens to the person concerned once he or she is apprehended. So, we do not propose to support that amendment or to introduce a similar one, but we support the remaining Labor amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is opposed to the amendments that have been moved by Senator Evans on behalf of the Opposition. I am surprised, although it is perhaps becoming less of a surprise, that the Australian Democrats have decided to support those amendments without having heard the arguments in the chamber which I understood--
—I put the argument during the second reading debate. I will bore you if you want.

—They had not heard the argument on the other side. The honourable senator assumes that because he gives an argument, everyone accepts it. The amendments deal with a variety of different matters, so it is not easy to deal with them all in one argument. The first amendment requires a limitation to be placed on the making of a declaration in relation to a country with which we wish to have arrangements for forces serving together. The amendment would simply require that the laws of that other country with which our forces were serving should be virtually the same as ours. That would be a very awkward proposition and would probably prevent such arrangements being made. Before arrangements are made with another country for our forces to serve with its forces, arrangements are entered into. As far as posible we seek to avoid our defence forces being subjected to laws to which we would have grave opposition; for instance, the death penalty. Other than that, the principle is that when forces are in another country they are subject to the laws of that country. For that reason the Government is opposed to that amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: The two other amendments which deal with much the same matter of defence forces serving with other forces would require declarations being made about the matter being subject to disallowance. The Government's opposition to that is really the same as the stance the Government took in the debate we have had recently. These sorts of arrangements are very much the same as for decisions on whether troops are to be sent abroad at all. Therefore, as it is an Executive decision, we do not think it is appropriate-for all the reasons that were canvassed in the previous debate-that those declarations or orders should be the subject of disallowance.

The other amendments deal not with this issue but with deserters from forces of another country who have come to Australia. There are long-standing provisions in regard to the return of deserters to the forces of the country to which they belong. The Government believes these provisions are perfectly adequate. They have been amended from existing provisions to give very wide discretion to and control by the Minister in relation to these situations. We do not think it at all appropriate that these powers should be limited to a period of only two years previous to the requests that have been made in this matter because that would be far too restrictive. As to making an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, we do not see why that is appropriate in a circumstance of this kind. The people involved are deserters from a foreign force and on the basis of comity they should be returned to that force. The question of whether they were deserters, which may be some ground for a claim being made, could be quite appropriately raised by these people under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The Government does not see why there should be any special appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal about the merits of decisions of this kind.

Finally, Senator Evans asked me whether I would comment upon another matter altogether which is not the subject of amendment but which he raised in his speech in the second reading debate. That relates to compensation for reservists. The only point that I think was raised in relation to this aspect of the Bill was that the provision of compensation based upon the wages or earnings of a young reservist may not be very satisfactory because his earnings or wages may be lower than what he would receive as a reservist. The point has been noted by the Minister for Defence (Mr Killen). I understand that it was raised in the other place. This legislation does not determine a scheme; the legislation gives the Minister the power to determine a scheme. The Minister will take into account the point that has been raised by the Opposition in formulating his determination which has yet to be made.
Amendments negatived.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Durack) read a third time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Powers of Committee and Appointment of Parliamentary Librarian

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 24 November, on motion by Senator Button:
1. That the Senate is of the opinion that the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee should be given specific terms of reference, including the power to pass substantive resolutions.
2. That the President be requested not to proceed with the appointment of a new Parliamentary Librarian until the applications have been presented to the Committee for its consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek leave to amend my motion to read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. That the Senate is of the opinion that the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee should adopt specific terms of reference, including the power to pass substantive resolutions within those terms of reference.
2. That Mr President be requested not to proceed with the appointment of a new Parliamentary Librarian until the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee has
(a) adopted the terms of reference referred to in (1) above, and
(b) has approved by resolution of the procedures to be followed in appointment of the new Librarian.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can we have a copy of that amendment?

—Copies are now being circulated. For the information of honourable senators, the motion has been amended in order to try to accommodate, more widely, the views of individual senators. The new motion incorporates two points. Rather than the Library Committee be given terms of reference-it is not quite clear who they would be given by, but presumably it would be by both houses of Parliament; we do not want to run the risk of falling between two stools on that issue-it is suggested that the Parliamentary Library Committee adopt its terms of reference.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point, which was the subject matter of debate in the Senate on Tuesday night, is that you, Mr President, be requested not to proceed with the appointment of a new Parliamentary Librarian until certain things have happened; namely, the adoption of the terms of reference and the approval by resolution of the procedures to be followed in the appointment of a new Librarian. This second point is designed specifically to meet objections which were made in the debate the other night that perhaps the Parliamentary Library should not be too closely associated with the actual appointment of a Librarian but at least it should be aware of the procedures which will be followed and have cognisance of those procedures. I interrupted Senator Harradine to make these observations and to seek leave to amend the motion in the way in which I have indicated. I take it that I have a right of reply in terms of the termination of the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. The honourable senator has a right of reply.
—I express my gratitude to the Senate for its liberal approach to this question and allow the floor to Senator Harradine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Previously a proposition was put forward which expressed the view that the President of the Senate be requested not to proceed with the appointment of a new Parliamentary Librarian until the applications had been presented to the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee for its consideration. I think it is important for the Senate to understand that what Sentor Button has put forward is to be read in place of that second part of the motion. Whilst I have only just seen the amendment, it seems to me that there is nothing in the amended second part of the motion which should give honourable senators any concern. I believe the original concern was that members of parliament as such ought to be involved in the actual appointment of the Parliamentary Librarian. To a number of honourable senators that appeared to be not in the best interests of the continued apolitical nature of the Parliamentary Library and its information and research services. It was felt-in fact the point was made-that the responsibility devolves by legislation on the President and Mr Speaker to make the appointment. They are the statutory officers who have this responsibility. In respect of the appointment of the Parliamentary Librarian they stand in place of the Public Service Board. No parliamentarian or group of parliamentarians can take away from them that right.
—But both of them are parliamentarians.

—I understand that. The honourable senator misunderstood what I said previously. In my view politicians should not have control over the recommendation for the appointment of the Parliamentary Librarian. Apparently we are not even discussing that now as paragraph 2 of the motion has been amended. Although I have only just been given a copy of the motion I cannot see anything in paragraph 2 to which I could take offence. Paragraph 1 is straightforward and states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee should adopt specific terms of reference, including the power to pass substantive resolutions within those terms of reference.
I cannot see anything wrong with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is it right for a committee of the Senate to adopt its own rules?

—No, it is not. That is the whole point. It is not a committee of the Senate but a committee of both Houses. Senator Button quite rightly said that if the situation was left simply as it was before, and the Committee was given terms of reference, in fact, it could fall between two stools-the House of Representatives and the Senate. In normal circumstances it is not unusual, of course, for the terms of reference of joint committees to be initiated in one House of Parliament and adopted in the other.
—Wouldn't that be better?

—With respect, I do not think it would. In my view, under current circumstances we would fall between two stools. But that is a matter of argument. I am not terribly fussed about it. If it is believed that the House of Representatives and the Senate should draw up those terms of reference jointly that is fair enough by me. But honourable senators should bear in mind that any proposition has to be adopted by a positive vote of both Houses of Parliament. That may not be possible under current circumstances. In order to allow the Committee to proceed I suggest that it might be appropriate to accede to the amended motion which has now been put forward by Senator Button.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the original motion moved by Senator Button and the amended motion. The current procedure in the Parliament is that by statute the Presiding Officers-yourself, Mr President, and Mr Speaker in the House of Representatives-jointly make arrangements for the departments of the Parliament, including the Joint House Department, the Parliamentary Library and Hansard. The Presiding Officers have a direct responsibility to make arrangements for those departments and to appoint the Parliamentary Librarian. There is nothing that this Parliament, or this chamber in particular, can do that can derogate from that authority given by statute except to change the statute and to take away those powers from the Presiding Officers. Motions put by an honourable senator that deny, limit or postpone the powers of Presiding Officers to go ahead with their proper statutory role of making provisions for the Library and appointing a new Parliamentary Librarian are out of order. The Senate is not empowered to adopt such a motion. I understand that the Parliament has appointed representatives from the Senate and the House of Representatives to a Presiding Officers advisory committee. This committee has no specific terms of reference. I think it should have specific terms of reference as this would clear up the kinds of questions that have been debated in the face of this motion.

SPEECH.PARA: It is understood that members of the House of Representatives and honourable senators who sit on the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee are acting in an advisory capacity to the Presiding Officers, both of whom are present and make arrangements for chairing and convening meetings. I, as one Government senator representative, am a member of the Library Committee and I understood from the beginning that we are there in an advisory role. If the Parliament wants to deny that advisory role, if it wants to take away from the authority and responsibilities of the Presiding Officers, I believe that the only way that that can be done is by direct amendment of the statute.

As for the intent of the motion that is before us, it is irresponsible because it directly seeks to deny the proper authority of the Presiding Officers. The motion, in its earlier form, stated that 'the President be requested not to proceed with the appointment of a new Parliamentary Librarian until the applications have been presented to the Committee for its consideration'. Senator Harradine has already indicated-and I support that part of his argument-that that would immediately bring the appointment under criticism-that it would involve politics and allow partisan attitudes to intrude into the decision.

I believe that the present members of the Library Committee can provide every area of advice about the kind of person who would best fill the position of Parliamentary Librarian and the arrangements for the administration of the Parliamentary Library. There is no limit to the advice that can be given by the Parliamentary Library. Advice having been given, it is still fully within the responsibility of the Presiding Officers to make decisions. The new form of the motion provides that the Presiding Officers cannot go ahead and make those decisions until, firstly, some terms of reference have been adopted by the Committee, and secondly, that some procedures that may be included in those terms of reference have been followed. I believe that that is just not in order. It will delay the exercise of the proper authority of the Presiding Officers to go ahead and appoint a new Parliamentary Librarian.

Senator Button is suggesting-I cannot understand how, if he is in his right mind, he could do so-that the Committee adopt its own specific terms of reference. Are we in the Senate of the custom of appointing a group of senators to a committee, giving it a name, and asking its members to go away somewhere, behind a bush or under a tree, and determine their terms of reference, their powers and what kinds of motion they may adopt? To adopt such a course would be entirely irresponsible. It is nonsense to suggest that any committee of this chamber would determine its own terms of reference. The practice always, as I have observed, is for individual senators to put a motion in this chamber and the Senate, as a whole, considers the terms of reference for a committee. The Senate as a whole determines the references to be undertaken by committees set up by the Senate. I believe the same holds for joint committees of the two Houses. Indeed, the people who are to serve on committees so defined are appointed by the Senate as a whole, not by one part of the Senate. I totally reject the notion that the Library Committee should somehow or other be set up so that it can determine its own specific terms of reference. There may be some merit in there being specific terms of reference for the Library Committee but that must be by resolution of the House of Representatives and the Senate.

A few other matters were raised in the earlier debate some days ago. One concerned the proposition that the Joint House Department, Hansard and the Department of the Parliamentary Library be amalgamated into one department. I reject that proposal for amalgamation until evidence has been presented to senators so that we may make some judgment in the matter. There has been a management consultant's report on the administration of these departments. I understand that some useful recommendations may have come from that report, but the report has not been in the hands of senators. We have not been able to assess the merits of any recommendations that have been proposed by that report. I agree with Senator Harradine that it makes sense, until we are persuaded otherwise, that the functions of the Library be administered by a body whose total terms of reference are to look after the Library and not to be muddled with other catering and Hansard functions in the Parliament. If there is merit in some parts of the administration of those three departments being amalgamated, such as the payment of salaries to staff, let that be put and be considered by the Senate or the House of Representatives. I do not support any of those amalgamations until the evidence for the amalgamation is put.

The other matter-and with this reference I conclude-is that the Library has received a reduced allocation of funds for the current financial year. As I understand it, that arises because of some misunderstandings about the way the submissions were received and discussed. There is regret on the part of some Ministers that there was such a reduction in the money allocated to the Library in this Budget. I, as a senator, very much regret the cut in funding and urge the Government to note very sympathetically the submission that will be received for the coming financial year and indeed, ahead of that, in the supplementary appropriation Bills early next year. I urge the Government to make an allocation to make up for those cuts so that, within this financial year, there is an adequate amount of money for the purposes of the Parliamentary Library. In summary, I do not believe that the motion is in order, particularly in its second form, in which it is now before the Senate. I urge senators to oppose every aspect of the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been a member of the Library Committee since early 1976. I think that technically I am still a member of the Library Committee even though I have submitted a resignation to you, Mr President. Along with all other Labor members on the Library Committee, I submitted a resignation from that Committee after we found ourselves to be in an untenable position especially in regard to the appointment of the new Parliamentary Librarian. I say that technically I am probably still a member of the Committee because I believe it takes a resolution of the Senate to discharge members from a committee once they are appointed to that committee.

SPEECH.PARA: It may be that, if we do not get around to having that type of resolution, I will stay on the Library Committee even though I have submitted that resignation. If I stay on the Library Committee and the terms of reference that we are proposing are adopted and I serve on the Library Committee again, I will be happy to do so. Even though there have been difficulties in the last year or so, my time on the Library Committee has been interspersed with some occasions when I have been able to make a contribution, and I am sure that I will be able to make a contribution again. There was some surprise, I think, when I said that I would be happy to serve on that Committee again. I do not think there should be that surprise because the resignation of every member of the Australian Labor Party on the Committee occurred almost over this specific issue of the appointment of the new Parliamentary Librarian. I admit that it was probably the final trigger, if one can use that word in the current political climate, that suggested to all of us that we should withdraw our services from the Committee.

I support the motion which is before us, although I have some reservations about one aspect of it which I will mention. I will outline how I think that reservation can be removed if we take some further action at a later stage. Certainly, in relation to the appointment of the Parliamentary Librarian, the President and the Speaker do have the power to appoint that person. But the appointment of a Parliamentary Librarian is a significant appointment for all members of the Parliament. That Librarian will control one of the parts of this Parliament which is absolutely vital to all members of parliament, especially members of the Opposition. For this reason it seems quite clear to me that members of the Parliamentary Library, being members who represent all members of the Parliament, both the House of Representatives and the Senate, should have some input into that appointment. How far that input should go is probably open to debate, but at the moment there is no input at all. It was mentioned by Senator Teague a few moments ago that the Library Committee is an advisory committee. But my experience is that when the crunch comes the Library Committee has no real role at all because if the President and the Speaker, in their wisdom, decide to take a specific course of action, that Committee's advice can be set aside. That is one of the reasons why Labor members recently found it necessary to withdraw from the Committee.

The Library Committee does not have any specific terms of reference. If it did have, all of us-not only the members of the Library Committee but also the Speaker and the President-would clearly know where we are going. I support the suggestion in the motion that we adopt specific terms of reference for the Library Committee, but I also share the concern of some other members that the Library Committee itself should adopt terms of reference. However, I do not see that to be an insurmountable difficulty. If we adopt specific terms of reference within the Library Committee, it seems to me that the logical extension to that would be to bring those terms of reference back at some stage and have them ratified by both the Senate and the House of Representatives. We could go a different way and suggest that specific terms of reference be introduced, say, in the Senate and then be sent to the House of Representatives for ratification, or vice versa. Then the Library Committee would have its terms of reference. It seems to me, however, that this might be a very long way round the problem. If the Library Committee were to meet, adopt terms of reference and then have those terms of reference ratified by both Houses of the Parliament, there would be some real backing to those terms of reference.

I have a concern that if we adopt terms of reference within the Library Committee and do not bring them back to the House of Representatives and the Senate, those terms of reference probably will not have much backing because, after all, the membership of the Library Committee changes from time to time. If we had the backing of the two Houses of Parliament, those terms of reference would really mean something. I support this motion as being an interim solution to the problem. However, I suggest that if we pass the motion and the Library Committee adopts specific terms of reference, those terms of reference should come back to both Houses of the Parliament so that the terms of reference which have been adopted can be approved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new amendments that Senator Button has moved to his original motion have nothing to do with the old motion. That motion was a totally different kettle of fish. We have an entirely new ball game. Indeed, Senator Colston has already spoken most effectively against Senator Button's amendment. He has admitted that the terms of reference laid down by the Library Committee, on its own, would have no credence at all. He suggested that the Committee work out some references and then bring them to the two Houses of Parliament for ratification. I think he has argued very effectively against Senator Button's motion. We can wipe off the first new amendment.
—Who was that?

—Senator Colston. Of course, Senator Colston being a member of the Library Committee-Senator Button is not a member-understands the situation a lot better. He realises that the 14 members of the Committee cannot possibly agree totally on terms of reference that can be given any credibility at all.
—That is nonsense. All the other joint committees do it.

—Senator Georges is not a member of the Committee either. It is possible that he has no idea of what has gone on. The Committee looked at the terms of Senator Button's motion. I agreed with them. I suppose that is one of the reasons I am not really surprised that he changed it. He moved then that the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee should be given specific terms of reference. I agree entirely with that because I believe there is some confusion on the Library Committee in regard to the part it plays. I think I have been a member of the Committee for as long as Senator Harradine. He claimed that he was the oldest member; I will give him the years in age but I will not give him the time of service. We both became members of that Committee soon after we came to this place. I think Senator Colston joined the Committee at about the same time. Members of the Committee were told originally that it was a committee formed to advise the Presiding Officers, to put forward the concerns of members and senators in this place and to look after their interests. The Committee is an advisory committee only; it was not created to advise the Presiding Officers on appointments to the Library. I do not believe for one minute that the 14 members of the Library Committee can possibly come up with any indication, no matter how many application forms we had before us, of who we believe should be the Parliamentary Librarian.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to ask Senator Button whether he does not agree that the Clerks of the two Houses, the Director-General of the National Library, and a senior representative of the Public Service Board make up a committee that should come up with recommendations to the Presiding Officers. That would be a completely non-political body. I believe he does gross disservice to those gentlemen by saying that they could come up with a recommendation for the position of Librarian with which either side of this Parliament might not be satisfied. I cannot agree that the Library Committee should adopt its own terms of reference. I certainly cannot agree that the Committee should approve of some other system to come up with recommendations. I think the recommendations of which the Library Committee was informed-the recommendations put by the Presiding Officers that this committee be non-political-are very justified. I certainly oppose all the amendments Senator Button has brought before the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In years past I have been a member of the Library Committee and therefore am acquainted with some of its functions. I oppose strongly the amended motion proposed by Senator Button. It is outside the competence of the Senate and contains some very severe defects. In the first place, one should not contemplate, as is the case in paragraph 1, that the Senate is of the opinion that the Joint Parliamentary Committee should adopt special terms of reference. The fact is that it would have no such powers. It is no good saying, as has Senator Colston, that perhaps we can rectify that by bringing the terms back to the Senate and having them passed. Any proposed terms of reference would have to be first considered by the Senate. We would need to know them to know what we had in mind as the remainder of the duties of the Library Committee. We are doing things the wrong way around. If we are proposing that the Library Committee should have fixed terms of reference, the first thing to do is to bring before the Senate a motion stating what those terms might be and have them adopted, amended or rejected.

SPEECH.PARA: Also the second part of paragraph 1 of the motion states:
. . . including the power to pass substantive resolutions within those terms of reference.

Thus, a knowledge of the terms of reference is fundamental to the understanding of that provision also. The words 'substantive resolutions within those terms of reference' could mean that the Committee could make executive type decisions. Here we are tonight not knowing what is meant by this motion. Do we mean that we intend to give to what is an advisory committee the power of executive decision making? Thus, the first paragraph is defective in its construction and its appropriateness for presentation to the Senate. It ought to be withdrawn, redrafted and, if it is to be pursued, terms of reference presented so that the Senate may have some understanding of what is intended, some explanation of whether the terms of reference are of an advisory or executive nature and therefore what could possibly be meant by the words, 'to pass substantive resolutions'. That defect, in itself, ought to be sufficient to defeat the motion. However, the second paragraph of the motion states:

That Mr President be requested not to proceed with the appointment of a new Parliamentary Librarian until the Joint Library Committee has (a) adopted the terms of reference referred to in (1) above, and-
We do not know what those terms are. We do not know whether they embody executive powers. The motion continues:
(b) has approved by resolution of the procedures to be followed in appointment of the new Librarian.

The essential, and first, thing for the Senate to decide is whether it intends to continue, as has been the case in the past, with the absolute freedom given the Presiding Officers to appoint key staff, free of direction. Paragraph 2 (b) of the motion is quite emphatic in stating that a new Parliamentary Librarian must not be appointed until the Library Committee has approved, by resolution, the procedures to be followed in such appointment. It provides, in effect, that the Committee shall prescribe to the Presiding Officers the procedures to be adopted in the appointment of the Librarian. In other words, it states quite emphatically that the freedom of the Presiding Officers to make arrangements for the appointment of staff is to be taken away. That represents a serious defect.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an important principle there that you ought to be supporting.

—Let Senator Georges stand up and speak if he wants to make a contribution. We have before us a motion which, on its face, is defective. It is defective in that it does not first seek the ratification of stated terms of reference. It asserts the power of a committee to make substantive resolutions, although that power has not been given to it and it proceeds to do something that is fundamentally opposed to everything that we have ever done in this Parliament or that, I believe, has ever been done in other parliaments. It proceeds to prescribe the right and power of the Presiding Officers to make appointments. The day that appointments in the various departments of the Parliament are made politically and not objectively and administratively will be a sad one for the Parliament. It is for the very reason that we want objective and apolitical decisions that we appoint Presiding Officers whose role is apolitical. On those grounds I find the motion totally defective in all its constructions. I believe that the Senate ought to have no recourse but to reject it roundly.

SPEECH.PARA: (Quorum formed).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing the Parliamentary Library Committee and the appointment of a new Parliamentary Librarian. We have before us an amended motion on whether the parliamentary Library Committee should be given or adopt terms of reference. Firstly, I want to deal with the arguments put by Senator Walters with regard to what I take to be a collective Government view hastily arrived at relating to the first paragraph of the amended motion which states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee should adopt specific terms of reference . . .

I do not think there is any substantial difference of opinion amongst a lot of honourable senators about the fact that the parliamentary Library Committee should have terms of reference. The debate is concerned with how it gets them. I think it is very silly for anybody, including Senator Walters and Senator Carrick, to come in here and seriously suggest that it is not a practical consideration for the Senate to have a debate about terms of reference for the parliamentary Library Committee when the Senate is composed, as Senator Walters went to great lengths to point out, of ill-formed people like me who do not have her vast experience in these matters. Neither the insult from nor the silliness of Senator Walters surprised me. That would be an extraordinary position to adopt. We would argue that the best way for the Library Committee to get some definition of its terms of reference is for that Committee to meet and to adopt for its own purposes terms of reference which have force only when they are adopted by each House of the Parliament. Honourable senators are in fact asking the parliamentary Library Committee to be a sub-committee in the drafting sense which would present terms of reference to the Parliament which would have to be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what your motion says.

—Oh, I have heard all of Senator Carrick's quibbles. He would put every quibblous legalistic argument to this place to put off a decision about any of these issues. That is precisely what he did. I indicated the other day that there is concern about this issue. The Minister, of course, is not prepared to meet that concern in any way.
