Nothing he has said has suggested that he is prepared to meet this concern. The Fraser Government has in the present situation half a library committee because of the concern.

SPEECH.PARA: Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting I was thinking on my feet, trying to hammer out a solution to the difficulty which the Senate has about the Library. During the dinner break further efforts were made to arrive at a solution.
—Fruitful talks.
—Fruitful talks have taken place, I understand. If Senator Macklin will deal with the matter I will respond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-There seems to be a growing agreement in this discussion that we should move two amendments to the original motion and have separate votes on those. The first amendment is firstly to delete the word 'adopt' in paragraph 1 and substitute the words 'be given' and, secondly, to delete the words 'within those terms of reference' so that paragraph 1 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee should be given specific terms of reference, including the power to pass substantive resolutions.
The second amendment is to delete paragraph 2 and substitute another paragraph. I move:
That the motion be amended to read as follows:
(1) 'That the Senate is of the opinion that the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee should be given specific terms of reference, including the power to pass substantive resolutions.

(2) That the President be requested to ensure that in the appointment of a new Parliamentary Librarian, the Parliamentary Library Committee be kept informed of the procedures to be adopted in the appointment of such Librarian, and given an opportunity to express its views.'

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is perfectly happy with the second part of the amendment. It would have been the contentious part. My only worry is the inclusion of the word 'substantive'. I do not want to be fiddling. I would prefer the motion to read 'pass resolutions' because I do not know whether Senator Macklin means Executive-type resolutions. If he deleted the word 'substantive' I think we would find agreement with him.

—In order to speed the process I indicate that the deletion of the word 'substantive' is acceptable to me. I am indebted to those honourable senators who have contributed in a co-operative way in the discussion to reach a resolution which is designed to alleviate a problem which many honourable senators have. The position now is that firstly, we recognise the arguments which have been put by Senator Walters and others about the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee being given terms of reference and, secondly, we want the consultative process to take place in connection with the appointment of a Parliamentary Librarian, if that is possible. I am indebted to the Senate. I will not waste the time of the Senate any further.
—Will you withdraw your motion?

—As the mover of the original motion I indicate that I accept the amendment moved by Senator Macklin. I accept paragraph 1 as amended and paragraph 2 in substitution. The motion, so amended, would then become the resolution of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek leave to omit the word 'substantive' in my amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the proposition. I will not now be proceeding with my foreshadowed further amendment in relation to the current proposals to amalgamate certain facilities of the Parliamentary Library with other departments, in view of the clear statement given by the President to the Joint Parliamentary Library Committee that no such action would be taken before that Committee had been informed of the matters at issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 August, on motion by Senator Macklin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the Repatriation Acts (Tuberculosis Pensions) Amendment Bill 1981, which was introduced by Senator Macklin on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The Bill does not achieve much, but it expresses the Senate's view that those people who were previously on the maximum tuberculosis pension before November 1978 should again receive this pension. There are several reasons for supporting this proposition. In fact, at the time the changes were made as a result of the Budget in 1978, the Opposition expressed the very concerns that Senator Macklin has expressed in his introduction of this Bill. The Bill does not seek to appropriate money and, by itself, does not achieve much. But, as I said, it at least expresses the Senate's view on this matter. The Hughes Government, as far back as 1922, first granted a permanent pension to those ex-servicemen who suffered from tuberculosis. At that time a letter was writen to all ex-servicemen who had tuberculosis. The letter contains the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of recent investigations of your war pension claim, your pension has been continued at the rate of 84/- per fortnight. This rate of pension will continue subject to further review but under no circumstances will the rate be reduced below the 100 per cent ordinary rate, namely, 84/- per fortnight.
That letter, which is in my possession, is dated December 1927. More than 20 years later World War II veterans got similar letters which read:

In conection with your war pension which is payable at the rate of #10 2s per fortnight, you are informed that pension will continue subject to further review, but will not under any circumstances be reduced below the ordinary total rate prescribed by the Australian Soldiers' Repatriation Act.

Certainly since those days the treatment of tuberculosis has improved. The prognosis of those who suffer from tuberculosis has improved to the extent that now most people who suffer from tuberculosis, those who suffer from pulmonary tuberculosis, will in fact be treated effectively and have very few residual after-effects. Certainly those who suffer from meningeal tuberculosis, or perhaps spinal tuberculosis, which is increasingly less common, may have after-effects. The ordinary case of pulmonary tuberculosis, if treated effectively, causes no difficulties and leaves very few residual problems. Therefore, it is reasonable to do what the Government did in 1978: It suggested that cases of tuberculosis discovered after that time, which, in most part would be treated very effectively, should be judged as all other repatriation disabilities were judged, that people should be judged on their degree of disability.

That was not the case when Mr Hughes introduced the legislation; it was not the case after World War II; it was certainly not necessarily the case when I first graduated in medicine and first dealt with cases of this nature. At that time, the treatment of tuberculosis was prolonged. It frequently involved surgical procedures which were disabling. People who had tuberculosis could not, in fact, join the Commonwealth Public Service as permanent public servants and receive full superannuation; they were restricted from many occupations. Because of the long and protracted nature of the treatment they frequently missed out on work and study opportunities to advance their future careers.

It was for this reason that over those years governments persisted with the policy that the tuberculosis pension should be paid, and should be paid at the full rate from then on. There was a further reason: Tuberculosis was more common then, as it is now, in those who were socially disadvantaged, those who were malnourished and those who lived in poor living conditions. It was felt at the time that we should do what we could to keep ex-servicemen out of situations where they were likely to have their tuberculosis exacerbated.

When all these ex-servicemen received their pensions they were given letters to the effect that they would stay on this 100 per cent rate of pension for life. Through their organisation and as individuals they have complained with some justice that successive governments of all political persuasions in this country have maintained this policy and have told them that they would receive this pension. Many of them, therefore, have organised their affairs on the assumption that they would receive this pension. They felt fairly well compensated for the difficulties they had suffered and the career opportunities and the superannuation they missed out on over the years by the fact that they had this 100 per cent pension, and they believed that the word of the government of the day would be kept. It is therefore unfair and quite wrong for the present Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) to write back to these people and say that the letter meant that their pension would not ever go above the level of the pension they received then, which was 84s in 1927 and #10 2s in the post-Second World War days. It is not fair or just for the Minister to suggest, as he has, that in fact what that letter meant was that that was the level that the pension would stay at. The level of pension to which the Minister referred and which was assumed by governments, by ex-servicemen's organisations and everyone else involved in this situation was, in fact, the 100 per cent disability pension.

In 1978 the Government changed the procedures because of the new situation. Because of the fact that tuberculosis could now be treated effectively it was reasonable for that situation to apply to those who suffered from tuberculosis after 2 November 1978. It was not reasonable for the Government to say that that set of conditions should apply to those who had for years been on this pension and who had been promised by successive governments that they would continue to receive this pension. It was in fact the retrospective application of a new set of procedures which were introduced in 1978.

Senator Macklin's proposal is that in fact those who received the pension before 2 November 1978 and who received letters saying that they would stay on that 100 per cent rate should be left on that rate and that the promises of successive governments from the Government of Hughes in 1922 through the governments of Curtin, Chifley, Menzies, Holt, Gorton, McMahon and Whitlam should be kept. If there is anything else that is needed in our social security and our repatriation system it is a feeling by those who are receiving assistance that there will be consistent application and that the application of these provisions will not be capriciously changed as they were in 1978.

I am not arguing that ex-servicemen who have suffered tuberculosis since 1978 should not be treated like other ex-servicemen who suffer from other diseases. There would be very few of those who would qualify for the 100 per cent pension. But those who received the pension before 1978 were given the promise that in fact they would stay on that rate. Many of them, particularly those in the 30s, the 40s and the 50s suffered considerably because of the treatment that was necessary. This treatment was often traumatic, it was always prolonged and it was sometimes not very effective. They suffered considerably because of the restrictions that were imposed on them, because of the community's attitude towards tuberculosis, an attitude which one could understand because of the tendency for tuberculosis to recur. They suffered the restrictions of not having the same career opportunities and the same opportunities for advancement that their brothers and sisters in the community had.

This payment, like other repatriation payments, was in fact a compensation for these very real difficulties they suffered, as well as an attempt to keep them away from the depressing conditions which may have made their treatment difficult and may have made an exacerbation of their illness more likely. Therefore, Senator Macklin's proposal in the legislation is a reasonable one. It is a proposal which is backed, of course, by the organisations which represent the tuberculose ex-servicemen. It is backed by the Returned Service League in this community and it was backed recently in Canberra by a combined meeting of returned veterans organisations.

I think the worst aspect of what happened in 1978 was the breach of faith by the Government going back on the promise which previous governments had made to these people. The second aspect, I believe, was the Minister's interpretation of the letters that they received. I think it is very hard and harsh to suggest to these people that what those letters meant was that they would remain on the money figure they were receiving in those days. If we carried that through to its logical extreme, the people who first received the tuberculosis pension in 1927 would still be receiving the decimal equivalent of 84s a fortnight. If we carried it to its extreme, those who received it in the post-war years would still be receiving the equivalent of #10 2s a fortnight. That is a nonsense argument. It is an argument used by someone who is desperate to justify the unjustifiable position that he or she is taking. It is for that reason that we support Senator Macklin's private member's Bill, a Bill which expresses the view of the Senate that these people who were taken off their 100 per cent pension on 2 November 1978 have been hardly done by and that this Government has not kept faith with those deserving people who served their country and fought for it at a time when they were needed to maintain for this country the freedom that we all, I suppose, have come to take for granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to explain the Government's position and the decision which was originally made, as Senator Grimes has pointed out, in the Budget of 1978. It is clear, as was acknowledged by Senator Grimes, and I believe also by Senator Macklin, that tuberculosis has been treated very effectively in later years. In fact in the Australian community the disease has almost been wiped out. In terms of the effects of tuberculosis upon ex-servicemen from both world wars, it is well and truly acknowledged that those who have been assessed in the way in which Senator Grimes outlined during his speech have been relatively well cured of the disease. The incidence and, particularly, the effects of the disease are not very evident amongst those in receipt of disability pensions at present.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important to recognise that the special rate of pension which has applied since 1978 in respect of previous tuberculosis sufferers has not been reduced in money terms. Rather, it has been frozen at the level that was being paid at that time. Ex-soldiers who suffered from the disease were examined and their disability pensions were assessed in line with the degree of the incidence of the disease. The disability from which they suffered at the time was taken into account and assessed.

It is clear that some people have won in terms of their disability pension as a result of the re-assessment. It is also true that others may have been disadvantaged to some extent. However, the substantial point remains, that persons in this situation have been in receipt of the cash benefit of the special pension. They are also, of course, properly assessed in terms of the repatriation legislation on their degree of disability. In fact, they are in receipt of money incomes as a result of these pensions, which are designed to compensate for their degree of disability as a result of their disease.

Free medical treatment was restored in August 1979, following the August 1978 decision. It was granted as a result of representations made to the Government by the Federated TB Sailors, Soldiers and Airmen's Association. In that respect previous sufferers of tuberculosis have not been disadvantaged in the treatment which is available through the repatriation hospital system. For these reasons, the Government maintains its opposition to the Bill. It believes that its decision in 1978 was correct in line with the experience of those who have recovered from the disease and proper assessment of their disability and their war service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Due to lack of time I intend to be brief. I thank the Australian Labor Party senators and other senators who, I hope, will vote for this private member's Bill. I was heartened somewhat by the response of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). Fairly obviously, his heart was not in it. At least that says something for him, if not for the Government. The argument that is proposed is a very simple one.
—I don't think he knows the Minister.

—If Senator Walters listens, she will learn that the disability that these people suffered was suffered after the war. While the disease may have been curable since the war that has absolutely nothing to do with the disability that those veterans suffered after World War II. The disability was encountered after the Second World War. Here we are talking about the majority of pulmonary tuberculosis veterans who numbered 1,146 as of 30 June 1980. This is out of a total of 1,198 tuberculosis sufferers.

SPEECH.PARA: Immediately after the Second World War, these people suffered severe social restrictions, very painful and lingering treatment and the inability to re-establish themselves within the community. The type of medical advice that they were given was to restrict their lifestyle. They were told: 'Don't work overtime and don't push yourselves'. A host of other quite proper medical advice was given at that time to those veterans. In other words, at that time those veterans suffered a disability in economic, social and physical terms. Those problems have not gone away, simply because the disease has been cured. If a person suffered a disability in 1946 and so was not able to gain a suitable occupation and establish a family and home in the way he could have done had he been in full health, that problem is still present in 1981, regardless of any medical cure in the meantime. These are the only veterans we are speaking about. These are the veterans who had the disease prior to 1978. We totally accept the proposition that with the medical treatment now, no special attention over and above that for veterans suffering from other diseases is warranted for those in our services suffering from TB.

We are solely concerned with those people to whom the Government at the time made promises and who then worked on the supposition that they would be supported. Some of these veterans were from the First World War. Indeed, they numbered 24 veterans as of 30 June last year. On calculations those people as of 12 November are now some $13.15 poorer. That may not seem very much to the Minister and other honourable senators in this chamber, but it is a lot to those people. We are talking of only 1,198 people. Here is the miserliness of cutting off aid to veterans from the First and Second World Wars and the Malaysian and Korean encounters. These are the people we are talking about. These are the people who retrospectively-after all the promises this country has made to them-are now to be penalised.

I sum up simply by asking honourable senators to remember that, after World War II, our troops came home to tickertape processions and to the adulation and thanks of the whole population. We were thankful enough then. Forty years on we have forgotten them. They feel forgotten. We have forgotten our duty to assist those people. Probably we have forgotten too that we meet in this chamber because of the actions those veterans took. Would any government have acted in 1945 in the same manner that this Government has acted in 1978? Would any other government have defended so openly and so brazenly a denial of basic rights which had been granted to our veterans by all governments up to that date? Would any government have done that when the veterans stepped off the troop-ships? Of course not. But memories die, and 40 years on it seems it is all right to penalise people. It is hoped that people forget. Is it not interesting that the motto of our leading veterans' organisation is 'Lest we forget'? The action which was taken in 1978 shows that some had already forgotten.

I hope that by the vote here tonight more honourable senators than just those belonging to the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party will show that they have not forgotten. I hope that they will at least give their vote and their moral support to a campaign to restore the pension to those who had it in 1978. Perhaps if it is remembered that their numbers will grow fewer every year, therefore the total cost will be less every year, that will loosen at least a few votes. I do not care why honourable senators support this Bill, but I ask them at least to cast their votes in support of those veterans to show that somebody in this country has not forgotten what they have done for us.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON PARLIAMENT'S APPROPRIATIONS AND STAFFING: REPORT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 19 November 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When debate on this matter was adjourned last week I had the call and I moved: 'That progress be reported'. I remind the Committee that on that occasion I said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I think we should put the matter in a perfectly sound and accurate manner.
That is, the motion which seemed to me to have certain defects. I went on to say:

Therefore, I think it would be wise if we had a few days in which to tidy up the details of the motion. It is for this reason that I have spoken to the Opposition parties because we are assured that this matter can come back for debate next week.

Progress was then reported. I have since tabled-they have been circulated to all members of this chamber-amendments to Senator Jessop's motion which I will now move in the form set out in the document tabled. I have also submitted-this has also been tabled-a redraft of the motion with the amendments included. That document is also before honourable senators. I move:
Paragraph (1), fourth line, leave out sub-paragraphs (a) and (b), insert the following sub-paragraphs and new sub-paragraph:
'(a) endorses the conclusions of the Committee as summarised on pages (viii) and (ix) of its Report and the recommendations contained in the report;
and in relation to the recommendations of the Committee in Chapter 6 of the Report-
'(b) resolves that the Senate should establish a Standing Committee as recommended to consider the Senate's appropriations and staffing;

'(ba) proposes that the Estimates for the Senate as finally agreed to by such Standing Committee be submitted to the Minister for Finance for inclusion in a separate parliamentary appropriation Bill;'.

I have moved these amendments because, as I said on the previous occasion, I believe that the motion which was moved initially did not include all of the recommendations. In fact, it omitted one of the most important of the proposals which is contained in paragraph (c) of the amended motion. It relates to the recommendations in chapter 6 of the report. Paragraph (c) states:
Proposes that the estimates for the Senate as finally agreed to by such standing committee be submitted to the Minister for Finance for inclusion in a separate parliamentary Appropriation Bill;

I will not repeat the arguments which I raised on the previous occasion in which I indicated that there was a defect in the motion as then proposed. I know there have been discussions but since that time, so far as I know, there has not yet been presented to the Senate any statement of the Government position, although documents have been discussed by honourable senators who are members of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing which presented this report. I want to explain why the amendments I have moved are vital amendments. In the first place if one looks at the situation and the motion as it was before one finds that if, in fact, the Government took a position that it should retain control of the total amount of the parliamentary appropriation that, of course, would be a vital decision. That is the position at the moment. It is not the position in most of the parliaments of the world. The Committee has clearly recommended that that should not be the position hereafter but that when a standing committee of the Senate has decided what is necessary to carry out the functions of the Senate properly that decision should be submitted to the Minister for Finance for inclusion in a separate parliamentary Appropriation Bill.

In our recommendations we went on to say that if the government did not like that amount and felt it was excessive, on the floor of the Parliament it could move accordingly to reduce the amount of that appropriation. I think that is a vital part of the Committee's recommendations. If, in fact, the government can retain that global figure and can say that $100m or $10m is the amount that is to be spent for the expenditure of Parliament in a year we can well see what the situation would be. There may be a committee. The Government may feel that a joint committee is needed. Whatever form it is in, committees of both chambers may say that they want so much money. They may say: 'On our committees' advice we need this amount of money'. But of course there would inevitably be a battle between the committees of both Houses. There would be fighting over the bone that the Government had provided as the total amount.

It is my belief that it is fundamental to the Parliament of this country that it regain control over the total amount that it determines-acting, I believe, quite sensibly and responsibly-is needed for the carrying out of parliamentary functions. These should be determined, of course, by members of the Parliament who know the committee responsibilities and the other responsibilities of the Parliament. Of course, if the Government retains the global figure there will be inevitable conflict between the House of Representatives and the Senate. We all know that there have been conflicts in very recent times between the Senate and the House of Representatives as to the number of rooms and places in this House that should be occupied either by senators or members. One can imagine that the doctrine of divide and rule will apply and that when there is a lack of agreement between the Houses the Government will have to step in and say: 'You cannot agree, so the Senate will have this amount and the House of Representatives will have that amount'.

The control over the total figure is vital and must be included in any resolution that adopts the Select Committee's proposals. The same problem arises in relation to staffing. If staff numbers and expenditure relating to the Houses of Parliament were to be controlled by the Prime Minister or by Cabinet the same degree of argument between the two Houses could occur. Both Houses could be restricted to quite inadequate amounts to carry out their tasks. That should be avoided at all costs.

My amendment to the motion which is now being debated by this Committee adopts the recommendations of the Select Committee. The Committee consists of representatives of all parties in the Senate. We considered the evidence. The Speaker of the House of Representatives, in fact, was among the witnesses before the Select Committee. We came to certain conclusions. We now request this Committee to adopt the recommendations which the Select Committee made. There will be room for negotiation. It will not alter the position which is, at the moment, unsatisfactory. But at least this Committee will indicate that it agrees with the recommendations which that Select Committee has made. That should be done before we rise for the summer recess. It is well within the capacity of honourable members of the Senate and members of the Government to discuss the situation in a calm atmosphere. Then other arrangements may be made. I urge that this amendment be adopted because it complements and completes the motion which is based upon the Committee's recommendations. We will then be able to attempt to achieve some result with the Government. With those thoughts in mind I commend my amendment to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, and the members of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing who dealt with this important subject, support Senator Missen's amendment. His amendment highlights matters that were implicit in the original recommendations that were before the Senate. I believe it is proper that we should agree to Senator Missen's amendment. The Committee believes that it has presented a reasonable and responsible approach to the reform that is suggested in the report. The Committee was aware that the reference before it required a cautious and reasoned approach. Testimony to the fact that the report of the Select Committee achieved this objective is given by the wide acceptance of the recommendations approved by senators and members from all parties and by Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine recognised that point. I believe it is important that the Parliament assume the responsibility in this area. The Government recognises that the Committee has identified areas that are important. We deliberately did not recommend a single line appropriation administrative vote for the simple reason that once parliament has its own Appropriation Bill a single line appropriation is unnecessary. In addition, the Committee did not wish to apply one set of accounting practices for the Parliament when the Senate and the Government are on record as objecting to one line appropriations for the Public Service generally.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of what is and what is not an ordinary annual service is not a justiciable one. Long ago, in 1911, the High Court of Australia decided that it is a matter for decision between the two Houses. That is why we have agreements such as the so-called 1965 compact. The Government could take the view that Parliament is an ordinary annual service of the Government, but it is only a view. The important point is that the Attorney-General's Department advised the Select Committee during its hearings that the matter is one for determination by the Houses concerned. Senator Missen pointed out that each House should have a capacity to deal with its own destiny as far as appropriations are concerned. I believe and the Committee believes that Joint House matters should be dealt with jointly by the two Houses. Our report suggests this course of action. I think that I have made my point and my attitude to the matter clear in my previous speech. I simply endorse Senator Missen's amendment to the motion that I have already presented.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief in my remarks. The report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing has been considered by the Government. It has been put under detailed study. The Government has reached some conclusions. Prior to the presentation of those conclusions the Government believes there should be detailed discussions with each of the Presiding Officers and members of the Committee. It is possible that within the scope of that framework some give and take might be possible. The Government has, through me in this chamber, approached Mr President and the Committee and has provided the Committee with a summary of its present thinking. Through the Leader of the House in the other chamber, Mr Sinclair, an approach has been made to Mr Speaker. The deliberations have started. The Government believes that it ought to be able to put forward its thinking in more precise terms upon the resumption of the Parliament. It would hope that during that period the two Presiding Officers will have their views presented to us. Therefore, the Government is acting with good will. I simply indicate that the Government believes it can make some considerable reforms which will go a long way towards achieving the kinds of goals that were contemplated by honourable senators in the preparation of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too shall be brief. As one of the Australian Labor Party representatives on the Senate Select Committee inquiring into Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, the Committee's report, as we see it, is a moderate document and one which has been based on the principle of gradualism at all times. Having considered the motion of Senator Jessop and the amendment of Senator Missen, the Opposition supports Senator Missen's amendment because it strengthens the original motion of Senator Jessop and is in line, as Senator Missen has said, with the Committee's recommendation set out in paragraph 6.8 on page 21 of the report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the Estimates, the Committee-
That is, the Committee to be established for the purpose of considering the parliamentary estimates-

would examine the proposals of the President and the officers of the Senate at, unless otherwise ordered, public hearings. The Estimates as finally agreed by the Committee would be submitted to the Minister for Finance for inclusion in a separate Parliamentary Appropriation Bill. The Minister would then introduce the Bill in the House of Representatives in accordance with current practice. The Senate, upon receipt of the Bill from the House of Representatives, would consider its provisions in the normal way and, at that time, would also have before it a report from the Appropriations and Staffing Committee covering its deliberations concerning the Estimates.

As I have said, the approach has been one of gradualism. The Opposition firmly believes that the Parliament cannot be regarded as an ordinary annual service of the government. Therefore, we believe that the motion of Senator Jessop and the amendment of Senator Missen should be supported this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —(New South Wales) (8.56)-As the Australian Democrats member of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing, I wish to indicate the Australian Democrats' unreserved support for the motion. We applaud this beginning, as we see it, of a greater liberation of this chamber from the trammels placed upon it by the Executive.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am in a quandary as I do not know what is the actual response of the Government to this report of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. I believe that some people in the Parliament have had the opportunity of seeing it but I have not.
—Members of the Committee have.

—Why should members of the Committee be the only ones to see something of this nature? Has the response been tabled? Until it is tabled, I will have to go along with what has been said by Senator Jessop and Senator Missen. I am very much of the opinion that the financing of the Senate should be independent of the Executive. More importantly, I believe that it should be independent of the House of Representatives. In other words, I do not think a joint committee should be set up to deal with this matter.
—It should be independent.

—Senator Harradine said that the committee should be independent. I know why he said that and I agree with him. There has been a definite attempt of late by the Executive to set up joint committees in many areas. I would hate to see this kind of situation come under a joint committee because, obviously, the Senate would be swamped by the numbers from the House of Representatives. I would be more than happy to see the Senate housed in a building separate from the House of Representatives. I agree entirely with what Senator Missen, Senator Jessop and other honourable senators have said. I support the motion and the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.
Resolution reported; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: LIQUOR ADVERTISING TAX ASSESSMENT BILL 1981LIQUOR EDUCATION FUND BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Chipp) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the questions with regard to the several stages for the passage through the Senate of the Bills being put in one motion at each stage and the consideration of such Bills together in the Committee of the Whole.
Bills presented, and-by leave-read a first time.
Second Readings

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
These Bills provide for a tax of 10 per cent on the advertising of liquor and establishing a fund to cover the costs of a nationwide advertising campaign designed to reduce excessive use of alcohol.
Surely it is unnecessary to describe in detail the tragic consequences of alcohol abuse.
The World Health Organization nominates alcohol as the third largest killer of the human race. It closely follows heart disease and cancer.
It has left a trail of broken families, battered children, innocent people killed and maimed on the road.

According to medical authorities (Dr Chesher and Associate Professor Starmer, Sydney Morning Herald, 23 November 1981) alcohol has been proved to cause brain damage, be toxic to the heart muscle, cause liver damage, gastritis, reduce resistance to infection-the list goes on.

Logic would demand a conclusion that for society to allow millions of dollars to be spent inducing or seducing members of that society to consume such a product or to abuse such a product borders on social insanity.

The fact remains that the abuse and misuse of alcohol kills millions more people than the abuse of heroin or cannabis, and yet what kind of public outrage would there be if someone advocated the allowance of the uninhibited advertising of heroin, of opiates, of marihuana or drugs of addiction.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics reported the following facts concerning 1980. There were 3,272 people killed on Australian roads, and more than 90,000 injured. 50 per cent of these deaths and injuries has been estimated to be due to alcohol.

The National Health and Medical Research Council estimates that 'not less than 10 per cent of admissions to public hospitals are substantially due to alcohol'. This means that public hospitals spent at the very least $540 million on treatment of alcohol induced illnesses or injuries in any one year.

This figure does not measure the exquisite agony of personal, physical and mental suffering and heartbreak. These Bills are not designed to prohibit the consumption of alcohol, as such a course has already proved a social disaster in the United States in the late 20's. It does not ban the advertising of alcohol. It is not based on an assumption that it is possible nor even desirable to persuade society to totally forsake the use of this drug. Sad though it may be, it is doubtful that our present society with its mad way of life and false and materialistic ideals could survive without some form of social lubricant such as alcohol. Imagine what a jolly affair the Melbourne Lord Mayor's Ball would be if only orange juice was served.
One could well question the wisdom of permitting the continued advertising of alcoholic beverages.

The Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare has already made a recommendation to the Commonwealth Government to ban advertising of alcohol. The Government has refused to accept this recommendation. The Government stated, that instead, it would use preventive and curative measures to combat alcohol abuse. The 1980-81 report by the Director General of Health shows there is little evidence of any determined, broadly based attempt to identify what makes us drink to excess and to concentrate our efforts in those areas. In recent months, I have studied the results of a great amount of relevant research.

None of the available research evidence discloses a correlation between the level of advertising, consumption and abuse. Somewhat reluctantly, therefore, I conclude that at this stage, there is no conclusive evidence to my knowledge of a direct causal relationship between increased liquor advertising and an increased level of alcohol consumption and abuse. In fact, incredible though it seems, some of the figures I have studied seem to indicate the opposite conclusion.

I say ''reluctantly'' because I have a healthy respect for the business acumen of the liquor industry and hence find it a little difficult to accept that annual expenditure exceeding $25 million is directed only to persuading people to switch brands or beverages-(say between beer and wine).
In 1979, according to the Australian Association of National Advertisers, expenditure in Australia on media advertising alone amounted to over $23 million and was allocated as follows:
$m Press 9.80 Metropolitan TV 10.66 Country TV 1.80 Radio 1.46
Total media 23.72

It remains difficult to believe that expenditure of this order has no effect on consumption, but until we find specific evidence to this effect we are confronted with an extremely complex causal interaction of cultural social and psychological factors. However, this does not relieve the advertising industry or the liquor industries of their responsibilities.

The images projected, particularly in television advertising associate alcohol with commercial success, ''well earned'' rewards, sophisticated people in glamorous settings, healthy, outdoor living, gaiety and mateship-images which relate to the aspirations and anxieties of most people. To this extent the advertising industry contributes however subtly, to the maintenance and reinforcement of the social and economic climate which, it says, is to blame if people persist in using alcohol to excess.

In this context, but at another time, the role played by our not so hidden persuaders in determining the kind of society we live in may be worth examining. As I said, another time. I do believe, however, that there is a case for the Alcoholic Beverages Advertising Council to review its code for alcohol advertising with the aim to discourage advertisements creating general receptiveness to alcohol and to concentrate more on its proper functions in this area-the provisions of specific information.

Recently I was privileged to be one of the guests of honour at the annual presentation of the television advertising awards conducted by the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations (FACTS). The series of advertisements which won first prize was one which featured Paul Cronin, the distinguished Australian actor, suggesting to his mate that he had had too much to drink and should not drive home. Cronin takes the keys and offers his mate a bed in his house or a taxi fare.

I have gone into some detail here to show that educational advertisements need not be preaching, moralistic, nagging or narrow minded. In this case a practical real life situation firmly implants in the viewer the concept that he or she can save a mate's life. I was distressed to learn from the producers of this advertisement which had been commissioned by the Commonwealth Department of Health, that the Department did not have sufficient funds to show these advertisements beyond a couple of provincial towns.

The Bills proposed by the Australian Democrats seek to expand this approach into a carefully prepared and targetted attack on the misuse of alcohol and to ensure that sufficient funds are available for this purpose.

The Liquor Education Fund Act 1981 seeks to establish a Fund to be available to the Minister for Health to run public education programs to reduce, '. . . the dangers of the misuse or excessive consumption of liquor'.

The Liquor Advertising Tax Assessment Bill 1981 provides for the assessment and collection of a levy on all liquor advertising to enable the Government to appropriate adequate funds for the purpose of running the education programmes.

Under S.53 of the Constitution, taxing and appropriation bills may not originate in the Senate. Hence, following passage of these bills in the Senate, a message would be sent to the House of Representatives requesting passage of these bills together with a bill for an Act imposing a 10 per cent tax as defined in the Assessment Act. The message will include a request to pass a Bill for an Act to appropriate a sum equal to the sum estimated to be collected under the Liquor Advertising Tax Assessment Act and to apply it for the purpose specified in the Liquor Education Fund Act 1981.
On an estimated total annual liquor advertising expenditure of $26 million the proposed tax would raise $2.6 million nationally.

In the field of health education we have not progressed as far as I would have liked in the past decade. I can remember turning to health educators between 1969 and 1972 when as Minister for Customs and Excise I was warning against the growing menace of illicit drugs. In those days we relied essentially on the fear technique, which I believe does not work and in fact may well be counter productive. We have learnt that there is a wide range of techniques suitable to achieve acceptance of the positive aspects of moderation.

The trend towards education rather than prohibition is illustrated by other instances: the continuing Queensland Government program on alcohol abuse, the $1 million appeal by the Victorian Foundation on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence to combat drug and alcohol misuse, pilot education programs in Tasmania are just some examples. Surely prevention is better than cure and surely our resources are better used to eliminate causes rather than to cope with the damage once it is done.
I also note a recent report (Age 13/11) that the crime rate in Ballarat, Victoria, fell by 14 per cent following an intensive campaign based on personal contact by the local police force.

The potential of such campaigns to change people's perceptions about the consequences of drug abuse and, as a result, to reduce the level of consumption has been demonstrated recently by the Healthy Lifestyle Program in the North Coast Region of NSW.

Part of this program, run by the Health Commission of NSW, in conjunction with the Commonwealth Department of Health, was directed towards the reduction of smoking in the two test towns chosen-Lismore and Coffs Harbour. Mid-term results are now becoming available and show a reduction in the prevalence of smoking of 9.6 per cent and 11.3 per cent respectively.

Clearly, there is a case for extending the principle of co-ordinated, nationwide educational programs to the use of tobacco. Here I wish to commend Mr Fraser for his courage for insisting on the ban on tobacco advertising on TV and radio in the face of massive opposition.
The State Governments stand condemned for their gutlessness in failing to enact similar legislation for the print media. A lot more needs to be done in this area.

I wish to make it clear that the Australian Democrats do not hold a brief for any particular type of education program. Here we should turn for help and advice to the people who are expert in finding out what makes us tick and who, I am told, can even make us tick in a particular manner.

What the Democrats want is a fund administered by the Department of Health which would employ advertising agencies of equal brilliance, cleverness, astuteness as those who work for the alcohol industry who would simply get the message across that if you drink do not drive, you could be killed, mained, or kill an innocent person.

I personally do not believe the acceptance of this measure is the total solution to the problem of carnage on our roads. I have a personal view that we should also be moving towards the extremely severe penalties imposed in Sweden, where being in charge of a vehicle while having a minimum blood alcohol count means a mandatory jail sentence. However, that would be the subject of another Bill, and clearly the Commonwealth's powers are limited and such a Bill brought in by this Federal Parliament would need complementary legislation by the States. However, these Bills are a start.

When any party or when Parliament attempts such a reform it necessarily is confronted by opposing vested interests. I have not the slightest doubt this Bill will be strongly resisted by the breweries and the liquor industry generally. However, unlike a measure which would ban the advertising of this product, we do not expect opposition from the television and radio industry or the advertising profession. Indeed, we expect their active support and co-operation.
Their financial and active participation in combatting misuse would be an expression of social responsibility as well as good economic sense.

I accept without question that excessive use and the tragic consequences are neither intended nor directly promoted by either the makers, marketers or advertisers of alcoholic beverages. I believe it is not beyond the combined resources of the liquor industry and of Government to reduce substantially the devastatingly harmful effects of the misuse of alcohol.
These Bills are designed to make this co-operative effort possible.
I appeal to senators to avoid party lines or party direction on this issue and treat it as a conscience measure. I ask that it be examined on its merits.

I have left it until the end of this Session so that it can be discussed during the next few months within the community and then brought back hopefully for a positive decision by the Senate and subsequently the House of Representatives.
I commend the Bills to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 29 October, on motion by Senator Siddons:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mindful of our tight schedule, I will not go into endless repetition. I will make one observation and one explanation. My observation is that the worker-management concept in Yugoslavia, the trade union-management representation in West Germany or even the experiment in the New South Wales State Dockyard all have valuable consequences. I think Senator Siddons will agree with me when I say that the reinvestment of profit in new plant can affect conditions, wages and salaries. The problem is the same in West Germany as it is here. I have been to Yugoslavia several times and talked to the people on the worker-management committee on Litistrov and Lex. We discussed this problem. The Bill proposed by Senator Siddons will remove most decisively some of the overseas boardroom decisions that General Motors-Holden's Ltd has been very notable for. I think we should give the Bill our blessing on that basis.

SPEECH.PARA: I strike a note of caution. When this Bill first came before our appropriate committee, we had discussions with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, as did my leader. The result of those discussions is that, whilst in principle we agree with the innovation, I think it is agreed that each industry has its own particular problems. This legislation is not the millennium but it is a step forward. I will be speaking later during the adjournment debate on another topic, so I will leave it to my leader at a later stage to establish clearly what the understanding was with ACTU, being mindful of its last congress decision.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time is short and the Senate is debating an Industrial Democrary Bill, so-called, which has been introduced by Senator Siddons. I say at the outset that the Opposition has some qualifications about this Bill. We do not, for example, think that it should be called an Industrial Democracy Bill, as we do not think it is an Industrial Democracy Bill. It is perhaps a step towards industrial democracy legislation with which we feel Australians should be concerned and with which this Parliament should be concerned as a matter of importance and priority.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that we have qualifications about the Bill-and in the Committee stage I will indicate some of those qualifications-we welcome the general spirit of it because it seeks to bring a more constructive and imaginative approach to industrial relations than has ever shown by the present Government. It seeks to encourage new approaches within the community to industrial organisation. Most importantly, I think the Australian Democrats are to be congratulated because, in a sense, it widens the agenda of political debate in the area of industrial relations. I hope that Senator Chipp took note of what I said-that the Australian Democrats are to be congratulated for widening the agenda of political debate on this important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing you say, Senator, of which I do not take careful note.

—I wanted Senator Chipp to hear that because sometimes I suspect he thinks I am less than charitable to him. The device used by this Bill to try to encourage employee participation in the ownership of organisations, companies and so on is the provision that, in return for certain concessions which are made by the employer in terms of employee participation in ownership and in return-as the Bill will be amended-for employee participation in decision-making, a tax concession will be granted to those companies which fall within the classification or description of an industrial democracy company. That classification would be determined by a board or committee, I am not sure which.
—A board.

—It would be a board, established under the legislation, which would have the discretion, according to guidelines, to determine whether or not a company falls into that category. One or two amendments will be made to the Bill. We welcome the fact that it encourages not only more humane and more productive management techniques but also in that process it encourages employee participation of one kind or another. As I have said, the Opposition would like to see a Bill which goes further than this Bill goes. We think it is important that this Parliament discusses this issue for the first time in Australia. It has been an issue widely discussed in most European parliaments and it has been the subject of a special report commissioned by the former Minister for Productivity, Mr Ian Macphee, entitled 'Employee Participation in Industry'. It has been the subject of discussions by the National Labour Advisory Council and also of discussions between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government and the ACTU and employer groups. So we think it important that this Bill should pass through the Senate and widen the agenda of pgditical debate on these issues.

SPEECH.PARA: In passing, Senator Siddons, in approaching the introduction of this Bill to the Parliament, to our knowledge had discussions with the Opposition and with the Australian Council of Trade Unions about his proposal. In neither case, as he knows, was there total approval of this Bill. However, there was approval of the notion that this should be the subject of political debate in the Australian context. We welcome the Bill and wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Siddons has raised a most important subject; one which should not be ignored. There can be no doubt that relations between management and employees in this country are generally most unsatisfactory. I would also agree that there is, at least in theory, no logical reason why the management of a company should be solely in the hands of the providers of capital while the providers of the other element of production, labour, have no influence on company policy except by confrontational tactics. We certainly must not be satisfied with the status quo. The subject is too important and our present arrangements so obviously defective for us to be complacent about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem is what to do about the situation. I am not satisfied that Senator Siddon's solution is the best one, even as the basis for an experiment. One might well ask: If the advantages of his proposed company structure are as clear cut as he claims for both management and employees, why are they not adopted without government incentives? It may be because of the conservatism of both employers and trade unions, both of whom would have to give up some of their power and capacity for confrontation. It may be that that is the reason, but I think further investigation is needed before we make that assumption.

There have been many different attempts in various countries to tackle this problem. Some are clearly not suitable for us. Others quite possibly could be. It seems an ideal subject for a Senate standing committee to investigate and report on. A Senate committee is the best approach, for there would be some chance of achieving bipartisan support for such a scheme and without it any scheme would be stillborn anyway. Firstly, it should investigate whether a system of industrial democracy is desirable and, if so, which is the preferred solution. Secondly, it should investigate whether there is any necessary role for the Government in such a system. Thirdly, it should investigate what form the Government's role, if any, should take. If Senator Siddons likes to move, at some future time, the referral of this problem to a Senate standing committee, I will support him. The question is: Which Senate committee?

I have pointed out previously that the present division of responsibilities between our eight standing committees is far from ideal. A matter such as this, covering industrial relations and business management, does not sit very happily with any of those committees. I suppose the closest is the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce, of which I note Senator Siddons is a member. I therefore commend to him the suggestion that he should move to have the problem referred to one of the standing committees. Even if the Bill is passed tonight, it is almost certain that it will not be passed in its present form by the House of Representatives. I think the matter should be kept alive by its being referred to a Senate committee, but I will oppose the present Bill.

I would like to make a few preliminary remarks before incorporating in Hansard a paper that Senator Lewis thought was relevant to the problem. I submit it on his behalf. The paper was prepared by Mr Symons, Chairman of Directors of the Fletcher Jones group of companies, which are owned, as to 76 per cent, by present and past employees and the widows of deceased employees. Mr Symons has spent nearly 40 years examining and implementing employee participation schemes under the guidance of, and in furtherance of the aims of, the company's founder, Sir Fletcher Jones. Mr Symons went to the trouble of making a submission on this subject to the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of that submission.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
SUBMISSION TO THE COMMITTEE OF ENQUIRY INTO THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM
This submission is made by Donald Neil Symons of 201 Liebig Street, Warrnambool, Chairman of Directors of F. J. Organizations Pty Ltd and the associated companies in the Fletcher Jones Group.
The business now conducted by the group was begun in 1943 by the late Sir Fletcher Jones.

It began as a manufacturer of trousers. Later the business was extended into retailing activities and the product range has been progressively broadened. Retailing activities are conducted in all states (other than the Northern Territory) and manufacturing activities are conducted both at Warrnambool, where the business began, in Melbourne and at Mount Gambier.
From the outset, one of the fundamental objectives of the founder was to establish some form of co-operative staff ownership in the business.
There were two reasons for this.

First, he was concerned to attempt to create worthwhile jobs which would be available to several young men who had been employed in his business as a clothing retailer before joining the armed services during World War 2. He felt a responsibility to try to ensure that on their return from war service they would have better future prospects than he had enjoyed on his return from service with the first AIF.

The second reason stemmed from his interest in the co-operative movement, his reading on the subject and his personal involvement in the co-operative activities of the late Doctor Kagawa in Japan. He had come to believe that it should be possible to establish some sort of compromise between socialist and capitalist philosophies by encouraging a situation in which the ownership of the means of production and distribution would be placed in the hands of those directly involved in these processes. He saw in this development the possibility for a personal crusade to spread the gospel that the only justification for ''a licence to own the means of production and distribution was the acceptance of a responsibility to try to give more and more for less and less.''

This phraseology sounds naive in these inflationary days but it expressed a belief which the Late Sir Fletcher Jones attempted to practise during the remainder of his business career. In real terms, he achieved very considerable success in the process.

I was closely involved in the establishment of the corporate structure which was intended to facilitate the involvement of employees of the business in share ownership. Currently we have about 1300 shareholders. The interest of the founder and his family has progressively reduced from about 95 percent at the outset to 24 percent at the present time and the remaining issued capital is owned entirely by present and past employees and the widows of deceased employees. Each share carries one vote and thus, technically, the company can be said to be under the control of its employees. It can be expected that the founder's interests will continue to reduce progressively as his family has fully accepted the obligation to attempt to continue the implementation of his staff co-operative ambitions.

I appreciate that this forum is not the place at which to discuss the merits or demerits of this particular philosophy but in my submission no study of the Australian Financial System would be complete without consideration being given to trends in ownership of the private sector and the investigation or ways and means which trends seen to be potentially undesirable might be arrested.

Our own philosophies and techniques have been entirely home grown and it was not, in fact, until we came to study the Employees Stock Ownership Plans espoused by Louis Kelso in the United States and the social aims which had led the U.S. Congress to support them, that we came to realize that we in our organisation were in fact unwittingly following much the same path but without any of the assistance which the U.S. Congress deemed appropriate in that country.
So far as I am aware, this is a subject on which no evidence has been placed before the Committee and I would not like to hold myself out as being the best equipped witness to argue the case.

Put very briefly, I think that it can be demonstrated that there has over the years been a progressive narrowing of the base of ownership of privately owned capital assets. This has been clearly established in the United States of America.
The joint Congressional Committee, in the report which led to the 1974 Trade Act made the following observation:

''Over 95 percent of investment finance is based on either the reinvestment of current profits of borrowings repaid with future profits; only a tiny fraction is based on the sale of new equities for cash to the small segment of the public who can afford such a cash transaction. But conventional techniques of investment finance are expanding the productive power of U.S. corporations by annual increments of over $100 billion of newly fabricated capital formation. Some industry spokesmen are projecting U.S. capital needs over the next decade at $4.5 trillion. If industry continues to rely almost exclusively on conventional methods of finance, we may achieve that estimate, but we will create virtually no new capital owners in the process.''

The Committee recognised that almost 100 percent of privately owned United States capital was concentrated in less than 10 percent of United States households and that the top 1 percent of wealthholders owned over 50 percent of all stock of United States corporations. It took the view that the removal of barriers between capital owners and workers, accomplished within principles of private property, could only strengthen national well being.

''Qualitative studies of the U.S. capital ownership base show that almost 100 percent of privately owned U.S. capital assets are concentrated in less than 10 percent of U.S. households. Although 30 million Americans own at least one share of corporate stock, the top 1 percent of U.S. wealthholders own 50 percent of all U.S. corporate stock. Few workers, including most corporate executives, own capital of any appreciable income significance. Hence, few working Americans have any effective means of participating as stockholder-constituents of our free enterprise system, even in the corporations for which they work. A removal of any barriers between capital owners and workers, if accomplished wholly within the principles of private property and free market economics, could only strengthen our national well-being and our capacity to remain competitive in world trade.''
I know of no authoritive Australian statistics on this subject and would be hesitant about quoting the A.M.W.S.U. Publication ''Australia Ripped Off'' as a statistical source.

It does seem to be reasonable, however, to assume that the American trend exists to a greater or lesser degree in this country. In fact, discussions which took place before this Committee in the course of the evidence given by Mr John Brunner, B.H.P. Chief Economist, as reported in the Melbourne Age, would seem to suggest that the trend has at least been touched on in evidence already given.

The progressive decline in the number of shareholders in B.H.P., accompanied by a progressive increase in issued capital, has been apparent over a number of years. Similar trends can be seen in other companies.
On the other hand, there is also clear evidence of substantial increases in the investment of financial institutions in particular companies, both in money terms and as a share of total ownership.

I have not attempted to obtain any recent statistics but the trend was clearly demonstrable in the figures relating to the purchases of equity shares in the years 1970 to 1973 by comparison with the years 1954 to 1957 as set out in the following information which was supplied to me some years ago by the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research.
Net purchases of equity shares

$m $m $m $m $m $m $m $m Persons and Unincorporated Enterprises 87 132 101 58 37 37 48 407 Australian Institutions 30 26 37 51 356 291 258 541 Total Australian 117 158 138 109 319 328 210 134 Overseas Net Purchases 24 60 63 64 311 317 224 228

It could be said that this is a trend which must be seen as inevitable under existing conditions of inflation, coupled with the world wide move towards more capital intensive activity but, even taking into account the fact that a significant proportion of the institutional investment can be seen as being theoretically representative of the small investor as a member of superannuation fund or the holder of life insurance, I would suspect that it might be common ground that every reasonable step should be taken to spread the ownership of private capital over the widest possible base.

I do not, therefore, propose to attempt to develop the merits of this argument but I would submit, with respect, that if the Committee is not in substantial agreement with it, then the subject should be thrown open for widely representative public debate before the Committee's report is finalized.

My own view is that the trend has to be seen as being most serious and that there is a greater likelihood that our so called ''free enterprise system'' will move, as a result of public inertia, towards a financial obligarchy than there is that it will move, as a result of political or disruptive activity, towards a state of socialism.
I believe, therefore, that Australia could well follow the lead of the United States in adopting the policy proposed by the 1976 Joint Economic Committee's report:

'To provide a realistic opportunity for more US citizens to become owners of capital, and to provide an expanded source of equity financing for corporations, it should be made national policy to pursue the goal of broadened capital ownership. Congress also should request from the Administration a quadrennial report on the ownership of wealth in this country which would assist in evaluating how successfully the base of wealth was being broadened over time.'
The Kelso theory takes the view that the use of Employee Stock Ownership Plans could be a very important part of this process and apparently the United States Congress agrees.
I would not regard myself as competent to express the full Kelso philosophy but, as I understand it, put very simply, it goes like this:

If a company decides to expand its activities in a way which requires the use of additional funds, in general terms those funds will come from one or other of two sources, or possibly a combination of both.

Most likely they will come from borrowing, in which event not one additional owner of capital will have been recruited in the process. The future earning capacity of the business will be charged with the responsibility to generate funds to repay the loan.

To the extent to which the funds are generated by the raising of additional capital, the probabilities are that the additional funds will be raised from the existing shareholders and that the more affluent shareholders will acquire the rights of those who are unwilling to add to their investments. In this case, the result is more likely to be a progressive narrowing of the ownership base.
If new capital is to be raised from outside the ranks of existing shareholders, the probability is that it will come from institutional sources.
Kelso sees the ESOP as being both a financial tool and a means of broadening capital ownership.

Thus, for example, if a company wished to raise a million dollars for a new project, rather than borrowing or looking to existing shareholders for the required funds, it would arrange to issue one million shares to the trustees of its Employee Share Ownership Plan.
The trustees would raise the necessary funds by an external loan, repayment of which would be guaranteed by the company.

Associated with the company's guarantee to the lender would be an assurance to the trustees that contributions to the fund by the company over the period of the loan would be sufficient to cover the repayment of the debt and interest. The company's contributions could be in two forms-a direct contribution to the ESOP and the payment of dividends on the shares held by the trustees.

Because company contributions to an ESOP are made on a pre-tax basis, the prospective lender can view the guarantee with rather more confidence than he could in the case of the company's guarantee of the repayment of a conventional loan. In effect, the company would be able to charge the repayment of a capital debt against revenue.
The ultimate ESOP concept is that dividends payable in respect of shares held by an ESOP should also be payable on a pre-tax basis.

This appears to be a reasonable recognition of the proposition that funds invested back into the company in this way are very similar to loans, interest on which would be tax deductible on the part of a company.

As could be expected, the tax deductibility of an ESOP scheme is contingent on the trust deed providing appropriate safeguards to ensure that there will be no abuse of the system to the advantage of major shareholders and that the real benefits of the scheme will be enjoyed by bona fide long term employees of the company. I am not as fully informed as perhaps I should be with regard to these safeguards nor am I completely up to date as to the current limitations on the extent to which tax deductible contributions to the ESOP may be made.

My most recent information was that the maximum contribution was 15 per cent per annum of the total wages of the employees covered by the plan. This might seem a high percentage by comparison with our general limit of 5 per cent for superannuation contributions and it can perhaps be seen as a measure of the importance of this process in the eyes of the United States Congress. It should be noted that the 15 per cent limitation relates to the total wage bill of the people concerned and that the actual benefit to an individual can in fact be greater than 15 per cent of his actual wage.

Income in the hands of the ESOP trustees is non-taxable and it would seem that in the normal circumstance, the shares which the individual participant receives-which are generally not available to him until retirement-do not attract taxation.

It is significant to note that in the United Kingdom the provisions of the Finance Act of 1978 relating to profit sharing schemes indicate a similar acceptance of the importance of this type of activity in that country, although I am not aware of anything which encourages the use of profit sharing schemes as a financing tool, as advocated by Kelso.

Under the English system the safeguard for excessive erosion into the taxable income of the company concerned appears to rest in the limitation that the maximum market value of shares appropriated to any one participating employee in any year of income must not exceed 500 pounds. In practical terms, in a scheme in which there was extensive rank and file participation, 500 pounds could very likely represent about 10 per cent of annual wages. The English legislation contains safeguards, also, with regard to capital gains tax but it would seem, in general terms, that an individual participant who retains the shares allocated to him over a period of years ultimately reaches the point where disposal of the shares does not attract any tax at all. Dividends paid in the meantime are taxable whereas, under the USA system, it would appear that no tax attaches to dividends received by the trustees in respect of shares which have been notionally allocated to individual participants.

In my submission a careful analysis of the respective merits and demerits of the two systems, would be justified and this would obviously involve an investigation in some depth. For present purposes, however, the significant point appears to be that in both countries the importance of the encouragement of employee participation in share ownership has been recognised and it is perhaps particularly significant that in the U.K. this recognition came in an Act of Parliament introduced by the Labour administration.

Low key representations have been made for the introduction of Kelso type system in the Australian scene. The subject was looked at by a Committee of the Liberal Parliamentary Party at a fairly early stage of the present Administration and it is my understanding that the Committee was in favour of its inclusion in the Policy of the Party-subject to more specific information being obtained about the development of the movement in the U.S. I am not aware whether this investigation, which would presumably have involved some cost to the Government, was proceeded with but I think it must unlikely, in the face of strong Treasury opposition.

Apart from the necessary amendments to the income tax legislation, it would appear that it could be necessary to amend provisions of Section 67 of the Companies Act to broaden the exceptions to the restrictions which currently prevent companies from dealing their own shares. There is currently a power for a company to lend money in circumstances associated with the purchase of shares for the benefit of employees but there is no power to issue guarantees.

(On the subject of guarantees, the Kelso philosophy includes the establishment of an insurance corporation with government backing to guarantee the repayment by E.S.O.P. trustees of loans raised for the purchase of shares. Attention has also been given to ways and means of creating opportunities for employees in government and semi-government instrumentalities to acquire a portfolio of investments through an E.S.O.P. in compensation for the fact that their type of employment does not naturally lead to share ownership in the employer organisation.)

In the current state of preoccupation with the necessity to balance the budget, it is understandable that Treasury should have viewed with considerable suspicion the suggestion that the E.S.O.P. system should be introduced in Australia. I understand that it has been suggested that the introduction of the system could only be justified on the basis of clear evidence that schemes of this cost could with confidence be expected to result in great improvements in productivity and, presumably, also in industrial relations.

This, of course, is a very effective riposte by those whose concern it is to protect the revenue at all cost, because to those of us who have been concerned in this area for some time, no more counter-productive argument in support of the E.S.O.P. system could be suggested than one which suggested that employer participation in ownership converted workers into contented cows.

Personally I do not see that there is much justification for concern about the need to protect the revenue. If there were likely to be a wide scale adoption of E.S.O.P. techniques, which presupposes an initial wide spread enthusiasm for the subject, a control such as applies in the U.K.-which could be progressively relaxed if circumstances warranted it-would seem to provide an adequate safeguard and if there were a wide spread enthusiasm for the system, the ultimate social consequences would seem to be likely to be most advantageous.

Kelso lays great stress on the effect on purchasing power which can be achieved by the creation of a second income through an E.S.O.P. investment. He believes that this could result in a significant improvement in consumer demand, pointing out that under the current system the excessive purchasing power enjoyed by the few tends to be directed towards increasing the value of their capital investments rather than adding to demand for normal consumable goods and services.
