There would be little doubt that, in the case of some organisations in which E.S.O.P. procedures have been adopted for a relatively small number of individuals in highly capital intensive activities there must have been substantial increments to the assets of the individuals concerned but I would be inclined to join issue with Kelso as to the extent to which, in the short term, the average man in the street would see much in the way of immediate benefit other than a greater feeling of security in retirement. This latter is, in itself, of tremendous social significance particularly as the average age of the community increases and reliance on social benefits is likely to increase at least in proportion.
But there are many other facets of the subject which could be discussed.

Over the years I have been involved in various local fund raising activities. In metropolitan eyes, this might be seen to be a small town experience but the Warrnambool scene could well be a typical part of a wider landscape.

There was a time when local business and industry could be looked to for substantial personally interested support. Over the years the scene has changed-at times almost imperceptibly at times dramatically-and, from being a community of locally owned undertakings we have become a collection of branches of national undertakings. With one or two rare exceptions, those of the locals who have determined to dig in and maintain their independence have either dug a grave for themselves or at best have created a rut which allows no prospect of growth, no prospect of expanding job opportunities.
This trend away from local ownership is not only the result of economies of scale. Other factors include
the impact of taxation, which adds intolerably to the difficulties involved in ploughing back profits to allow for growth or replacement of assets,
the impact of inflation, which has tremendously increased these difficulties,

increasing difficulty in recruiting, motivating and retaining suitable staff. Higher educations levels have produced higher expectations. Big business can at least offer prospects of advancement-perhaps through transfer to other branches-for which the one unit business can have no hope of offering competition, except perhaps through prospects of partnership.

So called 'employee shares'-the sort of thing which we investigated when we were first setting up our ownership system-involving limited voting rights (if any) limited dividend rights, limited participation in growth-seemed to us to be only cynical lip service to a form of professed paternalism. They are not the answer.

But participation in ownership and the responsibilities as well as the benefits of ownership could be a very different thing, particularly if it were as part of a system which had the imprimatur of legislative respectability, as being seen to be socially desirable and responsibly administered.
I would have to be the first to acknowledge that on this subject I have an axe to grind.

We are probably as well equipped as anyone else to take quick advantage of the E.S.O.P. procedure because we are psychologically and technically adjusted to it already but we are certainly no more in need of this type of blood transfusion than many other companies both public and private.
Personally, I would sooner see an E.S.O.P. procedure established by legislation than a reduction in company taxation. It would be less costly and better for Australia.
Better in what way?
Better for the organisations concerned, for the people who work in them-their self respect, pride in belonging to a team and, possibly, for their productivity.

We can't talk about the effect of employee share ownership on productivity because it has always been with us, though we can envisage a variety of intangible reasons why it could stabilize the climate required for good productivity.
But I would never try to sell participation in ownership on the basis of productivity.
The motive would be wrong; the psychology would be wrong; the knockers would have a field day and the trade union movement would be justifiably suspicious.

I would sell it because co-operation is a healthy thing to promote, because it is a useful way of developing a second income and a retirement benefit which avoids the need for complete reliance on a welfare state, because the future of a stable, wholesome well based capitalist system is dependent on the widest possible spreading of the ownership of capital resources amongst people who care about the way in which those resources are deployed-because in the final analysis the increased involvement of financial institutions in the ownership of equity capital, no matter how benevolent and public spirited the managements may wish to be, is not all that different from socialist control except for one thing-you can't control a financial obligarchy through the ballot box.

One of the most traumatic things which happened to the traditional craftsman as a result of the Industrial Revolution was the way in which he was divorced from the job satisfaction of working for himself and for his customer.

I like to think that the basic objectives of our organisation-which were directed first towards quality, service and value and then to management by consultation and co-operative ownership-have helped to reduce the incidence of these traumas.

Kelso offers us all the opportunity of giving our employees a feeling that they are working for themselves and their fellow shareholders in the group and not for an unknown mass of changing, faceless, uncaring investors whose sole interests are dividends, the security of their cash and the prospect of capital gain.

This would be a worthwhile prospect at any time. It could not be more timely than now because the E.S.O.P. means of financing would add a valuable tool for those of us in the private sector who are now desperately looking for bootstrings to clutch.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Mr Symons says that his reference in the submission to the United Kingdom Finance Act of 1978 is now out of date; that the benefits that were available under the Labour Administration have been substantially improved upon under the present Conservative Administration. Mr Symons, with his many years of both practical application and theoretical knowledge of employee participation schemes, says that the scheme proposed in the Bill presented by Senator Siddons is impractical and impossible. He says that very few companies-in fact he doubts if any-would be able to comply with the intricate and complex details of the Bill. Those remarks were given by me on behalf of Senator Lewis. They reinforce my view that, rather than this Bill being implemented by the Government, a detailed examination is needed of its practicalities, of the best way to go about it and of the proper role of government in such a scheme. For that reason, I would support Senator Siddons if he chose to ask that the proposal be referred to a Senate standing committee. However, I will oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Government, I indicate that it does not propose to support the Bill put forward by Senator Siddons. I have prepared a fairly extensive speech, which sets out the reasons. However, I propose to speak briefly to the matter and, because of the pressure of business upon us this evening, to seek leave of the Senate to incorporate the speech in Hansard. In summarising the speech, I would like to say that the Government agrees that the thrust of the Bill is such that it would receive general support. I refer to the encouragement of a closer link between employers and employees, to the benefit of both. Indeed, as is indicated in my prepared speech, the Government has been pursuing precisely that objective. However, the specific means proposed in the Bill to meet the objective are open to very severe criticism and the Government's list of criticisms are set out in the document which I will be seeking leave to incorporate.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, so that honourable senators and those listening to the debate will have some idea of the Government's approach, which is not inconsistent with the view which has already been put by Senator Hamer a few minutes ago, I point out that our approach in this broad field where we have the common objective of trying to encourage the closer link between employers and employees, has had two central elements. It has a firm basis in trying to achieve a three-way consensus approach involving employers and trade unions in the development of programs and strategies and the rejection of a prescriptive approach presenting a blueprint of practices to be adopted by all enterprises regardless of their particular circumstances. In the view of the Government neither of these essential elements is present in the approach suggested by Senator Siddons's Bill. Although there is scope for involvement of the Australian Council of Trade Unions on the Industrial Democracy Board, and perhaps for employers or their representatives, the system is put forward as a fait accompli.
The ACTU issued a policy on these matters in 1979. On the question of legislation the ACTU stated:
Congress stresses that proper consultation and agreement be reached between governments and the trade unions prior to the introduction of legislation and amendments to existing legislation.

Moreover, the ACTU emphasised that representatives involved in employee participation structures must be trade unionists employed by the enterprise or persons nominated by trade unionists and that these trade unionists must be financial. It could be argued therefore that the approach by the trade union movement is one which sees employee participation as a means of achieving greater trade union control rather than employee control. In any event, with respect to this Bill, it is easy to foresee trade union opposition to any attempt to sidestep its authority in the labour movement.

It is the view not only of the Government but also of the Confederation of Australian Industry and the ACTU, as reflected in joint statements by the National Employee Participation Steering Committee, that there can be no detailed blueprint for employee participation which will suit all enterprises. Within each enterprise employers and employees need to work together to develop approaches which suit the particular needs and circumstances of each organisation. It is neither possible nor desirable to develop, as suggested in this Bill, a master plan to be adopted by all enterprises.

Finally, there would be a great deal of administrative complexity in the scheme. The Board would be required eventually to watch over each resident Australian company with regard to organisational structure, the operation of the consultative council and the level of employee share ownership. It would therefore come to have very great power and influence over the private sector and in some respects duplicate the functions of the National Companies and Securities Commission. In particular, the share ownership level of employees in the individual enterprise could fluctuate dramatically over a year. The cost to the taxpayer of the bureaucratic organisation which would be required to oversee the scheme could thus be extremely high. To repeat, the present Bill makes no provision for supplying the funds necessary for the Board's arrangement and operations. That summary of the argument does not do full justice to the matters raised by Senator Siddons. However, in deference to the pressure of business, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the full substance of the Government's stance on this Bill.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
INDUSTRIAL DEMOCRACY BILL

Difficult not to agree with the thrust of the Bill-namely, to encourage a closer link between employers and employees, to the benefit of both. Indeed, as indicated below, the Government has been pursuing precisely that objective. But the specific means proposed in the Bill to meet this desirable objective are open to very severe criticism.

1. The Government's Record The Government has taken the view that questions of 'employee participation' should be achieved through freely entered into discussions between labour and management, appropriate to the requirements and characteristics of each individual enterprise. Voluntarism in this area much more in keeping than legislation with the spirit of what employee participation ought to be about.

Our view has been that the most appropriate approach is one which creates the environment within which labour and management can develop the most appropriate practices for each enterprises, as determined by labour and management.

In June 1978, the then Minister for Productivity, the Hon. Ian Macphee, announced the Government's policy on employee participation. The general thrust of that policy was, and remains, to encourage procedures which enable Australians to influence work processes and their work environment. While facilitative legislation may be required in the future, it must be determined on the basis of experience gained. The development of employee participation in Australia is still at a very rudimentary level, and it is therefore inappropriate to be considering legislation at this stage.
Since 1978, the Government has undertaken a four-pronged program of action:
(a) Public Relations-to increase the community's understanding of employee participation;
(b) Research and Documentation-to investigate, evaluate and distribute information on the results of programs of employee participation throughout Australia;
(c) Training-to assist, both directly and indirectly, those who may wish to introduce or expand the practice of employee participation;
(b) Corporate Action-to provide a consensus three-way approach for the promotion of employee participation.
The Department of Science and Technology has undertaken wide-ranging information, research, advisory and training activities in line with the first three elements of this progam. These include:
the provision of information and advice on employee participation and personnel practice generally to approximately 3,000 organisations each year;
the dissemination of information through publications such as the Department's journal 'Work and People' and individual booklets, such as those concerned with job design and financial participation;
the development of standard training models on different aspects of employee participation;
research into the experience of companies introducing participation practices;
the development of an inventory of resources (e.g. consultants, training courses, training aids) available in this area;
the funding of 5 research projects into specific approaches and issues relating to employee participation, such as safety and technological change.

The fourth element-Corporate Action-has been pursued through the National Employee Participation Steering Committee which the Government established in 1978 following Mr Macphee's announcement. This was a tripartite committee, comprising representatives of employer and trade union bodies and appropriate Commonwealth Government departments. Its work has been directed towards developing a greater understanding, and encouraging the implementation, of employee participation in Australia.
One of its major achievements has been the production and promotion of two consensus statements on what employee participation entails and how it should be introduced.

In other words, thanks to the mechanism established by this Government, for the first time in Australia there was an agreed view shared by employers, unions and Government on these very important and sensitive issues. Both booklets have stimulated a high degree of discussion and action in this field.

As part of the recent Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Government has adopted an even more comprehensive approach to the general question of employer/employee relations. The Steering Committee's functions have been placed under the umbrella of the National Labour Consultative Council and the Human Relations Branch of the Department of Science and Technology is to be transferred to the Department of Industrial Relations. This integration of the Government's consideration of these matters, it is hoped, will stimulate further development along the lines that I have already described. In summary, then, the Government's approach in this broad field has had two central elements:
its firm basis in a three-way consensus approach involving employers and trade unions in the development of programs and strategies;
its rejection of a prescriptive approach presenting a blueprint of practices to be adopted by all enterprises regardless of their particular circumstances.

2. Specific Criticisms of the Siddons Bill Neither of these elements is present in the approach suggested by Senator Siddons' Bill. Although there is scope for involvement of the ACTU on the Industrial Democracy Board, and perhaps for employers or their representatives, the system is put forward as a fait accompli.

(i) Industrial Relations Aspects One of the practices to be encouraged through this Bill is employee share ownership. Frequently with such schemes, so many restrictions are placed on the shares held by employees that their ownership has limited impact. Experience suggests that, in order for this kind of scheme to be effective, a number of conditions should be attached. For example, voting rights should be accorded with the shares, the scheme should cover all employees and not discriminate in favour of the senior personnel of an enterprise, and the eligibility period for the scheme should be relatively short. The Bill gives quite inadequate attention to these matters.

The Bill does not include any reference to the resources, skills and training that companies will require to introduce such practices. The implementation of employee participation is not an easy process and requires considerable time, effort and expertise. There is currently a lack of resources and skills in this area and it is this gap which the Government has been working to fill.

Experience has indicated that the practices outlined in the Bill are not appropriate in every case. For example, semi-autonomous work groups are not compatible with all forms of work processes. Works Councils will not succeed unless there is a real desire for them and continuing interest in them amongst participants. It is most unwise to try to channel companies into establishing and/or maintaining certain practices when these may not be the most appropriate for those particular companies. It is unlikely that the benefits cited by Senator Siddons as flowing from this scheme would be forthcoming in such cases.

There would, of course, be considerable difficulty in determining whether enterprises had fulfilled the requirements imposed on them by the terms of this legislation to an extent sufficient to gain the taxation benefits.
The Bill raises the general question as to whether it is appropriate to impose mandatory conditions on companies in order to establish a co-operative environment within an enterprise.

The arbitrary level of employee share ownership required under the scheme would cause significant inequities and costly inefficiencies. For example, employees of unincorporated businesses, the self-employed and those providing public services would be unable to participate in such a scheme. Moreover, firms whose employees did not participate in share acquisition to the required level would be unable to take advantage of the scheme and would find it more difficult to compete against those firms which attracted the concessional treatment.

The Scheme seems designed to include private companies along with public companies. While presumably excluding companies with less than 10 employed shareholders, most private companies would be easily able to arrange their affairs (shareholders becoming ''employees'') to meet the requirements of the scheme. The result would be a potentially large revenue loss with no possibility of any associated gains, and no significant advancement in benefits to the ordinary employees.
The requirement that profits from each production unit be distributed to employees would pose problems where some units are profitable and others make losses, but no overall company profit emerges.

The arrangements regarding employee share ownership seems to require that the shares be sold to employees at par. It is not hard to imagine that BHP employees would be happy to purchase BHP shares at the $2.00 par value, but it is hard to imagine who is going to sell them.

(ii) Taxation Aspects Rigid organisational structure which the scheme would tend to force on businesses because of the associated taxation incentive would not be appropriate for the majority of those businesses.

The highly disaggregated monthly profit reporting requirements for each production unit would be extremely costly and often impracticable for firms with large numbers of employees firms, for which presumably the scheme was particularly designed. Inefficiency, rather than improved efficiency, would be the result, and over and above the cost of the scheme to participating firms, there would be a cost to taxpayers, running possibly into hundreds of millions of dollars.

Private companies would no doubt criticise the scheme on the grounds that, while their after tax profits might rise, the distribution requirements under Division 7 would tend to reduce the scheme's benefits.

Companies making losses while still being candidates for the Board's register would not be able to benefit from the reduced rate of company tax. Yet these companies could well be the ones in greatest need of a restructuring of their operations.

There is no apparent reason for the selection of 8 per cent as the maximum level of reduction in the company tax rate. Perhaps the only criterion was to keep the potential revenue loss in the realm of a few hundreds of millions of dollars, rather than getting up to the billion dollar mark.
As presently drafted, the Bill proposes a reduction of 8 per cent in tax payable, not a reduction of 8 per cent in the company tax rate as seems to be the intention.

Nor is it at all clear who gets the 8 per cent tax saved-the company (as a reward, or as an offset to the additional costs of the scheme, or as a fund for investment); the shareholders; or the employees via higher wages.
Allowing a partial reduction for a part year compliance would provide scope for manipulation.

The scheme seems to be based on the belief that the present system of taxing companies and their shareholders as separate entities would continue idefinitely. Whether this would be so following the Government's consideration of the Report of the Campbell Committee is a not insignificant question. Simple reductions in company tax would not work (or would work only partially or clumsily) if the present system of taxing companies were replaced by another system. There is a further question of whether it is appropriate that provisions to grant a reduction of tax be included in a Bill of this kind rather than in an appropriate income tax rates bill and supported, if necessary, by a bill amending the Income Tax Assessment Act.

The Bill defines ''enterprise'' as meaning a company for the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act. But that Act contains three definitions of ''company'' for differing purposes. This would be incompatible with the intention of the Bill, including as they do syndicates and unincorporated bodies.

The draft Bill establishes a Board without, however, providing the necessary funds and provides for a (conditional) reduction in company tax. It has to be asked whether such a composite Bill is constitutionally sound.

(iii) The Views of Employer and Union Organisations It is clear that the Confederation of Australian Industry would have a number of objections to the Bill, not the least being that it seeks to impose on management a degree of control over financial administration which would simply not be acceptable to employers. While employer organisations might accept the potential benefits of employee participation (in terms of increased productivity and job satisfaction) on bases appropriate to individual enterprises, the C.A.I. would not accept an across the board approach which would have a severe impact on the capacity of a firm to restructure or cope with the many corporate decisions which determine the profitability and economic viability of an enterprise. There are some businesses where the approach suggested by the Bill might well bear fruit. But that is a decision which should issue from negotiations between the parties and not be imposed from above by Government.

At its 1979 Congress, the ACTU issued a policy on industrial democracy which bears on matters contained in this Bill. On the question of legislation the ACTU states that 'Congress stresses that proper consultation and agreement be reached between Governments and the Trade Unions prior to the introduction of legislation and amendments to existing legislation'. (Article 7, p.75)

Moreover the ACTU emphasizes that representatives involved in employee participation structures must be trade unionists employed by the enterprise or persons nominated by trade unionists; and that these trade unionists must be financial. It could be argued, therefore, that the approach by the trade union movement is one which sees employee participation as a means of achieving greater trade union control, not employee control. But, in any event, with respect to this Bill, it is easy to foresee trade union opposition to any attempt to side-step their authority in the labour movement.

It is the view not only of the Government but also of the C.A.I. and ACTU, as reflected in joint statements by the National Employee Participation Steering Committee, that there can be no detailed blueprint for employee participation which will suit all enterprises. Within each enterprise, employers and employees need to work together to develop approaches which suit the particular needs and circumstances of each organisation. It is neither possible nor desirable to develop, as is suggested in this Bill, a master plan to be adopted by all enterprises.

Finally, there would be a great deal of administrative complexity in the scheme. The Board could be required eventually to watch over each resident Australian company with regard to organisational structure, the operation of the Consultative Council and the level of employee share ownership. It would therefore come to have very great powers and influence over the private sector and, in some respects, duplicate the functions of the National Companies and Securities Commission. In particular, the share ownership level of employees in an individual enterprise could fluctuate dramatically over a year. The cost to the taxpayer of the bureaucratic organisation which would be required to oversee the scheme could thus be extremely high-and, to repeat, the present bill makes no provision for supplying the funds necessary to the Boards arrangement and operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to debate this matter afforded by the introduction of the Industrial Democracy Bill 1981. The tax laws are used for a variety of purposes. However, I do not believe it is appropriate to use tax concessions to introduce industrial democracy to Australia. Industrial democracy as a concept has a lot to commend it. But I believe if it is to be viable it has to stand on its own two feet. It will not succeed merely by concessions being given to business. One must have the right sort of relationship between the people who run the organisations and the workers who are producing the goods. I believe that if we are to introduce any tax concessions it must be to help small business and we can do this by providing differential rates to private companies. We should help small business in this way rather than forcing a concept of industrial democracy on business through the tax mechanism.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the pressure of business I regret that what I have to say will be somewhat truncated, as I have indicated that I will speak for only two minutes. I believe that the Industrial Democracy Bill deserves a great deal more time in discussion and debate than we are able to afford it on this last night of the last sitting day of the last session of the year. I, along with Senator Button, welcome the introduction of this piece of legislation. I congratulate Senator Siddons on his initiative in bringing it forward. It is a step along the way to the principle of worker participation in industry. As I understand it, it does not go to the final step of worker participation at board level, making provision for election to that level directly from the employee level.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been a very strong advocate of the principle of co-operatives. I have had a long association with the role of co-operatives in the economic and social development of developing countries. I have always been concerned with co-operative societies throughout Australia. I think they do a marvellous job. A recent Four Corners program reported on the famous Mondragon experiment, which is no longer an experiment but a very profitable operation in the Basque country of Spain. This Bill, of course, does not relate to co-operatives but it is a step in the general direction of involving workers in their enterprise for the benefit both of the workers themselves and of the enterprise. I say that Senator Siddons is to be congratulated for bringing the Bill forward. I wish it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I foreshadow certain amendments to the Bill, which I shall move in the Committee stage. The Bill has been discussed with many individuals and organisations, and I wish to pay tribute to the many people who have helped to shape it. We see it as an important first step in the humanisation of the work place in Australia. To refresh the memories of honourable senators, who in recent weeks have been deluged with legislation, I shall very briefly-I assure the Senate that I will be brief-outline the functions of the Bill. The Bill is designed to encourage the introduction of industrial democracy through granting reductions in company tax for enterprises which meet certain specified criteria. In essence, the Bill provides for the establishment of a seven-member Industrial Democracy Board, with three members nominated by the Minister for Industrial Relations, three members nominated by the Australian Council of Trade Unions, and one member nominated by the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The Board is to maintain a register of industrial democracy enterprises which, in the opinion of the Board, substantially comply with the following four criteria: Firstly, the employees to share ownership of at least 14 per cent of the issued share capital of the enterprise; secondly, the activities of the enterprise to be carried out through autonomous working groups based on profit centres within the enterprise; thirdly, a profit sharing scheme which distributes an agreed proportion of the profits within each group to employees of the enterprise; and, fourthly, a consultative or works council, one-half of the members of which are elected by employees and the other half of which are elected by the management. If enterprises substantially comply with these criteria the company tax paid by a registered enterprise is to be reduced by 8 percentage points.

I will comment briefly on Senator Chaney's remarks. I believe that the seven-member Board would be composed of part time members, at least in the initial stages. I believe it would not have a heavy work load. The whole thrust of the Bill is a first step in this important area. As I said in my second reading speech, probably not more than 5 per cent of the enterprises in this country would attempt to meet the criteria in the first instance and those companies that did attempt to meet them could be looked at with great interest by governments, trade unions and employers as a valuable experiment to see how well this concept was working.

Senator Chaney commented that the Australian Council of Trade Unions would not support the Bill. At least, that is what I understood him to say. I am happy to say that the ACTU described the Bill as an important and welcome initiative. The ACTU in a written submission to me stated:

The Bill will provide an impetus for further discussion and action towards the promotion of industrial democracy schemes in Australian enterprises and the improvement of job satisfaction for workers in this country.
It went on to state:

The Bill is concerned with improving the quality of the work life through the encouragement of greater worker participation in enterprises and that the principles of the new Bill, if implemented, would tend to encourage better industrial relations.

That was the comment from the ACTU. However, the ACTU did have, as Senator Button has outlined, some important reservations about the Bill. The amendments which I intend to move in the Committee stage will go some way towards meeting the reservations of the ACTU. However, I must stress that although the Bill is still not all that the ACTU might want, its President, Mr Cliff Dolan-I would like to comment in passing that in all the discussions and negotiations I have had with him he has been very reasonable and forthright-and other officials of the ACTU support the Bill as an important development in the area of employee participation. That, I suggest to honourable senators on the Government side, is no mean first step.

The ACTU, however, as one would expect, remains committed to encouraging directly the adoption by enterprises of suitable forms of industrial democracy through discussion and negotiation between unions and employees, as its position paper on this subject clearly points out. Basically, the ACTU would like a broader range of criteria including agreement between unions and management on an industrial democracy scheme for a particular enterprise. In other words, it is saying that it wants a more varied approach to the subject. The amendments which will be moved at the Committee stage represent an attempt to give the Board greater discretion so that it can take up some of these objections which have been put forward by the ACTU. The ACTU also believes that the promise of greater efficiency and improved industrial relations should be sufficient incentive in themselves. Of course, Senator Chaney made this point also. In an ideal world perhaps they should be, but sometimes people need to be educated to perceive their own self-interest. This Bill gives that educative process a nudge.

One of the most important functions of the Industrial Democracy Board would be to publish and disseminate information on industrial democracy. This Bill allows a start to be made. The whole subject is immense. It is the greatest challenge, I believe, facing Australian industry today or likely to face it during the rest of this century. This Bill does not pretend to solve that immense problem. It is a first step, an important step, a step that does not lay down firm directions but seeks to encourage firms in this area. We need a humanisation of the work place and a work environment that frees people to use their human qualities of imagination, initiative and technical expertise. These vital human qualities frustrate people if they are not given the scope to be developed. The undoubted virtues of industrial democracy in many forms are practised in this country by diverse organisations. Parts of the concept of industrial democracy are practised by Repco Auto Parts and Fletcher Jones and Staff, quite diverse and separated industries--

TALK.START.PARA: —They haven't even tax concessions to do it, have they?
—Let me finish, please. In spite of these cases, relatively few Australian firms have adopted any, let alone all, of the reforms this Bill gives enterprises an incentive to introduce.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1979 I had the honour of giving the Kirby lecture. I discussed some of the principles that are incorporated in this Bill. I have lectured on the subject since that date hundreds of times in universities and colleges of advanced education and to business leaders and experts in this area around the country. Unfortunately the progress has been slow. A tremendous amount of talk and a lot of lip-service was given to the principle but there has been very little action in this country. Australia is rapidly becoming an industrial backwater. Countries like Japan have been practising these principles for 10, 15 and 20 years and are so far ahead in industrial relations that the Japanese are now going to the United States, to the centre of industry in Detroit, and explaining to the leaders of the automotive industry there how to develop quality circles and decentralised management. Australia has not even begun to think about this matter to any great degree. A number of improvements have been suggested to the Bill by various individuals. I thank them for their contribution. The Bill has also been discussed extensively by the Opposition. Some drafting points have been improved with the help of the Opposition. I am delighted to acknowledge its support for this Bill and, in particular, the support of the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, and his staff, even though the Bill may not go as far as the Opposition wants.

The thrust of the amendments I now propose is to give the Industrial Democracy Board greater flexibility in dealing with applications for registration under the Bill. I believe Senator Chaney made the point that the Bill requires too much of most organisations. We take that point. We have attempted in our amendments to give greater flexibility to the Board. In particular, the Board is now empowered to lay down criteria for registrations of enterprises employing less than 25 non-executive employees and to lay down guidelines regarding the share of profits to be distributed to employees, the allocation of shares to employees, and to distinguish between non-executive and executive employees for various purposes. I commend the amendments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I amend the motion of which I have given notice. I move accordingly. The motion now reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the following matters be referred to the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence:
(a) The human rights and the condition of the people of East Timor
(b) United Nations resolutions and actions with regard to East Timor; and
(c) the appropriate policies to be adopted by an Australian Government in relation to matters revealed in the Committee's inquiry.

(2) That, as soon as practicable after this Resolution is agreed to by the Senate, the Committee cause public advertisements to be made advising of the reference of these matters to the Committee and inviting submissions in relation to these matters, such submissions to be lodged with the Clerk of the Senate on or before 30 March 1982.

I will just indicate briefly something of the history of this matter. I think there has been reasonably widespread concern in the Australian community about the situation in East Timor. That concern has manifested itself in two ways: Firstly, concern about human rights in East Timor and, secondly, concern about the condition of the people in East Timor particularly in relation to the question of poverty. I think that a number of honourable senators on both sides of the Senate have been subject to representations about these issues from the food aid organisations in particular or overseas aid organisations in general, which organisations have maintained a commendable and consistent interest in the plight of the people of East Timor. It is in response to those pressures that honourable senators on the Opposition side of the chamber-Australian Democrat and Labor senators-and some honourable senators on the Government side have been concerned to see that this issue be examined by a committee of this Parliament.

I say on behalf of the Opposition that an approach was made to the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence to see whether it would deal with this matter which is expressed in the terms of reference set out in the motion which I moved. We were told by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence that because of other commitments it would not be able to consider this matter at all. It was consequent upon that situation that it was proposed to set up a select committee of the Senate to look at this matter. It was for that reason that I moved some two weeks ago that a senate select committee on East Timor be established with terms of reference almost identical to the ones the subject of this motion tonight. Subsequently-I see that all sorts of influences are at work in this place-it was suddenly decided today by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence that it would examine this reference. There is some urgency about it. It should not be put off indefinitely because there is a great deal of community concern about it. For that reason, in paragraph (2) of the motion which I moved the suggestion is made that submissions should be called for on this issue and that they should be returned to the Clerk of the Senate on or before 30 March 1982.

I want to say one or two things about this motion. I said earlier that a number of food aid organisations and other bodies in Australia had expressed an ongoing and continuing concern about essentially quite basic humanitarian issues relating to Timor. The Opposition does not intend that this Committee should embark on a political investigation of rights and wrongs of the past. It is my view that not one of the major political parties-that is, the Australian Labor Party and the present Liberal-National Country Party coalition-has, if I might put it mildly, an impeccable record in relation to East Timor issues.

What we are concerned about is that the inquiry should be directed towards very positive matters, namely, the deprivation of human rights and human poverty. It will be a continuing, ongoing and running sore in Australia's public posturing in the world at large if we continue to talk as we do about human rights in various other places in the world and ignore a situation which exists on our own doorstep. That matter cannot be swept under the carpet. It will not be allowed to be swept under the carpet because of the great community concern about it and because of the continuing interest of the Fourth Committee of the United Nations on the East Timor issue. It is in that general spirit that I move my motion.

I said earlier that two groups were particularly involved in the matter-the aid organisations and people concerned about human rights issues. It might be asked: What could the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee, which will now be asked to examine the matter, find in relation to the issue; what will be new? Of course, it is unlikely that it would be allowed to visit East Timor. It is unlikely that it would get a great deal of co-operation from governments. But the point is, of course, that new information about Timor is available. There is new information about massive poverty in East Timor. It has been possible to bring out of the country, one way or another, new information about human rights situations in East Timor. There is a growing concern about several other issues in relation to East Timor which are of particular relevance to Australia. One of those concerns refugees from East Timor, a large number of whom are in Australia-I think the second largest number after Portugal. This raises the question of family reunions for those refugees.

It is now three years since arrangements were reached with the Indonesian Government, arrangements which have not been fulfilled in respect of the reunion of families who have come to Australia. Only a short while ago I asked a question in the Senate-to which, I think, I have not yet received an answer-about a report of 60 Timorese being arrested in Jakarta, effectively on their way to Australia to rejoin their families. That sort of matter is one which a Committee of this kind can legitimately look at. Mr Deputy President, in conclusion, in view of the terms of this motion and the reference to the Foreign Affairs and Defence Committee, I seek leave to amend my motion by replacing the words 'Clerk of the Senate' in the second last line in the motion with the word 'Committee'. Submissions would then be lodged with the Committee. Paragraph (2) of my notice of motion would then read:

(2) That, as soon as practicable after this Resolution is agreed to by the Senate, the Committee cause public advertisements to be made advising of the reference of these matters to the Committee and inviting submissions in relation to these matters, such submissions to be lodged wit' the Committee on or before 30 March 1982.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that a number of honourable senators in this place have a very genuine and legitimate concern about this issue. I believe that for those who have taken an interest in this matter and have taken the opportunity of consultations with Timorese refugee groups, this issue, in terms of the actions which Australia should take and of the size of the human tragedy involved, transcends parties. I have great pleasure in commending the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in seconding this motion because I believe it is desirable that the Senate should undertake an investigation, in the general language in which this motion is now phrased, of the situation which has arisen in East Timor. Without going into great detail tonight, because I know that time is short, I believe we have great obligations to Timor and to the Timorese people-obligations which go back many years to war time periods and obligations since then. I am afraid that there have been certain regrettable incidents in our past in regard to this matter. I think it important that we should recognise that, whatever the legal situation of Timor might be, we still have a continuing obligation in this matter because of evidence which has come forward in recent times to indicate that in East Timor there are possibilities of famine, that there is certainly a great deal of discrimination and that there has been unfortunate behaviour on the part of the ruling authorities. So, we are not free of our obligations.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the motion as now proposed is a good one. I take it, from information given to me tonight, that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence is prepared to accept this reference, otherwise I would not be prepared to second the motion in this way. Honourable senators will recall that in October I endeavoured to ask questions of the Chairman of the Committee and to persuade the Committee to take up a reference of this type because I believe it was the appropriate Committee to do so. It is the Committee which this Senate has created and to which it gives authority to speak on foreign affairs matters. Therefore, I believe it is obviously the better choice. Having failed at that time to achieve that result, I approached the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, but it said that likewise it did not have the opportunity to take up this matter because of other work. I believe the other alternative which was subsequently floated, that of a select committee set up merely for this purpose, was certainly the least adequate choice. Because of the number of select committees already in existence in this Senate, the choice of such a committee would have meant considerable delay before this matter came forward.

I believe there is in the Australian community a very strong demand for such an investigation. I have received from organisations scores of letters and resolutions. I realise that some of them are part of an organised campaign which is perhaps directed more particularly to those honourable senators, such as Senators Bonner, Kilgariff and Martin, who are known to have taken a particular interest in the matter for many years and who have been very active and concerned with the cause of the Timorese people. Probably no subject has figured so largely in my correspondence in recent months as this. Therefore, one cannot disregard the concern which people in this country feel for the Timorese situation. I believe the Committee would be concerned not so particularly with past actions and past mistakes but rather with present situations.

The motion, in the way in which it is phrased, is directed more particularly to human rights and the conditions of the people of East Timor, to certain resolutions of the United Nations and to the appropriate policies to be adopted. It is certainly predicated on the present situation. Of course, it concerns the reunion of families, which Senator Button referred to; and nobody can be very satisfied with the delays and complaints with regard to that situation. I do not propose to go into those details tonight. They are matters for the Committee. I believe evidence will come forward. Likewise, I will not go into the question of what is happening in Timor. I believe that investigations of this sort may well bring up a lot of material.

It may be that this Committee cannot go to Timor. Several of us have endeavoured to go to Timor on previous occasions as members of this Parliament and have been refused entry. But I do not give up on the possibility that the Indonesians may be persuaded to allow a responsible committee of this Parliament to go into Timor and make its own observations with people who can speak the language. I believe that evidence is available outside Timor, in Australia and overseas. People have come from that country in recent times. One knows that so far, following questions asked in the Parliament, there have been some requests by the Government to obtain information, particularly in relation to recent reports which have been sent from Timor and which have complained of very serious violations of human rights. The answer to a question which appears in Hansard of 12 November this year states:
The Indonesian Department of Foreign Affairs has provided the following official response to the request from the Australian Embassy in Jakarta for comment on recent Press reports about East Timor:

The Government has taken the matter into its attention and is still processing it to verify the authenticity of the document itself. As for the sensational news reports, it is noted as an annual exercise before the United Nations General Assembly session commences. It is aimed to attract public sympathy and to discredit the efforts made by the Indonesian Government in East Timor.

I regret and deplore that that sort of attitude was taken in reply. I seriously suggest, as one who has no reason for any particular dislike of the Indonesian Government and wants to see that country grow in strength economically and in good relations with Australia, that it is not necessary for a country such as that to take the attitude which the Soviet Union very much takes. It says: 'It is our domestic affair; do not interfere'. That is not accepted by human rights defenders anywhere in the world and certainly not in this country. I believe it is important to stress with the Indonesian Government the idea that a sensible, carefully conducted inquiry which, of course, does not try to inflame but tries to inform the Australian people, is one which will do its best to improve ultimate relations with the Indonesian people. Therefore, I believe this inquiry, which is now to be held by the proper and recognised authority on foreign affairs in the Senate, ought to be supported. I, therefore, have much pleasure in supporting the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have held a position of preference in the past that this matter should be considered by a select committee only because a select committee would be able to give its full and concentrated attention to the matter. However, it is of primary significance that the matter should arise and be discussed within the terms of reference. If, indeed, the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence can accommodate this reference in the midst of the many other pressing matters which engage its attention-and, after all, members of that committee are merely human-and can provide a report which is satisfactory to the Australian people, the Australian Democrats certainly support this initiative. At this stage I only want to add to the comments Senator Missen has made that I have found this to be an issue of very great importance in Australia. The number of people at a meeting in Melbourne, at which both Senator Missen and I spoke, surprised me; there were 600 or 700 people at it. It was on the issue of East Timor.

SPEECH.PARA: I look forward to the consideration of this reference and I look forward to attending some of the Committee's meetings. I feel that the Australian people will be looking forward to a very thorough report from the Committee. I feel that any effort it can make in that direction would be worth while, including going to Timor, if possible, as Senator Missen has mentioned. I do not see that the Committee can really report in any conscientious or final way unless facilities are made for it to go to Timor. We urge the Government or any necessary authority to try to make that facility open to the Committee. On that basis, the Australian Democrats support the amended motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak very briefly. I too support the inquiry-and, in fact, any inquiry-into past events and present and future happenings in East Timor. I wish to speak because of something Senator Mason said and just to repeat the old problem that the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence has always had in the many years I have been on it-that is, the lack of funds and facilities to travel abroad to carry out investigations. On a recent reference two other members of that Committee and I paid our own way around Asia in an attempt to pick up information. That finally allowed us to bring down a report. It seems that for there to be a thorough investigation of the situation in East Timor the Committee should be provided with funds to travel to East Timor if that is possible. But more so I believe that the Committee should be given the ability to travel to Portugal which seems to be the source of a lot of information that has recently been available via the underground route. I think it would be a pity if we could not tap that source as a Committee to fill in the gaps in the information that may be available in other areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a short statement on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment on comments made by Senator Keeffe during the Committee stage of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) on Thursday of last week.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly I would like to point out to the Senate that I am aware of the Press release issued by the Vietnam Veterans Association on 18 November. In fact, I issued a Press release in response on the same day. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard my Press release of 18 November 1981, relating to the pesticides inquiry being conducted by the Science and Environment Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows:
STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE AND THE ENVIRONMENT
Pesticides Inquiry-Examining the use of 2,4,5-T, 2,4-Dand Agent Orange

Senator Don Jessop (Liberal, S.A.), Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment, expressed surprise at the claim by Mr P. Thompson, National President, Vietnam Veterans' Association of Australia (VVAA), that the Association was being disadvantaged in the organising of the public hearing to be held in Sydney on 8-9 December 1981. Senator Jessop said that Mr Thompson's claim that the VVAA would be allowed an appearance of only 1 1/2 hours before the Committee compared to at least six hours by Commonwealth Departments, neglected a number of very important points and was a gross misrepresentation.

(1) A number of specialist witnesses who were planning to appear with the VVAA would now be appearing individually, making a total scheduled appearance time of 6 hours compared with 5 hours for Commonwealth Departments. It is anticipated that further VVAA witnesses will give evidence at later hearings.
(2) Mr Thompson did not seem to appreciate that in arranging public hearings it was the Committee's normal practice to allocate time periods to witnesses for scheduling purposes.
(3) The organisation of the public hearing was quite flexible and extra time could be given to witnesses if necessary. Witnesses could also be recalled for further examination at future hearings.

In relation to Mr Thompson's statement that the Committee was delaying consideration of the VVAA's case, Senator Jessop said that the Committee had to allow a reasonable time period for the preparation of submissions and that was the reason why, following the initial hearings in December, further hearings had been scheduled for 9, 10 and 11 February 1982.

Senator Jessop completely rejected Mr Thompson's claim that a Judicial Inquiry would be more effective than the Senate Committee's investigation. Senator Jessop pointed out that it is the Government's policy to respond to Committee reports within six months of their being tabled and that no such obligation existed in relation to Judicial Inquiries. Senate Committee's were also able to review actions taken in relation to reports.

Senator Jessop added that the Committee would seek the approval of the President of the Senate to appoint specialist advisers in the fields of genetics, research design and epidemiology to provide it with independent expert advice during the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to reiterate that witnesses appearing on behalf of the Vietnam Veterans Association, together with several specialist advisers to the organisation who will be giving evidence separately, are scheduled for some six hours of hearing time. Clearly, as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) pointed out last Thursday, the scheduling of witnesses is completely the responsibility of the Committee. I can assure the Senate that at no time has the Minister or his Department attempted to influence the time allocated to witnesses. I am pleased to report that the Committee staff are keeping in close contact with Mr Phil Thompson, President of the Vietnam Veterans Association. They are offering his organisation their co-operation and assistance in ensuring that witnesses who want to give evidence to the Committee are being given this opportunity. The scheduling of witnesses is now proceeding smoothly and should soon be finalised. I am assured that the Vietnam Veterans Association is quite happy with the proposed arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate authorises the President to have closed circuit television facilities for the monitoring of the Senate Chamber installed at certain locations and in offices of certain Senate Office Holders as approved by the President.

I do not think that I need to explain that the brevity of my case tonight has nothing to do with the importance of this matter but obviously relates to the problem we have with time. I will be brief. This is a matter that I believe is very important. I do not think I have to press the point, but honourable senators appreciate the need for the three party Whips to know what is going on in the chamber. They need to know that the Minister or shadow Minister is on duty. They need to know that speakers are ready to move into their speeches. I recall that Senator Brown used to speak with his eyes shut. I recall one evening that he was speaking with his eyes shut and sat down also with his eyes shut but unfortunately there was no one else in the chamber and he had to spring to his feet very smartly and recommence his speech. If we had some way of watching what was going on that sort of thing could be avoided.

It is important that the Whips ensure that the chamber is kept. This is the responsibility, by tradition, of the Government. They need to know how many people are in the chamber. The Whips also need to be alerted to any problems-I use that word in the fullest sense of the word. We need to know what is going on so that we can perhaps avert some of those possible problems. This can be done by Whips sitting in the chamber; by frequent movements of the Whips in and out of the chamber through the various doors; by having a peep-hole in the wall to the left of the Chair; or by closed circuit television. We have tried all of these. Firstly, the Whips sat in the chamber. I think it would be generally agreed that that is time consuming and that it is not really an efficient use of time to have the Whips sitting in the chamber all the time. When I refer to Whips, I refer also to Deputy Whips since either the Whip or the Deputy Whip is in the chamber.

There are certain problems, of course. If the Whip is in the chamber he has to listen to the speakers, and that is sometimes disturbing, given some of the speakers. The frequent movements in and out of the chamber are disturbing. They disturb the people who are speaking, and the person is not always there when necessary. The peep-hole is not effective. One has to be about 6 feet 4 inches tall to be able to operate it. Apart from not having good coverage, we notice that when we open the slide a light shines through from the Whip's office. So closed circuit television is quite clearly the answer. It gives a good coverage; the cameras give a good picture of what is happening. The proposal is to have four cameras mounted in the chamber. These cameras will be small. They are similar to the units that were on display here a short time ago and similar to those that operate in shops. They will be mounted to the ceiling under the galleries and will not be obvious. Certainly they will not detract from the look of the chamber. Monitors will be placed in the Whips' offices so that the Whips will be able to see both sides of the chamber. Basically, each Whip will be concerned with his own side of the chamber.

Let me stress-again I am hurrying this because of the time factor-that the test we carried out, of which all honourable senators were aware, was authorised by the Senate Standing Orders Committee. The monitors will be placed in the Whips' offices and nowhere else. My motion allows the President to have a monitor in the corridor or in his office, but that is at his discretion. No monitors will be placed in members' rooms. Let me stress very strongly that this is not associated at all with the possible televising of the Parliament at a later stage. This has no connection at all. In no sense is there any idea of spying on members. The system will enable the Whip, instead of looking at members from his seat in the chamber, to look at them from his office. It is simply using technology to be more efficient. Once again I stress that the control of this system is clearly in the hands of the President since the wording of the motion gives him the authority to say where the facilities will be placed.

I conclude by saying that it is not that we do not enjoy the speeches of our colleagues from both sides of the chamber-we would like to sit here and listen to them sometimes-but we want to be like other senators and be able to do some work in our offices as well as doing the job we have been given by being elected as Whips. I wish to thank the Australian Broadcasting Commission for arranging the test which was done a short time ago and for giving us its advice. I thank you, Mr President, for your co-operation in assisting with the arranging of the test and your involvement in it. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion that has been introduced by the Opposition Whip, Senator Robertson. I think that the case for the closed circuit television monitoring of the Senate chamber has been well put by t'e honourable senator. I recommend it and support the motion.

— The stage was reached today where, because the order of business was being changed around, I could not even go out of the chamber unless I had a radio to enable me to listen to what was going on here. If closed circuit television facilities are to be introduced in the Whips' offices I would be interested in having a discussion with you, Mr President, about that matter at some stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the debate be adjourned to a later hour this day.
I so move because it might be possible to resolve some differences of opinion which exist between members of the Senate about this issue.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ELECTORAL SYSTEM

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to amend motion No. 70 standing in my name. There has been some consideration of this matter to meet the requirements of the Senate. The proposal now is to amend the motion in the following way: Paragraph (1) (a) is to read:

SPEECH.PARA: That a Joint Select Committee to be known as the Joint Committee on the Electoral System--
In sub-paragraph (1) (viii), the words after 'media coverage' are to read:
and the allocation of time by the Australian Broadcasting Commission-

Finally, I seek leave to amend the last paragraph in which we call upon the President of the Senate to take such steps as are necessary to call for advertisements and submissions by interested parties in respect of a review of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. That paragraph has been amended to read:

That, as soon as practicable after this Resolution is agreed to by the Senate, the President shall authorize public advertisements inviting submissions in relation to the matters referred to in paragraph (1) (a) of this Resolution, such submissions to be lodged with the Clerk of the Senate on or before 10 March 1982, and that any such submissions be presented to the Senate and forwarded to the Committee in the event that the House of Representatives agrees to the establishment of the Committee.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) (a) That a Joint Select Committee, to be known as the Joint Committee on the Electoral System, be appointed to inquire into and report upon all aspects of the conduct of elections for the Parliament of the Commonwealth and matters related thereto, including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing-
(i) public funding and disclosure of sources of funds;
(ii) electoral advertising;
(iii) franchise and registration of voters;
(iv) voting systems;
(v) polling procedures;
(vi) legislation governing, and operation of, the Australian Electoral Office;
(vii) ballot paper format;
(viii) media coverage and the allocation of time by the Australian Broadcasting Commission, and
(ix) electoral distribution, procedures and systems.
(b) That provisions relating to the composition and powers of the Committee be contained in subsequent Resolutions.
(c) That the date on which the Committee shall commence its inquiry be contained in a subsequent Resolution.
(d) That the foregoing provisions of this Resolution be communicated to the House of Representatives by Message, requesting its concurrence in the Resolution.

(2) That, as soon as practicable after this Resolution is agreed to by the Senate, the President shall authorize public advertisements inviting submissions in relation to the matters referred to in paragraph (1) (a) of this Resolution, such submissions to be lodged with the Clerk of the Senate on or before 10 March 1982, and that any such submissions be presented to the Senate and forwarded to the Committee in the event that the House of Representatives agrees to the establishment of the Committee.

It was a decision of the Australian Labor Party originally to try to establish a joint committee because it accepted the principle that a change in the electoral system was more likely to be of effect and value to those who reside in the House of Representatives rather than in the Senate. However, at that time, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) refused to consider such a submission. We believe that if the Senate were to adopt such a proposal this evening and make a request to the House of Representatives it is likely the Government would reconsider that matter and agree to the appointment of such a joint committee. I indicate to the Senate that the Government has recognised the need for amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act. It called for a report which was made available on 22 August 1979. A further report was made available to the Government this year but those reports have not been made public documents.

Honourable senators might recall the appointment of the Harders Inquiry into the Disclosure of Electoral Expenditure which was designed to inquire into a number of matters associated with elections. That report is in the hands of the Government, and similarly, has not been made a public document. As it is the desire of the Opposition, with the support of the Australian Democrats and the independent in this place, for the Senate to have a look at the Commonwealth Electoral Act in the event of the Government not proceeding to carry out what one of its departments has suggested, there is a need for a thorough overhaul of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. In fact, in that first report which has been suppressed significant recommendations were made upon which the Government has not been prepared to act. I ask the Senate to take the action that we propose. A lot more could be said about this matter but, in view of the pressure of time, I ask the Senate at least to take this step which will enable the President to call for submissions from interested parties and groups during the period in which the Senate is in recess. When the Senate and the House of Representatives reassemble in February next year the matters can then be considered by such a joint committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak from two points of view on this motion. I speak briefly as a Minister, to the substance of the motion. I will not go through the amended form of the motion at this stage but will just reiterate that the Government has already taken a number of initiatives in the area of examining electoral procedures and the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I place on record the fact that last year the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Newman, announced on 2 December 1980 a wide ranging comprehensive review of electoral legislation and procedures. That review is still continuing; it is incomplete. The Senate should understand that what it is proposing is taking place against the background of a continuing government review.

SPEECH.PARA: Also last year Sir Clarrie Harders was appointed by the Government to conduct an independent inquiry into matters of electoral expenditures. That report-I think I referred to it on 19 August in the Senate-is also before the Government and will require some attention. That study took Sir Clarrie Harders some months of full time effort and the Government needs a fair time-whatever that is-to respond. There is a background of government activity in this area. Whether the Senate decides on the matter of substance to proceed is a matter for the Senate. I do not offer a government view except to say that in my opinion anything that the Government proposes as a result of its consideration would have to come to the Parliament and to the Senate for endorsement and resolution. There is no way that any government proposal could avoid being considered here. It would open up the question of the Electoral Act for parliamentary review when that happened.

I put that matter aside. While I may be a Minister I am no less a senator than any other senator in this chamber and I have as much interest in the committee system as any other senator. I have a past record of committee service and I am quite troubled by the motion originally proposed by Senator Geitzelt from the point of view of a senator who has served and still serves on Senate committees. I have concerns about the procedures which are being sought and about any proposal for any kind of joint committee. I am now talking personally, as a senator in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a Senate chauvinist.

—Senator Evans has a particular view. In how many of the joint committees does the Senate get fair or equal treatment? Let us take that question first. I ask honourable senators, before they seek to establish a joint committee, to look at the joint committees which exist and at the relative strengths of honourable senators who serve on those committees and at the people who occupy the chairmanship of those committees. Sir Magnus Cormack as an exception, had a chairmanship, but mostly the Senate is subjugated on joint committees. That is my belief. Having served, like Senator Georges who is trying to interject, on joint committees that is one of my points of concern. I find that joint committees do not operate to the advantage of the Senate. I am not certain that a joint select committee would operate to the advantage of the Senate. If it is the wish of honourable senators to put this study into the hands of the House of Representatives, which is what will happen on the experience of numbers as these committees have been constituted, then so be it.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned about the whole question of proliferating Senate committees. I have stayed out of most of the debates, but on this occasion I want to raise my concern and say that the Senate established its committee system in 1970 with two standing committees. It has expanded the committee system at a steady rate. It now has eight standing committees and the system, as it was proposed and as it has grown, has never envisaged a large or excessive number of select committees. In fact, one might even say that the Senate is its own worst enemy in the way in which it has watched the committee system grow. The original six standing committees extended to seven committees in 1974 and to eight committees in 1975. The estimates committees started with six committees and have now extended to eight committees. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances formally extended its role in 1979.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the negative.
