DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED SELECT COMMITTEE ON THE ELECTORAL SYSTEM

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: -Last week the Senate established a further standing committee-Senator Missen will recall this-to undertake the scrutiny of Bills. There are now 23 active Senate committees. There are five joint committees on which the Senate is represented. There are 28 active committees, even ignoring the committees that have not met for years or that have met only occasionally. There are still only 64 senators. If we exlude the six Ministers-I serve on the Standing Orders Committee but basically Ministers do not play a significant role-and we exclude the Presiding Officers and probably most of the office holders, that leaves only about 52 senators and each senator, on average, with the committee load we have now, is required to serve on three or four committees just to make the system work. So I have a concern about the proliferation in the number of committees. Of course, the proliferation of select committees is adding to our problems because we are having difficulties in staffing the select committees.
—That is the Government's doing.

—Senator McLaren cannot avoid making a partisan interjection when I am trying to make a speech about problems facing the Senate. The matter is of no concern to me personally. I remind honourable senators that between 1971 and 1976 the average number of select committees was about one or two in each year. At some stages there were three, but mostly it was only one or two.

SPEECH.PARA: We have been establishing select committees which we have to service. We have to service them with staff, we have to service them administratively and we have to service them with membership. I am concerned about the capacity of the Senate to continue to service the committees it sets up. There is a limit to what we can do; there has to be a finite limit somewhere. I put it to honourable senators that we need to consider how many select committees should be operating at any one time. I suggest that two or three select committees might be about the limit which we can service and operate properly at any one time. I think until tonight there were three select committees actively operating. There were five shown on the Notice Paper, but two of them have completed their work. Senator Gietzelt's motion originally set out to establish a parking lot, as it were, to give precedence to particular select committees for the next vacancy that might come up. He gave notice yesterday of a motion to establish a committee in principle, to be established in fact at some later date. I am not certain that that is a desirable development for the committee system, but that is a matter for the Senate in the end.

I come now to the motion. The procedure which is being proposed is extraordinary. If honourable senators look at the motion proposed by Senator Gietzelt, they will see that paragraphs (1) (a), (b), (c) and (d) really are unexceptionable. The Senate will either agree or disagree to them on their merits. But paragraph (2) of this motion is quite extraordinary, I think. It is certainly unprecedented in my experience in this place. I do not know whether it is unprecedented in the operation of Senate committees. I am not certain that it is really proper in a parliamentary sense. Let us go through what was proposed yesterday, when notice of the motion was given, and what is proposed now. What was proposed yesterday was extraordinary enough. That proposition was that a committee be established in principle, with the details to be spelled out by later resolution, but that we were to proceed nevertheless, before the committee was established, before its membership was established, before its secretariat existed and before it had determined the form in which it wanted submissions, to advertise for submissions to the committee.

That is extraordinary enough. I would suggest-since it no longer applies I just raise this matter for honourable senators to consider-that it is a procedure which we probably would not want to adopt. At the very least a committee should have a chance to meet and to make some decisions about its procedures, the form in which it wants submissions, the priority it will give to the various matters contained in its terms of reference-is that so unreasonable-and then to advertise for submissions to meet its determination as to how it will carry out the reference given to it by the Senate. But what is proposed now really is extraordinary. The Senate on its own does not have the capacity to establish a joint committee. A joint committee can be established only by resolution of both Houses of the Parliament. This committee can only be recommended by the Senate.

Paragraph (1) (d) of the motion suggests that 'the foregoing provisions of this Resolution be communicated to the House of Representatives by Message'. The purpose of that is to seek its concurrence in the formation of a committee. As a senator, I find it improper that we should seek in paragraph (2) to advertise for submissions to a committee which really does not exist and which cannot exist, in the parliamentary sense, until the other House of Parliament indicates that it wishes to be a part of the joint committee exercise. I put it to honourable senators that that is an extraordinary departure from proper parliamentary practice.

Mr President, I ask whether, in accordance with the Standing Orders, you will separate paragraphs (1) and (2) of the motion and put separate questions on those paragraphs. I indicate that, whatever happens in regard to paragraph (1), I will be seeking to divide the Senate on paragraph (2). I oppose paragraph (2) simply because I believe it is not a proper procedure to undertake. If a committee is to be established under paragraph (1), so be it; but at the least we should have enough concern for parliamentary propriety to wait until the committee is established before we go off seeking submissions to what in the end may be a non-existent committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The arguments Senator Peter Baume has raised on the procedure adopted are very sound. This proposal constitutes a very extraordinary change and precedent for relations between the two Houses of the Parliament. Speaking to the general issue, I believe and have believed for many years that there is a good case for investigation by a committee of the Parliament of a number of questions dealing with electoral reform. A number of matters in Senator Gietzelt's motion call for a great deal of public discussion and consideration. There is no doubt that many divided views are held in the community and there is no doubt that various proposals are of greater interest to some parties than to others. There is a vested interest-not necessarily an improperly vested interest-by some parties in some matters and less interest in others.

SPEECH.PARA: I have taken part in debates on electoral matters in the Senate for many years. I have seen the folly that has been disclosed in Bill after Bill-the fault is not all on one side-whereby the party in power proceeds to put forward proposals for electoral reform that suit it and ignores others. On several occasions I have suggested the desirability of discussing this. I do not resile from the idea that it ought perhaps to be a joint inquiry. It seems to me that it is equally the concern of both Houses of Parliament-though in different ways. They are both concerned with even the electoral methods that apply to the other House. Therefore I strongly believe that there is a good case for a general inquiry to be conducted, preferably at a time when an election is not immediately in the offing, but I do not believe that it would be desirable for a committee to be set up now as a result of this motion.

There is an eagerness to establish an inquiry-in fact many inquiries-at present; there are plenty on the agenda. It has been said that there have been at least two inquiries recently, the results of which have not been made available to the Parliament. I know that the Minister has been undertaking a very extensive review of the Electoral Act. I know also that the Harders inquiry has been concerned with electoral expenditure. It is an important area and I look forward to its report. I regret that the results of recent inquiries are not yet public knowledge. I hope they soon will be. If in fact they do not become public knowledge in the coming year, there will be a stronger case for a committee to be given the power to conduct its own investigation. Clearly, that is something which must be taken into account.

TALK.START.PARA: —When is the next election?

—I remind the honourable senator, who apparently has not been paying close attention, that an election is probably two years off. Of course, in the meantime consideration should be given to this matter. This is a premature motion which is perhaps designed to demonstrate a great deal of interest in electoral reform. But, until we know that there is a joint interest on the part of both Houses of Parliament, such a proposal cannot be effected. I will not go over the ground which Senator Baume covered so ably. It is extraordinary that we should try to prejudge the method and timing of such an inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly, in view of the many different aspects involved it would be necessary for such a committee, if formed, to have sub-committees and to decide the order in which it would conduct its investigations. Therefore, from time to time, it would want to seek up to date submissions on the questions before it. To seek now, before such a committee even exists, submissions on the whole range of matters involved would waste the time of a lot of people who would respond. This proposal is premature. If the motion is not carried tonight, I am sure we will hear more about the matter in the next year. However, the proposals embodied in the amendment, which came to our hands only a few minutes before the debate began, should not be accepted by the Parliament. It would be an affront to the other House to suggest that the matter be proceeded with in the way proposed.

For many years I have called for investigations by committees of the Parliament whereby we could exchange views and perhaps agree to proposals that were not necessarily helpful to our own particular parties. For example, the Australian Labor Party has strongly supported the removal of ballot procedures that make it more difficult for people to vote and cause mistakes to be made. The highest degree of informal voting has taken place in Labor-held electorates. I think this is a greater concern in that area. I do not criticise that matter yet many other matters are of more interest to other people. I believe that none of these matters is unworthy of consideration and acceptance by a committee of this Parliament. However, I do not think it is desirable that the committee be formed in the way in which it is being proposed at present. I hope that the matter will be the subject of further discussion and consideration in the coming year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, suggested that paragraphs (1) and (2) of the motion might be dealt with separately. I know that you, Mr President, have a power under the Standing Orders to so order. Might I indicate on behalf of the Opposition that in view of the comments made by Senator Baume we would be agreeable to that course.

SPEECH.PARA: An invitation was extended to the Government to have a joint committee on this issue. That invitation was refused. The Senate, by passing this motion, would extend a further invitation to the House of Representatives to have a joint committee with the Senate to examine these issues. What the Senate is doing is expressing its view of the terms of reference of a joint committee. If there is to be a joint committee the House of Representatives would express its view. We do not believe there will be a joint committee; such a proposal has been quite explicitly refused in the past. Paragraph (1) (b) of the motion provides that the composition and powers of the committee be contained in a subsequent resolution. That means that, if the House of Representatives accedes to the request for a joint committee, the Senate, acting upon paragraph (2) of the motion, would provide for the composition and powers of the committee, as would the House of Representatives. We see nothing extraordinary about that proposition. All that paragraph (2) of the motion seeks to do is to advertise to the public that there will be a joint committee of the House of Representatives and the Senate if the House of Representatives accedes to this view. If the House of Representatives does not accede to this view, under paragraph 1 (b) the Senate would establish the composition and powers of a Senate committee and-

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot ask for a Senate committee.
—Yes you can.
—The motion is for a joint committee. You would need another motion.
—All one would need would be an amendment to this motion. I think it is inappropriate for the Minister to take technical points in order to defeat or frustrate a sincere and genuine initiative.

SPEECH.PARA: The second part of the motion indicates that the public should be entitled to make submissions on this issue, which is of widespread concern, on or before 10 March 1982. Where those submissions are ultimately directed would be dependent upon the final opinion of the House of Representatives and the Senate. That is all we seek to do. We are happy to accommodate Senator Baume's request for a separate vote on the two parts of the motion. I wanted to explain the connection between the two parts of the motion as we saw it. I did not want to let it be thought that there was some attempt to muddy the waters.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Ryan) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to sex and marital status discrimination.
Bill presented, and-by leave-read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The objectives of this Bill are to implement Australia's treaty obligations under the International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women; in particular, to make sex and marital status discrimination unlawful in a number of specified areas, to promote affirmative action for women in employment and create the necessary enforcement mechanism. The Bill makes it unlawful to discriminate on the ground of sex or marital status in the areas of employment, education, the provision of goods and services, accommodation, land and clubs. The Bill also makes unlawful victimisation, certain advertisements, and aiding and abetting of unlawful acts.
With regard to employment, protection is extended to employees who are employed by:
the Commonwealth or a Commonwealth authority;
a foreign corporation or a trading or financial corporation formed within the limits of the Commonwealth;
a bank other than a State bank;
a firm engaged in insurance other than State insurance;
a firm engaged in trade and commerce with other countries or among the States;
a registered organisation under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904; or
an authority of a State or the Northern Territory in receipt of section 96 payments from the Commonwealth.
All areas of employment in respect of which the Commonwealth has powers will be covered by the provisions of this Bill.

Before proceeding to a description of the Bill, I will indicate the need for this kind of legislation. Legislation of this kind is necessary because throughout Australia woman experience discrimination based on sex or marital status. The result of this discrimination is serious economic and social disadvantage. There are several major areas in which women suffer disadvantage and discrimination.
Employment

The latest unemployment figures as at October 1981 show that 6.7 per cent of the female work force is unemployed compared with 4.7 per cent of the male work force. For females from 15 to 19 years of age, 17.4 per cent are unemployed compared with 12.9 per cent of males aged from 15 to 19 years of age. These figures, of course, do not take into account hidden unemployment amongst women. Because so many women are ineligible for unemployment benefit and therefore do not register, the unemployment situation is actually much worse than the statistics indicate. Migrant women have much higher unemployment rates than do the rest of the female work force, and Aboriginal women have higher rates again.

Another disturbing trend in female employment is the substitution of part time and casual work for full time permanent employment. Most part time and casual jobs do not carry with them the benefits of full time permanent employment such as holiday pay, sick pay, superannuation and long service leave. A total of 36 per cent of the female work force is now in part time or casual employment, the majority of it without the benefits of full time permanent employment; 79 per cent of the part time work force is female.
Income

The 1981 Budget figures on taxable income of males and females show that while 90 per cent of men earn less than $30,000 per annum, about 90 per cent of women earn less than $15,000 per annum; 55 per cent of women who pay tax have incomes of under $10,000 per annum compared with 27 per cent of men. One-quarter of all women paying tax earn less than $7,000 a year. Women comprise a disproportionate percentage of the poor. Almost two-thirds of those who rely on social security benefits for the major proportion of their income are women. This reflects women's reduced access to employment.
Education

In the area of education, not only do few women have post-school qualifications, but even in areas where the number of women students approaches the number of men, such as in undergraduate courses at universities, the women are channelled into restricted areas. Statistics compiled from a sample survey of university graduates in 1980 show that women are significantly under-represented in scientific, mathematical and technical fields of study. For example, in engineering courses less than 2 per cent of students are female; in architecture, dentistrq and commerce only 20 per cent of students are females; in agriculture and economics only 25 per cent of students are female, and in law and mathematics less than 30 per cent of students are female.

Discrimination, both overt and covert, occurs not only in the private sector but also within Commonwealth Government departments and instrumentalities. The most blatant discrimination occurs within the defence forces. Women are not accepted in the Service apprentice and technical training programs in areas where career employment and progression involve employment in restricted areas. Women are not accepted into the Service's youth apprentice schemes. With the exception of adult apprenticeship training in the electrical technical communication category, there is no provision for female technical training in the Royal Australian Navy. Women are not accepted into pilot training in the Royal Australian Air Force. Women are not accepted as officer cadets at the Royal Military College, Duntroon. In the Department of Defence, out of some thousands of engineers, draughtspeople, naval architects, technical officers and trainees in these fields, less than one dozen are women.

It is not only honourable senators and members of the Australian Labor Party who acknowledge the gross economic and social disadvantage of women. I am pleased to note that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in a speech to the Australian Businesswoman of the Year Award on 16 November 1981 acknowledged this disadvantage in some detail. I quote from the Prime Minister's speech:

. . . women now fill only 14 per cent of administrative, executive and managerial positions and although women comprise almost 40 per cent of the workforce, there is an unnatural concentration of women in a narrow range of jobs. For example, 62 per cent are in clerical, sales and service occupations and last year, women made up less than half of 1 per cent of those in apprenticeship training in Australia if hairdressing is excluded. . . .

. . . there are persisting barriers to equality and diversity in employment opportunities. There is in some places a continuing bias in education towards traditionally female occupations. There is in some places a continuing bias of one kind or another in recruitment procedures and without doubt, there are still various forms of discrimination.

Clearly, recognition of discrimination is widespread throughout this Parliament and throughout the community. The legislation that I now propose is a practical and responsible way to reduce the disadvantages acknowledged in the Prime Minister's speech. I must make it clear that legislation will not eliminate all forms of discrimination against women. The effect of social prejudice against women will not be totally and immediately addressed by this legislation. However legislation is the function of this Parliament; it is a part of the achievement of social change, a necessary, if not sufficient, part.

The experience in those States where similar legislation operates has demonstrated beyond doubt that such legislation creates opportunities for women which did not previously exist and that this in turn breaks down community prejudice against women.

In Victoria, for example, the annual report of the Victorian Commissioner for Equal Opportunity, for the year ending 30 June 1980, shows that a total of 164 matters were referred to the Commission. Eighty-two per cent of these complaints were from women and the vast majority were on the grounds of sex discrimination rather than marital status. Complaints of discrimination in employment dominated, making up 72 per cent of all complaints. Of the 164 matters referred to the Commission in 1979-80, 46 per cent resulted in a conciliated settlement, in 38 per cent of cases there had been no negotiated change at the time of the report, 13 per cent of cases were in progress and 2 per cent had been withdrawn.

In South Australia the annual report of the South Australian office of the Commissioner for Equal Opportunity for the year ending 30 June 1980 shows that a total of 189 formal complaints of discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status were received. Of these 79 per cent were received from women and 21 per cent were received from men. Complaints concerned with discrimination in employment comprised 60 per cent of total complaints received. A further 30 per cent of complaints received concerned the provision of goods and services, access to public places, services of public bodies, clubs, credit, banking and insurance. Of the 189 complaints received in 1979-80, 47 per cent were settled by conciliation, 12 per cent were withdrawn, 19 per cent were found to have no basis or found to be outside the jurisdiction of the Commissioner and a further 22 per cent had been redirected or were in progress at the time of the report.

In New South Wales the report of the New South Wales Anti Discrimination Board for the year ending 30 June 1980 shows that the New South Wales Counsellor for Equal Opportunity received 285 complaints of discrimination on the grounds of sex or marital status. Eighty per cent of complaints received were from women, 20 per cent from men. Fifty per cent of complaints concerned discrimination in employment. Of the 285 complaints received in New South Wales in 1979-80, 32 per cent were resolved through conciliation; 4 per cent were referred to the Anti Discrimination Board for inquiry; 18 per cent were not proceeded with; 5 per cent were not substantiated or were referred elsewhere; and 41 per cent were still under investigation as at 30 June 1980. In making a general comment on the operation of sex discrimination legislation in these three States I note that approximately 20 per cent of complaints came from men, demonstrating that the legislation extends the rights of men as well as women, and that a large percentage of complaints were resolved by conciliation. It appears then that legislation discourages discrimination and provides an effective remedy where discrimination occurs.

I now turn to a brief description of the Bill. The constitutional basis of the Bill is twofold: First is the International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women, which was signed by the Australian Government in Copenhagen in 1980. The Convention came into force on 3 September 1981 after ratification by 20 countries of which Australia was not one. A second constitutional power resides in section 51 of the Constitution and this power is set out in clause 4 (2). The Bill is in six parts. Part I sets out the objectives and extent of the Bill. Part II defines discrimination and sets out the areas where discrimination becomes illegal. This area includes all Commonwealth employment and employment in the private sector where there is constitutional power. The basic format of Part II follows the New South Wales, Victorian and South Australian Acts on sex and marital status discrimination. These Acts have been followed because they have been shown to be adequate for the establishment of an individual's rights and remedies in this area. An additional reason for following the pattern established by the States is to develop a similarity of jurisdiction and to create legal mechanisms which are readily understood by the community.

The provision concerning clubs in clause 22 is based on a similar one in New South Wales. The purpose of this provision is to ensure that in many important social situations women are not denied access to facilities. In many country towns as well as in many of our suburbs registered clubs provide the only recreation facilities in the community. Women should not be excluded from full access to these facilities. Clause 24 makes it unlawful to advertise an intention to breach the act, for example, by advertising for 'men only' and 'salesman wanted'. This provision is essential to break down sex segregation of the work force. There are exceptions to Part II in clauses 28 and 29 covering superannuation funds and insurance policies.

Part III sets up an enforcement mechanism for Part II. It provides for investigation and conciliation of complaints by a Director of Conciliation. This mechanism is based on the enforcement mechanisms under the State Acts. Where a matter cannot be resolved satisfactorily by the Director of Conciliation, the Director shall refer the matter for investigation by the Human Rights Commission. The Commission is given powers to operate effectively in this area, that is$ it has been given powers to call witnesses and demand documents. It will have the enforcement powers of penalties up to $5,000. The Commission may make a determination which may direct the re-employment or promotion of a complainant or that the respondent should pay damages.

Part IV of the Bill provides for affirmative action in public and private employment. It is important to include constructive provisions in this Bill. It is not enough simply to render certain forms of discrimination illegal, without taking positive steps to provide for equal employment opportunity for women. While individual complaint-based mechanisms are essential as a recognition of rights and remedies for individuals they will have only a limited effect on the breakdown of sex segregation in this society, in the work force and in access to goods and services. Numerous studies have shown that there is still a large amount of structural discrimination. This can be eliminated only by positive action; the establishment of affirmative action plans for both the public and private sector. These provisions are based on New South Wales provisions relating to public sector employment and have been formulated with the United States of America experience in mind. It should be noted here that the requirements are in terms of goals and targets and not in terms of quotas. Quotas can create artificial opportunities which can be counterproductive to the cause of equality. On the other hand provisions for goals of eliminating discrimination based on sex and marital status and targets for the achievement of equal opportunity in employment for women can be pursued in a method that is fair and just to all and enables the promotion of women at a realistic rate.

The inclusion of private corporations in the provision for affirmative action plans will ensure that large scale employers in the construction industry, manufacturing, wholesale and retail trades, finance, property and business, will be covered. Small enterprises are not included as they are not suitable for the introduction of such plans. I stress that it is certainly not the intention of this legislation to create difficulties for small business. Similarly the obligation to develop an affirmative action plan is imposed on any firm which has entered into any contract with the Commonwealth Government for the supply of goods or services exceeding the value of $50,000. Part V sets out the administrative provisions for the directors of conciliation and affirmative action and the Human Rights Commission. Part VI gives the Human Rights Commission power to conduct research and community education progams relating to the objectives of this Bill. It also includes provisions for exemptions and exclusions from the Act. It is important to point out that these provisions are included because it is not the intention to create unworkable situations or to introduce anomalies.

This is a very brief description of the Bill, a more detailed description is contained in the explanatory memorandum which accompanies it. From this brief description it can be seen that the aim of the legislation is to cover major areas of employment and the provision of goods and services in the areas where Commonwealth powers apply. It deals with the significant forms of discrimination based on sex and marital status; it does not attempt to cover every possible form of discrimination nor does it attempt to regulate all employment or all provision of services. It is a realistic and sensible use of Federal powers. The particular stimulus to my introducing this Bill at this stage was the decision by the Australian Government to sign the international convention eliminating all forms of discrimination against women. It ought to have been the case that the Government itself introduced this legislation. Had it done so it would surely have had the support of the Opposition. In the absence of Federal Government action in this sphere, I am not prepared to allow Australian women to go without the protection which can so readily be provided.

Although I introduced this Bill as a private member, its objectives accord with the tradition of Labor governments legislating to strengthen human rights. It is a natural development from those policies and programs of the Whitlam Government which advanced the status of women and it extends human rights in a manner similar to the manner in which the Whitlam Government's Racial Discrimination Act 1975 used the Commonwealth's constitutional power to make discrimination on the basis of race illegal. It is interesting to note that the Fraser Government is now defending the Racial Discrimination Act against a challenge by the Queensland Government. I hope that the sex discrimination Bill will gain similar bipartisan support.

I put forward the Bill at this stage of the parliamentary session for particular reasons. The Bill is lengthy and complex. I acknowledge that it raises constitutional issues of some substance. By including the conciliation and affirmative action machinery I have added to the complexity of the Bill. However, I judged that it was important to be positive and to lay out in some detail the way in which the objectives of the Bill should be implemented. Because the Bill is so detailed and complex in its provisions it is necessary that honourable senators and the community in general have adequate time to consider it before proceeding to a vote. Therefore, I lay the Bill before the Senate this evening but do not intend to seek leave to proceed with the second reading debate until some months have elapsed.

I acknowledge also that, because of the extent and complexity of the provisions, honourable senators may wish to move amendments in the Committee stage. In the spirit of bipartisanship which I hope will inform the consideration of this legislation I will welcome any suggested improvements or clarifications of the Bill.

In conclusion I remind honourable senators, particularly those who are always concerned to protect the rights and responsibilities of State governments against the intrusion of Commonwealth powers, that only Commonwealth legislation can deal with the area of Commonwealth employment, only Commonwealth legislation can deal with the employment practices of corporations and the major deliverers of goods and services in our community. There is no more effective way of dealing with these major areas of discrimination than Federal legislation. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Durack) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: FOREIGN FISHING BOATS LEVY BILL 1981FISHERIES AGREEMENTS (PAYMENTS) BILL 1981FISHERIES AMENDMENT BILL 1981CONTINENTAL SHELF (LIVING NATURAL RESOURCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take advantage of the opportunity presented by the first reading of these money Bills to draw attention to the way in which the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union has been a fabulously rich legal aid gold mine for Mr Frank Galbally and his Melbourne firm of solicitors, Galbally and O'Bryan. Information provided by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) in his answer today to my Question on Notice No. 956 reveals that, under an agreement reached with the Commonwealth in November 1980, the firm of Galbally and O'Bryan was paid a total of $172,930 between 1 October 1980 and 16 July 1981 for legal representation of the union before the Royal Commissaon. The major components of this sum were, in round figures, $96,000 at $800 a day, for 120 sitting days of the Royal Commission; $62,400, at $800 a day, for 78 non-sitting days of the Commission; an additional $8,400, at $600 a day, for 14 sitting days on which Mr Frank Galbally himself appeared on behalf of the union; and approximately $6,000 for interstate hearings, at $100 a day, and for air fares to and from such hearings. It is nice work if you can get it!

SPEECH.PARA: When certain questions arose demanding the appearance of Mr Galbally and members of his firm as witnesses before the Commission and the union, as a result, had to be represented by other lawyers, payments by the Commonwealth were still made through Galbally and O'Bryan until the Commission finally denied that firm, Galbally and O'Bryan, leave to appear further on 16 July 1981. Although the Attorney refused to answer this part of the question, I understand that the fees paid by Galbally and O'Bryan to its sub-contractors, as it were, were significantly lower than the fees being received by that firm for the very same services. I believe that the barrister who conducted most of the case for the union from May 1981 to 16 July 1981 received only around $300 a day and that a similar sum was paid to the acting solicitor, leaving some significant balance retained by Galbally and O'Bryan.

The whole affair has all the appearance of a disgraceful rip-off. Discredit is reflected not only upon Mr Galbally and his firm but also upon the Government for allowing itself to be persuaded to agree to such extraordinarily generous terms. In these days of recurrent legal aid shortages, sweetheart deals of this kind, negotiated behind closed doors, are simply unacceptable. While needy litigants are repeatedly unable to get legal aid, it is intolerable that the Galbally and O'Bryan nest should be feathered at the rate of $800 a day, especially when the rate is the same for non-sitting days as for sitting days.

The right of the union to be represented before the Royal Commission is not in issue. What is objectionable though is the inequality of access to legal aid when persuasive and influential lawyers can attract a large slice of the legal aid cake for a single case and in so doing impoverish the legal aid fund for the great majority who lack that political clout. If the legal aid dollar is to be efficiently and equitably used, legal aid must be provided increasingly through salaried practitioners. That will enable far more people to receive assistance and will prevent insider trading of the kind graphically illustrated by this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to deal very quickly with a matter that I regard as purely a Senate matter. Over the last couple of days the Senate has been sitting at different hours from those it usually sits. Except for some of the people who work in the printing area and maybe one or two other areas, the matters that are important for keeping the Senate running have been able to be organised. It is my feeling that it is time the Government looked once again at this matter of the sitting hours of the Senate. Admittedly it is a matter that affects the Senate and could well be decided by the Senate at its leisure; and it certainly is using its leisure to do it. But I admit that there are certain matters that any government would need to take into account when it looked at sitting hours.

SPEECH.PARA: I just hope that some arrangements can be organised to enable the Government and the Opposition to look at the matters they have to look at whilst the Senate is running. I believe it is a waste of money to keep the Senate running the way it does. I believe that is an historical fact. In the beginning-I do not want to sound biblical-when the Senate started early in the century many of the people who came to Parliament were only part time politicians. Now I do not think anyone has any time to do anything other than what they have to do in this place. From a personal point of view, I find it is reasonably tiring having to be here from early in the morning until quite late at night.

For many of the people who work in this building I believe the hours present a health risk which they should not necessarily be asked to carry. They are certainly bad for the staff who work in every area. They are bad for the people who have to drive parliamentarians and others to and from work. They are bad for those who work in the offices and who have to work for an hour or so after we go home late at night. As I have said, they are bad for the printing people who have to have Hansard and things of that nature ready for us when we get here each day. In every respect the sitting hours that are now a habit in the Senate and really in this Parliament are something that I believe we should change experimentally. If we cannot make the decision to change them in a definite way let us change them experimentally.

No one else I know who works in any sensible business activity around this country works the hours that the Senate does. When I tell people outside this place the hours that I spend inside this building very few of them believe me, but if they do they reckon I am crazy. I think we are all crazy to put up with the hours under which we have been operating over the last few years& I know there are some people who would say that it is bad for staff if they lose their overtime. I think it is time we paid our staff well enough so that they do not need to work the hours of overtime they are working.

If some of those who now work late into the night need the overtime they could well be doing what they need to do before we get here. They could start early and they could have the benefits of daylight saving that we in Tasmania know so well.

Do not think for a moment that I am trying to limit the income of the people who work here. Not for a moment am I trying to do that. I am trying to get back to a sense of reality that some of the doctors in this place have spoken about and some other people have spoken about when they were not Ministers. Since I have been here thank goodness I have not had the misfortune of seeing anybody die within this chamber. But I was reading an article last night that gave an account of some of the things that do happen. I have seen people from this chamber die, but not within the chamber. I would have thought that when Senator Chipp had the heart attack he had just a few months ago we might have seen some action on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —From the Government.

—Not necessarily-from the Government. As I have said, this is not a government matter. Perhaps that needs emphasis. This is a Senate matter. It is time the Senate decided what it is going to do about it, at least for a trial period. When former Senator Murphy, to whom I was talking last night, was here we saw some attempt to change the hours. I do not believe the amount of time the experiment was carried on was long enough. As regard what should happen, after the way in which the Senate has been sitting over the last few days, I believe all the staff in this place should have off completely the day after the Parliament rises. I know that sometimes when I go back to Tasmania I am tired out from the week's work. I have the ability perhaps to sleep on an aircraft and to have an hour's sleep in the afternoon on a Friday. I have no hesitation of saying that because I know how tired one can get in this place. We have to remember again that the staff are here for longer hours than we are. It is time we thought about the hundreds of people who work in support of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: That is all I want to say at this stage because I know we are in the dying hours of this sessional period-I hope they are not dying hours for some people. I wish well those people who may leave the Senate during the next few months when we are not sitting, whether they go by the gift of God or otherwise. I think it is high time that the people who now control the numbers in the Senate recognised the facts. They should have the courage to do the things that they think should be done. This is not a party matter; it is a Senate matter. It is time that we did something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had the numbers until June.

—But until last year there had not been a heart attack among senators. That is what brought my attention to this matter. Senator McLaren is one of those in this place who look after their health, as I hope I do. It is time we forced some other people in this place to look after their health.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on two matters. Firstly, the Liberal Party of Western Australia, for reasons both realistic and devious, has decided to put the skids under the honourable member for O'Connor, Mr Tuckey. He is to be replaced as the member for O'Connor by a sitting State Liberal member of the Legislative Assembly whose vacated seat will then be taken over by the leader of the rump, known as the National Country Party, Mr Old, whose seat was abolished in the recent redistribution which is the subject of court challenge, the ultimate outcome of which is uncertain.

SPEECH.PARA: The second matter I wish to raise concerns a question asked by Senator Bolkus of Senator Carrick today which was in four parts. He asked whether the former head of the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Besley, resigned one morning and was physically and permanently out of his office and the Department by 5 o'clock that afternoon; whether it was announced the next day that he was to be appointed managing director of Monier Ltd; whether he is still on leave from the Department; and whether the Public Service guidelines on the private employment of retired senior public servants had been observed. Normally, when a question such as that is asked without notice-no notice was given-one would not expect Senator Carrick to be able to give a detailed or definitive answer. In this case he did. He was obviously prepared for the question and gave a very carefully prepared reply which raises two questions. The reply, by the way, to paraphrase it was: Yes, Mr Besley did resign one morning and was physically out of his office for good that afternoon; it was announced that he was to be managing director of Monier Ltd; he is still on leave; and the Public Service guidelines had been observed.

This raises queries about the extraordinary speed with which Public Service Board approval was secured. There was, obviously, a strenuous endeavour to facilitate Mr Besley's sudden retirement from the Public Service. Indeed, one might say, there was even indecent haste in the Public Service Board approving his taking the position with Monier while he was, and still is almost two months later, on the public payroll. Well sourced information which has been given to me reveals that Mr Besley was the subject of an Australian Federal Police inquiry and report. I do not care at this stage to go into the reasons for his having been subjected to that Federal Police inquiry and report. I just observe that there was obvious collusion between the Public Service Board and the Government-no doubt on the direction of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser)-to pre-empt any further action which may have arisen from that Federal Police report by removing Mr Besley from the scene of his peccadillos.

The final observation I make is that Mr Besley is a protege of the Prime Minister. A former protege of the Prime Minister, Keith Compton Gale, is currently doing 13 years in Long Bay gaol for fraud and other charges. Another protege of the Prime Minister has, to say the least, fallen from grace. This leads one to speculate whether it is an unfortunate coincidence that prime ministerial proteges are the sorts of people they are or whether the Prime Minister actually selects such people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —When speaking to the motion for the first reading of these fisheries Bills one can probably talk about anything but my contribution tonight will relate to fishing. I refer to the lack of control over fishing by the Fisheries Division of the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry. That Division is so disorganised that it is contributing to the complete destruction of our fisheries in Australia. On the whole Australia is a very barren country. Any barren country does not have very large fish supplies in surrounding waters. We could have a very viable fishing industry if it were properly managed and controlled. Unfortunately, that is not so.

SPEECH.PARA: I raise the question of prawn fishing in South Australia. For many years South Australia did not believe that prawns were present in that area. It was always considered that the region was far too cold to support a prawn industry. As a result of an investigation in the St Vincent Gulf in 1969 we found that we could have a sizeable prawn industry if it were managed correctly and very delicately. After a lot of investigation it was found that in South Australia, because of colder waters, prawns took something like between four years and five years to develop. That is quite different from the situation which applies in the northern regions of Australia where prawns can develop into fully grown species in a period of between 12 months and 14 months. It was always felt that mangrove swamps were essential for prawns to breed and multiply. But we have very few mangrove swamps in South Australia and it was found that prawns breed and shelter in weeds. In 1969 South Australia started a prawn industry. Several boats were registered to fish. Over a period a total of 14 boats have entered the industry. For a number of years the fishermen found that this was a very profitable enterprise. They said to the South Australian Government that they would voluntarily place restrictions on a large section of the Gulf as there were a lot of small prawns in the area. The fishermen decided that they would not fish in waters of a depth below five fathoms. For 11 weeks during each winter, they completely stopped fishing. They only fished the large prawns in the centre of the Gulf. They never fished the Investigator Strait Area. It was always recognised that this was a hatchery area where small prawns bred in weeds. Eventually, as they grew, they moved up into the centre of the Gulf.

In 1977, there was a dispute between the South Australian Government and the Commonwealth Government over who controlled the waters in Investigator Strait. After court action it was decided that the Commonwealth controlled those waters. From that point the Commonwealth Government registered boats to fish prawns in Investigator Strait. Fishermen who were fishing in St Vincent Gulf warned the Government that fishing this area would upset the whole of the industry-but the Commonwealth Government still registered fishing boats. Originally it registered eight boats in that area. As a result of that Commonwealth action, the prawn fishing industry is being completely destroyed. Despite all the warnings that have been given, the Commonwealth Government refuses to withdraw the licences of those fishing boats. Only four of the original eight boats remain in the area. They are still fishing the very small prawns and are destroying the whole of the industry.

The fishermen who are registered by the State Government each pay a fee of $2,000 a year. The boats registered by the Commonwealth each pay a fee of $50. There is no control of this Commonwealth area. There is nothing to stop over-fishing. These people fish for the whole of the 12 months. There is no attempt to keep the industry viable. I repeat that these fishermen have completely fished out the whole area.

To illustrate this matter further, I refer to an area of Venus Bay on the west coast where, despite many approaches by the South Australian Department of Fisheries, Commonwealth fishing authorities would not co-operate in its management policy. In the three years from 1976 to 1979, the average catch dropped from 239 tonnes to 16 tonnes a year simply because the area was not managed. The Commonwealth went into that area, imposed no restrictions, and allowed the wholesale slaughter of the fishing industry. If the Commonwealth Government does not withdraw the licences of the boats that it has registered in Investigator Strait, that prawning industry will never recover. I believe that it is absolutely ludicrous to allow such a situation to occur. I said earlier that the 14 fishermen who were registered by the South Australian Fishing Department earned a very good living from this area but, because of interference from the Commonwealth Government, the whole of that industry will be destroyed. Because South Australian prawns are in colder water they take longer to mature and any interference with the small prawns has major effects on the whole of the Gulf area. There have been rumours of what happened and why the Commonwealth Government will not withdraw those licences. Mr Buick from Kangaroo Island has been registered under the Fisheries Division of the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry. He stated in front of other fishermen that during election time he put his hand in his pocket for the Liberal Party and that if his licence were withdrawn he would raise the very devil. At least 20 people can verify that statement.

TALK.START.PARA: —He ought to, he authorised all the advertisements in the papers.

—That is true, he did authorise advertisements in newspapers. They were not supporters of the Labor Party at the meeting either. The majority of fishermen do not support the Labor Party. Some do and some do not. I think the Commonwealth Government should look at what it is doing. I think that this situation provides a case for political parties to be funded from the public purse. Mr Buick said that if he loses his licence he will make certain statements. I was not present when he said that and I cannot verify it. I was just informed on the matter. Any fisherman in the region will require an income of about $150,000 a year for prawn fishing to be a viable proposition. Fishermen in the Gulf are now earning about $90,000 a year and this figure is still dropping. As I said the whole industry is being destroyed and there is no need for this. There should be complete co-operation between State and Federal governments in this field.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to tuna fishing. Recently the Commonwealth Government allowed licences to be issued for tuna fishing to all-comers. By issuing those licences the Government will in turn destroy that industry as well. Fishermen tell me that the Heinz company demanded that this be done. It wanted more fish and it did not care about the preservation of the industry. Some people in the Fisheries Division of the Department of Primary Industry have a lot to answer for. We have not exploited the industry for the benefit of Australians. We have protected primary industries and I agree with that policy. I believe that the fishing industry should be protected, as should any primary industry. Insufficient help is being given to fishermen. It is very difficult for them to procure finance to build boats and to develop the fishing industry. They get very little help. They pay very high interest rates on borrowed money in order to build boats. I think this Government, or any Federal government, should look seriously at not just one aspect of the fishing industry but the whole of it. I believe that a viable fishing industry in Australia can be achieved. There are a lot of difficulties with it, but it can be achieved if it is properly managed, and I think that is the way to go about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — This morning I received a reply from the President to a question I asked. I would like to read that reply because it outlines what my question was and sets the scene for the remainder of what I want to say this evening. The reply stated as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: On 18 November 1981, Senator Colston asked me whether the 1982 diaries supplied to honourable senators were printed in Hong Kong. I am informed that the 1982 Senate Diary is a standard item (Model 72PA) supplied by an Australian company based in Sydney. The diaries for 1981 and 1982 were manufactured in Hong Kong to that company's specifications.

Since 1978, the Department of the Senate has purchased desk diaries from a Canberra firm, which selects an Australian company to supply the diaries on the basis of the lowest available price. The Canberra firm arranges with a local manufacturer for the hot foil stamping of the Australian crest and the word 'Senate' on the front cover of the diary. It is understood that the recommended retail price (which includes sales tax of 17 1/2%) is $6.80 and that the recommended retail price of a similar diary made in Australia is approximately $15.00. The cost of each 1982 Senate diary is $5.85.
Inquiries will continue to be made of other Australian companies to ascertain whether a similar diary made in Australia can be puchased at a price comparable with that of the present Senate diary.

When I originally asked the question, I was referring to the small diary with which we were issued-E3P. When I received the answer to my question I was surprised to find that the larger diary with which we were issued was in fact made in Hong Kong. I would be interested to find out at some subsequent stage whether the small one with which we have been issued was also made in Hong Kong. As it was produced by the same company, I presume it was.

I do not want to raise the protection-free trade argument which is often before the Parliament. In fact, I have never raised it myself in the Parliament and I do not intend to do so tonight. But surely Australian printers would expect that the Australian Senate would purchase an Australian product. In my opinion, it is an absolute disgrace for the Australian Senate to distribute diaries to honourable senators when those diaries have been made in Hong Kong. I suggest that next year a firm price be obtained for a diary which has been printed in Australia. In that way honourable senators will be able to determine what savings, if any, have been made by actually purchasing a diary which was produced in Hong Kong. I believe that we will be able to obtain a firm indication because this year we were told that the approximate price for a diary printed in Australia was $15. If we obtain a firm price we will know what, if anything, we are saving. Whilst I acknowledge that much Australian printing goes to Hong Kong, I consider that an Australian Senate which does not insist that its diaries are printed in Australia looks ridiculous.
Friday, 27 November 1981

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking at the first reading stage of these four fishing Bills, my colleague, Senator Elstob, said that he would be dealing specifically with fishing. I will deal with a person who for a short time has engaged in a bit of dirty fishing-in fact, filthy fishing. On 17 November, during the debate on the vote for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs under the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1981-82, I told the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, about this matter I wanted to raise but that I could not develop at that time. I said I was given to understand over the telephone that a most unwarranted attack was made on me last week by Mr Lewis, the member for Mallee in the State House, because of my action in trying to assist the Ralkon Agricultural Co Pty Ltd at Meningie. I told the Minister that as soon as I got a copy of the Hansard report I would refer to this matter in the Parliament and would say a few things about Mr Lewis which he might not appreciate. I said Mr Lewis would get a shock when I mentioned them. I went on to say that Mr Lewis was just a babe in the woods so far as this matter was concerned. He was a newcomer to the problem, he had been in Parliament for only two years and he was one of those Johnny-come-latelys who put themselves up as instant experts. In the meantime I have been able to obtain not only a copy of one Hansard report but also of another in which this person is pursuing a vendetta against the manager of the Ralkon Agricultural Co. who has been rightfully and properly elected by Aboriginal people. Before I get on to that, I want to make some comment on the remarks made by Mr Lewis on 10 November in the State Legislative Assembly in South Australia. I remind the Senate that Mr Lewis is the Liberal member for the seat of Mallee. Mr Lewis said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I intend to pursue a question that will take me more than one opportunity to debate to the fullest degree. It is a question of great importance to a significant community within my electorate. The community to which I refer, in the vicinity of Meningie, has difficulties. We need to bring down the curtain and obtain a satisfactory conclusion to a sorry saga and a running sore, largely caused by one man's self-righteous ambition and awful duplicity. This man has given misleading advice to a community, either as a result of his own ignorance of the truth and the law or as a result of his own determination to gain control of very valuable real estate and control of a large number of people's lives, or else it is a combination of both those motives.

On 17 November I said to Senator Baume that if Mr Lewis was prepared to utter those remarks outside the Parliament, away from its protection, he would need a very large bank account. They are only a few of the accusations that this person has made. He went on to say:

Either way, he likes to exercise this power and seeks to discredit and destroy anyone or anything that threatens this position. Certainly he has always succeeded in getting a platform to publicly abuse anyone who sought the truth and sought to serve the best interests of this community. He has continued to attack them until they are silenced either by fear or are removed from influence in that situation. He has succeeded in seducing, or, if one likes, conning ALP members in the same way, notably Senator McLaren.

I have taken the trouble to consult the Concise Oxford Dictionary. It refers to a person who has been conned, who has been persuaded or who has taken part in a swindle, or things to that effect. Further on-this concerned me greatly-when we come to the explanation of seduction and the word 'seduce' we find that he has claimed that I have been led astray, I have been tempted into sin or crime, I have been corrupted, I have been persuaded as a person into an abandonment of principles, I have even lost my chastity or my allegiance and have been persuaded by tempting or attractiveness. I do not think that I am guilty of having fallen into any of those errors in my life. I have always endeavoured to be a law abiding citizen and since my election to this Parliament I have endeavoured to do the best that I can in the interests of people who I think need protection, guidance or help. I have always endeavoured to do that. Yet here we have a man saying these things about the manager of the Ralkon company, in the first instance, and then claiming that I have been seduced or conned. In the Hansard record the Minister for Agriculture, Mr Chapman, is reported to have interjected: 'Seducing them?' Mr Lewis then said:

In intellectual terms that is just about what one would call it, although I must say that Senator McLaren was obviously willing in the belief that he could make political mileage of it, which I think was regrettable and unfortunate.

I believe that Senator Chaney, who is in charge of the House tonight and who has held the portfolio of Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, will agree that any person who takes up a cause for Aboriginal people certainly cannot make any political mileage out of it. You do it out of the goodness of your heart and, in most cases, come in for very severe criticism. In regard to political mileage the speedo is wound back, not forwards. I regret that many members of this Parliament are like Mr Lewis who, whilst they espouse wonderful things for, and have very kind thoughts concerning, Aboriginals are not prepared when the crunch comes to do anything about the issue. They hide under a bushel and keep away from it. I have not been prepared to do that. I took up the case for the Ralkon people-the Aboriginal people came to me in the first instance, not the white manager- in the Parliament many years ago. I have not gained any political mileage out of it. In some instances I have gained a lot of abuse. In others I have been held up to ridicule-unfortunately by some members of my own party who, like Lewis, are Johnny-come-latelys and do not understand the problem but set themselves up as instant experts. As I proceed with my speech I will say something of what I endeavoured to do for those Aboriginal people.
Mr Lewis went on to state:
I refer to Mr Ian Hillock-

That is the person he was talking about, but when one reads the speech one realises that members of the South Australian Parliament thought he was talking about me until Mr McRae interjected: 'Who are you talking about, for Heaven's sake?' Lewis said:

I refer to Mr Hillock and to the mess that he has made of the Point McLeay people, its prosperity, and the proprietary agricultural company limited that they set up years ago to run their farming business.

Because the hour is late, I will not read the whole transcript into Hansard. The time will come when we will have more respectable hour to debate this whole matter. However, I want to enlighten the Senate as to some of the qualities of Mr Lewis. I have a transcript of a television program, the film on which is in the library for those who are interested to check, and particularly those who might be interested in the problems being suffered by these people at Ralkon. The transcript is of the program State Affair of ADS Channel 7 in Adelaide, on 6 April 1981. Interviewed were Spencer Rigney, the Chairman of Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd, Mrs Val Berry, the spouse of the returning officer for the election of the 1981 Point McLeay community council and Mrs Leta Padman of Narrung. I will not quote all of the interview because it is in the library for people to have a look at. However, I will quote the pertinent part. The reporter asked:

But certain outside influences want to control the council and thus the farm. Just before the election, a smear campaign against Ralkon was slowly leaked to the press. Point McLeay Aboriginals say it was done by outside bureaucrats.
I have claimed that here on many occasions-
There are also substantial allegations of social, legal and political pressure brought to bear on the returning officer for the election as his wife explains.

Then Mrs Berry, the wife of the returning officer, replied. I might add that Mr Berry was not only the returning officer elected by the then council for its elections but also was appointed by the State Electoral Officer and the Federal Electoral Officer to act as returning officer for State and Federal elections. In answer to the reporter, Mrs Berry said:
There were several suggestions that he should resign-
She is referring to her husband-

from different people but one was from the Member for Mallee who visited us on the Friday, the day on which the nominations closed, and suggested that John should resign that it would be for the benefit of the people of Point McLeay, that everything should be thrashed out before the actual election took place, that it really would be for John's own benefit too, if he did resign.
The reporter then said:
It sounds a bit more than a logical reason, it sounds almost like a vague threat.
The transcript indicates that Mrs Hammond replied. However, it was Mrs Berry. She said

Well, it could be taken as that. We couldn't see any logical reason because we were of the belief that the election should go on before things could be straightened out. It has been promised that Senator Baume is to come over and look into the situation once the elections are over and therefore we felt that this was probably the best way. There was so much ill feeling in the air too, until the elections were over but I think it's better that that is over.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was Mrs Berry, was it?

—That was Mrs Berry. The transcript shows that this was said by Mrs Hammond. I have seen the film and I can assure the Minister that it was Mrs Berry. What she was saying in answer to the reporter is that Mr Lewis, who stands up in the State Parliament and accuses me of being conned and being seduced by Mr Hillock, and who accuses Mr Hillock of all sorts of unlawful things, is the person who went there and threatened the returning officer with all sorts of reprisals if he did not call off the election. Of course$ we know what happened after that. I have spoken in the Senate about it. Pressure was brought to bear and a writ was taken out in the Supreme Court. Six of the people who for many years had been living a few miles away from the settlement on the property known as Ralkon, Bartlett's farm, were struck off the roll and were unable to take part in the election. Of course, a couple of those people were candidates and could not take part in the election. But shortly after the election a decision was made by the council that those same people were to be restored to the roll. It was decided that anyone living within five miles of the settlement was entitled to vote and to stand for election to that council.

SPEECH.PARA: Lewis said that this is a sorry saga. They were about the only truthful words that he used. I have been raising this saga in this Parliament for years. I have been trying to get a public inquiry into the problem and I will refer to that matter shortly. However, I want to proceed in proper chronological order so that my speech will not be distorted. I have a letter from the Commonwealth Ombudsman, Professor J. E. Richardson, dated 6 May 1980 which gives the lie to what some people in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs are saying. Documents have been hawked around the country which people have claimed are copies of the final report of the Ombudsman. The letter dated 6 May 1980 states:
Dear Senator McLaren,

I am writing to you about your criticism appearing in Senate Hansard of 22 April 1980, of the handling by my office of a complaint from Ralkon Agricultural Company Pty. Ltd., of South Australia. Your particular criticism was that although almost two years had elapsed since my office received Ralkon's complaint I had not made a report to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare.

On 21 July 1978, the Senate Committee advised Ralkon to approach the Commonwealth Ombudsman. Ralkon accepted this advice, my office receiving its complaint on 4 August 1978. The complaint was formally investigated and by letter of 25 October 1978 one of my deputy Ombudsmen informed Ralkon of the results of the investigation and offered to hold discussions with Ralkon should Ralkon disagree with the tentative conclusions reached.
I emphasise the Professor's words 'the tentative conclusions'. He continued:

Ralkon wrote to the Deputy Ombudsman on 31 October 1978 indicating disagreement with the conclusions. The Deputy Ombudsman met with Ralkon's directors at Narrung, South Australia on 6 November 1978, and the Manager of Ralkon agreed to provide taped comments which outlined Ralkon's objections. My office received the first tape on 18 December 1978 and following further correspondence with Ralkon we received the second tape on 9 May 1979.

It was not until last month, however, that my office completed its reconsideration of the complaint in the light of analyses of the tapes. Whilst I believe we acted expeditiously in our initial investigation leading to the communication of tentative conclusions to Ralkon it should not have taken nearly so long to pursue the complaint to completion. Since its inception my office has worked under considerable pressure in coping with the large volume of complaints we receive and at times we have simply lacked the resources to complete our tasks expeditiously. Notwithstanding, the principle cause of delay in the Ralkon complaint was an administrative failure which should not have occurred and for which I accept responsibility. It is important that complainants generally should have confidence in my office and revised operating procedures which I introduced last March will, I hope, ensure that such cases will not recur.

I should offer a comment on your criticism of my office's failure to report to the Standing Committee on Social Welfare. In March this year my Deputy Ombudsman explained to the Secretary of the Committee that the Ombudsman was not at liberty to make a report to the Committee. The Ombudsman Act confines the Ombudsman to reporting to the responsible department or authority and its Minister and sending particulars of the results of the investigation to the complainant. Had Ralkon not withdrawn its complaint it would have received last March the results of the investigation and it then would have been open to it to advise the Committee of them.
I am taking the liberty of sending a copy of this letter to the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Baume.
Yours sincerely,
(J. E. Richardson)
Ombudsman
Of course, that correspondence went to Senator Baume in May of last year. On 2 March this year the Ombudsman wrote to me again. He stated:
On 19 January 1981 I wrote to the Chairman of the Ralkon Agricultural Company Pty Ltd following conversations between you and this office and Mr Bob Randall and myself.
Mr Bob Randall is a State Liberal member in South Australia. The letter continued:
My letter to Ralkon contained the following.
I sought from the Secretary comments on the apparently unauthorised circulation-
I emphasise the words 'unauthorised circulation'-

of Mr Crotty's letter of October 1978 addressed to Mr Koolmatrie. The Secretary's response, not unexepectedly, is to the effect that he is unable to ascertain whether the copying and circulation of the letter took place within his department. He has provided details of the enquiries he made which show that the relevant files are recorded as having been in storage for many months previous to our inquiry, and there is no further information which would enable him to speculate fruitfully on how the document came to be circulated.

I can understand your company's concern at the circulation so long after the event of a letter which contained only the preliminary views of this office in relation to your complaint, but I have to say that if, as seems possible, people with interests opposed to the company are responsible, the likelihood of action by this office being successful in preventing the activity is small. I should, therefore, be interested to have your reaction to another possible course, which while it will not guarantee that the document ceases to be circulated, may go some way towards nullifying its effect. Should you wish it, I would be prepared to furnish you with a statement to the effect that the letter in question, dated 25 October 1978, represented preliminary conclusions only by this office, and that those conclusions and the evidence upon which they were based were contested by your company. It would be open to you to use such a statement to counter the effects of the circulation of the document. Beyond that, however, I find it difficult to perceive any other solution which could be of much assistance to you.
I have not heard further from the Company but if I do, of course, I will, if requested, provide the statement.

The same Mr Lewis is referring in the State Parliament in South Australia to that preliminary finding as the Obudsman's final report. Again, not only is he misleading the Parliament but also he is creating a mass of mischief among the people of South Australia who are being conned-I use that word now-by some of the bureaucrats in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs. That is not the first time that I have made a statement to that effect in this chamber. That is why I have been calling repeatedly in the Senate for a Senate inquiry to be set up. It was only recently-in June this year-that I sought to have a Senate select committee inquiring into the matter and got the brush off. Some members of this Parliament are not concerned about the problems of some of these people. I am concerned, and I will pursue this matter until my last day in this Senate to see that some justice is done and we establish this inquiry to find out who the culprits are. I have a further letter dated 31 March of this year from Mr W. J. Blick, the Principal Investigation Officer from the Ombudsman's office. It is addressed to Mr Rigney. It reads:
Dear Mr Rigney,
I understand from Senator McLaren that you had not received Professor Richardson's letter of 26 March by the 31 March.
A copy is attached in case the original does not arrive.
I shall read a copy of Professor Richardson's letter. It is dated 26 March. It states:
Dear Mr Rigney,

As promised earlier I am writing in connection with Ralkon Agricultural Company Proprietary Limited's (the Company's) complaint to this office about the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and this office's investigation of that Department's actions.

In particular I refer to a letter sent to the Company by the then Deputy Ombudsman, K. M. Crotty, in October 1978, to which was attached a document of 29 pages entitled 'History of Ralkon-events leading up to complaint'. That letter, insofar as it purported to contain conclusions about the conduct of the Company and of the Department, contained preliminary conclusions only, which were disputed by the Company. The Company also disputed a number of the assertions of fact in the 29-page attachment. Although we were close to determining our attitude at the time the investigation was discontinued, we had not done so.
You are free to use this letter in any way you see fit.

I am in possession of the letter because Mr Rigney brought it to my office. There again is conclusive proof of what some meddling people in this community are doing. I hope that some of the people who may be listening around Parliament House tonight who, in my view, have done things to frustrate this proposed inquiry take some notice and that when we come back here next year they will agree to the setting up of a select committee so that some honest people can be cleared of these false accusations that have been made against them. Some have been made only just recently, as I have pointed out, by a local member in the House of Assembly in South Australia saying that he is in possession of the Ombudsman's final report. When I pleaded with Professor Richardson to make that report available to Senator Chaney when he was the responsible Minister, he told me that under the Act he was prevented from doing so. So there is no final report so far as Professor Richardson knows. He has still got it locked up and he is unable under the Act to release it. Yet these mischievious people are peddling around the country stories that they have got it and they are using it to the detriment of these people.

On 27 May I gave notice of my intention to move in this Parliament for the setting up of a select committee to inquire into this subject. I will not read out the terms of my notice of motion, but I seek leave to have incorporated in the Hansard my notice of motion No. 28 on the Notice Paper of 24 November 1981.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
(1) That a Select Committee of the Senate be appointed to inquire into and report by 27 August 1981 on-

(a) the viability of the Ralkon Agricultural Company of Loveday Bay Road, Narrung, in the State of South Australia, and the competency of the Company to successfully farm (in the interests of the Aboriginal residents of Point McLeay) the three properties it now occupies:
(b) the relationship between the Company, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Point McLeay Aboriginal Council from the time of formation of the Company in 1975 until 30 June 1980; and
(c) the relationship between the Company, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, the Point McLeay Aboriginal Council and the Aboriginal Development Commission since July 1980.
(2) That provisions relating to membership, powers and proceedings of the Committee be contained in a subsequent Resolution.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record I point out that that is not the first time I had sought in this Parliament to have an inquiry set up because I did propose a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare on 31 May 1978. The terms of reference were: 'The management and financial affairs of Ralkon Agricultural Co. Pty Ltd, Narrung, South Australia'. It is the people who live on that property who want the inquiry, not me. They have asked me to try to get a Senate inquiry to look into those things, yet people have the hide to say that I am running around supporting Ralkon. I am supporting justice.
