I was hoping that we could get an inquiry and that there would be sitting on that Senate select committee-not me; they can call me as a witness if they like; I will be quite happy to go-some independent people who are prepared to see that justice is done. That is the sort of thing that we have to put up with.

SPEECH.PARA: On 28 September this year Mr Charles Perkins-I have criticised him in this Parliament before and I will criticise him again and again if need be-wrote a letter to the Adelaide-

TALK.START.PARA: —He must be all right, Senator.

—The Minister got rid of him. He got him out of his hair. He put him off to the Aboriginal Development Commission. Senator Baume has a very great smile on his face tonight. I want to read the letter that he wrote to the Advertiser and then in turn I will read the letter Mr Rigney wrote to the Advertiser which that newspaper did not see fit to print. The letter from Mr Charles Perkins is headed 'Faction fracas'. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Sir-On behalf of the Aboriginal Development Commission I totally reject allegations by Mr Hambidge (The Advertiser, 21.9.81)-

I interpose to say that Mr Hambidge is the well respected editor of the Murray Valley Standard in Murray Bridge and no one can validly level any criticism against him, but he saw fit to write a letter to the editor of the Advertiser. The letter from Mr Charles Perkins continues:
that the Commission is doing its best to split the Aboriginal community at Point McLeay with the aim of wrecking the Ralkon Company.
The Commission is attempting to reconcile factions separated by the actions of Ralkon itself.
How happy we would all be if that were in fact true. The letter continues:

Rather than butt in, as Mr Hambidge implies, the commission has been answering pleas for help from the Point McLeay Council first made 12 months ago for the commission to assist the council to regain lawful control of its farming lands from Ralkon.
The commission does not accept that the Ralkon project in its present condition is a good example of Aboriginal enterprise.
Unfortunately, it is clearly the most difficult enterprise with which the commission is involved.

The Ralkon Company, which has been responsible for a marked deterioration of the farming lands, is managed not by an Aboriginal, but by a white man who undertook the position six years ago on the understanding that he would train a local Aboriginal to replace himself within two years.
A recent report by expert consultants stated that Ralkon's management techniques are far from satisfactory.
For some time, the commission has been extremely concerned about the operations of Ralkon and its handling of a number of matters relating to the management of the lands it purports to control.

Not the least of these is the fact that the company has failed to give a proper accounting of the use of money spent on projects around the properties in question and has refused an audit for the past four years.

As a responsible body and the organisation that legally owns a part of the farming lands, the Aboriginal Development Commission cannot allow its lands which were acquired by substantial public investment to be jeopardised any longer. That is why it is taking action to support the Point McLeay Council.
Incidentally, Mr Spencer Rigney is not a member of the Point McLeay Council as stated by Mr Hambidge.

The letter is signed 'C. N. Perkins, Chairman, Aboriginal Development Commission, Canberra'. At one time Mr Rigney was a member of the Council and, if my memory serves me correctly, he was Chairman of the Council. I understand that he is one of those persons who were candidates at the last Council election. Through some actions of people in the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, no doubt supported by the Aboriginal Development Commission, his name was struck off the role and he was not allowed either to stand as a candidate or to vote. I have a letter dated 29 September headed 'Ralkon Agricultural Company, Loveday Bay Road, Narrung'. It is addressed to the editor of the Advertiser Newspapers Ltd, King William Street, Adelaide, South Australia. It states:
Dear Sir,
I wish to set on record certain facts relating to matters raised in the letter from Mr Charles Perkins (The Advertiser, 28.9.81).

Ralkon was established in 1975 at the instigation of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs following our representation to conduct farming operations on behalf of the aboriginal people of Point McLeay. The Department advised those residents that after the formation of the company they would each receive shares in the company. Following the formation the Department advised that the shares should be held by the Point McLeay Community Council on behalf of the residents and not by the residents themselves. This upset the residents who had paid money for the shares in the company.

In 1979 the company's articles were changed to enable the shares to be issued to residents so that they would have a direct say in the operation of the business of the company in farming lands purchased at Point McLeay.

In 1980 Ralkon made a submission to the Minister of Aboriginal Affairs which was conveyed to the Aboriginal Development Commission requesting that the land held by the Aboriginal Development Commission be transferred to it if necessary by purchase with adequate safeguards imposed to ensure that any public funding was properly protected. This transfer would enable long term development of the land to take place for the benefit of the aboriginal residents at Point McLeay. On the 23rd March 1981 the Aboriginal Development Commission without reference to Ralkon and the people of Point McLeay offered a lease of the land to the Point McLeay Community Council.

On the 28th March 1981 an election was held for the Point McLeay Community Council and after the election the Council reflected the views of the Point McLeay residents. At a number of Council meetings during March, April and May 1981 the Council resolved to reject all agreements between the previous Council and the Aboriginal Development Commission and requested that the farm land be transferred to Ralkon.

On the 29th May 1981 I visited Canberra with the Chairman of the Council to discuss this matter with Mr Perkins who stated there was nothing wrong with the company's Articles of Association and if the company could show that it could manage the farm the Aboriginal Development Commission would look to giving freehold title in the land.

A majority of the Point McLeay community signed a letter to the Minister of Aboriginal Affairs on the 12th June 1981 requesting that the Department should not interfere further in the activities of the Point McLeay people. This letter also requested that the land be transferred to Ralkon.

On the 27th July 1981 following further persuasion from the Aboriginal Development Commission the Council signed a lease with the Aboriginal Development Commission which endeavoured to exclude Ralkon from any farming operation in respect of the property. The Directors of Ralkon believe that this decision was made against the wishes of the majority of Point McLeay residents and have sought to have the matter raised at various levels to ensure that the wishes of the majority of people are carried into effect.
The company has not caused any split amongst the people at Point McLeay. This split has been brought about by outsiders interfering in the affairs of the Point McLeay residents.

The Company has not unlawfully retained control of the farmlands at Point McLeay as on a number of occasions the community council have requested the Aboriginal Development Commission to transfer those lands to Ralkon.
Ralkon has managed the farming operation at a profit and has carried out proper accounting procedures, it has not refused an audit and it is not opposed to its account being audited.

The Directors of Ralkon who are all Aboriginals have been very happy with the management and assistance given by Mr Ian Hillock who has been the company manager for six years. Mr Hillock has, on a number of occasions, indicated that he would leave if so requested by the Directors but the Directors and shareholders have expressed their desire for him to stay and have been grateful for his continued support. The company is capable of managing the farm operation profitably and has sought to have the land transferred to it with appropriate controls to ensure the long term development of the land. The Aboriginal Development Commission has ignored the request of a majority of residents of Point McLeay to lease or transfer the land to Ralkon and has sought to impose its own will upon the people of Point McLeay.
Yours faithfully, S. Rigney, Chairman, Ralkon Agricultural Company Pty Ltd.

So what! The Advertiser in Adelaide was prepared to print a letter from Mr Hambridge, the editor of the Murray Valley Standard, and in return to print a letter from Mr Charles Perkins, the Chairman of the Commission. It did not see fit to print a letter from the chairman of the company rebutting much of the statement made by Mr Perkins. So there again we have people in the community being misinformed. It then falls to my lot to raise the matter again in the Senate. I probably would not have done it if I had not been attacked by Lewis. I would have waited to see whether the Minister, when we return for the Autumn session, would agree at last to the setting up of a select committee so that we can have this public inquiry into the affairs at Point McLeay and examine all the allegations which have been made by many people who are misinformed and ill-informed, as I have said. If this inquiry could be set up, perhaps we could at long last set this thing at rest.
I am sure that the people on that particular farming enterprise would be most happy if that were to happen. They are not afraid of an inquiry. They have asked for the inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, in goodwill, why do they not go back to the Ombudsman and get him to complete his inquiry?

—In goodwill, Mr Minister, why do you not agree to the setting up of an inquiry so that the matter can be examined? I will tell you why. You are afraid of what might be uncovered. I said to you when you were appointed to this portfolio what I said to your predecessor, Senator Chaney: 'For goodness sake do not be snowed by the bureaucrats in your Department. Have a bit of commonsense'.
—Tell us about the Ombudsman.

—I have told the Senate about the Ombudsman and what he said in his letter. If the honourable senator had been here he would have heard it. It will be in Hansard tomorrow and I suggest he read it. I do not blame the Ombudsman in any way whatsoever. The Minister knows and I know why the Ombudsman's report was not proceeded with as expeditiously as it should have been. He knows a lot of the facts and he is not prepared to act on them.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been claimed, and the Minister has claimed this himself, that the people at Point McLeay do not support the company. The Minister has a copy of this letter but just to refresh his memory I will read it out again and take up the time of the Senate. This letter is dated 12 June 1961. It is addressed to Senator Peter Baume, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Parliament House, Canberra. It states:
Dear Senator Baume,
We heard your rejection of Senator McLaren's request that our problems be looked into as a matter of urgency.

It was at that stage that I moved to have Standing Orders suspended in order to try to get this committee set up so that it could do its work during the winter recess when we had staff and senators available. The letter continues:

We heard you say that there was no urgency. We heard you say that negotiations were taking place. We heard your inference as to why the Ombudsman's inquiry was discontinued. The matter is urgent. There are no negotiations taking place and you know very well why the Ombudsman's inquiry was discontinued.

Your answer gave no credit to the dignity of your office and it did nothing to bring a solution any closer. This affair has been dragged out beyond all reason and beyond all sense. We are tired of it. Point McLeay is not a political football to be kicked around to satisfy or protect the sensitivities of your Department. It is a small community of Aboriginals doing their best to make something of themselves for the future and for their children.
Enough is enough. We know what has happened and so do you and, thank God, so do others. You and your Department mean nothing to us. Ralkon means everything. So let's stop pretending.

We have made our requirements as to Land Tenure perfectly clear. They are normal commercial requirements, no more no less. We want no further interference from your Department. That is reasonable and you should be glad of it. You know what has to be done. The decision is yours and the time is now.
Yours sincerely, The PEOPLE OF RALKON
As the Minister knows, that letter was signed by 31 residents of Ralkon.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the date of that one?

—The date of that letter is 12 June of this year. It was written because those people happened to be listening to the broadcast of the Senate when the debate took place. They heard every word that Senator Baume said and every word that I said. They know what the result of the vote was.

SPEECH.PARA: I have checked the list of shareholders which was attached to the statements of the company which were lodged with the Office of Corporate Affairs in Adelaide in 1979. I took the trouble this evening to go through that list. Of the 31 people who signed that letter to Senator Baume, 24 are shareholders in the company. Shares are also held by the community council. I will read the names of the shareholders. People by the name of Rigney had nine shares and nine signed the letter. People by the name of Long had one share and one signatory. The Koolmatries had five shares and five signatories to the letter. The Sumners had four shares and two signatories to the letter. The Rankines had three shares and one signatory to the letter. The Wilsons had three shares and one signatory to the letter. The Gollans had two shares and two signatories to the letter. The Marks had two shares and two signatories to the letter. Harradine had one share and one signatory to the letter. Twenty-four of the shareholders signed that letter. There were 31 signatures. As far as I can ascertain, seven people were not shareholders. I might be wrong and they might also be shareholders but that is the latest list I had.

I told the Minister on 17 November that I would have to raise this matter. I did not think I would have to do so at this late hour. I have always been opposed to the Senate sitting late. This is the last day of sitting on which this matter can be raised. I put it on the record once again for the information of Senator Baume in the explicit hope-I think it is a forlorn hope-that he will get off his backside and get something going for these people. I have told them that he has said to me that Ralkon has something to hide. I have said to them: 'If you have anything to hide it will all come out in the inquiry'. They said: 'We are quite prepared for the open inquiry'. They asked me for it. I did not interfere in their affairs. They came to my office, as a member of parliament, many years ago to ask me to take up this matter for them.

Senator Baume knows the whole history of the matter. When he was Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare, I gave to the Committee my complete file of Ralkon. I kept nothing back. If he had done his job as the Chairman of that Committee, he would have read everything. He would have known, if he had read the documentation in the Department since he became the Minister, what was there. From the private conversations that I had with him, I really believe that Senator Chaney was honestly trying to do something for those people. I have no reason to doubt that he had the ifterests of the people at heart and was trying to solve the problem. For some reason there was a change in the portfolio. We got Senator Baume. I immediately asked Senator Baume to try to follow up the work that Senator Chaney had done. We are now back in limbo. These people are being falsely accused by a Liberal member of parliament in South Australia of being untruthful. He is saying that they are crooks. He is saying, in particular, that they are being led by this chap, Hillock, who, he said, is trying to get his hands on the property.

Any sane person would know that if the Aboriginal Development Commission or the Aboriginal Affairs Department holds title to that property there is no way that any individual can get hold of it and use it to his own benefit or sell it. I say again that these are false accusations. The sooner we can set up an inquiry to solve the problem, the happier the people at Ralkon will be. If it is proved that they have not been doing the right thing in running the farm, it will be because they have to leave their farm so often to go to Adelaide to take part in stupid court cases, instigated by white people, who go there and manipulate some of the Aboriginal people.

I cannot say any more tonight but I will keep on saying these things in the Parliament. It is time that people on the other side of the chamber who have the wherewithal and the methods to set up this inquiry did so. If they did, Senator Baume might be able to tell me that I am completely wrong. He might say that I have been chasing a hare up a blind burrow. If I have, I have done it in all innocence and out of my duty as a member of Parliament trying to help people who have come to me seeking assistance. I cannot do any more except stand up in this place. Whilst I have a few more years here I am going to annoy honourable senators on the other side-apparently that is what I am doing-as long as they sit over there. If they are not on that side I assure them that we will have a committee of inquiry to see that justice is done.

I say again that I hope that some of the people who are doubting Thomases about what has taken place will read both letters from the Ombudsman which will prove that they have been misled in relation to what they think has taken place. They have been misled by some people in the Department who I claimed before, and who I claim again, have a skeleton in the cupboard and something to hide. I hope Senator Baume will see that justice is done and will agree to set up a Senate select committee immediately we come back after the recess. Had the committee been set up during the winter recess the job would have been done. Had it been brought forward this session we could have found out who was right and who was wrong. At least we would have laid to rest all these lies which people are peddling around the country. I only hope Mr Lewis is prepared to make those statements which he made on two occasions in the State Parliament outside the Parliament so that he will get his just deserts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that the hour is late and the session almost finished. This is the sort of subject I had hoped to bring on much earlier during a first reading. This was not possible because of the inability of the Government to produce the type of legislation during which I could have introduced the matter. I realise this is an important subject but I hope to finish speaking on it within the next 40 minutes or 50 minutes.
—Ha, ha!

—I am sorry that it does not take much to stir up Senator Walters's mirth. I think I heard somebody say here today that that is all that the honourable senator contributes to the Senate. As far as the Government is concerned there have been problems because for the whole of this week and all last week the Government has suffered many serious defeats in this chamber.
—Which one?

—Perhaps somebody might like to make a suggestion as to which one. I think the Government is in the happy situation of not having won very much in the last four or five weeks. The next session will not be any better. As we move towards the double dissolution-provided the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has enough courage to go through with it-there will be other defeats which the Government can chalk up. I make those preliminary remarks. The razor gang which was appointed very early in the life of this Government to cut out public expenditure has been a total disaster. Even according to the razor gang's reckoning the final amount that will be saved is merely the petty cash in the whole of the Budget Estimates. One of the things that disturbs me greatly is the inroads that have been made into education. It is the sort of thing that betrays the views of the Government almost to the point of corruption.

SPEECH.PARA: In my city of Townsville-one of the remoter areas of this country-the decision to amalgamate the Townsville College of Advanced Education and James Cook University is a great disaster so far as education is concerned. Courses that have been introduced by the CAE under the directorship of Ross McKee have been unique and have brought higher education to people who would otherwise not have been able to obtain it. Incidentally this new system is not going to save any money in the short term. In fact, it will cost us a lot more money in the short term and will probably cost us money in the long term. There is no possible way in which it can be a financial advantage as far as the Government is concerned.

In spite of my earlier threat I do not propose to speak at great length. There are two or three points I want to make. I instance that one of the people guiding this amalgamation at the State Government level occupied a very high position in the Government of Queensland. He was unable to pass his scholarship when he sat for his final school leaving exam. I think there were four or five students in the class. He failed it. He was the only one who failed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was that?

—I do not think it really is necessary to mention names. I leave that to honourable senators' imaginations. I am sure they all will come up with the same answer. I will read what this document, which came off the back of a bus or a truck, has to say. This is the sort of document that was used to convince some people in certain areas, but the people who prepared it made sure that not everybody got a copy of it. Item 1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Townsville College of Advanced Education Council and Student Union will cease to exist as from 1 January 1982. All property, liabilities, assets, contracts, etc., will be transferred to James Cook University.
Of course, the James Cook University is not interested in some of the courses that the CAE has been running since its inception. Item 4 states:
The Institute will offer the same courses as were offered at Townsville CAE. The courses can be altered, dropped, or substituted only with the Minister's approval.

Any honourable senator who knows the Minister for Education, Mr Gunn, will know that his only ability in directing education is to go bang. He will be quite happy to see things like Aboriginal primary teacher training disappear totally because of the States Government's intense hate of anybody who is less than white. He will be quite happy to see the social services courses disappear because the people who are trained in those courses and who obtain a diploma are people who look after the poorer people in the community. Item 6 states:
If a dispute arises between the University and the Boards, it may be referred to the Minister whose decision shall be final and given effect to by all parties.

In other words, the National Party will take over the amalgamation. It will ensure that the CAE is totally crippled. That will lead to a disintegration of some of the major courses at the James Cook University. I am not scaremongering; I am stating a fact. Item 7 states:
The University Council composition will be altered by the addition of the following members:
(i) Five members appointed by the Governor-in-Council.

I point out that the Council has five members, all of whom are either card-carrying members or supporters of the National Party. Your party, Mr President, will not get a look in, nor will the Australian Labor Party. People interested in education will not be appointed to that Council. One of the qualifications required for appointment will be that an applicant has not passed his or her primary school grades. That item goes on to state:
(ii) One member of the staff of the Institute of Advanced Education appointed by the staff.
(iii) One student of the Institute appointed by the Institute's students.
Those two people probably will be well qualified, but they will be outnumbered. They will not be able to do one thing about the situation. Item 8 states:

Council of the University shall within one month of amendment of the Act establish an Advisory Committee for Advanced Education in North Queensland, to consist of five new members of Council who have a particular interest in advanced education, and four other members of the Council.

I understand that those people will not have any degrees or any academic qualifications at all. Wal Fife, the Minister for Education at the Australian Government level, has been totally hoodwinked. He does not know that is going on. I doubt that he understands what is going on. The other day I heard a suggestion that there will be a reshuffle of the Ministry. If the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) is advised properly, he will make sure that Wal Fife is no longer the Minister for Education because people at government level in Queensland have totally hoodwinked him. Earlier tonight I referred to a copy of the document which fell off the back of a truck. I have an extract from the Townsville Daily Bulletin, the first paragraph of which states:
Students are the first and major consideration in the amalgamation of the James Cook University and the Townsville College of Advanced Education, the Minister for Education, Mr Gunn said yesterday.

Of course, that was referring to Mr Bang Bang Gunn. That is not on. Gunn does not even know what is happening. He is not particularly brilliant in the field of education. He has been hopeless as Minister for Education, and there is no way in the world that he will be able to rectify the present situation unless the Federal Government takes the initiative. My second quote is from an article reporting criticism by academics, which appeared in the Courier-Mail on 4 November 1981. It reads:
The senior academics described the Bill as 'a power grab by the State Government in an area normally free of the Bjelke-Petersen administration'.

As I said a few moments ago, this will be run by Gunn and Bjelke-Petersen. They will decide who constitute the committees. They will decide who runs the CAE. Ultimately, if they survive long enough, they will decide when the CAE goes out of existence. But they will be able to decide in the next 12 months which courses disappear. Mr President, I have shown the document from which I quoted to your predecessor in the Chair tonight and to a Minister who was in the Senate earlier tonight. The document read as follows-
STUDENTS-TOP PRIORITY IN AMALGAMATION PLAN: GUNN
Students are the first and major consideration in the amalgamation of the James Cook University and the Townsville College of Advanced Education, the Minister for Education, Mr Gunn said yesterday.
Replying to claims of Government control over the University in legislation effecting the amalgamation, Mr Gunn said some measure of monitoring was necessary to protect advanced education courses.
'There was a real concern that advanced education could be swallowed up and some courses disappear in the amalgamation, with a resultant dramatic effect on students,' he said.

Mr Gunn said the Federal Minister for Education, Mr Fife, had approved of the legislation and in insisting there be a genuine amalgamation of the two institutions, said that two distinct streams of higher education must be maintained in North Queensland.

'This was stated clearly on more than one occasion by both Mr Fife and the Prime Minister. The Commonwealth's State Grants Tertiary Education Assistance Act provides for a reduction in grants to universities which have amalgamated with colleges of advanced education if they fail to offer in 1982 the courses offered by the college in 1981,' Mr Gunn said.
'Therefore I would see the Queensland legislation as being a protection for James Cook University rather than 'a power grab by the State Government' as some academics had described it,' Mr Gunn said.

'These are unusual circumstances, which have been forced upon us which require unusual measures, but in all matters to do with education, no matter what level, the interests of the students are paramount,' he said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I conclude with these words: I hope that during the recess your Government, Mr President, and particularly your lame duck Minister for Education, will examine the matter in detail. The Minister is scared stiff of Bjelke-Petersen in the same way that your Prime Minister is scared of Bjelke-Petersen-witness his decision to allow all sorts of things to happen on the Great Barrier Reef, in mining and in various other fields which I will not elaborate on tonight because I have only another 40 minutes to go. I hope that some time in the next few weeks before we come back on 16 February this particular aspect will be examined in very great detail and that the CAE will be allowed to survive as an autonomous institution under its present directorship doing the magnificent work it is currently doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.

Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
FOREIGN FISHING BOATS LEVY BILL 1981

This Bill is the first of a package of four Bills that I am introducing today for the purpose of authorizing the imposition and collection of a tax on various kinds of fishing activities by foreigners. The others are the Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Bill 1981, the Fisheries Amendment Bill 1981 and the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Amendment Bill 1981.

This Bill imposes a levy on the grant of licences authorizing foreign boats to fish in the 200 nautical mile Australian fishing zone or to take sedentary organisms from the Australian continental shelf. Since the establishment of the fishing zone on 1 November 1979, the Government has collected amounts in addition to licence fees in accordance with agreements between the Commonwealth and the foreign interests concerned. This Bill does not affect that practice. I shall refer to this in more detail later.

The Government's policy is to encourage joint fishing operations between Australian and foreign interests as the preferred method of allowing foreign fishermen to have access to the portion of fish stock in the AFZ that Australian fishermen do not harvest.

The principal purpose of this Bill, is to enable implementation of an aspect of the new guidelines for joint Australian/ foreign fishing arrangements, developed by the Australian Fishing Zone Committee comprising representatives of the fishing industry and State, Northern Territory and Commonwealth governments.

Following endorsement by the Australian Fisheries Council in September 1980, the Minister for Primary Industry announced the Government's acceptance of the new guidelines. The guidelines provide that in addition to administrative fees prescribed by regulation under the Fisheries Act, joint venture partners during the period when foreign vessels and crews are utilised, might be required to pay access fees which may be reviewed during the course of the project. This provision in the guidelines is designed to cover the initial situation where there is little Australian involvement in the joint venture. As the Australian content is increased the levy could be phased out. Alternatively where considerable benefits are offered the levy would be payable if the benefits do not materialise.

This Bill provides for the assessment of a levy payable in respect of the grant of licences for foreign boats operating under the control of joint fishing arrangements and for the liability of licence holders, who may be Australian residents or companies, for payment of the levy. Other Bills in this package provide for the collection of the levy, and how it may be reduced or waived if other suitable benefits are provided to Australia.

The Bill applies not only to licences granted as the result of a joint fishing arrangement. It subjects all licensees of foreign fishing boats to an obligation to pay a tax to be called 'levy' except in two cases. The first case is where the licence is granted under an agreement with a foreign government which specifies that an amount is payble over and above the licence fee. The second case in which levy is not payable under this Bill is where the boats are temporarily imported, and the regulations prescribe them to be exempt. The Government's intention is that the regulations will exempt only those temporarily imported boats that are under the exclusive control of Australians for use in developmental fishing.

The amount of levy that is payble under the Bill will be set out in the Regulations. Clause 7 provides that the Regulations may set out the amount of levy payable for any boat or class of boats by reference to a wide range of matters relating to the boat or its operations.

As I have just mentioned, the amount required to be paid in respect of boats in joint fishing arrangements may be less than the applicable levy as the result of provisions in the Fisheries Amendment Bill or the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Amendment Bill, to which I will refer later.
Finally, neither this Bill nor any other Bill in the package, applies to fishing operations with Australian boats.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
FISHERIES AGREEMENTS (PAYMENTS) BILL
This Bill is the second of the four Bills dealing with payments in respect of foreign boats licensed to fish in waters or areas of the continental shelf under Australian jurisdiction.

The purpose of the Bill is to provide the Commonwealth with legislative powers to give effect to fisheries agreements entered into with a foreign government, providing for the payment by nationals of the other country of amounts additional to administrative fees payable for the issue of licences. Boats licensed pursuant to a government-to-government agreement are exempt from levy under the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Bill and any amount required to be paid under the agreement is payable in lieu of levy.

This Bill has the constitutional character of a taxing Bill and has no other application than in that sense. There are mirror provisions in other Bills to which I will later refer, which have effect if the provisions are held not to deal with the imposition of taxation. This course of legislative action has been taken on legal advice to put the matter beyond doubt. What is not caught by this Bill will be caught by one of the others.
The Bill does not of itself provide statutory authority for the Commonwealth to enter into agreements. The Commonwealth does this in the exercise of its executive authority.

Since 1979 when the Australian fishing zone was established, the Commonwealth has collected an access fee in respect of Japanese tuna longline vessels in accordance with the subsidiary agreements with the Japanese Government. The Bill does not replace provisions of that kind in any past or future agreement. It leaves the two governments free to agree that all or some of the amount becomes payable after the licences are granted. This additional flexibility is of benefit to both parties in negotiating the agreement. The Bill supports this flexibility by providing a power to suspend the licences granted under the agreement while amounts agreed to be paid remain outstanding.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
FISHERIES AMENDMENT BILL 1981
This is the third of the four Bills dealing with taxation in relation to foreign fishing boats.

The purpose of this Bill is to provide for the collection of levy payable on the grant of licences under the Fisheries Act 1952, which the Bill amends for the purpose. The Bill also contains provisions to facilitate giving effect to fisheries agreements entered into with foreign governments, to the extent that those provisions do not deal with the imposition of taxation.

When moving the second reading of the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Bill, I referred to the Government's policy of licensing foreign fishing boats to fish in the Australian fishing zone-AFZ-only after entering into formal agreements with the foreign fishing interests seeking the licences. These agreements fall into three general categories, each of which this Bill deals with separately.

The first category is agreements for the conduct of joint fishing operations. Where a joint fishing company offers benefits to Australia, in consideration of which the Commonwealth has agreed to release the company from additional impost by way of levy, the Bill empowers the Minister to give effect to that agreement. The Government expects that the use of this power will encourage joint fishing companies to create employment for Australians, to invest in facilities on shore in Australia, or to provide other tangible benefits.

The second category of agreements is where Australia agrees with the Government of a foreign country to license fishing vessels flying its flag to fish in the AFZ. The Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Bill exempts boats licensed pursuant to such an arrangement from liability to pay the levy. The Fisheries Agreements (Payments) Bill provides legislative authority to give effect to the agreement insofar as it may be held to deal with the imposition of taxation in relation to the agreed amount. The Fisheries Amendment Bill provides for giving effect to the agreement in cases that do not have taxation implications.

The final category of agreements comprises those which do not fall into either of the previous categories, such as the agreement with the Kaohsiung Commercial Fishing Boat Guild of Taiwan. Foreign boats licensed under agreements in this category will continue to be liable to pay the full amount.
The Bill requires the Minister to table agreements of any of these kinds in both Houses of the Parliament within 15 sitting days after entering into them.

The Fisheries Act which this Bill amends, sets out objectives in section 5B, to which the Minister is to have regard when administering the Act. The Minister exercises his discretionary power to grant or refuse a licence under section 9 of that Act in accordance with those statutory objectives. The Bill will require the Minister to disregard those objectives when granting licenses pursuant to agreements. The stage at which the Minister considers the conservation and fisheries management objectives of the Act is when the agreement is being negotiated.

It is proposed to insert a new section 9C in the principal Act to provide for collection of levy payable in respect of all foreign fishing boats that have not been exempted under the Foreign Fishing Boats Levy Bill.

Proposed sub-section 9C (2) enables the Minister to make arrangements with people or companies liable to pay the levy, concerning the time and manner of payment of the levy. In such a case, proposed sub-section 9C (10) requires payment in accordance with the arrangement or, where there is no such arrangement, within 30 days of the grant of the licence.

By proposed sub-section 9C (6), when the Minister has made an agreement approving a joint fishing arrangement and the company has defaulted on the provision of a promised benefit, the amount of levy that had previously been waived becomes payable. The Minister may then suspend some or all of the licences held by the company in respect of foreign fishing boats. Agreements for joint fishing arrangements will normally refer to the benefits to be provided on a year-by-year basis, in conjunction with the issue of licences.

If the company subsequently either pays the levy together with any penalty that has accrued or provides the promised benefit, the Minister is then required, by proposed sub-section 9C (7), to reinstate the suspended licences.

In the case of an agreement in the third category, when levy is not paid by the due date, proposed sub-section 9C (8) empowers the Secretary to the Minister's Department to suspend the licences for the foreign fishing boats concerned. Under the next proposed sub-section he must revoke the suspension when the levy and any penalty is received.

Proposed sub-section 9C (11) provides a rate of penalty of 10 per cent for each month the levy remains unpaid after the due date. Penalty ceases to accumulate on the date that the license would have expired.

The combined effect of these provisions is that the licensee would commit an offence against the Fisheries Act 1952 if he used the boat for fishing in the AFZ during the suspension and even if the levy were not paid during the period of the licence, it and the penalty would remain as money owing to the Commonwealth, recoverable in a court of competent jurisdiction.

The intention of these sanctions is that they should serve as much as an incentive to the provision of promised benefits of prompt payment of levy as a punishment for default. Nevertheless, the sanctions will be applied whenever a default occurs.

It is not appropriate, in the case of an agreement with the Government of another country, to make any unpaid amount a debt to the Commonwealth recoverable in a court or to impose any penalty for non-payment. However, the Bill contains provisions for suspension of licences in such a case.

To assist in verification of the amount due when levy is assessed in accordance with the size of the boat, Clauses 5 and 6 provide a power for an officer to go on board and measure the boat or to obtain the assistance of another person, who would have the powers and rights of an officer while so engaged. It is envisaged that the other person would be a qualified marine surveyor employed by the Commonwealth or a State.
Finally, clauses 7 and 8 make a number of formal amendments to the principal Act.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
CONTINENTAL SHELF (LIVING NATURAL RESOURCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

The Bill is the final Bill in the package concerned with taxing foreign boats. In substance, it is identical with the Fisheries Amendment Bill. For that reason, I will not take the time of the Senate with a recital of its detailed provisions.
However, there are several points about which it is appropriate to inform the Senate in relation to the Bill.

Australia's sovereign rights in relation to living sedentary organisms on the Australian continental shelf differ significantly from Australia's sovereign rights and responsibilities for managing the swimming fishery resources of the AFZ. In particular, Australia is not obliged to allocate to foreigners, any surplus of the allowable catch of sedentary organisms that Australians do not take.

Since the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968 came into force, the Commonwealth policy has consistently been not to license foreign ships. This does not mean that, if Australian fishermen did not harvest the allowable catch of presently known or newly discovered stocks of a sedentary organism, we would not at some future time review the policy to see if there was benefit to be gained for Australia by allowing foreigners to harvest those stocks on terms and conditions determined by the Commonwealth.

The Government considers it appropriate to provide now for collection of the levy in relation to licences that may at some future time be granted for foreign ships to take sedentary organisms. Without the Bill, the Government would be limited in the options available to it in relation to any future proposals it might receive from foreign fishermen seeking permission to harvest sedentary organisms from the continental shelf of Australia or the external Territories on a commercial basis. At present there are no such proposals under consideration.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is not opposing this package of Bills. In the unlikely event of anyone wanting to know why, I refer them to Mr Kerin's speech in the House of Representatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fishing Bills before the Senate this morning deal with a range of issues that are of importance to the various fishing industries in the States of Australia. I wish to raise some points about the fishing industry and the problems that it is currently facing in Queensland, which problems I believe are symptomatic of the types of problems the industries around Australia are facing. Leaving aside the problem of fuel costs, which contribute so much to the costs of fishermen, particularly the fisherman with a single boat, the major problem for fishermen seems to be the availability of loans. The Primary Industry Bank of Australia, which has provided low interest finance in a range of primary industry areas, unfortunately still insists on linking forestry and fishing together. Up to 30 June 1981, $8.1m out of $364.9m went to fishing and forestry.

SPEECH.PARA: The fishing industry feels that this reflects the continuing disinterest of the major trading banks in recognising ship mortgages and vessel hulls as collateral for loans. This unfortunately has had the effect of moving fishermen out of the market for low interest loans, which are so necessary to primary producers, into the area of finance companies, from which many fishermen have had to seek loans at interest rates sometimes in excess of 20 per cent. In Queensland it has had serious long term effects not only on the fishing industry but also on associated industries.

I will mention one of those which is, of course, the underwriters and insurers of the fishing boats in Queensland. For example, in the year just ended claims in excess of $4m were made on these insurers. Apart from the smaller claims this record loss relates to some 40 boats being either totally written off or disappearing during the year. It does not take much imagination to know why, when a small business person is forced to the wall, there will be repercussions for other industries. Indeed, in that industry the losses and the payouts far exceeded any of the income which means that many of the underwriters who are currently in the industry will move out, thereby forcing up the rate of insurance for those who remain within the industry.

The problem of rising fuel costs is one which, of course, is not confined to the fishing industry alone but is shared between it and other primary industries. I will take an example. We can look at a trawler which may be using 45 litres of fuel per hour with the following results: In one night's fishing-steaming to anchorage, trawling for, say, ten hours and returning to anchorage-we would be looking at a cost of roughly in excess of $170 using figures for early 1980. If one looks at the average catch and cost at that time one finds that the boat would take in roughly $180. We thereby see the enormous problem that in one night what is left to make repayments and pay other expenses is something in excess of $10. If this is spread over the years to illustrate the enormous increase in charges we can see the results.

In July 1978 the total costs of that type of example I have given for an average trawler working 200 night in the year would be in excess of $15,000. In July 1980 we were looking at a cost in excess of $30,000. In other words more than double the amount of money would have to be expended by that trawler on fuel. Those types of problems-in relation to loans and rising fuel costs-illustrate fairly clearly the types of difficulties that one of our major primary industries is running into in this country. It is a pity that while much is being done and some useful initiatives were taken in the last Budget-up until the last Budget I think most fishermen were looking for some alleviation of their costs and all they managed to do was to get increases loaded upon that industry. Yet, of course, in industry terms the fishing industry is one of the major contributors to our export earnings in the primary area and one of our major income earners.

The last point that I want to raise in relation to the fishing industry is one which I believe has exercised a large number of people's minds; that is, the enormous difficulty that the industry is facing because of imports. Particularly in Queensland, imports of such things as crumbed scallops, peeled prawns, sea perch and a number of other items are seriously undermining the viability of individual fishermen. I believe that in the short term unless immediate and urgent measures are taken we will see many more of those small businessmen go to the wall, we will see many more of their boats repossessed and we will eventually see the destruction of small individuals in the fishing industry. They will be replaced by large companies which are generally overseas owned.

I believe that unless the Senate comes to grips with this problem it will be residing over the demise of an extremely important and valuable primary industry. I believe it is a pity that so much time was devoted to other matters in the first reading debate and so little was devoted to what is a vital industry to Australia and to so many people in this country. I hope that early in the next session it will be possible to have a more general debate on this issue. I believe time will be made available for debate on a report which will be brought down and that we will have a much more extensive debate so that the problems of these people can be raised. I hope that some suggested solutions to their enormous difficulties will be presented.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without requests or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion that has been moved by my colleague Senator Robertson. I move an amendment to the motion in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after ''That'', insert ''the Standing Orders Committee be requested to consider improvements required in the Senate Chamber, including the provision of closed circuit television facilities for the monitoring of Senate proceedings, and to report to the Senate on the cost of such improvements''.

I shall indicate briefly the reasons for my amendment, but before doing so I want to indicate why I oppose the motion. When Senator Robertson moved the motion earlier he made some mention of snooping or perhaps a lack of snooping. I understand quite well that there is no wish on behalf of Senator Robertson to snoop on what is happening in the chamber but, with the restricted installation of closed circuit television facilities, it is easy to be suspicious about this possibility. If closed circuit television is to be beamed into certain locations within the building, one of the questions I would ask is: Why is it to be restricted? Initially it will be beamed to the Whips so that they do not have to be present in the chamber to see what is going on. Perhaps I have an old fashioned feeling about this, but it seems to me that the place for the Whips is in the chamber. If they want to see what is going on, I suggest that they be present.

If we intend to introduce closed circuit television so that the Whips can have access to a visual display of what is happening in the chamber, why stop there? It would seem to me that if the Whips need closed circuit television to see what is going on in the chamber so too do the leaders-the Leader of the Government in the Senate, the Leader of the Opposition and the Leader of the Australian Democrats. If the leaders need it, why do not the deputy leaders need it? If the deputy leaders need it, why do not the deputy Whips also need it? If the Whips, the leaders, the deputy leaders and so on need it, why not introduce it for the Temporary Chairmen of Committees? After all they need to know what is going on in the chamber. If all of those people need to have closed circuit television, why not the Clerk? Obviously the Clerk wants to know what is going on.

Perhaps this is being ridiculous but, if it is, it is being ridiculous right at the very start. If all of those people require closed circuit television facilities, why not all honourable senators? If all honourable senators had closed circuit television beamed to their rooms perhaps I would have fewer reservations about the whole proposal than I have with the facilities going only to one or two locations or perhaps half a dozen locations in the building. We have been told that when we move into the new Parliament House-that is, those who are members of this Parliament at that time-we will have closed circuit television in all the rooms. If the facilities were provided in all the rooms I would see that as quite acceptable. Perhaps there could be some voice coverage also. As Senator Bjelke-Peterson would know, in all the rooms in the Queensland Parliament there are closed circuit televisions. It is not the crummy type of television which we had here-black and white; it is colour television. The point I make is that if the facility is to be provided in all the rooms, perhaps there would be some justification for it. If it is to be provided in only a few locations, I would be opposed to it.

I now turn to another plane. Perhaps other improvements need to be made in this chamber before we spend money on closed circuit television. If we have money to spend let us see whether it can be spent in a better way. Perhaps there are other priorities at which we should be looking. For instance-perhaps this does not refer specifically to the chamber-we have been decrying the fact recently that we have had a cut in funds allocated to the Parliamentary Library. If we have money to spend why do we not put it into the Parliamentary Library rather than into closed circuit television? Many honourable senators have been decrying the fact for some time that we need staff for Senate committees. If we have money to spend, why do we not put on additional staff for the Senate committees?

Perhaps we should be more adventurous than this and think of some of the other things that would improve this Senate chamber. Why do we not have an electronic system whereby we can vote without having to cross the floor and being tallied like sheep? Why do we not have an electronic system so that during Question Time we can just indicate to the President through this electronic system that we would like to be called upon to ask a question rather than spend an hour every day exercising ourselves by getting up and sitting down and probably eventually going out of the chamber frustrated because we did not get the call. It seems to me to be much better to look at this sort of possibility. I am not saying that at some stage we should not introduce a closed circuit television system. I am saying that we should be looking at all of the improvements that we require in this chamber and perhaps the improvements that we require for the service of the chamber before we decide that we will spend money on some particular aspect.

One of the things that concern me about the proposal that has been brought to us this evening is that we were not told what the costs would be. Before the Senate decides to take the radical step of bringing closed circuit television into the chamber I think we should look at the costs and perhaps even compare these costs with the cost of other improvements that could be made. Therefore, I propose an amendment which will cover some of these points. I move:

Leave out all words after 'That', insert 'the Standing Orders Committee be requested to consider improvements required in the Senate Chamber, including the provision of closed circuit television facilities for the monitoring of Senate proceedings, and to report to the Senate on the cost of such improvements'.

I wish to make a few remarks concerning that amendment. Included in that amendment is provision for closed circuit television facilities, although I understand that there is a reference before the Senate Standing Orders Committee to look at the provision of television. I am not quite sure whether that involves closed circuit television or the televising of the proceedings of the chamber. But I included that provision in the amendment to indicate that I do not have any objection to the Standing Orders Committee having a look at that as one of the improvements that might be required in the Senate chamber.

I think other improvements should be looked at-perhaps some of those that I mentioned; perhaps some others might come to mind as well. We could then look at the costing of all of those improvements and perhaps the priorities in which they should be implemented, if we are to implement them, and report back to the Senate giving the priorities, the types of improvements that might be required and the costs of such improvements so that the Senate can have a look at them and make up its mind on the basis of some clear data-data that was not given to us this evening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Colston in what he has had to say. I have mentioned before in this place this matter of having an electronic apparatus, which is a relatively simple matter these days. A very simple little system would be able to convey to you, sir, our voting intentions and would assist also during Question Time. The four, five, six or seven minutes involved in counting a division may not seem long, but when we take the costs of the Senate over a year to the community those costs are very considerable. With respect to the community it devolves on us to consider that we are not really an antiquated sort of a place in which tradition is the only thing that is important. We are here to do a job for the community for which we are paid accordingly. We should support Senator Colston's amendment for that reason.

SPEECH.PARA: We should look at a system by which votes in divisions can be communicated to you, Mr President, through a quite simple computer-that is all it would be-so time, which costs money, is not taken up unnecessarily. The present procedure for Question Time, whilst quaint, is antiquated and has no real relevance to the present-day world. Through some electronic means honourable senators could communicate to you that they want to ask a question and the details as to order could be recorded. Mr President, you would know who had asked questions. This would make it less necessary for you to keep a complicated list. It is not proper and right that you should have to keep such a list. You should have the assistance of whatever modern conveniences is available so that the intentions of honourable senators is known to you.

On that basis I suggest that we should have a general exploration of what might improve the conduct of business in this place and which might make it easier for honourable senators and you, Mr President. That would make it apparent to the public that we were not a sixteenth century chamber but a place cognisant of the modern world and its facilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I take the unusual step of opposing my colleague Senator Colston, but as he has opposed me I suppose I have some justification in doing it. I do not want to detain the Senate for long but I will cover a couple of points that have been raised in the course of the debate. Firstly, the matter of closed circuit television monitoring of the Senate chamber has been considered by the Standing Orders Committee. It authorised the present test and it is for us to make a decision on the basis of the recommendations made by the Committee. I believe that a delay would be unfortunate. There has been some urgency in getting this matter moving because, if we are to have closed circuit television, we want to see it installed during the recess. If we put it off it would have to be left certainly until the next recess if not later. I apologise for the fact that we moved fairly quickly on this matter. It was considered by the Standing Orders Committee and I was authorised to have the test done. The job was done quickly by the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Perhaps it would have been better had we raised the matter in the chamber and talked about it first. But in that event we might have decided to look at it in 1982 and perhaps introduce it in 1983. I believe it is important that we get television brought in as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: It is proposed that the television facility be restricted, for a very important reason. The leaders and a number of senior people believed that it should not be in every room. Most of them spend one and a half to two hours per day in the chamber and we certainly would not want to discourage them from attending for that time. Cost is a factor to be considered. This was raised by Senator Colston. In a moment I will give the cost of installing four cameras and three monitors. Honourable senators can imagine the additional cost if an attempt were made to place monitors in all rooms, as I understand will be the case in the new Parliament House. We do not have that sort of money to play with at this time. We have to keep within a reasonable budget. The reductio ad absurdum that my colleague went on with really supports the case that I want to make. No suggestion has been made that closed circuit coverage go to all rooms. The suggestion was that it be introduced as a technological aid to the three Whips, and this was made quite clear.

Senator Colston said that there were other priorities. No doubt there are. It is not an either/or situation. We do not look at all such propositions. We went through the normal arrangement of saying: 'Let us have a look at this and attempt to identify the need. When we have identified the need then let us try to meet it'. The proposition was put up on that basis.

I am advised that the cost to install four cameras and three monitors would be $15,500. Honourable senators will notice that my motion mentions authorising the President, who has a responsibility to provide certain facilities for honourable senators. If after considering the matter he thought it was worth while, he would be authorised by the Senate to go ahead and have the job done. This whole matter is tied in to a degree with what we were looking at today, that is, the staffing and appropriations for the Senate. We want senior officers of the Senate to be given the authority to make those decisions, to say: 'Yes, we think that is good and it can be installed'. I would like to see a situation whereby the senior officer is advised by a small committee, but that is a matter for another debate.

Senator Mason made comments about wanting the most efficient situation. He talked about not wanting to live back in the middle ages, I think. But, as I tried to explain this afternoon for the purpose we are looking at-the most efficient way of doing our job-we believe, after looking carefully at the test, that the best method would be to use modern technology. It is perhaps unfortunate that more time is not available to discuss this matter. I have apologised already for this fact. It may have been better to have stretched the matter out over some months or perhaps years before we made the decision. Nevertheless, we have gone ahead. The test has been made. I think, without any doubt, that the test has been most effective. I think that the introduction of what is not exactly radical technology will add to the efficiency of the Senate. So I do not think we need to go any further on this matter. I simply ask the Senate to reject the amendment and to support the original proposition.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I believe that this constitutes the end of a rather lengthy business list for this session, and I take a brief time of the Senate to make a number of comments that I think should be made. First of all, sir, I want not only to congratulate you upon your appointment as President of this chamber but also to say that those who took part in that appointment are fully justified. You have brought to the Chair a dignity, an impartiality, and objectivity and a good humour which have added to the dignity and functioning of this chamber. On behalf of all honourable senators in this chamber I thank you for what you have done.

SPEECH.PARA: Through you, sir, may we thank the Clerk and his assistants and all the staff of the Senate, including those who are dispersed throughout this building and elsewhere who serve the Senate committees. May we thank the attendants who function here and those in the dining rooms and kitchens; indeed, those in the whole of the Joint House Department who make this Parliament work. May I ask the Hansard officers to convey our thanks to their staff for a job exceedingly well done, with great tolerance and patience, and a great imaginative creativity regarding our sometimes clumsy English usage.

Having said that, I would like to convey to members of the Opposition and their families the warm wishes of Government members for the festive season and for the New Year. We wish them happiness and good health. Turning to my own political parties, I would like to express to them my gratitude for the work they have done in carrying things out and for their tolerance, particularly of myself and the warts that I bear. If I may, too, I thank the Whips on both sides of the chamber and their assistants for a job extremely well done. I wish everyone in this chamber and those who serve this Parliament a wonderful Christmas and a New Year of health and happiness.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with Senator Carrick in thanking all those persons-from you, Mr President, down, if I may put it in that order-who have assisted us in this year's work. I include everybody whom Senator Carrick mentioned. I wish all honourable senators, irrespective of their party, a happy Christmas and a safe return to do battle in 1982.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of my party, I, too, endorse the good wishes expressed by the Leader of the Government (Senator Carrick) and the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button). As Christmas approaches, I hope we do not find that we have left all tolerance and good will here in this chamber and that we take to Christmas lots of both those things. I offer to all honourable senators, to the officers of this chamber, to the attendants and Mr President, to you for the job that you have done with us and on our behalf, the best of wishes for Christmas and a healthy and peaceful new year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My first good wishes are to you Mr President, if I may with respect subeit thee. We in our little part of the Senate have found you to be a fair and tolerant yet disciplined President. We appreciate very much the contribution you have made to this House since you have been in your high office. I say to members of the Australian Labor Party and to the Liberal Party that they have our best wishes for Christmas and the new year. If at times the Australian Democrats seem to be rather new and naughty children, bear with us. We are in this place, like all of us, learning. We feel that we have our role to pursue and we have a purpose in this place. If we sometimes assert it with more enthusiasm than other honourable senators would like, we ask that they bear with us with tolerance.

SPEECH.PARA: Beyond that, I express, perhaps more than almost anything else, our great debt to the staff of this place, particularly the Clerk and officers of the Senate who have had to bear with our ignorance and with our lack of knowledge of the procedures of this place, and who have always with the greatest of patience endured many more ditherings, vicissitudes and changes of mind in what we have wanted to do than Senator Evans would ever imagine. I think this is necessary because we are in a rather unusual position in this place in that we have to judge and understand what is occurring on both sides of the chamber. Whatever virtue one may see in our decisions, at least we have to make decisions. We try to pursue that task with some enthusiasm.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would that you did.

—Senator Evans, now you just pipe down. It is time for you to shut up. Just be quiet for a while. I have nearly finished; you do not have to interrupt me any more. Beyond that-and I think I can speak on behalf of the three Australian Democrat senators who have entered this place more recently than I-we have been given tolerance and accommodation from a number of people in this place and we appreciate t'at very much.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to respond and say thank you very much to the respective leaders for their kind words and best wishes to me personally and also for what was said to the staff, generally, who operate within this chamber and outside it. I also take this opportunity to thank my Deputy President, who now has the double honour of being also the 'Father' of the Senate, for his co-operation. Likewise, I express my thanks to the Temporary Chairmen. I appreciate very much what they have done during the session. While I am making reference to what the Deputy President and Temporary Chairmen have done, I also say a big thankyou to honourable senators for their co-operation and generosity during my first term as President. At times I felt it was the 'kindness to the President' session. Long may that continue. To all of you, I extend the very best wishes for Christmas and wish you a bright and happy new year and 1982. I hope that you will be as pleasant and tolerant in 1982 as you have been for this last session of 1981.

INTERJECT.PARA: I take this opportunity also to give personal thanks to the Senate staff, to those who work at the table and generally within this chamber, to the staff supporting the chamber and to all of the other people who are so closely involved-from the attendants who operate within the chamber and outside of it, to the staff of the dining room, the cooks, the staff of the refreshment rooms and all of the other people who help to make this place operate as it does. I extend to one and all my best wishes for a merry Christmas and all the best in 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, with your tolerance I have three procedural motions to propose: First I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, unless otherwise ordered, the Senate, at its rising, adjourn until Tuesday, 16 February 1982, at 3 p.m., or such other day and/or hour as may be fixed by the President, or, in the event of the President being unavailable, the Deputy President, and that the day and hour of meeting so determined shall be notified to each Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add: Provided that the President, upon a request or requests by an absolute majority of the whole number of senators that the Senate meet at a certain time, shall fix a day and hour of meeting in accordance with such request or requests, and such time of meeting shall be notified to each senator by telegram or letter.

For these purposes a request by the Leader or Deputy Leader of the Opposition shall be deemed to be a request by every senator of the Opposition and a request by the Leader or Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats shall be deemed to be a request by every Australian Democrat senator.
Provided further that the request or requests may be made to the President by leaving the same with, or delivering the same to, the Clerk of the Senate, who shall immediately notify the President.

In the event of the President being unavailable, the Clerk shall without delay notify the Deputy President, or, should he be unavailable, any one of the Temporary Chairmen of Committees, who shall be deemed to be required by the Senate to summon the Senate on behalf of the President, in accordance with the terms of this resolution.
I move that as a motion customarily proposed by the Leader of the Opposition whether he be Senator Murphy or Senator Withers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has no objection to the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Carrick) agreed to:
That leave of absence be granted to every member of the Senate from the termination of the sitting this day to the day on which the Senate next meets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I propose the final motion, I would note that perhaps all of us overlooked conveying our greetings and best wishes for the future to all members of the Press Gallery and their staff. I ask that that expression be conveyed. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not apologise one bit for this dawn appeal. I ask the Leader of the Government (Senator Carrick) to convey to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Macphee), in relation to the special humanitarian program announced last week, an appeal that on behalf of the Latin American communities of Victoria and New South Wales, we alert our Ambassador in Peru within the next week to have a look at the political exiles from Bolivia, Argentina, Uruguay and Chile to see whether they can be the first beneficiaries under this program. It has been well canvassed in the past and I make that appeal to the Government for implementation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

Senate adjourned at 1.34 a.m. until Tuesday, 16 February 1982, at 3 p.m., or such other day and/or hour as may be fixed by the President, or in the event of the President being unavailable, by the Deputy President in accordance with the resolution agreed to this day.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Was the non-official postmastership of the Mount Lewis postal outlet, Wattle St, Bankstown, offered to Mr R. B. Blackett-Ord in 1979.

(2) Was Mr Blackett-Ord supplied with figures on the utilisation of that outlet which led him to expect that his income from the position would be considerably higher than it actually turned out to be.
(3) Was a mistake made in the preparation of the figures; if so, what steps have been taken to investigate who or what was responsible for the mistake and to ensure that such mistakes do not recur.
(4) Who or what was responsible for the mistake.
(5) Have any steps been taken to compensate Mr Blackett-Ord; if so, what are they and are they adequate; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mr Blackett-Ord sought appointment as Non-official Postmaster at Mount Lewis because of his interest in purchasing the business in conjunction with which the post office is conducted. He completed a printed application form on 23 May 1979 and was subsequently appointed to the position on 27 July 1979.

(2) Mr Blackett-Ord was supplied with figures which indicated that for the first year of his appointment, payment would be at the rate of $9,867.50 pa. He was advised that this rate would be reviewed annually and would vary in accordance with the level of business transacted at the post office.

(3) Yes. The figures quoted were based on the level of business transacted for the year 1976-77 and the payments being made to the incumbent Postmaster. This information did not take into account the fact that business had declined during 1977-78 to the point where, should the office be transferred to a new non-official postmaster, it should have been re-classified to a lower category at a lower rate of remuneration. Investigations revealed that the mistake was caused by records in the Divisional Manager's Office not being maintained in the prescribed manner.

The relevant recording methods have been changed so that variations in the level of business are not overlooked, and that the current level of business and the current rate of payment are readily discernible. These changes are designed to ensure that similar errors do not occur in the future.

(5) Given the circumstances, payment to Mr Blackett-Ord was adjusted to the rate he had originally been advised he would receive (plus national wage adjustments) for the full period of his appointment as Non-official Postmaster at Mount Lewis. He suffered no loss of expected income for the period.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has President Marcos of the Philippines invested several hundred million dollars of his personal fortune in Australia.
(2) If so, where has the investments been made and has any of the money been used to buy real estate, including pastoral properties.
(3) Did the investments receive approval of the Australian Government.
(4) If the Government has no knowledge of the matter will the Treasurer initiate an investigation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) to (4) In view of the commercial sensitivity attaching to much of the information provided to the Government and the Foreign Investment Review Board in connection with foreign investment proposals, this information is treated in strict confidence and details of proposals are not disclosed to other than the parties directly involved, except in special circumstances.

Proposed investments by persons who are not residents of Australia are, of course, subject to examination under the Government's foreign investment policy and the Foreign Takeovers Act and provided the investments satisfy the requirements of the policy and the Act, they would be approved by the Government.

Foreign Investment Review Board data relating to foreign investment proposals approved by the Government show that expected investment associated with proposals by Philippines residents and Philippines companies totalled $0.3m in 1977-78, $5.6m in 1978-79, $1.7m in 1979-80 and $6m in 1980-81. Australian Bureau of Statistics data show that net inflow of Philippines investment into Australian enterprises has been negligible. In the six years to 1979-80, Philippines investment has totalled $4m.
