QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there a considerable waiting time, long queues and only one attendant at the counter at the Immigration Section, Canberra House, Stockholm; if so, why.
(2) Does it take approximately two months to process visas to Australia at the Department of Immigration, Stockholm; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As is usual with enquiry services, there are variations through the day and from day to day in the numbers of people wishing to make enquiries. In these circumstances, delays sometimes occur. (2) Visitor visas are issued to bona fide travellers approximately 48 hours after applications are lodged. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1800) Senator Colston asked me a question, without notice, concerning Australia's relations with Pakistan.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Government is aware of the restraints on political activity in Pakistan and the continued detentagn of Benazir Bhutto, the daughter of the former Prime Minister. We also know that the Government of Pakistan has recently begun legal proceedings against the Bhutto family to recover funds allegedly misappropriated by the former Prime Minister while he was in office. At the time of Bhutto's execution my predecessor, Mr Peacock, made it clear in the House of Representatives on 4 April 1979 that this Government deeply regretted that event. Australia, together with many other countries, had appealed to the Government of Pakistan to exercise clemency but these representations were not accepted.

My Government continues to regret the detention of Benazir Bhutto and looks forward to a return to a situation where political parties can again play a role in a democratically elected government. We welcome as a step in this direction the announcement by President Zia that he will appoint this month a broad-based Federal Advisory Council. At the same time we are aware of the special difficulties Pakistan is now facing as a result of the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan. We have given what diplomatic and other support we can to Pakistan in its efforts in the UN and elsewhere to find a lasting political settlement to the Afghanistan situation. As you are probably aware, Australia has also given substantial assistance to Pakistan in its efforts to cope with the Afghan refugee problem.
The Government has no objections to the current test tour of Australia by the Pakistan cricket team, which returns a visit by the Australian cricket team to Pakistan in 1980.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1981, (Hansard, page 1801) Senator Watson directed to me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs in the Senate, a question without notice concerning the intended closure of the Australian Consulate-General in Lae.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In your question you drew attention to the strategic importance of Papua New Guinea and Australia's role in the Pacific region. The Government recognises the strategic importance of the South Pacific region. This is evidenced by the number of new posts, such as Apia, Vila, Nuku'alofa and most recently, Tarawa, that the Government has opened in the past four years. In continuing its process of examining the need for opening or closing posts, the Government will keep in mind the importance of Papua New Guinea and the decision on Lae.

I appreciate the honourable senator's concern that the Consulate-General in Lae, opened in 1974 to cope with consular demands resulting from Papua New Guinea becoming an independent nation, is now to close. The decision was taken, however, as a result of a review of workloads at overseas posts and the pressures on financial and staffing resources of the overseas service, and because the High Commission in Port Moresby is able to undertake consular duties for Lae through regular visits by consular and other officers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1981 (Hansard, pages 1806-1807) Senator Ryan asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning the Australian Gallery Director's Council.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australia Council has advised me that it has made several attempts to assist the Australian Gallery Directors Council (AGDC) to overcome serious financial difficulties. The AGDC is facing an accumulated deficit of about $300,000. Principal among these attempts was an offer to maintain the 1981 grant level ($278,000) and an offer of an extraordinary grant of $100,000 conditional on the AGDC raising from non-government sources the balance of $200,000 required to meet the deficit. The AGDC has been unable to raise these funds and as a result the Board of the AGDC has decided that it will recommend voluntary liquidation to a general meeting of Council members to be held on 18 November 1981.

The decision by t'e AGDC to go into voluntary liquidation would be regarded by the Australia Council as a matter for regret, particularly in view of the important role played by the Company in organising major local and international exhibitions. Council funding for the AGDC through the Visual Arts Board has been on the basis of annual grants towards exhibition programs and operating costs of the AGDC. The Australia Council has no legal responsibility for debts incurred by the AGDC which is an independent, incorporated company.

It is not possible at present to say definitely what will happen to the exhibitions which are currently touring under AGDC auspices. It is expected that individual galleries or other suitable bodies will assume responsibility for individual exhibitions such as 'Aboriginal Australia', so that tours within Australia can be completed. Some exhibitions which are only in the planning stages, and the overseas tour by 'Aboriginal Australia' may be cancelled, but current indications are that of approximately 20 scheduled exhibitions, only a few may be affected in this way. The Australia Council will examine ways of helping the regional galleries overcome the problems which may occur if the AGDC goes into liquidation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 20 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the policy of Trans Australia Airlines Limited and Ansett concerning the cancellation of flights due to low demand.
(2) Does this sometimes result in passengers who have booked flights being refused travel on a flight on which they have booked.
(3) What are the details of: (a) flights cancelled; (b) numbers of people inconvenienced; and (c) money thus saved by TAA and Ansett, in 1979-80 and this year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Both TAA and Ansett schedule their aircraft to achieve an economic passenger load factor. Timetables are also designed to supply a level of capacity proportionate to average expected traffic demand. However, due to unpredictable fluctuations in demand, cancellation of some lightly loaded schedule services occurs on occasions when demand is well below the level required to return a reasonable load factor. Flight cancellations of this nature are rarely made over routes or to isolated areas where suitable alternative travel arrangements cannot be made for passengers affected. Such cancellations are intended to minimise costs and contain pressures for increased air fares.

(2) Flights cancelled as a result of low demand are more often than not cancelled well before the day of operations when advanced passenger bookings are minimal. Passengers holding bookings at the time of cancellation are offered alternative travel on other services or if preferred, another carrier who may have a more conveniently timed flight.

(3) There are no separate records kept of flights cancelled as a result of a low traffic demand, nor the number of people inconvenienced or money theoretically saved by the airlines for 1979-80 and 1980-81. It should be realised that all cancellations take place against a background where scheduling is prepared some months in advance, and as a result, some cancellations will always occur. However, TAA advise that in weeks unaffected by industrial problems in the past financial year, more than 97% of total timetabled flights operated as scheduled.

I have been most concerned at cancellations occuring at short notice on some routes and the inconvenience caused to intending travellers. I have therefore asked the airlines to review their scheduling against passenger traffic experience in order to reduce the necessity to cancel flights on any route.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Australian National University have an ethics committee or equivalent to control experimentation involving human subjects or the use of tissue or organs obtained from human subjects.
(2) When was that committee established, what were and are its guidelines, who established those guidelines, when were the guidelines last reviewed, who are the current members of that committee.

(3) When did that committee consider and agree to the work of Dr K. J. Lafferty of the John Curtin School of Medical Research which involves, or is to involve, the use of tissue obtained from human subjects.

(4) From what sources is it intended that Dr Lafferty will obtain the human foetuses that he intends to use in his work? What private and/or public institutions have been contacted, or are intended to be contacted, to provide this human foetal material.
(5) What are the sources of grants, bequests, etc. that are used to support the work of Dr Lafferty that may involve the use of human tissue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Registrar of the Australian National University has advised me as follows:
(1) The John Curtin School of Medical Research (JCSMR) of the Australian National University has a Clinical Research Committee, which is a Committee of the JCSMR Faculty Board.
(2) The JCSMR Clinical Research Committee was established by JCSMR Faculty Board on 9 February 1968. The guidelines set by the Faculty Board were:

(i) to consider the Helsinki and National Health and Medical Research Council statements on human experimentation and any other relevant publications, to determine their application to the work of the JCSMR, and to ensure that the Helsinki and NH&MRC statements and any others the Standing Committee considers necessary are brought to the attention of investigators engaged in work involving human beings.

(ii) To be informed on the general outline of proposed investigations, on the qualifications of the investigators, on the facilities provided for the conduct of the work, the steps taken to safeguard the rights and welfare of subjects and any contentious matter.
(iii) To discuss specific points. when considered advisable, with the department and investigators concerned, and to offer advice.
(iv) To report whatever it thinks is advisable to the Faculty Board.

The current duty of the Committee is to advise the Faculty Board on any matters relating to experimental investigation involving human subjects and to exercise a general oversight of such investigations by the members of the JCSMR.
These duties were last reviewed and reaffirmed by Faculty Board on 8 September 1980.
The present members of the JCSMR Clinical Research Committee are:
Dr A. F. Knyvett (Chief Medical Administrator, Royal Canberra Hospital or his deputy)

(3) The John Curtin School of Medical Research Clinical Research Committee considered the work of Dr K. J. Lafferty on transplantation of human foetal pancreatic tissue at a meeting held on 16 September 1981. The Committee has not yet given its approval to this protocol.

(4) Dr Lafferty does not use whole human foetuses for his work. Dr Lafferty hopes to be able to obtain some foetal pancreatic islet tissue from The Royal Women's Hospital, Carlton, Victoria. He has contacted the Royal Women's Hospital about the matter.
(5) The sources of grants for Dr Lafferty's work are as follows:
(i) Kroc Foundation grant (title: Human islet transplantation).
(ii) A grant under the University's internal scheme for grants for 'New Initiatives' in research. Title: 'Clinical Transplantation'.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many illiterate or functionally illiterate Australians are there in our society today.
(2) Does Australia have a literacy program capable of-
(a) determining the number of illiterate adults;
(b) devising programs to contact these adults and to secure their confidence;
(c) determining the criteria for the selection of adult literacy teachers and co-ordinators;
(d) researching the effectiveness of a variety of teaching methods;
(e) training the selected teachers and co-ordinators; and
(f) evaluating programs in operation, including a follow-up of both successful and 'drop-out' students.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The report of an Interdepartmental Working Group on Adult Literacy and Numeracy, made public in November 1979, indicated that significant numbers of adults and children have not mastered basic literacy skills at appropriate levels. However, there were insufficient data to establish the number of illiterate or functionally illiterate Australians.

(2a) The report noted that assessment of the literacy level of a population is very difficult, particularly if the concept of 'functional literacy' is accepted, because measurement of skills which are ranged along a continuum is required. The difficulties are such that it is unlikely there will be a method which can be applied to assess satisfactorily the functional literacy 'rate' of whole populations.

(2b-f) I would like to emphasise that the primary responsibility for adult education rests with the States through programs provided by technical and further education institutions. The Commonwealth involvement in this area has been limited to the provision of grants to the States to improve the quality and effectiveness of technical and further education. Funds are available to State TAFE authorities under the Particular Purpose Recurrent Grants Program. States may request funds for 22 categories of particular purpose, one of which is:
'the provision of adult literacy, remedial and special programs especially for the intellectually, educationally and physically handicapped and the unemployed.'

Among other things funds have been used for the training of tutors, the development of study modules, the establishment of community-based schemes, the operation of a summer school for students with reading problems and the evaluation of existing literacy programs.

A component of the Commonwealth's recurrent grants program of assistance to the States is its support for programs of non-government adult education. This program allows access to adult education for groups whose needs are not adequately met by the formal system. An important priority of the States in this program has been adult literacy.
Grants have been used by a variety of organisations, including national bodies, affiliates of local government and church groups, and smaller community groups.

Grants have also been made available under the TAFE Research and Investigation program. Since the program commenced in 1974-75 five projects have concentrated specifically on adult literacy, particularly in the areas of evaluating the effectiveness of programs and training teachers.

Commonwealth Departments and agencies consulted by the Department of Education have shown that there is a marked awareness of and concern for problems of adult literacy and where feasible action is being undertaken by Departments and agencies to adapt their services in appropriate ways to meet the needs of persons whose literacy level falls beneath that of functional literacy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 14 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Foreign Investment Review Board investigated any applications submitted by Minatome Pty Ltd to mine molybdenum at the Bencad Lomond site with less than the Australian equity required for a company to mine uranium.
(2) If the application is submitted to mine both molybdenum and uranium will the Australian equity requirements for the company be reduced.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is not generally the practice to disclose whether or not specific proposals have been submitted to the Foreign Investment Review Board because foreign investment proposals are, of course, dealt with in confidence. However, Minatome Australia Pty Ltd has indicated it has no objections to it being made known that no application has yet been made to the Foreign Investment Review Board for approval of the Ben Lomond project in Queensland. The company has, however, had various discussions with the Board on its continuing efforts to introduce Australian equity into the project. An application by Minatome to proceed with Ben Lomond is unlikely to be submitted to the Foreign Investment Review Board until late next year.

(2) A proposal to develop the deposit would be subject to the Government's foreign investment policy. As a general rule, the Government expects new projects for the mining and production of uranium to have 75 per cent Australian equity and to be Australian controlled. In cases where it is demonstrated that 75 per cent Australian equity is clearly unobtainable, alternative proposals will be considered, provided there would be significant economic benefits and at least 50 per cent Australian equity, and provided the Australian participants had the major role in determining the policy of the project.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Peko Wallsend and Western Mining Corporation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did a study (Technical Paper No. 22) by Mr Peter Davies for the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System (the Campbell Inquiry) show that 87.3 per cent of nominee shares in Peko Wallsend and 74 per cent of nominee shares in Western Mining were held on behalf of foreign residents.
(2) Did the Treasurer cite this study in a reply to question on notice no. 2022 (House of Representatives Hansard, 13 October 1981, pp. 1929-30).
(3) Do the figures in the study show that Australian equity in the Ranger uranium project is 68.54 per cent and not 75 per cent, and in the Roxby Downs project 40.1 per cent and not 51 per cent.
(4) Has the Treasurer stated that the Government has the power to ascertain beneficial ownership of nominee shareholdings; if so, has the Treasurer made such investigations.
(5) Will the Foreign Investment Review Board be instructed to remedy the satuation and restore Australian equity.
(6) Will the Board also be instructed to examine other proposals and ascertain if the Australian equity in those is similarly overstated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The study by Mr Peter Davies for the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System showed that 87.3 per cent of bank nominee shares in Peko Wallsend and 74 per cent of bank nominee shares in Western Mining Corporation were held on behalf of foreign residents.

(3) The study by Mr Davies covered only those foreign portfolio shareholdings that were held through bank nominees, and it is not, therefore, possible to derive the actual levels of Australian equity in the Ranger and Roxby Downs projects solely by reference to the results of the study. The information that is available, however, suggests that the actual levels of Australian equity in these projects are of the orders quoted by the honourable senator.

(4) and (6) Under the Foreign Takeovers Act and the foreign investment policy, approval is not required for investments of a purely portfolio nature. For the purposes of determining the standing of a project under the Australian equity participation guidelines, the effect of foreign portfolio shareholdings in the participants in the project on the level of Australian equity is normally disregarded, except in the case of uranium projects (where individual holdings of less than 10 per cent are disregarded in the absence of special circumstances), and in cases where the aggregate foreign portfolio shareholdings in a participant amounts to 40 per cent or more. The treatment accorded to foreign portfolio equity investment under the foreign investment policy is in recognition of the fact that, by comparison with foreign direct equity investment, it provides Australia with access to overseas funds on a basis that does not involve foreign control. Under Section 36 of the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975, the Treasurer may require information where 'he has reason to believe that a person is capable of giving information or producing documents relating to matters that are relevant to the exercise by the Treasurer of his powers under this Act'. This power may be used in relation to foreign investment proposals that are subject to the Act. In other cases, there is reliance upon the co-operation of the parties to the proposal in seeking any required information. Information as to the beneficial ownership of nominee shareholdings is sought in those cases where such information is of potential significance for the purposes of the consideration of a foreign investment proposal against the requirements of the Government's foreign investment policy, and careful consideration is given by the Government to those cases where the size of foreign portfolio shareholdings in a participant in a proposal would have implications for the policy's objectives regarding Australian equity participation.

The Government is, of course, concerned to ensure that Australians should have opportunities to participate as fully and effectively as practicable in the ownership and control of the country's natural resources and industries, and considers that the present features of the foreign investment policy are being effective in achieving this objective. These features include the Australian equity participation guidelines, which provide opportunities for Australian ownership and control of natural resource projects, and the naturalisation provisions, which provide an incentive for companies that are predominantly foreign-owned to introduce higher Australian ownership and Australian control.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why is a grant of $1.02m to be paid to the Northern Territory in lieu of uranium royalties for the period 1981-82.
(2) Does the Commonwealth own the uranium mining interests in the Northern Territory or is the Government subsidising the export of uranium.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under the Memorandum of Understanding between the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory, special arrangements were entered into in relation to revenues from uranium production in the Northern Territory. Unlike other minerals, which have been vested in the Crown in right of the Northern Territory, ownership of uranium and other substances prescribed under the Atomic Energy Act continues to be vested in the Crown in right of the Commonwealth. However, so as not to put the Northern Territory in a disadvantaged position as a result of this, the Commonwealth makes an additional annual grant to the Northern Territory of an amount in lieu of uranium royalties at a rate of 1.25 per cent of the value of production less certain allowable deductions. These arrangements were agreed to on the basis that payment of the grant would be conditional on the Northern Territory ensuring that the terms of stamp duties and similar charges applying to mining agreements or to financial transactions in respect of such agreements are in line with those that apply in the States. The $1.02m grant referred to by the honourable senator is the estimated 1981-82 payment under these arrangements.
(2) No, the Commonwealth neither owns any uranium mining interests in the Northern Territory nor is it subsidising the export of uranium.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Education, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the federal funding been withdrawn, or will it be withdrawn from the Curriculum Development Centre; if so, what will happen to various development projects of national concern and importance if such projects are not funded by the States.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Review of Commonwealth Functions recommended that the Curriculum Development Centre be maintained as a co-operative Commonwealth/State project if the States were willing to share 50 per cent of its cost, the Commonwealth providing the remaining 50 per cent. The States have since indicated that they are not prepared to enter into this co-operative arrangement. The Commonwealth will still maintain a curriculum development capacity within the education portfolio, but it will only undertake curriculum development in concert with the States-that is when the States share in the costs of the development work-or when the Commonwealth declares that a particular development ought to be undertaken in the national interest.

The Government decided in June that $2.04m would be provided for CDC activities in this financial year. The Commonwealth is still to decide which projects it will continue to fund as projects of particular national significance. It will be prepared to join in funding other projects sponsored by the Australian Education Council.

(a) What is the direction of causation;
(b) the nature of the causal mechanisms involved;
(c) the quantitative relationships;
(d) the statistical evidence; and
(e) what level of real wages would be associated with full employment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) (a) and (b) In this and in a number of similar questions, the honourable senator has requested information on the nature of advice that I have received in relation to passages contained in my Budget Speech presented on 18 August 1981. I can assure the honourable senator that I have received advice, from a number of sources and in a number of ways, in respect of each of the matters raised. It is, however, long-standing practice that such advice is a matter of confidence between a Minister and his advisers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Treasurer state on page 1 of the 1981-82 Budget Speech that the 'fight against inflation' was 'a means of achieving greater investment, more jobs and higher living standards for all Australians'.

(2) Has the Treasurer received advice to the effect that high inflation is associated with high unemployment; if so, (a) what is the nature of that advice; (b) what is the direction of causation, the mechanisms involved; and (c) what is the statistical evidence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) In this and in a number of similar questions, the honourable senator has requested information on the nature of advice that I have received in relation to passages contained in my Budget Speech presented on 18 August 1981. I can assure the honourable senator that I have received advice, from a number of sources and in a number of ways, in respect of each of the matters raised. It is, however, long-standing practice that such advice is a matter of confidence between a Minister and his advisers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there an estimate in the 1981-82 Budget Papers that Budget measures will directly add 1.5 percentage points to the consumer price index.
(2) Did the 1981-82 Budget Paper No. 1 suggest, on page 60, that 'the sharply reduced Budget deficit' will indirectly help contain inflationary pressures.
(3) Are the measures referred to in (1) expected to reduce the deficit and indirectly the inflation rate.

(4) Has the Treasurer received advice relating to the quantitative relation between the direct effects (if any) in (1) and the indirect effects (if any) in (3); if so, what is the nature of that advice and what is the statistical evidence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1981-82 Budget Papers include an estimate that the indirect tax increases announced in the Budget could add about three-quarters of a percentage point to the overall increase in the consumer price index in 1981-82. The changed arrangements for health care, announced prior to bringing down the 1981-82 Budget, are estimated to add another three-quarters of a percentage point to the overall increase in the consumer price index this year.
(3) Yes; any immediate CPI effects of these measures will be offset by the benefits in terms of longer run control of inflation through reductions in the size of the Budget deficit.

(4) In this and in a number of similar questions, the honourable senator has requested information on the nature of advice that I have received in relation to the Budget presented on 18 August 1981. I can assure the honourable senator that I have received advice, from a number of sources and in a number of ways, in respect of each of the matters raised. It is, however, long-standing practice that such advice is a matter of confidence between a Minister and his advisers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 August 1981 (Hansard, page 379) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, a question without notice concerning the unauthorised release of waters at Nabarlek on 7 March 1981. In particular, Senator Mulvihill sought information on whether there have been any other unauthorised releases of water.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Infringements of environmental requirements for uranium mining in the Northern Territory are reported in the annual reports of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region. The honourable senator's attention is drawn to Appendix 8 of the 1978-79 annual report, Appendix 7 of the 1979-80 Report and Appendix 8 of the 1980-81 annual report.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1981 (Hansard, page 636) Senator Siddons asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question without notice concerning the financing of colleges of advanced education.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
It has been announced that of the 30 colleges of advanced education identified for rationalisation, acceptable arrangements have been received for all but seven.
The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1981, gives the Minister some flexibility for funding in 1982 if final agreement has not been reached by the end of 1981.
Further consultations are continuing with New South Wales and Victoria on the remaining seven institutions listed for amalgamation.

The Minister has asked the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for advice on the grants that should be provided for recurrent purposes for 1982 for the colleges involved. The individual grants will be recommended by the Commission after it has had an opportunity to consult with the State higher education coordinating authorities. The grants for 1982 for these colleges will be provided on the clear understanding that consolidation arrangements will be actively pursued during that year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October 1981, (Hansard, page 1092) Senator Foreman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources to the latest survey of the economy undertaken by the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research economists which suggests that an increasing proportion of retail sales is drawing on imports. Will the Minister indicate specifically how much of private final demand is being met from imports rather than from current domestic production? Is the Minister aware that if this trend continues it will prohibit growth of Australian manufacturing industries and prevent thousands of Australians from obtaining jobs? Is the Government deliberately turning a blind eye to this trend in order to satisfy the whims of the farmers, who desperately want to see a devaluation of the Australian dollar?
The Minister for Trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

It is not possible to indicate precisely the extent to which private final demand is being serviced through imports rather than through current domestic production. There is a measure, however, which is commonly used to estimate the impact of imports on the domestic economy. This measure shows the ratio of imports of goods and services to gross national expenditure (which is defined as the total expenditure, both public and private, on final goods and services bought by Australian residents within a given period). In 1980-81 imports of goods and services accounted for 18.7 per cent of gross national expenditure compared with the long term average share of 16.5 per cent.

The honourable senator may be interested to know that the increase in the importance of imports in 1980-81 was largely due to a sharp rise in imports of capital equipment. In 1980-81, imports of capital equipment (excluding transport equipment) rose by 29.8 per cent compared with an increase in total imports of 16.9 per cent and a rise in imports of consumer goods (including imports of passenger motor vehicles and food and beverages) of only 8.4 per cent.

It was entirely appropriate that imports grew strongly in 1980-81 at a time when domestic demand also grew strongly and when, in particular, business fixed investment rose by 21.4 per cent in real terms. Without imports supplementing domestic supplies, the economy could have been subject to severe excess demand pressures with severe inflationary consequences.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1540) Senator Lewis asked me a question without notice concerning a proposed synthetic fuel plant in Sweden. I am pleased to be able to provide the following additional information:

ANSWER.PARA: The Swedish proposal is for a synthetic fuel plant to be constructed at Nynashamn, 50 kilometres south east of Stockholm by Nynas Petroleum AB and N. Storstock Holms Energie AB. The plant will consume 1.7 million tonnes coal per annum to produce 700 000 tonnes methanol per annum and low grade waste heat will be used to produce hot water for district heating.

A feasibility study for the plant has been completed. It is expected that process design will start in 1982 with construction in 1984 and operation in 1988. The project is however subject to Government approval and financial assistance, and environmental clearance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October, (Hansard, page 1714) Senator Hill asked me a question without notice concerning methanol. I am pleased to be able to provide the following additional information:

ANSWER.PARA: The study on market and production aspects of the use of methanol as a gasoline extender in Australia was carried out by Davy McKee Pacific Pty Ltd, and included a preliminary consideration of a number of sites and raw material sources for methanol production. The summary report only referred to the three sites which were investigated in detail. These are only national sites which were selected for the purpose of calculating indicative production costs. Further information on this aspect of the study can be obtained from the detailed report by Davy McKee Pacific Pty Ltd; this report can be obtained through the Parliamentary Library or the library in my Department.

Further consideration of the use of methanol-gasoline blends must await the results of the associated studies on blending and distribution, use in gasoline powered engines, administrative and policy considerations.

Of course, before commencing the commercial production of methanol for this purpose, it would be up to the private sector to undertake a detailed investigation of all the alternative sites and feedstocks, including any necessary pilot plant testing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 November 1981 (Hansard, pages 2011-2012) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question, without notice, concerning Deakin University Engineering School.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Government's decision to phase out the engineering school at Deakin Univeristy with no new students to be admitted after 1981 is based on the view expressed by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission in its Volume I Report for 1982-84 Triennium, that engineering courses in Victoria should be rationalised.

I am aware that a proposal has been put to the Commission which involves Swinburne College of Advanced Education providing part of its engineering course at the Deakin Univeristy campus. It is necessary for the Commission to consider this proposal in the context of the future total provisions of engineering education in Victoria and the distribution of State unallocated funds. The Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission is awaiting advice from the State co-ordinating authority.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2010) Senator Siddons asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question, without notice, concerning proposed amalgamations of tertiary institutions.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The overall levels of funding for tertiary institutions for 1982-84 in the guidelines announced by the Minister for Education on 4 June 1981 were based on a Budget policy of maximum expenditure restraint for tertiary education, as well as the Government's concern at the proliferation of institutions, and its intention that the consolidation of institutions should result in genuine amalgamations and real saving of resources. The Government has since approved the distribution of these funds as recommended by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, on the basis of a reallocation of effort by institutions and taking account of the Government's consolidation measures. There will be no overall additional costs to the tertiary education system as a result of these decisions. Payments to staff of individual institutions will be the responsibility of the institutions which are the employing authorities, and the States.

(2) When the Government announced its decision in the context of the Review of Commonwealth Functions to rationalise 30 colleges of advanced education it took account of the advice of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission but decided to accelerate the process and wished to reach agreement with each State concerning rationalisation matters by the end of 1981. Further consultations are continuing with New South Wales and Victoria on the remaining institutions listed for amalgamation.
The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) legislation gives the Minister some flexibility for funding in 1982 if final agreement has not been reached by the end of 1981.

The Minister has asked the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for advice on the grants that should be provided for recurrent purposes for the colleges involved. The individual grants will be recommended by the Commission after it has had an opportunity to consult with the State higher education co-ordinating authorities. The grants for 1982 for these colleges will be provided on the clear understanding that consolidation arrangements will be actively pursued during that year.

(3) A major objective of the policy of consolidating single purpose teacher education institutions into larger more broadly based institutions is to increase the particular opportunities available to students. The higher education institutions will be better able to respond to changing needs and to widen access to a greater range of more relevant courses.

(4) There have been extensive consultations between the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and the State Co-ordinating Authorities concerned. The Commonwealth's policy has been that it was a matter for the States to develop particular arrangements in relation to individual institutions so as to achieve a more efficient use of available resources. Agreements between the Commonwealth and the States on satisfactory proposals have now been reached on all but seven of the original 30 institutions listed for amalgamation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) As a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions in what ways will any departments or instrumentalities under the Minister contract more work out to the private sector.
(2) Is it estimated that this measure will save those departments or instrumentalities money; if so how much is it estimated that it will save.
(3) In what way will those savings break down into components savings.

(4) Can the Minister give an assurance that the services to be contracted out to the private sector will not contribute to inflation or the Federal deficit by costing the government more than would the same services provided from within the public services by salaried officers.
(5) If the Minister cannot give that assurance why have these moves been made without more comprehensive investigation and preparation.
(6) What investigations were made to ensure that the proposed action is economically sound.

(7) In the course of investigations that were made did the Minister receive any advice that in fact the proposed measures would cost the government more money than they would save and if so what are the details.
(8) Has the Minister received any advice since the measures have been proposed that they would cost the government more money than they will save and if so what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In addition to the specific decisions announced by the Prime Minister, the scope for contracting other departmental functions to the private sector is being examined.

(2) to (8) These matters are still being studied. Before decisions are taken on contracting services to the private sector, consideration will be given to the sorts of issues and concerns referred to by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs in his answer to Question No. 765 (see Senate Hansard of 20 August 1981, page 239) on behalf of the Minister for the Capital Territory.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, upon notice, on 25 August, 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: By whose authority, and why, was the 'reference withheld' in Note 56 to page 477 of the book by Ian Downs entitled The Australian Trusteeship: Papua New Guinea 1945-75 (Australian Government Publishing Service, Canberra, 1980).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: It is this Government's policy, and it was also the previous Government's policy, that documents less than thirty years old are not available for public scrutiny. This applies as well to Cabinet documents. In accordance with this policy, the request to delete references to Cabinet documents in Mr Downs' book was made by the Secretary to Cabinet.
This request was made some time ago-in 1978. The matter has not been raised with the Secretary to Cabinet since then.
It is unlikely that a need will be seen in future to delete references to Cabinet documents in official histories such as Mr Downs' work on The Australian Trusteeship: Papua New Guinea 1945-75.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs: Revenue

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister's Department aware of any information, disclosed in submissions to it, advice available to it or public documents such as Auditor-General's Reports, which suggest that the Department and instrumentalities under the Minister's responsibility are forgoing revenue because of insufficient staff.
(2) How much revenue is alleged to have been forgone.
(3) Approximately how much revenue does the Department estimate may have been forgone.
(4) When did the information or items of information become available to the Minister's Department.
(5) What has been done to improve the situation.
(6) What are the details of any staff rearrangements that have been made as a result of action in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Minister for Defence aware of difficulties faced by servicemen in Malaysia in having Australian cheques credited to their bank accounts; if so, will the Minister take appropriate action to ensure that Australian servicemen in Malaysia are no longer disadvantaged when receiving their pay.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Australian cheques are not involved in transactions concerning pay for servicemen in Malaysia. The mode of payment of salary and allowances is either by cash, in the form of Malaysian currency at a fortnightly pay parade, or by direct credit to a bank account nominated by the serviceman. Advice from service authorities both in Malaysia and Australia is that they are not aware of any instances of difficulties being experienced by servicemen in having Australian cheques credited to bank accounts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister rep- resenting the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What action has the Industrial Relations Bureau taken to investigate allegations by Mrs Maria Aganosi as reported in the Australian Financial Review on Friday, 25 September 1981, page 40, claaming that a clothing factory at Parramatta, New South Wales, owes her five weeks' pay for a sewing contract and refuses to pay.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Director of the Industrial Relations Bureau has advised that following publication of the report referred to by the honourable senator, the Bureau has made inquiries concerning the particular case of Mrs Maria Aganosi.

Those inquiries I am informed failed to identify the person named as being the holder of a current outdoor worker's permit issued in accordance with the provisions of the Clothing Trades Award 1964. The Director has further advised that no complaint has been made by a person of that name to the Bureau.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What entitlements do members of the staffs of parliamentarians whose salaries are paid by private sources have regarding (a) telephone usage, (b) use of Commonwealth cars, (c) use of the Parliamentary Library, and (d) use of non-members bar and other facilities such as the tennis courts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is set out below. As only some of the specified facilities are administered by my Department, information concerning the use of the facilities of Parliament House by staff of senators and members has been provided by the parliamentary departments.
(a) Electorate office telephones are provided for the use of the senator or member and those members of staff appointed in accordance with the Remuneration Tribunal's Determinations.

In Parliament House telephones are provided in senators' and members' rooms for their use and the use of their personal staff. No account is made of the source of salary of personal staff working for senators and members in their use of these telephones.
(b) There is no entitlement for this category of staff to use Commonwealth cars.
(c) Senators' and members' personal staff have access to all reference and research services when engaged on official duties. Books may be borrowed in the senator's or member's name only.

Because of the limited seating available personal staff may use only the carrels in the Newspaper Reading Room and the main Reading Room. Use of the Library for staff members' personal interests is not permitted. These arrangements apply irrespective of an employee's source of salary.

(d) The Presiding Officers have approved the use by persons employed in Parliament House of the non-members' bar and the staff cafeteria, and also restricted use of certain sporting facilities, including the tennis courts. This applies irrespective of an employee's source of salary.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Adult Migrant Education Centre in Caltex House, Sydney, which offers 21 classes on a full time and part time basis, have a lengthy waiting list for those classes and are migrants trying to enrol now being told they will have to wait until 'some time in 1982'.

(2) Does the creation of a cohesive multicultural society, and the ability of migrants to both contribute their skills and participate fully in Australian society, depend on adequate English classes for those Migrants.
(3) Does the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs consider that a 10-week course is sufficient for a migrant to learn English.

(4) Are there many teachers who would like to make a career in the Adult Migrant Education Service; if so, will the Minister fund the Service on the same basis as other areas of education, with the aim of retaining those dedicated teachers who at present are leaving the service only because of uncertainty of employment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Courses are grouped and start at the same time. It may be up to 12 weeks before the next group of courses commence. Persons who apply after the commencement of a group of courses have to wait until the next group of courses starts. Those persons who apply now (November 1981) will have to wait until early 1982 to commence a course.

Those persons attending courses at the Migrant Education centre at Caltex House or attending courses at other migrant education centres in Sydney are drawn from the total pool of applicants for courses at community migrant education centres in Sydney. Following consultations between the New South Wales Adult Migrant Education Service and my Department, I am advised that at the end of October 1981 there were 437 applicants for full time on-arrival courses at community centres, 472 applicants for full time courses in the ongoing phase of the program and 88 for part time courses in that phase. Those applicants are expected to be offered places in courses commenced early in 1982.
About 17,500 persons attend courses and other learning arrangements in the Adult Migrant Education Program at any one time in New South Wales. The number waiting should also be seen in that context.

(2) Through its complete acceptance and implementation of the recommendations of the Review of Post-Arrival Programs and Services for Migrants (the Galbally Report), the Government has clearly demonstrated its recognition of the role which the acquisition of English language proficiency plays in enabling migrants to have an opportunity to fully participate in and contribute to Australian society.

(3) A migrant is not limited to a 10 week course. The Adult Migrant Education Program provides an initial English language course of up to 10 weeks in length for new arrivals with no or limited fluency in English. That program provides further English language learning opportunities through a range of full and part time courses and other learning arrangements in the ongoing phase of the Adult Migrant Education Program. Nationally during 1981-82 over 16,000 people are expected to attend on-arrival English courses, and in addition people will enrol in more than 100,000 places in the on going phase of the Program.

(4) Teachers in the State Adult Migrant Education Services are employed by State authorities. A number of the teachers in those services have worked in them for some years. There does not seem to be any undue or abnormal wastage or turnover of staff. The Adult Migrant Education Program is a special program of limited size and is thus different to other broader areas of education. The Adult Migrant Education Program must also be staffed and organised in a way which allows the services within the program to be provided to meet the changing needs arising from variations in migrant intake and location. For that reason the most appropriate arrangements would seem to be a mix of full time and part time staff. Abut 120 full time permanent teachers are employed on the staff of the New South Wales AMES. A joint working party has been set up to examine staffing arrangements in that Service.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Passport Office operating efficiently; if so, can the Minister for Foreign Affairs explain why a Canadian businessman with substantial assets in this country and continually resident in Australia for 29 years should be informed, on applying for an Australian passport, that he must wait a further eight months for naturalisation procedures to take effect and an additional six to eight weeks for a passport to be issued.
(2) Is the Canadian Government able to issue passports in two to two-and-a-half weeks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Foreign Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) All Passport Offices in Australia are operating efficiently. The time involved in the issue of a passport varies from three to 10 working days for an application lodged in person and from three to 15 working days for a correctly completed and documented application lodged by mail.
It would be inappropriate for me to comment on the time involved in acquisition of Australian citizenship which is the responsibility of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.
(2) I am not aware of Canadian practice in this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 21 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Veterans' Affairs state, in response to Question No. 1195 (Senate Hansard, 15 October 1981, page 1350): 'The Commonwealth Government has no control over the War Veterans' Home in Caboolture'.

(2) Does not the Minister, nevertheless, have a responsibility for the welfare of Australian war veterans in circumstances of need; if so, will the Minister investigate the conditions under which veterans at the Caboolture home are allegedly living.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) While the Commonwealth Government has no control over the War Veterans' Home at Caboolture, in view of the honourable senator's concern, arrangements were made for the Department's Director (Social Work/Welfare Services) in Queensland to visit Caboolture. He spent the day there on 9 November 1981 and saw 26 of the 28 Repatriation patients in the nursing home and 53 of the 88 veteran pensioners in the hostel section. All the patients in the nursing home are classified as requiring extensive care. Of those able to carry out a conversation, all were happy with their care. In the hostel section an overwhelming number of veterans said they were happy with the accommodation, meals and treatment by staff.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 22 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government of Francois Mitterrand announced that it intends to nationalise eleven French companies, the fourth of which is Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann.
(2) Does this company own 50 per cent of Minatome Australia Pty Ltd, and is Minatome preparing to mine uranium at Ben Lomond in North Queensland for export to France.
(3) Is the Minister for National Development and Energy concerned that uranium products from Australia may come into the possession of a foreign, socialist, nuclear power.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The French Council of Ministers announced the proposed nationalisation of Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann on 23 September 1981.

(2) Minatome Australia Pty Ltd is a wholly owned subsidiary of Minatome SA of France which is in turn owned by Pechiney Ugine Kuhlmann (PUK) 50 per cent and Compagnie Francaise des Petroles (TOTAL) 50 per cent. Minatome's Ben Lomond project has not yet received development approval from the Commonwealth Government. An environmental impact statement is in preparation and is due for completion early in 1982.

(3) Minatome has been advised that it will be required to satisfy Australia's foreign investment guidelines by making provision for 75 per cent Australian equity in Ben Lomond and Australian control. Moreover, as a signatory to the Australia/Euratom Nuclear Safeguards Agreement, and the Australia/France Nuclear Transfers Agreement, France is required to meet the stringent nuclear safeguards requirements upon which Australia's uranium export policy is based.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Department of Health aware of any studies in Australia on the effect, if any, of long and frequent flights at high altitude on human health; if so, what are the details.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There are no Australian studies that determine whether health effects are related to any particular hazard of exposure to long and frequent flights at high altitude. Detailed and repeated examination of the health of commercial pilots and Air Force personnel has not indicated a prevalence of any specific health hazard effect which would indicate the need for such a study.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has an agreement been reached between New Zealand and the Australian Governments over a joint approach to the Federal Republic of Germany for the compensation of servicemen illegally held in concentration camps during the Second World War; if so:
(a) was the approach ever made; and
(b) what was the response from the Federal Republic of Germany; and
(c) what stage have negotiations reached.
(2) Were British victims of this action, which contravenes international law, compensated in the 1960's.
(3) Are Australian servicemen who were imprisoned in German concentration camps still waiting to hear what, if any, progress the Australian Government has made on their behalf.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (b) and (c) Negotiations have progressed to the stage where the authorities in the Federal Republic of Germany have suggested that some specific cases could now be examined with a view to determining whether or not the claimants would be likely to succeed with claims for compensation under the German Federal Compensation or Indemnification Law (Bundersentschadigungsgesetz (BEG) ), as amended.

(2) An agreement between the Federal Republic of Germany and the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland concerning Compensation for United Kingdom Nationals who were Victims of National-Socialist Measures of Persecution was signed on 9 June 1964. The distribution of funds provided under the Agreement was left to the discretion of the British Government.

(3) Australian servicemen are being informed of the response referred to in (1) (b) and (c) and are being asked for the documentation required by the authorities in the Federal Republic of Germany so that specific cases can be examined.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the Royal Australian Navy's River Class Destroyer Escorts be retired.
(2) How does the Navy intend to provide fire support for the Army when these vessels are replaced by the FFG-7 class and the follow-on destroyers.
(3) What armament options are being considered for the follow-on destroyers.
(4) Is a vertical launch system being considered to replace the Mark 13 missile launcher.
(5) Is an FMC 155 mm naval gun being considered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Under present planning the Royal Australian Navy's River Class Destroyer Escorts will be paid off between the late 1980s and the mid to late 1990s.

(2), (3) and (5) The Government intends that the initial two follow-on destroyers should be of the same configuration as the general purpose escort FFG 04 (HMAS Darwin), which includes capabilities for anti-aircraft and anti-shipping warfare, and for surveillance and reconnaissance. They will be fitted with a self defence ASW capability and a 76 mm gun. A broad range of weapon and sensor options is under examination for subsequent follow-on destroyers. The RAN's three DDGs will retain naval gunfire support capabilities for the rest of their Service lives.
(4) No. The verical launch system at present under development in the US is not compatible with the RAN DDG and FFG class ships.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will there be any industrial offsets for Australian industry as a result of the purchase of 10 new P-3C Orion anti-submarine patrol aircraft; if so, what form will the offsets take; and if not, why not.
(2) Was there any Australian industrial participation in the manufacture of existing Australian Orions other than that associated with the installation of Barra sonobuoys and Mulloka equipment.
(3) How many Harpoon air to surface missiles have been purchased for the Australian Orion fleet.
(4) What advantages does the Canadian Aurora electronics package based upon that used in the S-3A Viking aircraft, have and will this package be used as a basis for equipping our new P-3C aircraft.
(5) Will the electronic system in Australia's new P-3C aircraft be based on the United States Navy P-3C Update III program, with the addition of the Barra sonobuoy system.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Government's policies relating to Australian industry participation (AIP) will apply to the purchase of 10 new P3C aircraft for the RAAF. The request for tender which will be released in the next few months will require Lockheed to accept a contractual obligation to place work, both project related and offset, with Australian industry to an amount no less than 30 per cent of the contract value. AIP will be sought in a number of areas, including the manufacture of components for the P3Cs and other aircraft projects, technology transfer and co-development and co-production programs.

(2) The continuing AIP program against existing P3Cs has been running for some five years, and has amounted to about $34m. Local P3C tasks, outside the installation of the Barra system, has amounted to about $10m; the balance being other aircraft related work (including for the Lockheed 1011 Tristar) and technology transfer.

(3) No Harpoon missiles are being purchased specifically for the Orion fleet. Missiles are being procured for a common RAN/RAAF pool for use by all platforms capable of firing the Harpoon. All operational missiles presently in country are configured for firing from P3C aircraft. The number of missiles available is classified information.

(4) The chief advantage of the Canadian Aurora system over that of the USN P3C Update II derives from its more advanced radar, which has superior detection and discrimination capacity. The practicalities of fitting this radar to RAAF P3C are being investigated.

(5) The USN P3C Update III will not be available for foreign military sales; consequently, the new RAAF P3Cs will be based on the Update II. The AQS901 Barra Sonics System will be fitted to the RAAF P3C aircraft by Australian industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government considered the acquisition of a Light Armoured Vehicle for the Operational Deployment Force.
(2) What anti-tank weapons are available to this force.
(3) Is it intended to acquire modern anti-tank guided weapons for the ODF and the Army generally.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) No. The ODF is structured to provide the first land element of the Defence Force deployed in an emergency. It is for this reason that the ODF is air transportable and lightly equipped. It can, of course, be supplemented by other elements of the Defence Force, including armoured vehicles, should the circumstances warrant.

(2) The ODF is equipped with the M72 Light Anti-Tank Weapon and the Carl Gustav Medium Anti-Tank weapon. It can receive back-up from Cavalry Regiment elements equipped with the 106mm Recoil-less Rifle.
(3) Yes. My Department is presently examining a number of contending modern anti-armour guided weapons.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Army, Air Force and Naval Reserves

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the construction of new buildings at the Materials Research Laboratories at Maribyrnong to support advanced research and developments in laser technology give Australia the capacity to design, develop and produce guided air to ground munitions.
(2) Can the guidance systems of such weapons now be produced in Australia.
(3) Can the guidance systems of any precision guided munitions, including electro-optical, infra red homing, laser and radar homing missiles and bombs presently be produced in Australia.
(4) Has Australia acquired the technology to produce fuel air explosives.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Mark 10 depth charge mortar being retained on River Class destroyers after their half life modernisation; if not and the Mark 10 launcher is being discarded, will these ships be able to attack enemy submarines operating in less than 100 feet of water.

(2) Is the minimum operating depth of the Mark 44 and Mark 46 acoustic homing torpedoes 100 feet; if so, how can ships of the DDG and FFG classes attack enemy submarines lying in water less than 100 feet deep.
(3) How many square miles of Australia's territorial water is less than 100 feet deep on a mean average depth basis.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Mark 10 Mortar is being progressively removed from River Class destroyers during their half life modernisation. The last system will be withdrawn from service in 1984, having been replaced in each ship by Ship Launched Torpedo (SLT) tubes capable of launching Mark 44 or Mark 46 torpedoes. Ships of this class will continue to be able to detect submarines operating in less than 100 feet of water, and attacks could be conducted by directing aircraft to attack with depth charges, if the depth of water precluded attack by torpedoes.

(2) DDG and FFG class ships can detect submarines in less than 100 feet of water, and attacks could be conducted by co-operating aircraft with depth charges if the depth of water precluded attack by torpedoes.

(3) Approximately 175,000 square nautical miles of Australian territorial waters are comprised of water less than 100 feet deep. This represents approximately 20 per cent of total Australian territorial waters. However of this most is:
(b) off the North West Coast; and

in areas not navigable by submarines. Of the rest the 100 foot line is approximately one to two nautical miles from low water mark for most of the coast. It should be noted that dived operations for submarines inside waters less than 100 feet deep are extremely hazardous. Conventional submarines cannot remain submerged in water depths less then 50 feet, and nuclear submarines in depths less than 75 feet, due to their physical height from keel to fin top.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the modernisation of the DDG ships be undertaken in Australia or the United States and at what cost.
(2) Will the modernisation be similar to that undertaken by the United States Navy on its ships of this class.

(5) Will the MK 68 gunnery fire control system be replaced with the MK 86/GFCS.
(6) Will the SPG-60 and SPQ-9A radars be added to the existing suites.

(9) Will the Australian DDGs be equipped to fire Standard and Harpoon missiles.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the FA18 aircraft to be acquired by the Royal Australian Air Force from 1984 have an air refuelling capability.
(2) What is the combat radius of an FA18 carrying two Harpoon missiles, electronic counter-measures equipment and two light air-to-air missiles.
(3) Where does the RAAF intend to base the FA18 squadrons.
(4) Which existing RAAF airbases could aircraft of the FA18 type use at typical combat take off weights.
(5) Where will the M61A1 Vulcan rotary cannon for these aircraft be built.
(6) Where will the ammunition for this gun be made.

(7) How many replacement barrels or complete cannon will the RAAF require for these aircraft over the lifetime of the FA18 program, assuming the aircraft are not engaged in a major conflict during their service.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) Combat radius in the configuration specified would be dependent on the number of external fuel tanks carried and the mission profile (speeds and heights) flown. Exact combat radius data of the type requested bears both United States and Australian security classifications and is not available for public disclosure. Attention is drawn to the data provided to the Australian press by the Department of Defence on 20 October 1981. In these documents an FA18 strike radius 'in excess of 1000 km' was mentioned.
(3) Present basing plans are two squadrons and an operational conversion unit at RAAF Base Williamtown, New South Wales, and one squadron at RAAF Base Darwin, Northern Territory.

(4) FA18 type aircraft at typical combat take-off weights could use all existing RAAF airfields except Point Cook, Victoria, and Gin Gin, Western Australia (the latter is a satellite airfield for RAAF Base Pearce, Western Australia).
(5) The M61A1 gun will be manufactured in the US by General Electric Corporation, Burlington, Vermont.
(6) The type of 20mm ammunition for use with the FA18 aircraft is the subject of a technical evaluation currently being undertaken by the RAAF. The study is scheduled for completion by 1 July 1982.

Assuming favourable results from this study, a submission has been made for financial approval to establish a local capability for the manufacture of ammunition subject to completion of appropriate licencing arrangements.

(7) It is estimated that, over 20 years, each FA18 will require six replacement sets of barrels for its cannon; a total of 450 sets is required for the entire fleet, therefore. A set of barrels consist of six single barrels plus fittings. Unserviceable guns will be overhauled at a RAAF facility. Replacement of complete cannon assemblies is not envisaged.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

I wish to resume work 1,879 I wish to stay on strike 1,710
