QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 12 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the nature of the negotiations and consultations between the Department of Industrial Relations and State and Federal agencies referred to in the reply of the Minister for Industrial Relations to the question of the Honourable W. Hayden, M.P. (House of Representatives Question No. 982. See Hansard, page 2807, dated 29 October 1981).
(2) Which are the Federal and State agencies referred to.
(3) Why is the Minister for Industrial Relations no longer consulting with the International Labour Organisation.

(4) What are the remaining obstacles to the Australian Government's ratification of International Labour Organisation Convention 107 since Queensland withdrew its objection to the convention three and a half years ago.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As a Federal State, Australia is obliged under the ILO Constitution to consult with State authorities with a view to promoting co-ordinated action to give effect to the provisions of Conventions and Recommendations. To this end, there are on-going and ad hoc consultations between my Department and relevant State and Commonwealth Departments.
(2) In relation to Convention 107, State Labour Departments are consulted and the Commonwealth Department of Aboriginal Affairs.
(3) The inference drawn by the senator is not correct. Consultation with the ILO takes place when required.

(4) The Australian Government is the competent authority in Australia responsible for the formal ratification of International Labour Organisation Conventions. While agreement to the ratification of a particular Convention must be obtained from each State, it is the Australian Government, in the final result, which must be satisfied that the law and practice in all State jurisdictions as well as the Commonwealth jurisdiction are in compliance with the articles of particular ILO Conventions before proceeding to ratify formally those Conventions. In relation to ILO Convention No. 107, careful and detailed study is still being given to whether law and practice on all Australian jurisdictions do fully comply.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 12 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Repatriation Commission aware that the terms of reference of the epidemiological study are far more stringent than is required by the Repatriation Act, and that the study will by its scientific nature exclude many veterans who should receive the benefit of the doubt.
(2) Has the Commission been given a completion date for the study.
(3) Would it not be advisable to have a Judicial enquiry before deciding what scientific study should or should not be undertaken, or may even be necessary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The question recognizes that the nature of a scientific study differs from the determination of a repatriation claim, but implies that the Repatriation Commission is responsible for both.

The epidemiological studies relating to Vietnam veterans are initiatives of the Government aimed at obtaining scientific evidence about the health of Vietnam veterans and other matters. A veteran's participation in the study is not a claim for Repatriation benefits.

The Repatriation Commission is responsible for the administration of Repatriation legislation and is a determining authority in the Repatriation claims and appeals system. It is within this determining system that the findings of scientific investigations are considered, along with other evidence, before a determination is made on an individual claim.
(2) Results are being sought as soon as possible, consistent with the scientific requirements of the studies.
(3) The reasons why the Government has decided not to have a judicial enquiry have been given on many occasions, both in the Senate and outside.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 8 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1205) Senator Evans asked me, as Minister representing the the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services or, if he prefers, to the Attorney-General, because it is about the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence. With the appointment now announced of the new Director of the Bureau, and with its operations due to commence this month, will the Minister table all the papers relating to the formation of the Bureau which was announced on 6 February? Does the Government still claim, as it was certainly claiming last year, that the establishment of the Bureau is in accordance with the recommendation of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs, chaired by Mr Justice Williams, when it knows, or it ought to know, that such recommendations of that Royal Commission related only to intelligence associated with drug offences and not to criminal intelligence generally? What steps, if any, have been taken to ensure that adequate safeguards will be produced to surround the creation and operation of this Bureau, especially to meet the concerns of the Australian Law Reform Commission relating to the dissemination of information obtained by it and procedures whereby persons can check information about them in certain circumstances to see whether it is misleading or untruthful? What steps have been taken to ensure that the Bureau will be responsible and accountable to at least one elected government and parliament in the Federation, given the notorious difficulties which have been associated with other such exercises in co-operative federalism?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI) was formed by agreement between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory Governments. Accordingly, the tabling of the agreement would depend on all signatories agreeing to such action. I am consulting with the Police Ministers of the States and the Northern Territory Governments seeking their assent to the tabling of the agreement, if possible, simultaneously, both in the Commonwealth Parliament and in the State and Northern Territory Parliaments.

The establishment of the ABCI is in accordance with the major part of the recommendations of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs (ARCID). The ABCI was established for the purpose of gathering intelligence on organised crime, with an emphasis on drug trafficking. While the ARCID recommendations concentrated on drug matters, Judge Williams specifically commented that the proposed Criminal Drug Intelligence Centres could serve a broader purpose than this:

'The Commission sees these proposed arrangements as capable of providing a first-rate intelligence service to assist law enforcement bodies in combating drug trafficking. It also believes that the structure proposed can be adapted to provide intelligence about criminal activities unconnected with drugs.'

Although the ABCI represents a departure from the Criminal Drug Intelligence Centre Scheme proposed by ARCID in some respects, the essential functions of receiving, collating and disseminating information are the same.

The Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence is responsible and accountable to the Australian Police Ministers' Council which comprises Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers with portfolio responsibility for policing. Moreover, the Australian Police Ministers' Council can call for any report as it sees fit relating to the administration and functioning of the ABCI. In relation to privacy aspects, I can assure honourable senators that the Commonwealth will, for its part, examine any privacy implications of the ABCI Agreement in the light of the ALRC final report on privacy when that report is presented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 June 1981 (Hansard, pages 3019-20) Senator Coleman asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the visit by Dr I. Bayley to Australian spinal units and media advertising which glamorises dangerous behaviour.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

I am aware of the visit earlier this year to Australia of Dr Ian Bayley. I understand Dr Bayley, who is Director of the Spinal Injuries Unit of the Royal National Orthopaedic Hospital in the United Kingdom, saw value in visiting spinal units in Australia to assist in the development of the first such unit in London.

While he was here Dr Bayley was able to observe some of the preventive work being promoted by our Australian specialists in spinal injuries. One of their efforts in prevention is an audio-visual kit on the prevention of spinal cord injury. Dr John Yeo, Director of the Spinal Unit at the Royal North Shore Hospital in Sydney, has sent me a copy of the kit.

I believe it is particularly appropriate that during this International Year of Disabled Persons efforts of this kind are being made. Much of the publicity this year has been directed towards the effects of disabling injuries. To complement this, I understand that prevention displays, including the audi-visual kit, have been on show in some Sydney metropolitan banks in an attempt to make the public more aware of the risks of spinal injury.

I would encourage responsible industries to join with the medical profession and my Department in promoting greater public awareness of the need for greater care and healthier life-style practices. My Department's involvement in media advertising for health and safety included the pilot National Health Promotion Program during 1980 and some projects approved for funding under the Government's Health Services Research and Development Grants Program. Each of these programs has sought methods of effectively increasing public awareness concerning health factors.

The Government is funding a project under the latter program to evaluate the learning of behaviour from a television program for primary school children in New South Wales. The project aims to develop positive attitudes and behaviour towards health and personal development, and to promote awareness of a range of specific health problems and harmful health practices in children between the ages of six and 12 years. The effect of the television media on safety behaviour will be analysed.

The connection between allegedly dangerous behaviours promoted in media advertising and morbidity or disability is difficult to establish. Epidemiological studies may assist. Under the Health Services Research and Development Grants Program, the Neurological Society of Australia has received funds to establish the basis for a national plan for the reduction of mortality and morbidity from neurotrauma (head injuries).

The Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations has informed my Department that every attempt is made to limit the potentially dangerous aspects of advertisements for which it is responsible. This will often include obtaining expert medical opinion and ensuring that safety facets are obvious.

On the matter of approaches to advertising the honourable senator will no doubt be aware that an advertising code of ethics produced by the Australian Advertising Industry Council provides for self-regulation within the advertising industry. Part of this code states:
'Advertisements shall not exploit children nor contain anything which might result in their physical, mental or moral harm'.

The Council encourages inquiries in the event that a particular media advertisement is considered antagonistic to the code and I would hope that people would advise the Council of any advertisements which they believe should be brought to its attention.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Shipment of Uranium by the Military

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 (Hansard, page 896) Senator Jones asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a report in today's Australian Financial Review that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, has proposed to Cabinet that the military be used to ship Australian uranium overseas? What discussion has taken place with the military authorities? What conditions will have to prevail to allow the use of military authorities to transport Australian uranium overseas? What equipment is proposed to be used? What cost will be involved if this type of transport is undertaken?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I have read the article referred to by Senator Jones. The headline 'Military Plan to Beat Union Ban' and the lead sentence of the article are misleading in that there is not now, nor was there at the time the article was written, any Defence plan specifically designed to employ the Defence Force in shipment of uranium overseas. I do not propose to discuss hypothetical propositions of the kind raised in the question.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Defence Forces: Apprenticeships and Technical Training

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1271), Senator Giles asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) How many apprenticeship and technical training positions are available in the Defence Force and in the Department of Defence civilian workforce.
(2) In which trades and technical occupations are these training opportunities.
(4) How many applications have been received from women and how many have been successful.
(5) From which classifications are women excluded and on what grounds.
(6) Are both young women and young men able to train as pilots with the Royal Australian Air Force.
(7) What steps have been taken to ensure that the recruiting material and promotion material are designed to attract applications from young women whose training needs are too often neglected.
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
(1) There were 3204 apprenticeship and technical training positions in the Defence Force and 1333 positions in the Department of Defence civilian workforce on 30 June 1981.

(2) The Defence force youth apprentice schemes provide training opportunities in the trade classifications of motor mechanic, fitter and turner, carpenter and joiner, plumber and gasfitters, electrical mechanic, electrical fitter, electronic tradesmen, and aircraft mechanic. Adult apprentice and other technical training opportunities are provided in the fields of radio, electronics, aircraft engineering, motor mechanics and metal machining. The Defence civilian apprentice scheme covers the same trade classifications as the Defence Force scheme plus the classifications of electro plater, painter and sign writer, ship wright, boiler maker/welder, instrument maker and sail maker. Other civilian technical training opportunities are in the fields of drafting, naval architecture, engineering, science, navy systems, computers and data processing.

(3) Defence civilian trainees are employed at all of the Department's dockyards, research establishments and in numerous Defence Force establishments located in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory. Defence Force technical training positions are located in Victoria and New South Wales at HMAS Nirimba, HMAS Albatross, Army Apprentices School, RAFME Training Centre, RAAF School of Technical Training and the RAAF School of Radio.

(4) Ninety women applied for trade and technical training positions with the Department of Defence civilian workforce for 1981, of these, 20 were successful. Relatively few women have sought similar training with the Services but, as the records of applications do not show which applications are from women and which are from men, it has not been possible to determine the actual number of women applicants. During 1981 there have been 53 women selected for adult apprentice or technical training in the Services.

(5) Women are not excluded from any of the Defence civilian apprentice or technical training categories. Within the Defence Force there are, as a matter of policy, some restrictions imposed on their employment in such areas as sea duty, combatant duty and in certain types of field units. Therefore, women are not accepted in the Service apprentice and technical training programmes in which arrangements for training, career employment and progression involve employment in the areas subject to restriction. Presently women are not accepted into the Service's youth apprentice schemes. With the exception of adult apprentice training in the electrical technical communication category there is no provision for female technical training in the RAN. Current policy does not prevent women from entering most of the Army trade training areas however it does prevent them from serving in specific units on completion of training. Women are not excluded from entering any of the RAAF technical musterings.
(6) In compliance with the Government's policy on the employment of women in combatant roles, women are not accepted into pilot training in the Royal Australian Air Force.

(7) The Defence Force recruiting material used for the promotion of apprentice and technical training opportunities is designed to either encourage aspirants to seek more information or to provide applicants with further counselling to reinforce the decision. In cases where opportunities do not exist, no attempt is made to attract a female enquiry. In other cases no discrimination is made in the terms used. Recruiting material for the Department's civilian workforce includes material that is specifically designed to encourage young women to seek apprentice and technical training positions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1633) Senator Hearn asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning funding of the activities of family planning associations.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The Government recognises the importance of education in family planning and, for this reason, continues to provide financial assistance under the Family Planning Program for education, information and training activities undertaken by various family planning organisations, including the State and Territory Family Planning Associations.

I should emphasise, however, that Family Planning Program funds are appropriated annually by the Parliament and are finite. Therefore, it is not always possible to fund family planning organisations to the full extent of their stated requirements-nor has it been the Government's intention to do so. While the Government has continued to make as large a contribution as possible to family planning education activities, it has always been made clear to family planning organisations that there was no unlimited undertaking to underwrite those activities. However, considerable care is taken by my Department to recommend to me for approval Family Planning Program grants at levels that will enable the activities of Family Planning Associations to remain viable.

As the Program's appropriation is finite, increased allocations to one organisation can only be made at the expense of other organisations supported under the Program. Therefore, existing commitments to on-going activities do not enable increased financial assistance to be made available under the Family Planning Program for 1981-82.

It will be noted that, under the Family Planning Program, each organisation receiving Program support must accept responsibility for setting its own priorities within the context of the resources available to it, and I am sure this is a situation which the organisations accept as appropriate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Police asked the Commissioner of the AFP to provide a senior officer to assist the S.A. Police with an internal investigation into allegations of corruption against certain members of the S.A. Police. On 27 October 1981, a Detective Superintendent from the AFP arrived in Adelaide to assist with these inquiries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1803) Senator McLaren asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I preface my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs by reminding him that on 17 September I raised in the adjournment debate the matter of a mail van being burnt south of Meningie. The answer I received from Senator Baume was that the van was carrying mail and some 96 bags of mail were destroyed. Why is it that the Minister's Department took up to three weeks to honour cheques which were payable by it to recipients of repatriation benefits in the Mount Gambier area, when the social security cheques which come under the jurisdiction of Senator Chaney were able to be paid almost immediately to people who went to the Department of Social Security and said that they had not received their cheques? People who were expecting their repatriation benefit cheques had to wait up to three weeks. What was the reason for the inordinate delay in making payment to these people and causing them some undue suffering?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

I am informed that the accident occurred at Meningie on 16 September 1981 when an Australia Post contractor's van was burnt causing damage to the mail bags being conveyed. The mail bags contained pension cheques from my Department and cheques from the Department of Social Security.

There were 930 cheques from my Department involved in the accident. Of these, 124 were returned from the various post offices involved as being too badly damaged or having an indecipherable address. As these cheques were received by the Branch Office in Adelaide, replacement cheques were issued. The last of the 124 was returned to the Department on 25 September 1981 and replacement cheques for these were issued on the same day.

From 17 September to 27 October 1981, advice was received from some pensioners that their cheques for the 17 September payday had not been received. Duplicate cheques were issued to the pensioners involved immediately the advice was received. In this period 201 duplicate cheques were issued.

A check has been made of the pensioners whose cheques would have been involved in the accident, to identify anyone who had not presented the original cheque for payment or had not requested a duplicate cheque. This check showed that there were 36 pensioners in this category. They have been contacted to advise them of the accident and of the procedure to obtain a duplicate cheque if the original has not been received.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister's Department aware of any information, disclosed in submissions to it, advice available to it or public documents such as Auditor-General's Reports, which suggest that the Department and instrumentalities under the Minister's responsibility are forgoing revenue because of insufficient staff.
(2) How much revenue is alleged to have been forgone.
(3) Approximately how much revenue does the Department estimate may have been forgone.
(4) When did the information or items of information become available to the Minister's Department.
(5) What has been done to improve the situation.
(6) What are the details of any staff rearrangements that have been made as a result of action in this regard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (6) To my knowledge such statements have not been made in external authoritative submissions such as the Auditor-General's report. However, views have been put forward from time to time along the lines that the provision of a greater number of staff in the Department of Social Security may lead to greater accuracy in payments made by the Department and increases in the recoveries of overpayments. Generally, there is a realisation that on a cost/benefits basis the provision of additional staff has to be carefully balanced so that the cost of the employment of such staff is not greater than the value of incorrect payments avoided or additional overpayments recovered. When overpayments are identified the major constraint on recovering those overpayments is the difficulty many debtors face in paying, not insufficient staff.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Social Security planning to re-introduce an assets test before people can obtain the age pension; if so, will he provide details of the discretionary powers available to the Director-General of the Department to investigate pensioners' private financial arrangements and assets.

(2) Will the Minister consider the more practical and humane alternative of inviting pensioners with assets in non-interest bearing accounts to invest those monies in Australian Government Bonds on the understanding that the Government will disregard interest earned as income for the purpose of the means test for civil and service pensions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There is no plan to re-introduce an assets test at this stage. I am concerned, however, that, since the change from the means test to the income test in 1976, there appears to have been a marked increase in the number of people, some with quite substantial amounts of money, who are contriving to make themselves eligible for the pension by participating in artificial income avoidance schemes and by placing significant sums in non-interest bearing accounts. Such practices restrict the Government's ability to provide assistance to those in genuine need. The Government will be moving to counter such practices by strengthening the existing provisions in the Social Services Act which deal with the deprivation of income. I plan to introduce legislation on this matter during the Autumn sitting.

Some details of the intended new arrangements in respect of non-interest bearing accounts were announced recently. The intention is that amounts of up to $2,000 (for a single person) and up to $3,000 (for a married couple) held in non-interest bearing accounts will be exempt from the new arrangements. Allowance would be made for specific situations where such amounts were exceeded for reasons not related to pension entitlement, for example, during the period between the sale of one home and the purchase of another.

There are powers contained in sections 16 and 141 of the Social Services Act giving the Director-General of the Department authority to investigate pensioners' private financial arrangements for the purpose of determining pension and fringe benefit entitlement.

(2) Special investment schemes for pensioners are one possibility which will be considered by the Government as part of its ongoing review of retirement arrangements. No specific options are under consideration at this time.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Department of Social Security: Payment of Benefits

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1720) Senator Georges asked me a question without notice concerning the problem addressed in the Auditor-General's report about the overpayment of benefits by my department.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

The Auditor-General reported that the accumulated amount of overpayments outstanding at 30 June 1981 was $45m. The debts raised during 1980-81 amounted to $27.2m which was about 0.3 per cent of the department's total expenditure from the National Welfare Fund.

Overpayments are due to a number of factors including misrepresentation (a small proportion), mistakes or omissions by clients or delay by them in advising the department about changes in their circumstances. Excess payments are an unavoidable feature of any social security administration.
The amount of debts raised each year has been increasing, primarily because of increases in rates of payment through indexation and increasing numbers of pensioners and beneficiaries.

The accumulated amount of overpayments outstanding has also increased. Recovery of debts from people with limited means has to be effected in a sympathetic manner and in accordance with capacity to repay. This is the major constraint on the speed with which my department can recover overpayments.

The percentage of debts recovered to overpayments raised has, nonetheless, improved progressively from 55 per cent in 1977-78 to 61 per cent in 1980-81. My department aims to continue this improvement, but is not being assisted in its endeavours by union work-bans in some of the department's regional offices, an issue which the Director-General is currently addressing.

The department has a policy of pursuing recovery of overpayments, and this is being enforced. However, given the nature of many of the overpayments and the circumstances of the individuals involved, there will always be difficulties in effecting recovery quickly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard page 2266) Senator Button asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that there are a number of illegal television transmitters transmitting programs to the general public in Victoria and Western Australia which are not licensed? If so, what is the Government's attitude to this problem.
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

My Department is aware of several such transmitters. They are usually low-power installations used to translate signals from a station whose original signals are too weak for satisfactory reception by a standard receiving apparatus in the area concerned. Unless they interfere with other services, my Department has tried to administer the law regarding such transmissions in a sympathetic and flexible manner. Generally speaking those responsible are notified of the relevant legal provisions and encouraged to submit a planning proposal to the Department so that their service can be legitimised.

Unfortunately, the planning and licensing process as it presently stands is slow and quite complex. Consequently, a Working Party on Revised Planning Procedures (representing broadcasters, Telecom and my Department) has been established and is scheduled to make recommendations for a less cumbersome system in January 1982. I have also approved circulation of a draft paper entitled 'Self-Help Television Reception for Small Communities', which is directed towards enabling small communities to obtain television reception at minimum cost well in advance of available methods. I have arranged for a copy of this draft paper to be made available to Senator Button for information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 30 April 1981 (Hansard, page 1541) Senator Button asked me a question without notice concerning the administration of the new health care arrangements by the Department of Social Security.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
The Department of Social Security is responsible for classifying the disadvantaged groups defined in the Government's health statement.

For applicants in the low income group, eligibility is determined in relation to the claimant's income over the four-week period prior to his application or prior to the time of his treatment. Once eligibility for a card has been established, the card is issued covering a period of six months. At the expiration of six months, eligibility is reviewed and eligible people are issued with a new card for a further six months.

Only in specified circumstances is it necessary for the person to return the card prior to the expiration of the six months, for example, where his income in any four-week period equals or exceeds 125 per cent of the specified limit or where there is a reduction in the number of his dependants. The card holder is required to notify the Department if his circumstances change.
In cases where entitlement is lost, a card may again be re-issued as soon as the eligibility conditions are met and an application has been received.
A Health Care card for an immigrant or refugee is issued for a period of six months and is not renewable.
Where a recipient of unemployment or special benefit satisfies the relevant income test, he is issued with a card each fortnight.
In most cases, Health Care cards are issued by post. Only in cases where a delay would otherwise occur in establishing eligibility is an applicant requested to attend an office of the Department.
It is estimated that between nine and 10 million cards will be issued in a year.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 7 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What quantities of heroin were seized during 1980 (a) by Federal authorities; and (b) by State and Territory Police.
(2) What quantities of heroin were seized by Customs and the Federal Narcotics Bureau for each calendar year from 1975 to 1979 inclusive.
(3) How many drug-related arrests were made during 1980 (a) by Federal authorities; and (b) by State and Territory Police.
(4) What number of drug-related arrests were made by Customs and the Federal Narcotics Bureau for each calendar year from 1975 to 1979 inclusive.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) 7,900.23 grams (this includes 310.14 grams seized in joint AFP/State operations); (b) As reported to the Australian Federal Police-4,459.72 grams plus 22 ampoules 335 capsules and 326 foils. (Ampoules and capsules may be of any size. Foils may contain between 80-120 milligrams of powder).
These figures have been extracted from records of agencies preceding the AFP.
(3) (a) 364 (this includes 119 arrests in joint AFP/ State/Northern Territory operations); (b) As reported to the Australian Federal Police-11,352.
These figures have been extracted from records of agencies preceding the AFP.
The Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police has supplied the following additional information.

The Commissioner and his State Police colleagues have chosen to concentrate their resources, sometimes as joint task forces, in other cases by combining intelligence and staff, on securing evidence to bring about the conviction of financiers and others masterminding drug operations rather than seeking apparent short-term success in terms of quantities seized at the distribution end of the trafficking chain.
These changed police strategies are in line with the recommendations of the Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs.
While seizure amounts are down, it is a matter of record that major crime figures have already been brought to justice and lengthy and exacting operations against others are beginning to bear fruit.

An example is provided by the recent Zampaglione case in Victoria, where State and Federal Police co-operation resulted in the conviction of five offenders for conspiracy to import heroin. The two main conspirators received prison sentences of 25 and 20 years, while two others each received 15 years. No heroin was seized in these arrests but the amount those convicted might still be handling had they not been brought to justice is incalculable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the new guidelines for the provision of legal aid issued by the Attorney-General's Department in clause 21 provide that a plaintiff who applies for legal aid in a 'public interest' environmental case must, in order to be granted legal aid be; firstly 'prevented from pursuing the proceedings by lack of means'; while at the same time being prepared to be 'personally liable for costs'.
(2) Does this involve a contradiction which will prevent many worthy and needy prospective plaintiffs from obtaining legal aid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, the guidelines contain requirements to that effect.

(2) In the special circumstances of environmental cases, where the applicant is not seeking to enforce or defend a private right, legal aid is confined to persons who demonstrate a bona fide concern in the proceedings and their outcome. The preparedness of an applicant to be personally liable for costs is generally a good indication of such concern. Ordinarily, legal aid is not available as of course to pay costs awarded against a legally aided person.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Do the guidelines for the provision of legal aid issued recently by the Attorney-General's Department clause 2 provide that the Attorney-General may grant legal aid if: (a) 'it is reasonable in all the circumstances to grant the application'; and (b) 'it would involve hardship to the applicant to refuse the application'.
(2) Does clause 4 state that even if the Attorney is satisfied of these two requirements, his discretion to grant or not to grant legal aid is unfettered.

(3) Does the Attorney have power to refuse an application for legal aid where it has been shown that: (i) it is reasonable to grant the application; and (ii) refusal would involve hard- ship; and if so, why should the Attorney-General have power to refuse such demonstrably necessary and reasonable legal aid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) The discretion which the Attorney-General is to exercise in making the grants of aid is provided for in the relevant statutory provisions, for example, s.69 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975. The guidelines draw attention to the fact that, while those provisions refer to the considerations of hardship and reasonableness, they do not limit the Attorney-General's discretion to those matters. The additional matters which the Attorney-General may appropriately take into account will depend on the circumstances of particular applications but they would include the availability of funds.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 14 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which of those statutory authorities and prescribed persons not covered by Schedules 1 and 2 of the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Regulations, provide for maternity leave on a basis similar to the provisions of the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act.
(2) How is this provision accorded; for example, by administrative fiat, through award provisions, etc.

(3) What steps have been or are being taken, by the Government or the Public Service Board, to ensure uniformity of employment conditions with respect of maternity leave provisions across all Commonwealth statutory authorites.
(4) What specific information does the Public Service Board currently possess concerning these issues.
(5) What maternity leave provisions are applicable in commonwealth corporations such as Qantas.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Public Service Board is responsible for the administration of the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1973. It has advised that of the statutory authorities listed in its 1981 Annual Report whose staff are not covered by the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1973, the following provide for maternity leave on a basis similar to the provisions of the Act;
Albury Wodonga Development Corporation Administrative Decision
Anglo Australian Telescope Board Administrative Decision
Australian Dried Fruits Corporation Administrative Decision
Australian Industry Development Corporation Administrative Decision
Australian Institute of Multicultural Affairs Administrative Decision
Australian National Railways Commission Administrative Decision
Australian Trade Union Training Authority Administrative Decision
Canberra College of Advanced Education Award Provision
Capital Territory Health Commission Administrative Decision
Christmas Island Administration Administrative Decision and Award Provision
Legal Aid Commission (Australian Capital Territory) Administrative Decision
Parliament House Construction Authority Administrative Decision
Reserve Bank of Australia Administrative Decision

(3) and (4) Government policy is that Commonwealth authorities should normally adopt some maternity leave provisions for their staff. Steps are in train to extend the provisions of the Maternity Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act 1973 to 25 Commonwealth authorities which have agreed to prescription in the Maternity Leave Regulations.

(5) Conditions of service, including maternity leave conditions, of independent corporations owned by the Commonwealth (which as incorporated bodies cannot be prescribed authorities for the purposes of the Maternity Leave Act) fall outside the area of Public Service Board responsibilities. However it is known that two such corporations, Qantas and Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Service (CACS) provide for unpaid maternity leave for staff, but not for paid maternity leave.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Income Tax Assessment Act, Part III, Division 1, General, section 23ad., sub-clause (c), page 7045, except disability pensions of the kinds specified in sub-section (2) of section 365 of the Imperial Act known as the Income and Corporation Taxes Act 1970, from income tax assessment.
(2) Is the Attorney-General also aware, that a tax-payer is not beholden to disclose details of disability pension, as it is tax exempt.

(3) Is the legal aid program, at present practised by the Australian Legal Aid Office (ALAO), is now winding down, and about to be supplanted by individual Australian States and Law Institute regulated from of legal assistance, if so, will the Attorney-General: (a) in the interests of justice, and in conformity with the Treasury, consider legislation so that disability pensions of the type mentioned above, not be included on the notion of merit requirements of ALAO financial application forms; and (b) consider legislation immediately so as to complete reforms incorporated in (a) above, so that the successors of ALAO will not be able to avail themselves of this deplorable anomaly.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Such disability pensions are exempt from income tax by virtue of paragraph 23AD (3) (c) of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

(2) I am informed that as a matter of administration the Commissioner of Taxation does not require the disclosure of income which is exempt under sub-section 23AD (3) of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

(3) In accordance with Government policy, the functions of the Australian Legal Aid Office (ALAO) are being absorbed by independent State or Territory legal aid commissions, established by State or Territory legislation. Such commissions are now operating in Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory.

ALAO applications for legal aid require, in effect, disclosure of all sources of an applicant's income. Where service personnel, ex-service personnel or their dependants (veterans) seek legal aid in relation to proceedings arising out of war service, repatriation or rehabilitation, the information as to the applicant's financial position is not taken into account in determining eligibility for legal aid. However, that information is relevant to consideration of a veteran's eligibility for legal aid in respect of other proceedings. A change of the forms to exclude disability pensions would therefore be inappropriate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 28 May 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware that in the report of Mr K. Wiltshire, a consultant to the Coombs Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, suggestions were made firstly to abandon staff ceilings as a method of control of the Public Service and secondly if staff ceilings were retained as a control device, they be improved in some 21 ways.
(2) Why have the four alternatives to staff ceilings mentioned on pages 114-5 of Volume 1 of the Appendix to the Report not been implemented.
(3) Which of the 21 suggestions on pages 116 to 118 have been implemented.
(4) Which have not been implemented.
(5) In the case of each recommendation not implemented, why has it not been implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The staff ceilings system has a number of advantages. It provides direct and flexible control over the size of the Service overall and the staffing levels of individual departments and authorities. In conjunction with financial allocations the system provides an appropriate means of distributing limited resources and it complements establishment system control over staffing structures and classification aspects. Staff ceilings also encourage public service managers to think in terms of the efficient allocation of staff resources.

(3) and (4) Of the 21 suggested modifications referred to, 17 items-(a), (b), (d), (e), (f), (g), (h), (i), (k), (m), (n), (p), (q), (r), (s), (t) and (u)-have been fully or partially implemented; items (c), (j), (l) and (o) have not been implemented.

(5) The reasons for not implementing items (c), (l) and (o) are that they would involve practical difficulties or that alternative arrangements are considered more appropriate. Item (j) proposed that the Public Service Board make special allowances for those departments which cannot avoid numbers' restrictions by means such as overtime, consultants and day labour. The use of overtime or consultants as a means of avoiding ceiling constraints is not permitted. Day labour staff are subject to ceiling control in the normal way.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Regional Offices: Department of Social Security

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 3 June 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Which regional offices of the Department of Social Security will not open as a result of the Review of Commonwealth Functions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Social Security proposed 6 new offices for inclusion within the Commonwealth Leasing Program for 1981-82. The proposed offices were-
The number of new offices opened by my department is determined by the budgetary provision for the Leasing Program.

Normally my department would expect to have approximately half of its proposals included in the Leasing Program for a given financial year. However, in view of the recommendation of the Review of Commonwealth Functions, the Government's general constraint on expenditure and the urgent need to relocate three of the Department's existing offices (requiring new leases) no new offices will be opened from the provisions of this year's Leasing Program.
I must point out, however, that five offices have already opened or will open this financial year in respect of leases which we entered into with building owners/developers prior to 30 June 1981.

Of these five, Knox Regional Office in Victoria opened on 3 August 1981. Belmont (Victoria), Heidelberg (Victoria), Edwardstown (South Australia) and Perth East (Western Australia) are yet to be opened.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Alsatian Dogs: Travel in Commonwealth Cars

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Under what circumstances may alsatian dogs travel in Commonwealth cars hired by Parliamentary office holders.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Under rules I have instituted dogs are not to be carried in chauffeur-driven cars operated by my Department. These rules accord with motor traffic regulations in the Australian Capital Territory, the Northern Territory and most States which generally prohibit the carriage of animals in taxi cabs or private hire cars. The rules allow for special arrangements to apply in the very limited number of exceptional cases which may arise provided that my approval has been obtained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 26 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action, if any, does the Government intend taking to abolish the divisional structure of the Public Service in favour of a functional structure, as recommended by the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration, in view of the promptings contained in the Public Service Board Annual Report 1980-81.
(2) What is the reason for the length of the delay in implementing such reforms, having regard to the fact that the Royal Commission Report was presented to Parliament in 1976.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Government announced its decision to abolish the divisional structure of the Australian Public Service on 28 November 1979 (Commonwealth Record 4:47:1833-34).
Prior to that announcement the recommendation of the Royal Commission on Australian Government Administration had been the subject of careful study and consultation with the union Peak Councils.
Implementation of the decision requires amendment of the Public Service Act. An amending Bill was introduced in the Parliament on 29 October 1981.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Cabinet Ministers: Disclosure of Pecuniary Interests

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Leader of the Government in the Senate say in answer to a question without notice by Senator Primmer on 1 April, as to whether any Minister had disclosed to Cabinet a pecuniary interest in matters before Cabinet affecting the interests of radio and television broadcasters, that he had 'no doubt in the world' that any affected Minister would indicate that interest.

(2) Can he assure the Senate, as Leader of the Government, that no person to whom details of forthcoming amendments to the Broadcasting and Television Act were supplied, or to whom draft Bills were given, would have passed those details on to anyone able to profit from them.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: In my reply to Senator Primmer's question to me on 1 April 1981 (Hansard page 970) I said:

'I am not aware of any particular Minister having a pecuniary interest in that area, but I have no doubt in the world that if the Ministers concerned had a particular interest in the matter they would indicate that interest in terms of the Bowen Report before debate took place'.
I also refer the honourable senator to the reply to question No. 1121 on 14 October 1981 (Senate Hansard, page 1241). I have nothing further to add to these answers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Does Cabinet confidentiality apply to draft Bills which arise out of Cabinet decisions, in view of the answer given by him as Leader of the Government in the Senate to a Question Without Notice by Senator Bishop on 2 April in which he said that 'all Cabinet discussions are completely confidential'.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: I refer the honourable senator to my answer to Question No. 1120.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 27 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the rules followed by the Government relating to release of information on proposed legislation to outside interests for purposes of discussion.

(2) Did the Minister for Communications, in a statement on 9 April 1981, specifically say he was making his statement so that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, Administrative Appeals Tribunal and other bodies would be aware of the Government's intentions; if so, is this consistent with the rules referred to in (1).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Drafts of bills are from time to time discussed with interested parties to ensure there are no technical defects or unforeseen consequences. It is a matter for the Government to decide on the nature of such discussions. It is also a matter for the Government to decide the final content of the bill.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why did the review of Commonwealth Functions list a decision to allow production and marketing of High Court decisions to remain with the private sector.

(2) Did the Government have a previous intention to transfer the function to the public sector, if not, why was that decision to do nothing listed in the Review of Commonwealth Functions while hundreds of other decisions to do nothing were not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) In recent years there have been discussions about arrangements for the publication of High Court judgments, including the possibility that this function might be performed in the public sector. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 8 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister inform the Parliament how many Commonwealth Government departments use visual display units.
(2) What is the total number of units in full-time use.
(3) How many operators work full time on the units.
(4) Has any survey ever been conducted to ascertain if continual use of the machines leads to health problems, particularly eyesight defects.
(5) If such a survey has not been carried out will the Minister investigate the possibility of such a survey.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) While comprehensive information is not maintained, virtually all Commonwealth Government departments are believed now to use visual display units.

(2) Based upon a 1979 survey of actual units installed and anticipated growth, more than 5,000 are believed to be in use for a variety of purposes. Usage patterns vary greatly and it is not possible to estimate the proportion in full time use.

(3) Similarly, it is not possible to estimate the number of operators working on these units full time. Most of the Commonwealth's 73 Word Processing Typists would do so however, while a significant proportion of its 738 Computer Operators, 2188 Data Processing Operators, 1833 Computer Systems Officers and some other classifications use visual display units in various ways. Those figures relate to full time Public Service Act staff as at December 1980.

(4) and (5) The need for such a survey has not been demonstrated. Health and safety issues associated with the operation of visual display units have been considered by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NH&MRC), which has produced an occupational health guide on 'Vision and Eyesight Tests for Visual Display Terminal Operators' and a draft occupational health guide on the 'Use of Screen-based Equipment'. The Director-General of Health has endorsed the NH&MRC occupational health guide for application to Commonwealth staff.

In a memorandum issued on 23 October 1981, the Public Service Board advised departments, statutory authorities and staff organisations of the guide and of other authoritative sources of advice on the appropriate conditions for operation of visual display units. The memorandum notes the need for proper consultation with staff when screen based equipment is introduced, in accordance with the spirit of standing Board guidelines on joint staff/management consultation on technological change in the Australian Public Service. In keeping with these guidelines, the Board consulted with departments and staff associations on the issues covered in the memorandum, which include provision for eyesight tests under the supervision of the Department of Health.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 9 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In each calendar year from 1975, how many Indo-chinese male and female refugees aged from 10 to 18 years of age entered Australia, in each State and Territory, as (a) wards of the State and (b) in the care of guardians not their parents.

(2) In each calendar year from 1975, how many single Indo-chinese male and female refugees aged from 18 to 25 years inclusive entered Australia, in each State and Territory, unaccompanied by their parents.

(3) What were the 'Special Benefits' paid until November 1979 to refugee students up to the age of 25 who were undertaking full-time secondary education and who had no family to support them and no other means of support.
(4) Why were full-time refugee students no longer eligible to receive Special Benefits after November 1979.
(5) How many refugees in full-time secondary study in each State and Territory were affected by that decision.
(6) How were they advised, and what information and advice was given to them.

(7) When was the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs first informed by his Department that gaps in the provision of Commonwealth financial assistance to refugee students in full-time secondary education was forcing them to leave school.

(8) What financial assistance is now available, and has been available since November 1979, to encourage and enable refugee youth to study full-time towards an Australian matriculation qualification in the absence of the financial support of parents.

(9) What action has the Government taken to ensure that adequate assistance and encouragement is given to recently-arrived refugees who want to resume and further their secondary and tertiary education.

(10) What consultation has the Government had with refugee associations and communities, government and non-government agencies working with refugees and with State welfare authorities on the issue of financial assistance for full-time students.
(11) Which groups and individuals have made representations to him and his ministerial colleagues on this issue.
(12) Does the Government accept the need for short-term positive discrimination in favour of refugees.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has providedd the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Detailed statistics are not available. It is estimated that:

(a) Some 900 wards under the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act have arrived since 1976 and that about 320 of these are presently under 18 years. It is estimated these are approximately distributed across the main centres of settlement as follows-

(b) Since 1975, some 2,900 refugee children under 18 years at the time of arrival have been admitted in the care of relatives (other than parents). It is estimated that 1,800 of these are presently under 18 years. Distribution by State/Territory is not known. It is however estimated that these are approximately distributed across the main centres of settlement as follows:
(2) Detailed statistics are not available. It is estimated that 11,000 persons presently under 24 years but between 18-24 years at the time of arrival, have entered Australia since 1975.
(3) The 'special benefits' were payments made by the Department of Social Security under provisions under the Social Security Act.

(4) I am informed that following an examination of the legal position by the Department of Social Security, it was concluded that special benefits could not, as a general rule, be payable to full-time students.

(6) Advice was given to the refugees in receipt of special benefit that existing payments would remain undisturbed for the remainder of 1979 scholastic year but payments would not be continued beyond the end of 1979. Where necessary, counselling was given by social workers from the Department of Social Security or Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

(7) While difficulties in this area were brought to my attention soon after my appointment to the portfolio of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in December 1979, records available to me do not show the precise date on which I was first informed.

(8) There are two general Commonwealth schemes of student assistance under which full-time students in year 11 or year 12 studying towards a matriculation qualification may be eligible for assistance. These are the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme (ASEAS) and the Secondary Allowances Scheme (SAS), both administered by the Department of Education. The two schemes have been in operation for some years. Both include refugee students among their beneficiaries but ASEAS is more likely to be relevant to students who do not have the benefit of support from parents living in Australia.

The provisions of ASEAS are designed to assist adult students returning to secondary study after a significant break. To be eligible, a student must have turned 19 by 1 January of the year for which benefits are sought and must have been away from full-time secondary study for a minimum total period of two years in the previous five. Other conditions relate to such things as residence status, previous attempts at matriculation and tertiary studies undertaken. The major benefit is a means-tested living allowance with a maximum value of $49.67 per week. Refugee students generally qualify for the maximum allowance. Assistance is at present provided for only a single year of full-time matriculation study.

The Secondary Allowances Scheme (SAS) is specifically a scheme of assistance to needy parents to help them keep their children at school for the final two secondary years (years 11 and 12). The allowance of up to $660 per annum, which has been increased to $726 for 1982, is means-tested on parental income. Where students are supported by persons other than parents those persons may receive the allowance, subject to the usual means test. Refugee students therefore normally qualify for these benefits only if they are in the care of their parents or other persons who satisfy the means test requirements.

(9) New measures announced in the recent Budget will make the ASEAS and SAS schemes much more accessible to refugee students in future years. From the beginning of 1982 two years of benefits (i.e. for both years 11 and 12) will be available under ASEAS to refugee and other students who have not previously advanced beyond year 10 in the Australian education system. This is in recognition of the difficulties such students have in completing matriculation studies in a single year. The requirement for a two-year break in secondary studies will also be waived in the case of refugee students.

A change in the SAS provisions will benefit refugee students without parents in Australia if they are in year 11 or 12 but do not meet the requirements for ASEAS. Such students will be able to apply for and receive SAS benefits on their own behalf. Eligibility will be subject to their own income alone and will not take into account the income of persons other than parents who may be providing support. While this change will not provide a full-scale living allowance to enable such students to live independently, it will at least provide some assistance to students attempting to support themselves from other resources. It is also hoped that, in conjunction with another Budget measure in the Social Security area, it may provide greater incentive for families to take unsupported refugee students into their care. The other measure referred to is an amendment to the Social Services Act which will bring certain refugee children within the definition of 'double orphan' and permit the payment of double orphan's pension to their guardians.

(10) The decision of the Department of Social Security was immediately brought to the attention of State and Territory welfare authorities by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. It was also raised in such forums as the Australian Refugee Advisory Council and the Migrant Settlement Councils and discussed with interested community organisations.

(11) The Ministers for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Social Security and Education have received a range of representations from Parliamentarians, community and ethnic organisations and schools concerning problems of refugee students.

(12) The Government appreciates that as a consequence of their particular circumstances, refugees may not always be able to benefit from provisions made for the general community in relation to such services as schooling, unless special measures are taken.

The adjustments made to SAS and ASEAS in the last Budget reflect the Government's concern to ensure effective equality in regard to access for refugees to senior secondary schooling, as do amendments to the Social Services Act which provide for the payment of double orphan pension in respect of refugees both of whose parents were not in Australia or whose whereabouts were unknown.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration & Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 17 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Why has the Department of Immigration closed most of its offices in Beirut.
(2) Is the Minister aware of the hazardous journey that the people of Lebanon must undertake to Damascus, the nearest office, to lodge application for migration to Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration & Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs withdrew its officers to Damascus from the Beirut Embassy in October 1978 when continued hostilities and a breakdown of essential services prevented an acceptable standard of service being provided for applicants for permanent settlement in Australia.

While the less involved temporary entry applications, and the answering of personal enquiries about migration eligibility, were functions that could be handled spontaneously, as and when the public could attend Beirut, that centre lacked the stable and predictable working environment necessary for an immigration processing centre.

Beirut still clearly lacks the necessary operational stability. In contrast, the Australian Embassy in Damascus, a relatively short distance away, has, since its opening in early 1977, proved to be an accessible centre for the majority of applicants from the region, Lebanon, Syria and Jordan.
Travel to Damascus, like travel to Beirut can be subject to delay and detours; however, travel within Lebanon is generally much more hazardous than in Syria.
Very few applicants have been unable to attend Damascus during the three years since the Migration Office was attached to the Embassy there.

(2) Since 1978 the Australian Embassy in Beirut has continued to handle the simple applications for temporary entry and to provide general information on migration eligiblity. It closed temporarily on 21 October 1981 pending an assessment of the security situation in Beirut by the Department of Foreign Affairs, but resumed its temporary entry and other functions on 9 November 1981. The Embassy in Damascus remained accessible throughout.

From time to time the Department receives requests from Lebanese that they be given immigration interviews in Beirut. For practical operational reasons, however the department cannot conduct frequent or regular interviewing visits away from its immigration processing centre. Nevertheless, when valid reasons have been advanced why certain Lebanese applicants could not travel to Damascus, arrangements have been made for interviews to be conducted at the Embassy in Beirut when a Migration Officer is visiting the city. These arrangements will continue; however the department's experience is that the vast majority of Lebanese applying for permanent settlement in Australia prefer to attend Damascus because of the expeditious and reliable service available at that centre.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications-

(2) How much revenue is alleged to have been forgone.
(3) Approximately how much revenue does the Department estimate may have been forgone.
(4) When did the information or items of information become available to the Minister's Department.
(5) What has been done to improve the situation.
(6) What are the details of any staff re-arrangements that have been made as a result of action in this regard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answers to the honourable senator's questions are as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Radio Frequency Management Division (RFM) of the Department is aware that some revenue may have been forgone because sufficient staff are not available to fully follow up failure of licensees to renew their licences or to take up licences in the first place. Loss of revenue was mentioned in the Auditor-General's report of March 1981 but the amount was not quantified.

(2) Whether or not revenue is being forgone and to what extent, is very difficult to answer. A Radio License fee is charged to cover the costs incurred in licensing and control of the Radio Frequency spectrum. The amount of the fee is set having regard to the costs of the particular level of activity at the time including staff costs.

(3) It is not possible to quantify any loss in licence fees directly attributable to staff ceiling effects. However, my Department believes that the majority of radio-communications services in Australia are licensed.

(4) It is not practicable to ensure that all radiocommunication services are licensed as the costs of total enforcement would be prohibitive. This fact has been known to my Department and my predecessors for many years.

(5) The Government allocated additional funds in 1980-81 to enable the RFM Division to pursue activities related to licence fee collection. This, together with an increased emphasis on ADP processing of Divisional data, and rationalisation and streamlining of divisional staff and procedures should effectively increase revenue to recoup these additional expenditures.

(6) There has been a review of the various activities of the RFM Division. Some staff resources are being re-allocated to ADP and there are re-arrangements of staffing commitments between central office and state offices. This re-arrangement is necessary to develop computer systems supporting a more efficient licensing system.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) By how much has the Federal Government reduced annual capital expenditure in real terms since 1975.

(2) Does the Treasurer's Department have any information on the level of annual capital investment between 1975-76 and 1981-82 in other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries and if so by approximately how much have each of the other national Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development governments reduced or increased their capital expenditure between 1975-76 and 1981-82.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Statistician classifies Commonwealth Government gross fixed capital expenditure on new assets (viz. capital formation) into outlays by the Commonwealth's public trading enterprises and outlays in the remainder of the Commonwealth Government sector. While current price data for each series are available, the Statistician does not publish constant price estimates of the components of Commonwealth authorities' gross fixed capital expenditure. However, a broad indication of movements in the real value of these outlays can be derived by deflating the current price data by the published implicit deflator for the Statistician's estimate of total public gross fixed capital expenditure (which includes also capital expenditures by State and local governments).

On that broad basis, the implied decline in real gross fixed capital formation in the Commonwealth Government sector as a whole between 1975-76 and 1980-81 was at an average annual rate of 8 per cent; for the Commonwealth's public trading enterprises the average annual rate of decline was 5 per cent, and for the remainder of the Commonwealth sector 15 per cent.

In interpreting these figures, it should be borne in mind that they do not take into account Commonwealth payments to the States and to local government for capital purposes. For national accounting purposes these are treated as transfer payments. In 1980-81, general and specific purpose capital payments from the Commonwealth Budget to the States, the Northern Territory and to local governments amounted to $2,930m, or $1,180m greater than total Commonwealth sector gross fixed capital formation in that year.

(2) The OECD does not publish constant price estimates of central government gross fixed capital formation by its member countries, nor does it provide either current or constant price series for capital outlays by public trading enterprises. However, an OECD series of implicit price deflators for 'total gross capital formation' for each of its member countries can be used to deflate the published current price data to provide an indication of the real value of central government gross fixed capital formation. These data will be broadly comparable with that part of gross fixed capital formation in the Commonwealth sector other than by the Commonwealth's public trading enterprises.

The following table shows the estimated change (at an annual rate) in the real value of gross fixed capital formation of central governments over the period from fiscal year 1975 (financial year 1975-76 in Australia's case) until the latest year for which comparative OECD data are available.

The substantial differences between countries in the size and composition of their central government sectors, as well as the changes in those sectors over time, mean that considerable caution should be exercised in interpreting international comparisons such as these.

An example of the type of problem which can arise in making these comparisons is that referred to in part (1) above regarding the treatment of transfer payments for capital funding purposes between levels of government. With that problem in mind, the data on movements in central government gross fixed capital formation in OECD countries have been supplemented in the attached table with comparable data for the public sector as a whole (excluding public trading enterprises). Even these latter figures will be affected by the particular years chosen and may not necessarily be a good guide to the underlying trend in every country.
AVERAGE ANNUAL RATES OF CHANGE IN ESTIMATED REAL GROSSFIXED CAPITAL FORMATION
(a) Includes Central, State and local governments where relevant.
