QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 24 September 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is meant in section 87 (3A) of the Repatriation Act 1920, by the words: 'a payment of an instalment of a pension (other than a service pension within the meaning of sub-section (2) of section 52 of this Act)'.

(2) What are the details of pension payment under: (a) the Repatriation (Far East Strategic Reserve) Act 1956; (b) the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962; and (c) the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940.

(3) What type of payment is meant by 'a payment in respect of incapacity or death resulting from employment in connection with a war or warlike operations in which the Sovereign has been engaged', in paragraph 3A (c) of section 87.
(4) What are the details of payments as outlined in paragraphs 3A (d) and (e) of section 87.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: I am providing information by way of explanation of the way in which the provisions mentioned by the honourable senator apply to beneficiaries:

(1) Sub-section 87 (3A) of the Repatriation Act 1920 provides that only 40% of any disability pension is deemed to be income for the purpose of the income test used to determine the amount of service pension that an eligible pensioner is entitled to receive. The words 'a payment of an instalment of a pension (other than a service pension within the meaning of sub-section (2) of section 52 of this Act)' are applied to exclude from consideration those welfare-type pensions prescribed in Table A of Schedule 3 of the Act from being treated as disability pensions for the purposes of the sub-section.

(2) (a) Under section 6 of the Repatriation (Far East Strategic Reserve) Act 1956 pensions are payable to eligible members of the Defence Force (and their dependents) for incapacity or death as the result of a member's service with, or in connection with the British Commonwealth Far East Strategic Reserve in the then Federation of Malaya or the then Colony of Singapore. By virtue of section 7 of the Act the provisions of the Repatriation Act, in relation to the payment of pension and other related matters, are made to apply to the Repatriation (Far East Strategic Reserve) Act.

(b) Under section 6 of the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962, pensions are payable to eligible members of the Defence Force (and their dependants) in respect of any incapacity or death that results from a member's service outside Australia in a declared area, such as South Vietnam. By virtue of section 7 of the Act the provisions of the Repatriation Act, in relation to the payment of pension and other related matters, are made to apply to the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act.

(c) Under the Seamen's War Pensions and Allowances Act 1940 pensions are payable to eligible Australian mariners (and their dependants) in respect of incapacity or death suffered by a mariner as a result of a war injury.

Details of pension payments under the three Acts referred to in this part may be found in the Statistical tables of the Repatriation Commission's 1980-81 Annual Report, pages 33 to 38 inclusive; which was tabled in the Senate on 10 September 1981.

(3) Paragraph 87 (3A) (c) of the Repatriation Act is so applied that only 40% of a pension paid by a country other than Australia, which is similar in character to the disability pension paid under the Repatriation Act to Australian veterans, is considered in the assessment of service pension.

(4) Paragraph 87 (3A) (d) of the Repatriation Act refers to the Domestic Allowance that is payable to eligible widows under the Repatriation Regulations. This allowance is payable, in addition to war widows' pension, at $12 a week to a war widow who has attained the age of 55 years, is permanently unemployable or has a child under the age of 16 years. It is also payable in respect of a child over the age of 16 years who is undertaking full-time education or training and is not receiving an adequate living wage. Other details of this allowance may be found in the statistical tables on page 35 of the Repatriation Commission's 1980-81 Annual Report.
There are no allowances prescribed under the Repatriation Regulations or associated Regulations for the purpose of paragraph 87 (3A) (e) of the Repatriation Act.

(2) The NH&MRC report 'Case for funds for medical research in 1982' quoted per capita expenditure figures on medical research by national grant-giving bodies in 1980 as follows:
However, the comparison is of doubtful validity because of the different funding policies and roles of the respective organisations.
(3) The number of project grants awarded by the NH&MRC varies from year to year. Figures for the most recent five years are:

(4) The following table gives the State by State distribution of project grants awarded in 1981. It must be noted, however, that the sole criterion for the award of a project grant is scientific excellence as assessed by a complex peer review process. No account is taken of geographic considerations:

(5) The cot death research team at the University of Tasmania headed by Dr Megirian is receiving NH&MRC support in 1981 and has in fact been funded each year since 1976. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will the Minister for Veterans' Affairs investigate the case of Mr D. C. Gray, Main Road, Cudgewa, Victoria, who served in the Regular Army and was discharged as unfit in 1972.
(2) Will the Minister give reasons for-
(a) the delay by the Department in dealing with Mr Gray's applications for an increase in pension and for temporary incapacity allowance;

(b) the refusal of the Department to accept the opinion of Mr Gray's doctor-who is the Regimental Medical Officer appointed by the Department-that Mr Gray should receive the incapacity allowance indefinitely; and
(c) the rejection by a Medical Board of Mr Gray's application without first contacting his doctor for details of his condition and treatment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The case of Mr D. C. Gray has been investigated.

(2) (a) The delay referred to by the honourable senator regarding Mr Gray's application for increase was due to the deferral of a decision on his claim, along with those on many others, pending the decision of the High Court of Australia in the case, Repatriation Commission v. Nancy Law. Mr Gray was fully advised about this.

The decision was handed down by the High Court on 16 October 1981. In the light of this decision, and considering all the medical evidence, the Repatriation Commission has determined that Mr Gray be assessed at the Special Rate disability pension with effect from 12 June 1980.

As regards payment of Temporary Incapacity Allowance, Mr Gray lodged applications on 14 April 1981, 11 June 1981 and 9 July 1981. These were dealt with without undue delay and advice was forwarded to Mr Gray. He subsequently lodged an appeal on 22 July 1981 and action was taken immediately to review his entitlement to Temporary Incapacity Allowance.

(b) Regard was had to the opinion of Mr Gray's local medical officer. However, any opinion, medical or otherwise, simply forms part of the overall evidence to be considered against the legislative provisions relating to the grant of the allowance.

(c) A medical certificate may be requested before an application for Temporary Incapacity Allowance is considered. Provision for this is made on the application form and in Mr Gray's case it was completed in respect of each application by his local medical officer. It was considered that it was not necessary to obtain a further report from his local medical officer at that time.
As Mr Gray has been granted pension at the Special Rate, he is not eligible for the Allowance under the legislation and his appeal has lapsed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What definition of 'demonstrable hardship' is acceptable to the Department of Social Security before it will pay the travel expenses of an appellant on a Social Security matter wishing to appear before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
(2) Why are the guidelines for the payment of travel expenses not the same as those applying to appellants before the Social Security Appeals Tribunal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As I have previously advised in my answer to Question No. 808 (Senate Hansard, 27 August 1981, page 470), the Department of Social Security will meet the reasonable travel costs of an applicant wishing to attend the hearing of his appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in those cases where it is accepted that the applicant is without adequate means to meet those costs himself.

(2) Social Security Appeals Tribunals are established to advise the Director-General of Social Services upon the proper decision to be taken in respect of appeals made to him pursuant to section 15 of the Social Services Act 1947. In these circumstances it is considered appropriate that the Department should meet the reasonable travel costs of persons appearing before the Social Security Appeals Tribunals at the invitation of the Tribunals and for the purpose of assisting the Tribunals in their advisory capacity. By contrast, the Administrative Appeals Tribunal does not form part of any internal reconsideration process and proceedings before it are instituted at the initiative of the individual appellant. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 confers upon the Tribunal no power to order a party to meet costs incurred by another party to proceedings before it. Notwithstanding that fact, it is considered appropriate that the Department should be prepared to meet the reasonable travel costs of an appellant whose financial circumstances would otherwise prevent his attendance before the Tribunal.

(2) Between 1 April 1980 and 18 November 1981, 56 appeals lodged with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal were conceded by the Department of Social Security. Of these, 23 appeals involved medical assessments for the purposes of invalid pension and a number of those appeals would have been conceded following the handing down by the Administrative Appeals tribunal of its decisions in the Panke and Bradley cases, and having regard to the content thereof.

(3) All decisions of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal relating to decisions under the Social Services Act 1947 are circulated within the Department of Social Security, in the form in which they are handed down by the Tribunal, and with any accompanying instructions thought necessary. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

(2) Is the claim correct that 'every day, the Taxation Office bought three daily newspapers for the Valuation Section, but they never reached the men who made this claim because more senior people got them first'; if so, why were the newspapers bought by the Taxation Office if the claim for their purchase was disallowed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised me that the article referred to a taxation office in a capital city where copies of three daily newspapers are purchased for official use in the Valuation Branch. The papers are distributed to supervisors in that branch who peruse them for articles which relate to real estate matters or to the valuation profession and which may or would be of assistance or interest to valuers in the office, either individually or collectively.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 13 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Communications aware that about 2,947 service clubs (Rotary, Apex and Lions), have an aggregate membership of some 90,600 members.
(2) Is the Minister aware that millions of dollars are raised and contributed annually by these clubs in services to the community, for overseas aid and citizenship development.

(3) As thousands of dollars of these funds are siphoned off annually posting newsletters and notices for fund-raising dinners to members in an essential network of communication, will the Minister agree to reclassify the postage rate for these regular newsletter/notices from Category B to Category A to allow the money saved to be ploughed back into worthwhile community projects.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (3) No. Eligibility requirements for registration of publications are set out in the Australian Postal Commission Postal By-laws. Unless publications satisfy the special conditions prescribed in the Postal By-laws for inclusion in Category A, publications eligible for registration are classified as Category B publications.

Classification as a Category A publication is restricted to four types of organisations and registration is determined according to the dominant aims, intention or conduct of the person or organisation involved. Moreover, the dominant intention of the organisation in publishing the publication is significant.
Category A registration is restricted to publications which are:

published by an organisation, the dominant purpose of which is the investigation or relief of particular disabilities of individual persons. Additionally, the publication must consist mainly of articles relating to that dominant purpose;

published by a religious organisation and contain articles which relate to the interests of members of that organisation. (Publications reflecting social, recreational and scholastic activities are excluded);

Note-Specifically excluded from registration as Category A publications are the publications of the following types of organisations: social, recreational, motorists, employer/employee, business (other than primary) production and professional.

Australia Post has examined the constituent documents and activities of the Apex, Lions and Rotary organisations. Whilst it is recognised that these organisations are interested in and carry out worthwhile work in respect of the relief of disabilities of individual persons, activities of this nature do not rank as the dominant purpose and function of these organisations. Furthermore, their publications generally reflect the wider-based interests of the organisation and are concerned largely with administrative and social matters. Accordingly, the publications of Lions, Apex and Rotary are not eligible for Category A registration.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 20 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does an Australian citizen, Mr D. M. Bromet, who served in the Royal Dutch East Indies Army and who was a prisoner of the Japanese in the Dutch East Indies during World War II, have to pay income tax on the disability pension payments made to him by the Netherlands Government.

(2) Did a Report of the Taxation Board of Review No. 3, Brisbane, dated 27 April 1981, reveal a criticism of the limited relief granted by section 23AD (3) (c) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, as interpreted by two members of the Board, and a different interpretation by the third member, who found that the pension paid to Mr Bromet did classify for exemption from tax under that section.

(3) Did the RSL National Congress (Perth 1979) resolve 'that the National RSL urgently request the Federal Government to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 (as amended), granting exemption for disability pension payments by the Netherlands Government to ex-servicemen, exemption to be made retrospective to July 1975'.

(4) Will the Treasurer accordingly arrange for the appropriate amendment to be made to the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to ensure that Mr Bromet's pension, paid by the Netherlands Government, is exempt from tax.
(5) Will the Treasurer also instruct the Taxation Department to refund all monies paid by Mr Bromet to the Department in respect of this pension.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that, because of the secrecy provisions of the income tax law, he is unable to provide information concerning the liability to income tax of particular persons. However, by way of general comment, the Commissioner advised that a Dutch pension such as that referred to, received by an Australian resident, is subject to Australian income tax. This has been so since the Australia/Netherlands Double Taxation Agreement came into effect in 1975. Before that, such pensions were subject to tax in the Netherlands and so were exempt from Australian tax in the hands of an Australian resident recipient under provisions in the Australian law designed to avoid double taxation of overseas income of Australian residents subject to tax in the country of origin.

(2) Two members of Taxation Board of Review No. 3-in a decision of 10 June 1981 in a case involving the application of an exemption provision, paragraph 23AD (3) (c), of the Income Tax Assessment Act-did refer to the limited operation of the provision, in holding that it did not apply to exempt from Australian income tax the Dutch compensation pension received by the taxpayer concerned. The third member dissented.
(3) I am unaware of such a resolution.

(4) The Government is currently reviewing the taxation treatment of certain war related foreign pensions received by Australian residents, including pensions of the kind referred to in this question paid by the Netherlands.
(5) I have no authority to issue such an instruction.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Foreign Investment Review Board have a majority of Australian equity in all new projects approved by the Board.
(2) Does the table 1.7 of the Board's 1980 Report show that only one-quarter of expected investment is Australian; is the majority Australian ownership policy not being achieved.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The general objective of the Government's foreign investment policy is to seek Australian equity participation to the extent appropriate to the particular circumstances of each foreign investment proposal. There are specific guidelines for Australian equity participation in respect of new natural resource projects.

Under these guidelines, the Government expects new projects for the mining and production of uranium to have 75 per cent Australian equity and to be Australian-controlled. In cases where 75 per cent Australian equity is clearly unobtainable, alternative proposals incorporating not less than 50 per cent Australian equity will be considered, provided certain conditions are satisfied. Where projects do not have 75 per cent Australian equity, arrangments may be required to increase Australian participation over an agreed period.

A proposal for a new business or project in the mining (other than uranium), agriculture, pastoral, fishing and forestry industries involving a total investment of $5m or more will, as a general rule, only be allowed to proceed if it has a minimum 50 per cent Australian equity together with at least 50 per cent of the voting strength on the board or controlling body held by Australian interests. Where the Government judges that the unavailability of sufficient Australian equity capital on reasonable terms and conditions would unduly delay the development of Australia's natural resources, projects that are not contrary to the national interest may be allowed to proceed with less than 50 per cent Australian equity. In these circumstances, however, the Government will, as appropriate, seek satisfactory arrangements for Australian equity to be increased to at least 50 per cent within an agreed period. the Government may also seek 50 per cent Australian equity participation in proposed investments in other sectors of the economy, such as those where foreign investment is subject to restrictions, and in cases where the investment is to be undertaken in areas of the economy where foreign ownership and control is extensive.

(2) The expenditure identified in table 1.7 of the Foreign Investment Review Board 1980 Report as originating from Australia represents the expected contribution by Australian-controlled companies and Australian residents to the total expected expenditure associated with all foreign investment proposals approved by the Government. The table indicates that around one-quarter of the total expected expenditure was attributable to Australian investors.

This statistic relates to total expected investment associated with proposals for foreign investment in all sectors of the economy, and it is not, therefore, indicative of the results that have been achieved in the implementation of the Australian equity participation guidelines that apply to the natural resources sector. In this regard, it is noted that in the two years to 30 June 1981, ten of the fourteen proposals for natural resource development projects that were approved under foreign investment policy provided for at least the guideline level of Australian equity participation; the other four projects were required, as a condition of approval, to meet the guideline before production commenced.

Table 1.7, of course, only records investments which require approval under the foreign investment policy. The table does not, therefore, provide a measure of the overall Australian/foreign shares in the total investment undertaken in the Australian economy.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 28 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What case was advanced by the New South Wales Yellow Maize Marketing Board in support of its claim for $50,000 compensation for losses due to the grain export embargo to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, referred to in question 1174 (See answer to Senate Question on Notice No. 1174, Hansard, 14 October 1981, page 1525).
(2) What are the reasons for the rejection of the case, identifying specifically which guidelines it did not meet.
(3) Did the guidelines lay down that compensation is not payable if the actual on-farm returns to growers were above those that would have been received if the embargo had not applied.
(4) What were the relevant guidelines.
(5) What volume of maize was sold in the premium market which the Minister says developed during the period for which exports were affected by the embargo.
(6) What volume of maize would have been exported during the same period.

(7) Can it be shown that, had the grain exports continued at the same time as the premium market developed, the price would not have been higher, due to the reduced supply on the premium market; if not, is it presumed that it would have been higher.

(8) Can it be shown that a combination of export sales plus domestic sales at a price which, in the absence of proof otherwise may be presumed to have been higher, would not have yielded growers a greater on-farm return than they received under the actual situation; if not, what is the explanation of the grounds on which the claim was rejected.
(9) Do the guidelines provide that the government does not have to conclusively establish that no losses were incurred before a compensation claim can be rejected.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (9) The Yellow Maize Marketing Board for the State of New South Wales (Maize Board) submitted that in September 1979 it adopted an export strategy for the 1980 maize crop and that, in developing and seeking to implement this strategy, it incurred direct costs which it was unable to recoup from sales on the export market (because the entire crop was ultimately sold on the domestic market). It maintained that it should be compensated for these 'export costs'.

The Maize Board's claim was refused because it did not fall within the compensation guidelines that payments will only be made in respect of total unrecouped expenditure (excluding profits forgone, or reduced profits, and allowances for overhead expenses), after every effort has been made to find alternative markets and where sales had been affected at a loss. Although the 'export costs' were not recouped from sales on the export market, the returns from sales on the domestic market were more than sufficient to recoup the 'export costs' and still provide higher net returns to growers than they would have achieved from the disallowed sale to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Thus the Government's action did not lead to sales being effected at a loss.

As figures are not available of the quantity of maize retained on the farm, it is not possible to accurately determine the volume of maize sold in the premium domestic market. However, total Australian production of maize from the 1980 crop has been estimated at 151,000 tonnes, and total Australian maize exports in 1980 were approximately 30,000 tonnes.

It is unlikely that the export of maize delivered to the Maize Board would have significantly affected prices on the domestic premium market principally because of the much larger quantities of other grains, particularly wheat, that were being sold for stock feed at this time. Even if prices had been affected, however, the Maize Board would have been unable to exploit this situation as all of the maize delivered to it would previously have been contracted for supply to Exportkhleb (I am advised that the disallowed offer from Exportkhleb, the Soviet agency, was for up to 25,000 tonnes of maize (with a minimum of 15,000 tonnes) and that actual deliveries to the Maize Board were approximately 50,000 tonnes).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 28 October 1981: (1) Did Australia support the adoption of the United Nations Declaration of the Rights of the Child.

QUESTION.PARA: (2) Does Australia fully recognise those rights.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the 1981-82 Budget Paper No. 1, on page 41, state that the Australian dollar had appreciated by 9.3 per cent against the trade-weighted index of foreign currencies and did it also state on page 41 that the appreciation was required to increase imports and by the 'need for the savings/investment identity to be equilibrated.'
(2) In what sense were savings and investment not equal.

(3) Did the Treasurer receive advice to the effect that an appreciation was required to increase imports and equilibrate savings and investment; if so, (a) what was the nature of that advice; and (b) did that advice also contain the argument that a higher level of economic activity, at the same exchange rate, would have been consistent with a higher level of imports and a higher level of savings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The savings/investment identity in a national accounting framework must always, by definition, be equal. Since the demand for investment usually exceeds the availability of domestic savings, Australia is traditionally a net importer of capital which finances a real net inflow of goods and services from the rest of the world. This enables Australia to achieve a higher level of domestic capital formation, and therefore a higher rate of economic growth, than would result from investment generated by domestic savings alone. The supplement to domestic savings, or the increase in net indebtedness overseas, is represented by the deficit on the current account of the balance of payments. In 1980-81, the full rise in private sector investment could not have been achieved unless that level of domestic savings had been supplemented either by a lower level of private consumption and/or government expenditure, or by a larger current account deficit; otherwise, there would have been insufficient savings for the saving/investment identity to be equilibrated at its potentially higher level.

(3) In this and in a number of similar questions, the honourable senator has requested information on the nature of advice that I have received in relation to passages contained in the Budget documents. I can assure the honourable senator that I have received advice, from a number of sources and in a number of ways, in respect of each of the matters raised. It has been a long-standing practice of this Parliament, as of others, that such advice is a matter of confidence between a Minister and his advisers.

(2) From April 1978, Mr Waldron was an Engineer Class 4 in Broadcasting Engineering Division of the then Postal and Telecommunications Department. In June 1980 he was promoted as Assistant Secretary, Station Planning Branch and remained in this position until his resignation. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice on 28 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are Australian sheep on board carriers on their way to the Middle East thrown overboard whilst still alive, as eyewitnesses claim.
(2) Did 9,000 sheep suffocate on The Persia which sailed from Fremantle on 2 September, under charter to an Irish company, Purcell Bros, and owned by the Lebanese company, Rachid Fares.
(3) Did not Mr Nixon promise in Parliament on April 8, 1981 that if requirements for the live export trade were not met, sheep would not be sent.
(4) What measures did the Australian Government take to ensure that port facilities in El Adabia were adequate.

(5) Has a Government representative, or a representative of the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, which issues the export licences, flown to El Adabia to educate the Egyptian people on the handling of live sheep; if not, why not.
(6) Due to the unseaworthiness of The Persia, which is said to be about thirty years old, should not the Australian government have refused to allow it to carry live sheep.
(7) What steps has the government taken to implement the promises of the Minister to tighten up regulations controlling the export of live sheep.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Reports received from Government officers who have accompanied live sheep carriers to the Middle East state that this is not the case. All sheep are destroyed prior to disposal of the bodies. If the honourable senator can provide documentary evidence of this claim investigations will be made into it and disciplinary action taken as necessary.

(2) On the voyage of The Persia referred to losses attributed to ventilation failure occurred on 4 and 8 September 1981. The losses in these two incidents totalled 1269 sheep. A further 7495 sheep died from a breakdown in plant which provides water and from other causes.

(3) On 8 April 1981 I tabled a report 'Sea Transport of Sheep' and made a statement outlining my intentions regarding the conduct of the trade. I am informed that the sheep loaded onto The Persia for the voyage in question were inspected both at the feed-lot and at the time of loading and were found to be healthy and in good condition to travel. The high loss rate for this voyage is not in any way attributable to failure to observe the standards for the preparation and carriage of sheep by sea.

(4) No measures were taken by the Australian Government to ensure the port facilities at El Adabia were adequate. This is a matter of normal trade agreement and government intervention would not be warranted unless it was shown that problems are occurring.

As Egypt has just recommenced the importation of live sheep there has been no liaison with Egypt by Government representatives or Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation officers to date. Governments are loath to advise other countries on how to run their affairs unless asked to do so. Knowledgeable officers will be made available to advise Egypt on husbandry matters if a request for assistance is received. As part of its ongoing program of technical liaison relating to livestock exports a senior veterinary officer of the Australian Bureau of Animal Health is to visit the Middle East in November-December 1981. Matters of sheep husbandry relevant to the trade in livestock including facilities will be discussed.
(6) The approval of vessels for the carriage of livestock comes under the control of the Minister for Transport to whom questions of this nature should be directed.

(7) The Australian Bureau of Animal Health has again updated its standards for the preparation and carriage of livestock by sea. These have been forwarded to all parties involved in the trade for comment. These standards are to be implemented in the near future and I have informed the industry that these standards must be met.
Veterinary officers of the Australian Bureau of Animal Health are carrying out inspections to ensure the various standards are being met by the industry. This program will continue.
My colleague the Minister for Transport is shortly to introduce revised Marine Orders to give greater control over vessels engaged in the carriage of livestock by sea.

Steps have been taken to increase research inputs into the industry. Funds have been made available to enable veterinarians or other scientists to accompany livestock vessels to collect data, to make observations and to carry out research relevant to the industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 11 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What disposal procedures are currently being implemented for nuclear waste material generated at the Lucas Heights and Hunters Hill establishments.
(2) Is there a waste storage depot in Australia.
(3) With the devolution of nuclear responsibilities to the States and the Northern Territory, will the Commonwealth or the States be responsible for nuclear waste disposal.
(4) Will the Commonwealth retain an override authority if the States and the Northern Territory assume such responsibility.
(5) Have any guarantees been given by the States or the Northern Territory in relation to waste disposal; if so, what are they.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Arrangements for storage or disposal of wastes generated at Lucas Heights were given in answer to the HOR Question No. 176 on 2 June 1977. Since then the only change has been that, in relation to low level liquid waste, the treated water is now discharged to the Sydney Metropolitan Water Sewerage and Drainage Board's sewer, rather than to the Woronora River.

There is no establishment at Hunters Hill New South Wales generating nuclear waste. As a result of radium extraction processing operations early this century there is some soil in the Hunters Hill area registering low levels of radioactive contamination. The New South Wales Government is seeking to dispose of this soil and the Commonwealth Government has undertaken to assist financially and technically with this disposal.

(2), (3), (4) and (5) Uniform arrangements for management and disposal of nuclear wastes are subject to continuing development, in consultation with the States and the Northern Territory. On 21 November the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment made available for public comment a proposed Code of Practice on the Management of Radioactive Wastes from the Mining and Milling of Radioactive Ores.

Arrangements for the management and disposal of radioactive wastes arising from medical, research and industrial applications, were dealth with comprehensively in my reply of 6 May 1981 (Senate Hansard, pages 1717-18) to a question without notice from Senator Mason.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Why has the pensioner funeral benefit not altered since it was raised from the imperial equivalent of $20 to $40 in the 1965 Budget. Why was the funeral benefit offered to TPI pensioners in the last budget of $400 not offered to civilian pensioners who also have given a lifetime of service and taxation to this country.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Australian Governments have for many years provided special assistance to Repatriation disability pensioners in recognition of incapacity arising from war service.

In assessing the merit of increasing the rate of funeral benefit in respect of Social Security pensioners, the Government has regard both to the need for continued expenditure restraint and to its other priorities in the social welfare area.
These matters are subject to consideration in the Budget context.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 10 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the introduction of passports between the Australian mainland and Norfolk Island, which is a part of the Commonwealth of Australia, a precedent hindering the free flow of citizens within the Commonwealth. Does any other country demand the production of a passport for movement within the borders of that country; if so which countries.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In accordance with the wishes of the Norfolk Island authorities the Migration Act which controls entry to Australia does not extend to the territory of Norfolk Island. As a result, to maintain the security of Australia's entry controls, it is essential to have some form of identity check on travellers from Norfolk Island.

Australian citizens do not require a visa or any other form of formal authority to visit Norfolk Island and the passport requirement cannot be said to be any significant hindrance to free movement. The requirement of a passport is a small inconvenience when considered in relation to the importance of maintaining proper protection of Australian society from those who might wish to enter Australia anonymously for illegal purposes.
Inquiries about domestic travel regulations of other countries should be directed to the appropriate authorities in those countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 11 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the decision to further increase tuition fees for overseas students by 10 per cent in 1982:
(a) create great hardship for families of these students from developing countries;
(b) aggravate relations with those countries producing students as has already occurred to some degree with Malaysia;
(c) force many of these students to lose the opportunity of a worthwhile education due to financial insecurity in Australia and the lack of educational facilities in their homelands; and
(d) limit the valuable research that these students are performing in Australian tertiary institutions.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) No. The adjustment of around 10 per cent in the overseas student charge from January 1982 is the only variation in the charge since it came into effect in 1980 and is considerably less than the increase in education costs since that time.

(b) Other comparable training countries such as the United Kingdom, United States of America, Canada and New Zealand also impose similar and in some cases much higher charges than those in Australia. It is not considered that Australia's relations with countries from which overseas students come have been adversely affected by the introduction of charges which represent less than 40 per cent of the total average recurrent educational costs involved. It is reasonable to ask overseas students or their sponsors to make a contribution towards their education, from which they benefit, which is funded by Australians through taxation revenue to which overseas students do not make any significant contribution.
(c) and (d) the number of overseas students coming to Australia has in fact increased since the introduction of charges.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and environment, upon notice, on 12 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister for Home Affairs and the Environment expedite the implementation of the Kakadu National Park Plan of Management so as to ensure an ecologically sound system of development for this Park which is an extraordinary asset for the future of all Australians and indeed the world.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Kakadu was recognised as being of international significance for both its natural and cultural properties when it was included on the World Heritage list on 26 October 1981.
The Plan of Management for Kakadu National Park came into effect on 2 April 1981 and sets down the proposed form of management and development of the Park for a five year period.

As required by the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, public submissions in relation to the Plan were considered and the Plan itself was subject to public comment and subsequent modification prior to its submission to both Houses of Parliament.

The Plan takes particular account of Aboriginal aspirations and the development of facilities for public enjoyment of the area whilst ensuring the protection of the natural and cultural attributes of the Park.

The Appropriation for capital expenditure at Kakadu was $1.8m for the financial year 1981-82. Good progress has been made in the provision of facilities, staff accommodation and the protection of ecosystems and Aboriginal art sites.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 12 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: For the purpose of assessing eligibility for a Health Care Card, will the Department of Social Security regard a family as having acquired an additional dependent immediately on the birth of a child or not until four weeks later, because of the requirement that the family's income be below the cut-off point for eligibility for a Health Care Card for a period of four weeks before the application.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: On the birth of an additional child into a family already in possession of a Health Care Card, that child is entitled to immediate cover in respect of health care benefits. Where a person applies for a Health Care Card immediately following the birth of a child, the eligibility of that person would be determined having regard to the family income in the preceding four weeks. If that income was within the eligibility limits, and these limits would include an additional amount in respect of the newly born child, that person and his dependants, including the newly born child, would be entitled to health care benefits as from the date of application.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 12 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: What progress has been made in negotiations between Australia and Vietnam for a migration agreement under which close relatives of people already in Australia can migrate directly from Vietnam to Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Negotiations with the Vietnamese authorities on this issue were resumed in February this year after the failure of earlier approaches. At that time a detailed proposal for the establishment of a family reunion based migration program was put to the Vietnamese.
Following Vietnamese agreement, a negotiating team from the Department visited Hanoi between 22-29 July to discuss the establishment of a migration program.
While the talks were helpful there are a number of important matters that still require resolution. Further exchanges on these issues are being handled through the Australian Embassy in Hanoi.
Although some progress has been achieved in the period since February, it is difficult to predict when final agreement might take place.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Consultative Council on Social Welfare

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the present National Consultative Council on Social Welfare have either an economist or lawyer as a member of the Council; if not, is this the first time the Council has functioned without such expertise in its membership.
(2) Can the council call on departmental legal and economic advice when it is required.
(3) In the reconstructed Council, will a senior staff member sit in on its deliberations.
(4) What departmental support will be given to the Council.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) On 16 October 1981, I announced the formation of a new 16 member National Consultative Council on Social Security. The formation of a new National Council was recommended by the Government's Review of Commonwealth Functions and has replaced the National Consultative Council on Social Welfare, the Women's Welfare Issues Consultative Committee and the Homeless Persons Advisory Committees.

In considering the membership of the Council it was necessary to select a group of people whose specialist knowledge would cover a wide range of social welfare issues relevant to my portfolio. Understandably, it was not possible to include all possible areas of interest and expertise. However, the Council is able to call in economic and legal advice from the Department of Social Security and is also able to draw on the expertise of its State and Territory Consultative Committees on Social Welfare whose members include economists and lawyers.

(3) and (4) Senior officers from the Department of Social Security are not formal members of the restructured Council but are available as required, to discuss issues the Council may wish to pursue. A small Secretariat within the Department also assists the Council.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 24 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs say in the Senate on 20 October 1981 in relation to negotiations between the Northern Land Council and Pancontinental Mining Ltd and Denison Mines Ltd that 'A conflict could arise if I were to try to be at the one time both a participant in the negotiating process and the person who has to approve any agreement that is reached.'

(3) How do the current negotiations differ from those which lead to the signing of the Ranger Agreement, especially with regard to the potential for the kind of conflict which he himself wished to avoid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Government in 1977 decided not to disturb the arrangements entered into in October 1975 between the Commonwealth and the Ranger partners. The Atomic Energy Act was therefore used for the granting of authority to mine uranium at Ranger and the Commonwealth was required to negotiate an agreement with the Northern Land Council on terms and conditions for mining at Ranger. The negotiations were conducted for the Commonwealth by a team of officials instructed by the Government, of which the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs was a member. The Minister gave his approval to the agreement.

(3) The present negotiations between the Northern Land Council and Pancontinental Mining Ltd and Denison Mines Ltd differ from those which led to the signing of the Ranger Agreement in that the Commonwealth is not negotiating these agreements.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Are Timorese immigrants forced to pay expenses consisting of bribes (40 per cent), internal airfares within Indonesia (14 per cent), accommodation in Jakarta while awaiting permission to leave (27 per cent) and international airfares (18 per cent) of almost $9,000; if so, what action has the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs taken to minimise or reduce these expenses for intending immigrants.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: From time to time, allegations are made that bribes are sought. Naturally, we are concerned about such allegations and have brought them to the attention of the authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are intending Timorese migrants required to get documents from Indonesian officials; if so, is bribe money paid for such documents.
(2) Have Timorese migrants told any officials of the Department of Immigration about bribes they had to pay to Indonesian officials.
(3) Is it intended to re-open negotiations with Indonesia to extend the 'Agreed List' of 600.
(4) Has the Department of Immigration been requested to send a team to Dili to deal directly with Timorese who wish to come to Australia.
(5) How many Timorese now in Portugal and with no relatives in Australia wish to migrate.

The suggestion has been considered carefully but it is clear from recent exchanges with the Indonesian authorities that there would be no particular advantage in seeking agreement to send such a mission to Timor.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 25 November 1981:

(2) In each case with what organisations and on what level has the Minister for Social Security consulted on the recommendations of the reports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 March 1981 (Hansard, page 491), Senator Thomas asked the Minister representing the Treasurer the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and relates to section 36AAA of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Footrot is a serious stock disease and is increasing in some States of Australia. Traditional control methods are expensive, painful to the stock very time consuming, and not always successful. The costs are deductible in the financial year of expenditure. A more satisfactory solution is to sell all susceptible stock on the farm and replace them after a few weeks, by which time the footrot virus will already have died on the farm. The profit made from the sale of those tock is subject to taxation, which in some cases can be about equal to the value of the stock sold. Will the Minister suggest to the Treasurer that he consider amending section 36AAA with a view to stopping the discouragement of farmers from adopting better farming practices.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Section 36AAA was amended last year to enable a primary producer to elect to have the section apply to the proceeds resulting from the compulsory destruction of livestock in compliance with a law for the control or eradication of a disease or from the death of stock from such a disease. As a consequence of the amendment, profit on the disposal or death of the livestock may be deducted from the total proceeds received from the death or destruction that are required to be included in the taxpayer's assessable income and instead be applied to reduce for tax purposes the cost of replacement livestock acquired during the income year in which the death or destruction occurred or any of the five succeeding years. Any profit unapplied at the end of the last of those years is included in the assessable income of that year.

The Commissioner of Taxation has recently had occasion to review the operation of section 36AAA in relation to the treatment of footrot in sheep and, in so doing, to examine the various State and Territory laws that govern the control of stock diseases. As a result of the review it has been concluded that section 36AAA may be applied in cases where the relevant law makes provision for the compulsory destruction of sheep affected by footrot and where, on the advice of an appropriate official such as a district veterinary officer of a State Agriculture Department, sheep that have been officially quarantined for the treatment of footrot are sold direct to an abattoir for slaughter as the most effective means of eradicating the disease. The section will not apply, however, if the relevant law does not provide for compulsory destruction and a farmer decides to sell affected animals, or if no official quarantine has been imposed.

Graziers will thus be able to take advantage of section 36AAA to minimize the taxation consequences of any genuinely forced sales for slaughter of the whole or a substantial part of their flocks because of footrot, without the need for further amendment of the section.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 August 1981 (Hansard, page 323), Senator Jessop asked the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the tremendous damage being caused to Australia's reputation as a reliable international trading partner by industrial disputes which are interfering with our exports.

Is the Minister aware of statements made on Monday by Mr Bowen, the executive director of the Chamber of Shipping (Australian), in an appeal to the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions for help in resolving industrial disputes? Mr Bowen said that more than 60 ships around Australia were being delayed by industrial disputes or union bans and that the industry was losing $1m a day, while the loss in exports added many millions of dollars to that figure, to say nothing of the loss of jobs and employment opportunities. As many of these disputes involve demarcation arguments between unions, has the Government considered altering the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to encourage these disputes being resolved by the ACTU and to prevent such industrial disputation spreading to the detriment of the welfare of other workers not involved?
The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I appreciate the honourable senator's concern about this matter. It is true that demarcation disputes between trade unions have disrupted Australian maritime and stevedoring operations in recent years with serious consequences for both our export trade and our reputation as a reliable supplier. Such disputes are particularly frustrating and pointless.

The Government has felt that the best hope for successful and enduring resolution of disputes between unions lay with the trade union movememt itself. The ACTU appears to recognise the undesirability of the present situation and has made initiatives aimed at eliminating demarcation disputes. If the self-regulatory procedures which the ACTU is endeavouring to establish cannot resolve particular disputes then unions should make use of and abide by the decisions of arbitral tribunals which in the case of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has power to grant exclusive rights of coverage. This capacity was conferred upon the Commission in amendments to the Conciliation and Arbitration Act passed in 1979.

Peak Council concern about this issue has been recognised and discussions between the ACTU and the Confederation of Australian Industry are continuing under the auspices of the National Labour Consultative Council.

It has been suggested that the facilitation of trade union amalgamations or the formation of industry unions could lead to a reduction of demarcation disputes. While recognising that neither measure would solve the problem completely, the Government is closely examining legislative procedures and provisions in this regard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 August 1981 (Hansard, page 378) Senator Button asked the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Whether it is a fact that no implementation details have yet been decided, nor any effects calculated, of the Prime Minister's announced decision of 12 August to drop the 'Buy Australian' policy in Government purchasing. How does the Government reconcile this decision with its frequent advocacy of development of high technology industries in Australia, such as the computer industry which was specifically referred to as an example in a speech by the Minister for Science and Technology in July. Does the United States, by contrast, apply a 50 per cent national duty on all imported high technology brought by the United States Government? Also whether it is not a fact that Telecom Australia is the largest purchaser of high technology equipment in Australia and that that organisation has a policy, or has had a policy, of buying up to 80 per cent Australian Technology.
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

On 5 August 1981 the Prime Minister announced in the context of his Statement on Economic Policy that the Government would be acting to eliminate its purchasing policy in preference to Australian goods except for certain defence strategic industries.

At the time of the honourable senator's question the Government had under consideration its revised preference policy. On 18 October I announced details of the revised policy and associated administrative arrangements. My statement indicated that the Government had decided to include high technology as well as defence strategic areas of industry under its revised preference policy.

The reduction in Australian preference decision was one of a number of measures adopted by the Government to further its overall economic objective of reducing inflation as a pre-condition for establishing economic growth with increased employment opportunities and higher living standards. However, as the estimated value of Commonwealth Government purchasing represents about 2 per cent of total manufacturing sales in Australia, the elimination of the preference to Australian goods policy is unlikely to have a major impact on the Australian industry generally.

The United States does not have a purchasing policy dealing specifically with high technology products. The Buy American Act (1933) provides a general preference of 6 per cent to all American products and a preference of 12 per cent to products from 'small business' firms, or from firms in designated 'labour surplus' areas. These preferences are applied to the duty paid price of imported products which are products with less than 50 per cent American content.

A 50 per cent preference may be applied in the United States Defence purchases of military products as a balance of payments measure. For military products a preference is applied on the basis of either 50 per cent of the duty free delivered price or 6 per cent of the duty paid price of imports which ever is higher.
The Minister for Communications has provided me with an answer to that portion of the honourable senator's question on Telecom Australia.

Telecom has followed the consistent practice of requiring all of its major telecommunications products to be made by Australian industry. In 1977, when introducing a new system of local exchange switching equipment using stored programme controlled techniques, an Australian content of 80 per cent was stipulated. As a consequence of its dedication to local sourcing, 90 per cent of all telecommunications supplies are obtained from Australian industry sources.
Telecom is certainly a very large purchaser of high technology equipment in Australia and has done much to foster the local telecommunications manufacturing industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 9 September 1981 (Hansard, page 556) Senator Haines asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question concerned an ethnic communities forum held in Western Australia on 3 September 1981.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am informed that an officer of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs attended a public forum in Perth on 3 September 1981. The meeting was announced in a Press release and received advance media coverage. I am informed that the purpose of the meeting was to discuss immigration and migrant settlement policies and that the officer who had long played a prominent role, in his private capacity within the ethnic communities of Western Australia, attended that meeting in a private capacity.

I am informed that the officer recorded some statements made to assist him in compiling a record of the proceedings at the meeting. I am also informed that a full tape-recording of the meeting was made by someone from Perth radio station 6NR.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 (Hansard pages 892-893) Senator Ryan asked me the following question, without notice, concerning the distribution of the film On Sacred Ground:

The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
