Film Australia has further advised that where prints of the film are sold or otherwise made available to an individual or organisation, that individual or organisation may determine when, where and to whom the film will be screened.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 15 October 1981 (Hansard page 1268) Senator Gietzelt asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question was:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration received representations from individuals and groups concerning the current state of adult migrant education services? What has been the Government's response to these representations, if any, and what measures are proposed to remedy the problems raised-in particular the demand for adult migrant education far exceeding supply, the low provision of a permanent teaching force in adult migrant English education and the failure of Government policy to reach the Galbally targets concerning adult migrant English and on-arrival English education?
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
Yes. I have received a number of representations from New South Wales.

The current level of program activity in New South Wales is meeting for the most part the present rate of applications for English language and information courses. Within the context of some 17,500 persons attending courses and other learning arrangements in the Adult Migrant Education Program at any one time in New South Wales, there were (at the end of October):
510 applicants in migrant settlement centres seeking on-arrival courses (of these almost all will have received offers of a place in a course by the end of November), and
at Community Centres, 437 awaiting on-arrival courses, 472 awaiting full-time on-going courses and 88 awaiting part-time on-going courses.

Because courses are grouped and start at the same time, persons who apply after the commencement of a course may have to wait up to 12 weeks until the next group of courses commences. Those who apply now (November 1981) will have to wait until early 1982 to commence a course.

Teachers in the State Adult Migrant Education Services are employed by State authorities, which determine the terms of employment of their teaching staff. For the most part the Adult Migrant Education Services are staffed by full time temporary and hourly-paid teachers. There are permanent teachers in New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia, Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. A number of the teachers in those services have worked in them for some years. There does not seem to be any undue or abnormal wastage or turnover of staff. Also the Adult Migrant Education Program is a special program of limited size and is thus different to other broader areas of education. That program should be staffed and organised in a way which allows the services within the program to be provided to meet changing needs arising from variations in migrant intake and location. Given this need for flexibility and the mix of full and part time teachers within the services, the most appropriate arrangement would appear to be a core of permanent teachers supported by non-permanent staff as the need arises.

As a result of the steps taken by the Government subsequent to its acceptance of the recommendations of the Report of the Review of Post-Arrival Programs and Services for Migrants (the Galbally Report), the target for 1980-81 of 15,000 non-English speaking enrollees nationally in the on-arrival program was exceeded. It is estimated that over 16,000 such migrants undertook these courses in that year. Targets given in the Galbally Report for enrolments in the on-arrival program included a component of English language speakers who were to participate in the information aspects of the on-arrival program. The 1980-81 target of 18,000 newly arrived persons in the Galbally Report included information programs for 3,000 English speakers. That aspect of the overall target for 1980-81 has not been met because priority was given to non-English speakers and because of the information services available to English speakers throughout the community and at Migrant Resource Centres.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1445) Senator Jessop asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and ask whether he has noted a Press report indicating that ICI Australia Ltd has shelved a $500m petrochemical project in Victoria because of high local costs and the rise in the value of the Australian dollar? Is the Minister aware that another prime reason for this decision involved the doubts associated with the capacity of that company to deliver its product on the international market due to the general industrial disruption affecting the Australian waterfront? As my attention has been drawn to other companies in Australia which are in a similar position and which are contemplating withdrawing from Australia-two of them are considering establishing their industries in South Africa and Indonesia because of the assurance that their products can be delivered on the world market on time-I ask whether the Government is proposing to do anything to retain in Australia these industries which are so important to employment opportunities in this country? Also, does the Government propose to do anything in the interest of restoring our credibility as a reliable international trading partner?

The Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations in responding to the question undertook to obtain from the Minister for Industry and Commerce additional information on the precise reasons for the ICI decision not to proceed.
The Minister for Industry and Commerce has provided the following information:

ICI's decision to defer indefinitely the development of its proposed petrochemical and chloralkali complex at Point Wilson took into account a number of factors. The decision was reached after two years of detailed technical, commercial and environmental studies costing more than $2 million.

The feasibility study into the project would necessarily have examined the prospects of selling the corporation's output a number of years ahead. That study would have been influenced by conditions in the world market, and, in particular, by the major structural redevelopments taking place in the world petrochemical industry. This restructuring was sparked off by the oil price increases. It has been accelerated by the present depressed state of the world petrochemical market and the desire by some oil-producing countries to broaden their industrial base through the development of export-oriented petrochemical industries.

The company's decision should be kept in perspective, reflecting as it does conditions in the international chemical industry. The Chairman of ICI Mr Milton Bridgland has said that there was very little the Government could do to improve the economic attractiveness of the project in the short term.

ICI has pointed out that continually mounting wage costs and movements in currency values have affected export and import competing industries. The Australian petrochemical industry is presently experiencing severe import competition.

In respect of wage costs, the company said that excessive wage movements, particularly arising from a shorter working week, seemed likely to have a serious affect on many other cost factors, most importantly construction costs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 21 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1436) Senator Robertson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Will the Government give an assurance that uranium will never be mined in Kakadu National Park if it is placed in the World Heritage List.

TALK.START.PARA: —the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: As Senator Robertson may be aware, the Kakadu National Park was accepted for inclusion on the World Heritage List on 26 October 1981.

With regard to mining in the Kakadu National Park, there is no existing mine in the Park and none is proposed. In line with the initiative to include the Kakadu National Park in the World Heritage List, the government has taken steps to conserve and fully protect the natural features of the Park through a Plan of Management prepared in accordance with the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. Any future mining activities would only be permitted after very careful consideration and then in accordance with the Plan of Management.
Most of the Kakadu National Park is established on Aboriginal land and, as such, any future use of the land would need to be consistent with the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1531), Senator Elstob asked the Leader of the Government in the Senate a question, without notice, concerning foreign ownership of land in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Carrick undertook to refer the question to the Treasurer who has provided the following answer:

The subject of foreign investment in Australian rural land was discussed at the Australian Agricultural Council meeting of State and Federal Ministers of Agriculture and Primary Industry in Darwin recently. It was agreed that there would be further consultation with the State Governments to obtain their views on measures to obtain additional information on foreign beneficial ownership of rural land, and this is taking place.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: New South Wales Railway Fare Increases

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 October 1981 (Hansard, pages 1536-7), Senator Lajovic asked me, as the Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning the effect on inflation of the 18-25 per cent increases in railways fares and freight charges imposed by the New South Wales Government.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
The increases in railway fares and freight charges would have a two-fold effect on consumer prices, as measured by the Consumer Price Index.

First, there would be the direct effect on the consumer price index resulting from the railway fares increase. Public transport fares are a component of the consumer price index and it is therefore possible to derive an estimate of the effect on the consumer price index of an increase in such fares. Second, there would be indirect effects on the consumer price index resulting from the passing on to consumers of some or all of the increased costs faced by various industries as a result of higher freight charges.

As at the September quarter 1981 rail fares contributed 0.664 per cent to the All Groups consumer price index for Sydney. It follows that the direct effect of an 18-25 per cent increase in rail fares would be to increase the consumer price index for Sydney by 0.12-0.17 per cent. The corresponding effect on the six-capitals consumer price index would be 0.04-0.06 per cent.

However, it is not possible to provide an accurate estimate of the indirect effect on the consumer price index-that resulting from the increase in freight charges. That magnitude would depend on a number of factors, including overall macro-economic policy settings, the degree to which price increases are subsequently reflected in wages, the extent to which road or other transport will be substituted for rail because of the increases and the extent to which import competition restrains the passing on of cost increases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1721) Senator Giles asked a question, without notice, as to whether there is provision in the Social Services Act for the collection and utilisation of pension cheques by persons other than beneficiaries and if so, whether it is possible for approval to be given to a proprietor of a lodging house who is not registered to provide any form of medical or custodial care. Senator Giles also asked whether my department's records show possible abuses of such authorisation or whether a specific complaint is required before any investigation is made.

ANSWER.PARA: I answered Senator Giles question in part and undertook to have the points raised examined in order to determine whether a more detailed reply was in order.

Sub-section 40 (1) of the Social Services Act provides in respect of age, invalid and wife's pension that pension shall be paid to the pensioner or, on behalf of the pensioner, to such other person as the pensioner appoints. Similar provision exists in the Act in respect of widows pension and supporting parents benefits. The arrangement is essentially one between the pensioner and the person nominated. When a request is received for payment of a pension to another person, both the pensioner and the other person to receive payment on behalf of the pensioner are interviewed to ensure that each is aware of the responsibilities of both parties. If possible, the interview is conducted prior to the transfer of payments.

The majority of these payment arrangements are made within a family unit or where pensioners are residents of nursing homes or hostels registered under appropriate legislation, and the arrangements necessarily operate to the satisfaction of both partners.

There are a number of institutions to which special payment arrangements known as the group method have been approved. Pensioners residing in such an institution may request payment of their pension to the institution. The group cheque is not issued to a private individual but to the appropriate officer of the institution as payee, for example, 'The Secretary'. One cheque is forwarded to the institution covering payment for pensioners residing there who have chosen this option. When considering applications from institutions for inclusion in the group method the following principles are observed:

the circumstances justify payment by this method rather than to each pensioner individually; for example there may be a large number of pensioners involved or the institution may cater for senile patients.
each pensioner who is capable of looking after his or her own affairs has given consent in writing to the arrangements.

Section 43 of the Act provides that where the Director-General is satisfied for any reason that it is desirable for payment of the whole or portion of a pension to be made to any person, institution or authority, the Director-General may authorise payment.

However it is rare for the Director-General to authorise payment to another person without that person having been appointed by the pensioner. Such authorisations usually only occur where a person is mentally or physically incapable of appointing a nominee or where he is, for some valid reason, unable to manage his financial affairs.

Arrangements for payment of pension to another person on behalf of a pensioner are reviewed immediately there is any suggestion of abuse of the arrangements in an individual case. Similarly, where it becomes apparent to officers of my department in the normal course of review work that a pensioner is not capable of understanding the arrangements, they are required to satisfy themselves that the authorisation is authentic.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1981 (Hansard, pages 1809-1810) Senator Tate asked me a question, without notice, concerning a recent speech by Dr U. Lantzke, the Executive Director of the International Energy Agency.

ANSWER.PARA: I undertook to obtain a copy of Dr Lantzke's comments and put them under study, and I provide the following supplementary answer:

Member countries of the IEA including Australia, were not consulted prior to the release of the speech, nor would that have been expected. The Executive Director of the IEA was speaking in his own name and did not purport to express views on behalf of the Agency as a whole.

One newspaper report of Dr Lantzke's speech described it as an attack on US energy policies. Having read the speech I find it hard to agree with so colourful a description. The Executive Director did put views which differ in some respects from those held by the US Administration. The extent of Government intervention implied in Lantzke's speech plus his support for East-West energy relations are, I suggest, two areas where the current US Administration may not agree. On the other hand, Lantzke's comments would propably coincide with the views of other member countries of IEA. Overall, they reflect some of the ongoing discussion within the IEA. It should also be noted Dr Lantzke was responding to an invitation from the organisers of the occasion to be 'a bit provocative'.

Certainly the Government has considerable sympathy with some of his comments, particularly those on the dangers of complacency in the current relaxed conditions in the oil market and the importance of maintaining and intensifying our efforts to reduce dependence on oil.

There appears to have been no adverse reaction either from the USA or other members of the IEA to Lantzke's speech. Overall, the speech was an interesting and thought provoking contribution to the world energy debate.

Its overall theme-that despite the good progress in energy policy, the Western World is still vulnerable and cannot afford to relax its efforts-is one which is fully supported by the Australian Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1803) Senator Bjelke-Petersen asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning medical benefits for psychology services.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The Government recognises that there are many areas in the paramedical field which play a useful role in the well being of all Australians. However, it would be in direct conflict with the Government's policy of restraint in public expenditure for it to extend the medical benefits arrangements to cover psychology services or for that matter, services provided by a wide range of non-medical personnel such as occupational therapists, orthoptists, acupuncturists, physiotherapists and chiropodists. In fact, the Government receives many representations seeking extension of the medical benefits system to cover all of these services plus other items such as medical and surgical aids and appliances.

Because of the limited funds available, the Government believes that it should act to ensure that the basic health care needs of all Australians are protected. This it does through the provision of assistance for medical services.

I have recently received representations on this matter from the Australian College of Private Clinical Psychologists and representations on behalf of clinical psychologists from several honourable members.

While I have no doubt that clinical psychologists can assist people with specific health problems, and can be cost effective, I also believe that a similar observation can be made about the services provided by other health occupations which do not attract benefits under the Health Insurance Act. Consequently, the issue becomes one of either providing benefits for the services provided by all health occupations or setting criteria and priorities between occupations. The first option would involve substantial increases in costs, as there would be an increase in the utilisation of health services overall. The second is complex and would inevitably result in value judgments being made between occupations to determine to which occupations benefits should be extended. Extensions of this nature would be unlikely to be generally acceptable to the occupations excluded, or to the patients of those occupations.
In the current financial climate where the need for restraint in Government outlays is of critical importance, it would not be appropriate to consider any extensions of the benefit arrangements.

In respect of benefits provided by health insurance organisations, the Government has maintained a policy in relation to supplementary benefits tables provided by private health insurance organisations for ancillary services, of largely allowing these private health insurance organisations to determine for themselves the nature and extent of services they wish to cover and, to an extent, the terms and conditions applicable to the payment of such supplementary benefits.

Consequently, private health insurance organisations could extend and/or introduce a range of benefits for clinical psychology services if they wished to do so. Whether such action is taken, however, is a matter over which the organisations have discretion.

Very few health insurance organisations in Australia, except in Western Australia, provide benefits for psychology services. However, I understand that the Australian College of Private Clinical Psychologists is in the process of promoting the extension of benefits to cover clinical pyschology under the supplementary benefits tables of those organisations which currently do not provide such coverage.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 12 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2081) Senator Robert Ray asked me a question, without notice, about the timing of calculations of adjustments to the consumer price index (CPI) in Australia. Senator Ray asked whether it was true that in the CPI calculations by the Australian Bureau of Statistics the collation of fuel statistics is done at the exact middle of the quarter; that is, for the December quarter, at 15 November.

ANSWER.PARA: I said that I had seen this date and that I assumed he was quoting it correctly, but that I would check the point. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has indicated that prices used in compiling the electricity and gas components of the CPI are the prices charged to consumers whose meters were read on the middle day of the quarter; for example, 15 November in the case of the December quarter. Thus, the CPI for the December quarter 1981 will not reflect any increases in electricity charges in Victoria effective from 17 November 1981; such increases will be reflected in the CPI in the March quarter 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 September 1981 (Hansard, page 820) Senator Sibraa asked me, the Acting Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the future of the North Head Quarantine Station.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

There is no conflict between myself and the Minister for Administrative Services regarding the future of the Quarantine Station at North Head in Sydney. The honourable senator's question contains a number of statements that are not in accord with the facts which are as follows:

There has been a difference of opinion over very many years between the Commonwealth and the State regarding the ownership of the North Head land. In line with legal advice it has received, the Commonwealth has always asserted its ownership. In the Commonwealth's view, the question of leasing does not arise.

The entire Commonwealth holding at North Head (a total of 275.4 ha) was included in an agreement concluded between the Prime Minister and the Premier of New South Wales in 1979 concerning the exchange of certain Commonwealth and State lands in New South Wales including the Commonwealth holdings at North Head.

Under this agreement the Commonwealth undertook to release to the State, in two or more stages, the whole of the Commonwealth holdings at North Head. The 'first release' land of 172.9 ha was released at that time. The 'second release' lands (including the Quarantine Station, the School of Artillery and the Police College) were to be transferred as and when budget considerations permitted relocation of Commonwealth facilities or as the Commonwealth ceased to require the use of such facilities.

The New South Wales Government did not agree to pay the Commonwealth $5m to relocate the quarantine facilities. Relocation of the quarantine station was not a consideration when the land exchange agreement referred to above was concluded. The Prime Minister had already written to all State Premiers in 1977 with proposals for new human quarantine arrangements which involved, amongst other things, closure of all human quarantine stations (including the station at North Head) with the States accepting responsibility for selected operational human quarantine functions.

Under the land exchange agreement the New South Wales Government undertook to pay $5m to the Commonwealth as a contribution only to removal expenses incurred by the Commonwealth in relation to the release of the total Commonwealth North Head holdings; such payment to be credited proportionately to a 'pool' as this land was released. The pool was established under the agreement to cover the agreed prices debited and credited as the case might be, of all lands covered by the agreement (including the North Head holdings). The $5m had no relation whatsoever to the provision of alternate quarantine facilities. Indeed the $5m represented a small fraction only of the removal expenses for the School of Artillery and the Police College (estimated costs in 1978; $38m).

The Commonwealth has not asked the New South Wales Government to build a new quarantine station at a cost of $2m. Rather, the Commonwealth has been seeking to have New South Wales join with all other States in the new arrangements for human quarantine functions referred to above. These arrangements seek to integrate treatment, care and investigation of individual quarantine cases into Australia's health care delivery system for which the States have carriage. There are very few quarantinable diseases of concern which cannot be adequately treated in modern Australian hospital facilities. Under the new arrangements which now operate in relation to all States except New South Wales, States are reimbursed 100 per cent for operational quarantine functions undertaken on the Commonwealth's behalf.

The Commonwealth has also sought New South Wales participation in national arrangements which have now been formalised with all other States involving the use of a National High Security Quarantine Treatment Unit nearing completion at Fairfield, Victoria for the treatment of quarantine cases which cannot be safely treated in existing State hospital facilities (for example, suspected cases of viral haemorrhagic fever such as lassa fever).

Any such cases are to be transported to Fairfield from any Australian location by charter aircraft utilising specially designed microbiologically secure air transit isolators. The evacuation will be undertaken by a highly trained medical evacuation team drawn from the staff of the Fairfield Hospital.

Until New South Wales indicates its agreement to participate in the proposed arrangements outlined above, the station at North Head will continue to be required for a limited range of human quarantine functions, including the accommodation of unvaccinated persons from Yellow Fever endemic areas for the duration of the six day incubation period of this disease.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2259), Senator Primmer asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: By way of preface I point out that in the other place on 22 September, as reported on page 1585 of Hansard, Mr Anthony, when defending the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, from charges made in the Senate committee report on the Australian Dairy Corporation, said:

That is the Department of Primary Industry-has not blundered. If it did anything wrong, it was because it was conned by some very clever and very skilled people in the Australian Dairy Corporation . . .

Because of these conflicts of interest it seems to me that there were many occasions for various sectional interests to withhold information, to disguise the facts and to evade questions about the facts. It seems to me that some parties concerned have, over a long period, become skilled in withholding material facts, in diverting attention and generally circumventing the possibility of an inquiry or interest from the Department of Primary Industry and the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) and hence from this Parliament.'

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 November 1981 (Hansard, page 2335) Senator Mulvihill asked me a question, without notice, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in the Senate. The question was as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . I wonder what explanation will be given for the failure of the Government to bring in legislation to provide for the case of a resident migrant woman seeking citizenship who is presently denied the right to have her children on her citizenship certificate. My second query relates to the uniformity of electoral registration for overseas people which was promised by giving everyone now a permanent resident uniform entitlement, after an obligatory period, to vote in Australia.
The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
(a) The issues covered by the first query are complicated. Children who are under the age of 16 years may be granted Australian citizenship either by:
being included in the certificate granted to their responsible parent or guardian
being granted a citizenship certificate in their own right.

Under the Australian Citizenship Act 1948, the term 'responsible parent' of a child means 'the father of that child or, where the father is dead or the mother has been given the custody of the child by order of a court or the child was born out of wedlock and resided with the mother, means the mother of that child'.

The current legislation does not prevent a mother from including her children on her citizenship application. However, where she is not deemed to be the responsible parent, under present legislation the children would not be able to be included on her citizenship certificate if her application were approved.

When an application is lodged by or on behalf of a child under 16, it is the policy to seek the consent of the 'responsible parent'. Where the father is the 'responsible parent' and he refuses consent but the mother persists with a request that the child be granted Australian citizenship, the case is considered to ascertain whether Ministerial discretion to grant citizenship to minors in their own right should be exercised. In such cases account is taken of such factors as the views of the child, whether the child would be disadvantaged by not being granted Australian citizenship and the general family situation including future intentions regarding residence in Australia. If it were decided to grant the child citizenship, the child would be issued a citizenship certificate in his or her own right.

A review of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 is currently being undertaken and, in the course of that review, amendments are being considered to eliminate provisions which discriminate on the ground of sex.
(b) At the meeting on 14 and 15 April 1981 of Commonwealth, State and Territory Ministers responsible for immigration and ethnic affairs matters, agreement was reached on the following:

(1) Migrants, irrespective of their country of origin should be treated equally in relation to requirements to enrol, their right to vote at elections for parliament and nominate as candidates for election to parliament
(2) Australian citizenship should be the basis for the franchise
(3) No person currently enrolled as an elector should be disenfranchised
(4) Uniform legislation to give effect to the foregoing should be enacted by the Commonwealth and all States.
Ministers discussed progress in effecting this decision at their most recent meeting on 16 October 1981.
Parliament recently enacted the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1981 which amends the Commonwealth Electoral Act to implement these changes at the Federal level.
It is hoped to achieve a uniform Australia-wide commencement date as early as possible in 1982.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 19 November 1981, (Hansard, page 2341) Senator Tate asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources, the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it a fact that the International Bauxite Association Council had a meeting in Australia in the first week of November? Is it a fact that that Council recommended that, in view of the expected soft market situation for 1982, the price for base grade bauxite should, for references purposes, be set at two per cent of the average metal market list price for primary aluminium and soon for alumina? Do exporters of Australian bauxite and alumina regard themselves as bound by those recommendations? Whether the answer is yes or no, will the Australian Government be using its export controls over bauxite and alumina to ensure that the recommendations of the International Bauxite Association are adhered to in order to further the North-South dialogue to which this Prime Minister is committed, in the interests of those developing countries, particularly Jamaica, which would be well served by a strengthening of the cartel-like operations of the International Bauxite Association?
The Minister for trade and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Council of Ministers of the International Bauxite Association met in Canberra from 4 to 6 November. Australia was represented by the Minister for Trade and Resources.

The Council recommended that the minimum c.i.f. price index level for 1982 (on an equivalent base-grade basis) for metallurgical grade bauxite sold in North and South America and Europe should remain within the range of 2.5 per cent-3 per cent but in view of the expected soft market situation for 1982 the prices for base-grade bauxite should, for reference purposes, be set at 2 per cent of the average American Metal Market list price for 99.5 per cent purity primary aluminium ingot.

The Council of Ministers also recommended that the minimum c.i.f. price for alumina during 1982 should remain within the range of 16 per cent-19 per cent but in view of the expected soft market for 1982 the price for 1982 should be set, for monitoring purposes, within the range of 15 per cent-18 per cent of the average American Metal Market price for 99.5 per cent purity primary aluminium ingot.

Australia has not supported IBA minimum pricing policies and is not bound by the pricing recommendations for bauxite and alumina exports in 1982. Australia's attitude to IBA pricing proposals is set out in a statement of 8 January 1979 by the Minister for Trade and Resources.
The Australian Government will however continue to administer its export controls on bauxite and alumina in such a way as to seek fair world market prices.

Australia has informed other IBA member countries that whilst Australia cannot subscribe to the IBA's pricing formulations, Australia will not engage in predatory pricing practices. In this regard, Australia's actions are not seen as being inconsistent with the Government's commitment to the North-South dialogue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1631) Senator Jones asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Transport, without notice, whether the radar scanner at the Brisbane Airport has no duplicate backup facility. If the scanner is switched off, or breaks down, does the Brisbane Airport operate without radar? If this potentially dangerous situation exists, what action can be taken to overcome the danger?

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In my reply to a previous question from Senator Jones on 15 September 1981 (No. S1180), regarding radar facilities at Brisbane Airport, I advised that Brisbane Airport was provided with two radar facilitites, a primary radar and a secondary surveillance radar. While the electronics associated with each of these facilities is duplicated, certain highly reliable mechanical components are not duplicated. These include the antenna of each facility and the common rotator mechanism. Because of the high reliability of these mechanical components, adequate performance is obtained without duplication. None of the common rotator mechanisms of Australian ATC radars has so far failed in scheduled operation. If the rotator mechanism is switched off to allow maintenance to take place, Brisbane operates without radar. This is not a 'potentially dangerous situation' because safety is maintained by reverting to internationally accepted procedural (i.e. non-radar) control.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1716) Senator Lewis asked the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations and, in his tenuous link, representing the Acting Attorney-General, is about a Mr Noel Latham who, I am sure Senator Chaney will recall, was the worker at Broken Hill who was denied the opportunity to work in Broken Hill because he refused to join the union which runs that city. I ask: Is the Minister aware that today in the Supreme Court of New South Wales His Honour, Mr Justice Nagle, in a very lengthy judgment awarded Noel Latham damages of $100,000 against 41 of the 75 Broken Hill unionists who were the defendants in the case. Apparently 30 of the unionists were let off, three died and one disappeared.

Is the Minister aware that Mr Latham has claimed this judgment as the most important social decision given by the New South Wales Supreme Court this century? Does the Commonwealth have laws similar to those under which this judgment was given? If not, will the Government take steps to adopt such laws so that civil protection similar to this may be given to those in Australia who are denied the right to work by militant closed shop unions?
The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

In the case in question, Latham v Singleton and others, the Supreme Court of New South Wales found that, on the particular facts of the case, the actions of 41 of the defendants in refusing to work with Mr Latham, resulting in Mr Latham's suspension by the Broken Hill City Council, were a threat of an unlawful or illegal breach of contract and constituted the common law tort of conspiracy to intimidate by unlawful means.

The Court awarded damages to Mr Latham of the amount of $100,000 which was arrived at after consideration of his past, present and future economic loss, the pain, suffering and distress caused to him by the defendants' actions and the question of exemplary and aggravated damages against the defendants for their conduct against Mr Latham.

The judgment of the New South Wales Supreme Court is an important one, not least because the Court accepted the principle contained in a 1964 House of Lords decision (Rookes v Barnard) which acknowledged the existence in England of the common law tort of intimidation. It has not been clear whether the Rookes v Barnard decision, particularly as applied in the subsequent English case of Morgan v Fry, would be followed in Australia. It is important to note, however, that the Latham decision is at present the subject of an appeal to the New South Wales Court of Appeal.

On the question of whether the Commonwealth has laws similar to those under which the Latham judgment was given, the fact is that that case was decided on common law issues, as opposed to specific statutory provision. Remedies founded on a cause of action in intimidation or the other so-called 'economic torts'-i.e. conspiracy and interference with contractual relations-may be available in all Australian jurisdictions against unions and/or individual employees who have engaged in industrial action, provided that the necessary elements of the tort can be established. In addition the Trade Practices Act contains a statutory provision which enables a person who suffers loss or damage by conduct of another person (including a registered trade union) that was done in contravention of section 45D or 45E of that Act, which prohibits secondary boycotts, to recover the amount of the loss or damage by action against that other person or against any person involved in the contravention.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: European Pensions for Australian Citizens: Exemption from Tax

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 29 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1808) Senator Sibraa asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Does paragraph 23 (kc) of the Income Tax Assessment Act provide that income received from West Germany as compensation for Nazi persecution is exempt from tax, but that the exemption does not extend to similar pensions received from other European governments. If this is indeed correct, will the Government consider drafting new legislation to correct this anomaly by extending the scope of the exemptions to cover those pensions not now covered.
The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Paragraph 23 (kc) of the Income Tax Assessment Act exempts from Australian income tax pensions, annuities and allowances paid by a State of the Federal Republic of Germany under the laws of that Republic relating to compensation of victims of National Socialist persecution. Those pensions were set at lower rates, on the basis that they were to be exempt from tax, than similar pensions from some other countries which were set at higher rates on the basis that they were to be subject to tax.
The Australian taxation treatment of such pensions received by Australian residents from those other countries is presently under review by the Government.
